webTitle: Chris Balderstone, all-round sportsman, dies at 59

fields.headline: Chris Balderstone, all-round sportsman, dies at 59
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText: The worlds of football and cricket joined forces yesterday to pay tribute to Chris Balderstone, one of the last of a select and now outmoded band to make a rewarding career in both sports.
fields.body:
The worlds of football and cricket joined forces yesterday to pay tribute to Chris Balderstone, one of the last of a select and now outmoded band to make a rewarding career in both sports.

Denis Compton and Willie Watson, more than half a century ago, are among those who famously reached the heights in what used to be regarded as England's traditional winter and summer games. Len Hutton, the great Yorkshire and England batsman, once claimed he could have done the same "had my mother not thrown my football boots on the fire when I was 10".

But Balderstone, who died of cancer yesterday aged 59, was one of the last to combine both sports for a prolonged and successful period.

He was a Carlisle United stalwart, enjoying a brief taste of life in the old First Division with the club in 1974, and two years later, after retiring as a professional footballer, was selected at the age of 35 for two Tests for England against the fearsome 1976 West Indians.

He became a first-class umpire in 1988, finally ending a county career with Yorkshire and, primarily, Leicestershire that virtually filled three decades.

Peter Willey, a team-mate of Balderstone's at Leicestershire in the 70s, and a fellow umpire, said: "He was one of the calmest men I have ever known. I honestly can't remember him ever losing his temper. It could be in his umpiring career that ultimately worked against him - perhaps he was a little too gentle.

"He had great personal pride and made tremendous personal sacrifices to play for so long in both sports. At Leicestershire, people looked up to him as a father figure. He respected the game and those who played it. He was a Corinthian."

Jim Cumbes, Lancashire's chief executive, was another who successfully combined both football and cricket in the same era. Cricket's more protracted rhythms had encouraged a camaraderie between both men, and when Aston Villa once conceded a penalty against Carlisle at Brunton Park, Cumbes, the Villa goalkeeper, used it to his advantage.

"I remember telling Baldy that he'd no chance and that I'd whack the ball away with my bat. He just smiled, ran up and blazed it against the crossbar."

Cumbes eventually made amends, however, as his shut-out for Villa against Orient at the end of the 1973-4 season ensured that Carlisle gained promotion.

"Half the Carlisle side, including Baldy, were at the game," Cumbes recalled. "He deserved to experience a bit of First Division life. He had a wonderful left foot, not particularly tenacious but a great passer of the ball. In fact, he was more cultured as a footballer than a cricketer.

"And what a nice guy, so unassuming. The one thing you knew about his umpiring was that he had made an honest decision."

James Whitaker, Leicestershire's manager, added: "He was one of life's gentlemen and so professional in his outlook."

The majority of Balderstone the footballer's 524 league games, in a career stretching between 1959 and 1975, were for Carlisle. He had recently returned to live in Cumbria and regularly attended Brunton Park, where Carlisle are now striving to save their league status.

A United spokesman said: "The club is stunned. He was one of Carlisle's heroes in their most successful period between 1965 and 1974. He will be sadly missed."

fields.headline: Azharuddin lightens India's gloom
fields.standfirst:
South Africa won by an innings and 71 runs
Scoreboard
fields.trailText: Mohammad Azharuddin staged a brilliant if brief show of defiance as he raced to a century before India collapsed in little more than a hour on the final morning to lose the second Test in Bangalore by an innings and 71 runs as South Africa cruised to a 2-0 series win. With it went India's proud unbeaten record in a home series since 1987.
fields.body:
Mohammad Azharuddin staged a brilliant if brief show of defiance as he raced to a century before India collapsed in little more than a hour on the final morning to lose the second Test in Bangalore by an innings and 71 runs as South Africa cruised to a 2-0 series win. With it went India's proud unbeaten record in a home series since 1987.

Azharuddin, the former captain recalled after a seven-month absence for his 99th Test, resumed on 73 and took only 18 balls to reach his century. In one over he punished the man of the match Nicky Boje severely, hitting the slow left-armer for a six to midwicket and two successive fours to jump from 84 to 98.

He hit a straight drive off Shaun Pollock off the next delivery he faced to reach the 22nd Test century of his career.

But Azharuddin was soon out to a short-pitched delivery from Pollock as he skied a catch to Gary Kirsten at midwicket. His 102 runs had come off 163 deliveries and featured 13 fours and two sixes. It was a bravura performance praised by South Africa's captain. "Azza was awesome," said Hansie Cronje.

Azharuddin had put on 96 for the sixth wicket with Anil Kumble. But once Azharuddin went India, who had resumed on 196 for five, collapsed and were all out for 250 to suffer the embarrassment of their biggest Test beating by South Africa.

Boje sent back Kumble - who had fought for 122 minutes for his 28 - and then had Murali Karthik caught by Herschelle Gibbs.

With the wicket-keeper Nayan Mongia not batting because of a fever, the last man out was Nikhil Chopra, snapped up by Mark Boucher off Allan Donald.

Afterwards Sachin Tendulkar, who now steps down as India's captain to be replaced by Sourav Ganguly, blamed his side's inability to play as a team and a poor performance by the batsmen for the series rout. "In contrast," he said, "a team approach spelt success for South Africa."

Cronje readily concurred: "It's been the story of the last two years, where everyone has contributed to the team; it's really difficult to single out any player." Cronje has now led his country to three successive series wins.

Boje, who came into the South African squad as replacement for the injured Paul Adams, won his man-of-the-match award for his second-innings haul of five wickets for 83 - for match figures of seven for 93 - and his 85 runs as nightwatchman in South Africa's only innings.

The latest setback for India, after suffering a 3-0 whitewash in Australia, has further lowered confidence in the home camp. Their coach Kapil Dev said it would be difficult for his side to beat the South Africans in the five-match, one-day series which begins on Thursday.

webTitle: Shoaib is back with a five-wicket bang

fields.headline: Shoaib is back with a five-wicket bang
fields.standfirst: Scoreboard
fields.trailText: Shoaib Akhtar, the Nottinghamshire-bound fast bowler, took five for 75 as Pakistan gained the initiative on the second day of the second Test against Sri Lanka in Peshawar.
fields.body:
Shoaib Akhtar, the Nottinghamshire-bound fast bowler, took five for 75 as Pakistan gained the initiative on the second day of the second Test against Sri Lanka in Peshawar.

Pakistan, who have lost their last four Tests, finished the day on 67 for one in reply to Sri Lanka's first innings 268. Marvan Atapattu was the tourists' top scorer with 75.

Shoaib was playing his first Test after being banned for having an illegal bowling action in December. He was subsequently cleared last month by the International Cricket Council.

Shoaib's only previous five-wicket Test haul was his five for 43 against South Africa at Durban in 1998.

The West Indies fast bowler Courtney Walsh, still hoping to lead his country's attack on their tour of England this summer, is recovering from an ankle injury and should be bowling again within a few days.

Walsh, who needs nine wickets to beat Kapil Dev's world record of 434 Test victims, damaged ligaments in his left ankle in the Busta Cup final playing for the eventual champions Jamaica against the Leeward Islands last week.

The 37-year-old Walsh is taking part in a nine-day West Indies training camp preparing for the Test and one-day series against Zimbabwe.

In Hamilton centuries from Justin Langer and Damien Martyn put the Australian tourists in a strong position at the end of the second day of the four-day match against New Zealand's Northern Districts.

Northern Districts were eventually all out for 300 and in reply Australia declared at 383 for four. Langer made 155 and Martyn went on to score 109. At stumps Northern Districts were 48 for one.

webTitle: England expects and the pressure crushes

fields.headline: England expects and the pressure crushes
fields.trailText: Harry Pearson One man who is living testimony to both the benefits and pitfalls of allowing our sportsmen and women to build up a degree of mystique is Graeme Hick. He is the clearest example that, for the English sports fan, it is better to travel hopefully than to arrive.
fields.body:
Last week the names of the cricketers who have been awarded the 12 new England and Wales Cricket Board contracts were announced. These elite dozen are exempt from playing in the county championship. This is a bold step from Lord's, though clearly a sound one, for there is surely nothing more guaranteed to preserve the sporting hopes of the British public than not allowing us to see our best cricketers in action.

In fact, the ECB's move may well be the greatest sporting decision made on these islands since the football associations of the home countries determined not to enter the first three World Cups. The wisdom of this resolution was conclusively proved when foolish globalisers at Lancaster Gate sent England to compete in the 1950 event.

The result was catastrophic defeat by the United States. How lucky we are that wiser heads prevailed during the 30s, for it is hard to imagine that Britain would have performed quite so pluckily during the second world war if we had come into that conflict with morale dented not only by the Australians' steely grip on the Ashes but also having seen the cream of our footballing talent trounced on the fields of France in 1938 by Cuba or the Dutch East Indies.

One man who is living testimony to both the benefits and pitfalls of allowing our sportsmen and women to build up a degree of mystique is Graeme Hick. Despite a feeling in some quarters that our national team would have been better served not by offering the Worcestershire player a contract but by taking one out on him, the 33-year-old batsman was a surprise beneficiary of English cricket's new system.

Apparently the team manager Duncan Fletcher, who has known Hick since he was playing for Zimbabwe Schools, believes he has the key to unlocking the player's international potential. Perhaps so, though fears remain that anything that has been shut away for so long will not react kindly to sunlight.

It is hard not to feel some sympathy for Hick. When he began the long process of qualifying to play for this country through residency, having opted to take the seven-year route to an England cap rather than the four-year term required by New Zealand, English cricket was still in good shape. Victories came at a reasonable rate and we regarded ourselves, with some reason, as better than many other Test nations. The prospect of Hick's arrival on the scene was regarded as a matter of interest rather than urgency.

In April and May of 1988 Hick scored runs at a preposterous rate. The ball fizzed off his bat. His straight drives sailed through the air like a sweetly struck tee-shot, his cuts beat out syncopated rhythms on the boundary hoardings. Against Somerset at Taunton he rattled up 405 looking less like a man among men than Competitive Dad in The Fast Show. Yet still England, who had recently won an Ashes series in Australia, anticipated his Test debut with relish not desperation.

By the time Hick was available for selection, however, things had changed dramatically. England had been beaten home and away by Australia and West Indies; Hick was no longer a welcome addition to the national side but its saviour. The effect was disastrous. As was once remarked of the heavyweight boxer Gerry Cooney, "There's a narrow gap between being The Great White Hope and becoming The Great White Dope." Despite having shoulders as wide as a truck, Graeme Hick fell down it. After his opening appearance against West Indies he rapidly went from being a prodigy to the archetypal flat-track bully.

Hick's batting is not compared to what others do but what he should have done. That this is the case was clear following the disastrous 92-93 tour of India and Sri Lanka. In the Test series Hick scored more runs and took more catches than any other player. Yet he was not named as one of England's men-of-the-series, nudged aside by Alec Stewart and Chris Lewis.

Hick is the clearest example that, for the English sports fan, it is better to travel hopefully than to arrive. Not that we appear to have learned anything from it. Recently the lack of any midfielder in English football who can actually run with the ball has created a similar situation. Once we waited for Hick and his runs. Now we hold our breath for the coming of Joe Cole and his. Common wisdom has it that the West Ham youngster is the answer to all our prayers.

It is hard to know what lies behind the failure of some talented individuals to realise their potential. Certainly Hick's inability to carry his county form into the Test arena is regarded by many, including Raymond Illingworth, as a mystery to rival that of the Holy Trinity. It is impossible not to wonder, however, if the pressure of public expectation is not responsible for turning a phenomenon into an enigma.

It is hard to know what lies behind the failure of some talented individuals to realise their potential. Certainly Hick's inability to carry his county form into the Test arena is regarded by many, including Raymond Illingworth, as a mystery to rival that of the Holy Trinity. It is impossible not to wonder, however, if the pressure of public expectation is not responsible for turning a phenomenon into an enigma.

fields.headline: Bordeaux 1 - 2 Man Utd
fields.standfirst: Solskjaer takes United top in a trice
fields.trailText: Kick-off 7.45pm
fields.body:
Kick-off 7.45pm

Bordeaux (4-4-2): Rame; Grenet, Saveljic, Afanou, Bonnissel; Ziani, Batlles, Pavon, Micoud; Laslandes, Wiltord. Subs: Richert, Rouviere, Diabate, Zanotti, Colucci, Feindouno.

Man Utd (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; G Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Sheringham, Cole. Subs: Bosnich, P Neville, Cruyff, Yorke, Solksjaer, Berg, Fortune.

Referee: J Wegereef (Neth).

1 The players emerge into the stadium after a two minute walk from the dressing room and United, unchanged from last Wednesday's 2-0 win at Old Trafford, kick off.
2 Bordeaux make an early incursion on the right but Irwin shepherds the ball out for a goalkick. Then Wiltord puts in a dangerous cross but there is no one to meet it at the far post.
3 Ziani has a shot blocked for a corner from which Saveljic tests Van der Gouw wth a header.
6 Saveljic catches Batlles with his knee and the midfielder goes off on a stretcher with blood streaming from his nose.
9 GOAL Bordeaux 1 Man Utd 0 A howler from Van Der Gouw as he fluffs a soft left-foot shot from Pavon.
12 Bordeaux swarm at United but Stam puts in a good headed clearance and then the home side are caught offside.
13 Bordeaux substitution: Diabate for Batlles.
16 Wiltford left-foot shot from the edge of the box on the turn fizzes past United's right-hand upright.
19 Wiltford plays Laslandes into the area but his right-foot shot is smothered by Van der Gouw.
21 At the other end Cole wins a corner and from Beckham's delivery Sheringham sends a firece header just over from 10 yards.
23 Red card Laslandes is booked needlessly for dissent and then foolishly lunges at Beckham studs up and immediately receives a second yellow card. Beckham appears to have made the most of it.
33 GOAL Bordeaux 1 Man Utd 1 After slick work in midfield Sheringham, looking suspiciously offside, puts Keane clean through and the Irishman finishes at the second attempt, his first effort having been blocked by Rame. It's Keane's 11th goal of the season.
38 With their extra-man advantage, it's all United now.
43 Stam brings down Micoud and is booked for showing dissent. From the free-kick Van der Gouw punches strongly away.
45 Wiltford, fed by Bonissel on the edge of the United area, makes a monkey of Stam with a nutmeg and sends a shot fizzing narrowly wide.

Half-time: Bordeaux 1 Manchester United 1

47 Cole is put clear and a goals eems certain but just as he is about to shoot Afanou denies him with a superbly timed challenge to concede a corner.
49 Beckham, now relentlessly booed and whistled by the home crowd, curls a gentle shot into the arms of Rame.
51 Micoud takes on Silvestre and hammers United's right-hand post. Wiltord's follow-up effort flashes across goal but wide.
52 Giggs streaks down the left and his shot is deflected for a corner by Rame.
55 From a short-corner routine Beckham whips in a cross from the left which Keane meets with a glancing header that shaves the far post.
58 It's an end-to-end match now and Micoud drives narrowly wide from 25 yards.
59 Irwin crosses from deep on the left and Cole heads wide from seven yards.
60 Bordeaux substitution: Rouviere for Ziani.
61 Bonissel breaks down the left and puts in a superb cross but Wiltord cannott control his header from 10 yards.
64 Rouviere's excellent pass sets Wiltord free on the right and the striker cuts inside to test Van der Gouw with a low left-foot drive.
70 Grenet is booked for pulling Giggs's shirt. Beckham fires his free-kick into the wall.
74 Beckham sends in a dangerous cross from the right but Irwin, at full stretch, can only turn the ball over.
77 Man Utd substitution: Yorke for Sheringham.
80 Micoud picks out Wiltord on the left who leaves Stam for dead cutting inside and his low right-foot drive is turned round by Van der Gouw.
82 Bordeaux substitution: Feindouno for Wiltord.
82 With his first touch Feindouno has a chance for glory but Van der Gouw blocks his close range effort.
83 Man Utd substitution: Solskjaer for Irwin.
84 GOAL Bordeaux 1-2 Man Utd Barely on the pitch Solskjaer again grabs the late glory as he beats a couple of players on the edge of the area and slots the ball past Rame.
86 Man Utd substitution: Berg for Cole.
90 United mess about at a corner and Giggs is booked. Then Diabate is shown the yellow card for a tackle from behind on Keane who upsets the Bordeaux player by catching him under his chin with a trailing foot.

Full time: Bordeaux 1 - 2 Man Utd

webTitle: Lewis top of British rich list

fields.headline: Lewis top of British rich list
fields.trailText: If David Beckham ever needed encouragement to move abroad, it comes in the form of the latest (1999) earnings list for British sports stars.
fields.body:
If David Beckham ever needed encouragement to move abroad, it comes in the form of the latest (1999) earnings list for British sports stars.

If money matched profile, Beckham would be on his own at the top of the list but he ranks merely 10th and is not even the highest-earning British footballer. That honour belongs to Steve McManaman, whose passage from Liverpool to Real Madrid in the summer was greased by the promise of a £3m signing-on bonus and wages of £40,000 a week.

Nor is Beckham a natural salesman, as Alan Shearer and Colin Montgomerie are, and he does not have a vast portfolio of sponsorship deals, though adidas and Brylcreem look after him well.

His income had a turn for the better in July when OK! magazine paid £1m for his wedding photos. Until United become more generous or Internazionale beckon, Beckham will just have to be grateful that he is part of a two-income family.

Shearer and Michael Owen share the same management company as Beckham but both fared better in 1999, essentially because their pay cheques, at Liverpool and Newcastle respectively, surpass Beckham's. Shearer is also comfortable with the promotional work, Umbro, McDonald's, Lucozade and numerous other endorsements.

Lennox Lewis tops the British list with £16.6m, the highest ever sum earned by a British sportsman in a single year. The former Olympic champion has three times been the top earner and has grossed £49.7m since the list was first compiled in 1993.

Lewis is also the only British athlete to figure in the list published by the US magazine Forbes, which also comes out this month. Forbes, assessing his endorsements slightly higher, calculate that the British heavyweight earned a little more than £18m last year. Even so, Lewis can barely hold a candle to the leaders of Forbes's list, Michael Schumacher, optimistically rated at $49m (£30.6m), Tiger Woods, who was reckoned to have made $47m (£29.38m) in 1999, and the boxer Oscar de la Hoya, whose income is estimated at $43.5m (£27.19m).

Even Mike Tyson, who had only two relatively meaningless fights last year, is rated, at £33m (£20.6m), ahead of Lewis.

As ever, though, the Forbes list is remarkable for its strength in depth. Whereas only Lewis, Naseem Hamed and Damon Hill topped the £5m mark in Britain, the list of US athletes earning over $8m seems almost endless.

Though the Premiership continues to create new millionaires, the richest soccer league in the world still has some way to go to match major league baseball, the National Basketball Association and the National Football League.

The Detroit Pistons forward Grant Hill, who is part way through a seven-year $80m deal with Fila, earned $23m (£14.38m) last year. The Dallas Cowboys quarterback Troy Aikman received $13m (£8.12m) just as a signing-on fee, with another $7m (£4.38m) due this year. Kevin Garnett, a basketball player, negotiated a six-year $126m contract with the Minnesota Timberwolves, perhaps the most remarkable figure of all.

 Pete Nichols is editor of the BBC Radio 5 Live Sports Yearbook (Oddball Publishing, £15), out this month, for which the British earners list is compiled.

Home advantage: the top 10 earners of 1999

1 Lennox Lewis, Boxing, £16.6m. Lewis became the richest ever British sports earner in a single year thanks to successive fights against Evander Holyfield worth $10m and $15m. The endorsements come to around £1m with his American Express deal leading the way. And yet to come is the ultimate money-spinner: a bout with Mike Tyson.

2 Naseem Hamed, Boxing, £8.7m. Hamed's new six-fight $48m deal with HBO has been calculated on a sliding scale. Nevertheless, the Ingle fight and the Soto cabaret will have been extremely lucrative, say $13m the pair. The wheels are still oiled by adidas.

3 Damon Hill, Motor Racing, £5.6m. Hill's second year at Jordan gave him another £5m but the bonuses were few and far between and would not add up to much extra.

4 Steve McManaman, Football, £4.75m. Real Madrid paid Liverpool nothing for McManaman but paid the player lots: a £3m signing-on fee plus wages of about £2.1m. Half of that plus half of his Liverpool earnings (he moved in the summer) add up to heaps.

5 Eddie Irvine, Motor Racing, £4.1m. The highest-paid second string in the F1 game but very happy to move to Jaguar (for lots more money) and lose that tag. Reckon on $6m (including bonuses) for driving, extras from Lampo and Sony Playstation.

6 Colin Montgomerie, Golf, £3.5m. No majors yet again but year in year out £1.5m+ in prize-money. Lexus Cars, Calloway, Titleist-Footjoy, Lacoste, Ebel Watches, Starwood Hotels, sharepeople.com: the endorsement list is almost endless.

7 Colin McRae, Rallying, £3.2m. The second year of the mega-deal with Ford for McRae, who hardly hit the high spots in his first, finishing only sixth in the world championship.

8 Alan Shearer, Football, £3.1m. The £40,000 a week from Newcastle keeps the wolves from the door and, though Shearer has announced his impending retirement from international football, don't expect the endorsement king to say he's stopping making money.

9 Michael Owen, Football, £2.9m. Owen negotiated his current deal after the World Cup when the whole world wanted a piece of him. Last year he earned about £2m from Liverpool, a £1m publishing contract (over several books) and deals with Walkers Crisps, Umbro, Jaguar, Tissot and more.

10 David Beckham, Football, £2.85m. United are not as generous as Liverpool (except to Roy Keane) but the Irishman is hardly likely to get £1m from OK! magazine for his wedding snaps. Assume that he gets half of the £1m, and add big cheques from Adidas and Brylcreem.

Figures for 1999 calendar year; dollars converted at $1.60 to £1 sterling.

webTitle: Petit fingered for Villa Park gesture

fields.headline: Petit fingered for Villa Park gesture
fields.trailText: Emmanuel Petit's abusive gesture towards Aston Villa fans during Sunday's Premiership clash at Villa Park has earned the Arsenal midfielder a misconduct charge from the Football Association.
fields.body:
Emmanuel Petit's abusive gesture towards Aston Villa fans during Sunday's Premiership clash at Villa Park has earned the Arsenal midfielder a misconduct charge from the Football Association.

Petit delivered a one-fingered salute towards fans in the family enclosure behind the Arsenal dug-out immediately after his substitution in the 72nd minute of the 1-1 draw. The Frenchman will be joined on a similar charge by West Ham's Paolo di Canio on Thursday for the Italian's gesture towards Villa fans at Upton Park in December.

Petit claims he was the subject of racist abuse from Villa fans, a charge denied by the club's company secretary Steve Stride, who was seated not far from the incident.

Petit said: "There were many racist comments shouted at me - comments like French this and French that. It was racism directly straight at me, and to be honest I'm fed up with that."

The FA studied pictures of Petit's gesture yesterday before charging him. Their media relations manager Steve Double said: "We made our position clear two or three months ago regarding players making gestures towards spectators.

"We made it clear that, if we had evidence, then we would take action and we have charged Emmanuel Petit with misconduct after studying pictures of what happened at Aston Villa on Sunday. The player now has 14 days to respond and to request a personal hearing if he so desires and, as with anyone facing a misconduct charge, he is free to bring any relevant evidence."

On a more upbeat note for Arsenal, their manager Arsène Wenger has confirmed his interest in the PSV Eindhoven striker Ruud van Nistelrooy but insists a deal is not imminent. PSV are reportedly resigned to losing the services of the Dutch international to Highbury next season.

The Stockport striker Ian Moore has also been charged with misconduct after appearing to stamp on Barnsley's Chris Barker at Edgeley Park on Friday.

Rob Harris, the referee banned by the FA for his part in the Tranmere v Sunderland FA Cup controversy in which the Merseyside club had an extra player on the field to defend a crucial free kick, will make a low-key comeback tonight in the Third Division match between Shrewsbury and Peterborough.

webTitle: Little is sacked by West Brom

fields.headline: Little is sacked by West Brom
fields.trailText: Brian Little was sacked as manager of West Bromwich Albion last night after only seven months. Following Saturday's home defeat by Birmingham Little had accused people at the club of "poking their noses in". Now he has had his knocked out of joint.
fields.body:
Brian Little was sacked as manager of West Bromwich Albion last night after only seven months. Following Saturday's home defeat by Birmingham Little had accused people at the club of "poking their noses in". Now he has had his knocked out of joint.

Albion are third from bottom of the First Division with one win since late November and the chairman Paul Thompson announced: "Our recent form has resulted in us taking just eight points from the last 15 games. The position is unacceptable and has led to the decision we have taken."

It is hard to believe results are the sole factor given Little's attack on the way the club was run after Saturday's match. Upset at abuse from supporters, he said: "Everyone is talking about me behind my back and saying what the team should be. The only person who should get on with team affairs is the manager."

The comments were described by Albion as "unhelpful" but Little was unrepentant last night. "I said what I did in the hope that I would be given a licence to get on with my job," he said. "Rightly or wrongly I said my piece and I won't retract it. I said what I did in the hope things would be sorted. Things obviously have been sorted as far as the club is concerned."

It has been an unsettled two years for Little, who left Aston Villa in early 1998 but stayed only a season at Stoke before leaving for the Hawthorns. His job at Albion was made more difficult by the club's decision to sell two of their best players, Kevin Kilbane and Enzo Maresca, for almost £7m.

Thompson said he hoped to appoint a new manager, the club's fifth in three years, by the weekend. He insisted no one was lined up but Cyrille Regis, the reserve coach, is a candidate. He will take temporary charge at home to Tranmere Rovers tonight.

The leading Turkish club Fenerbahce are preparing an audacious £12m bid for the Newcastle United forward Duncan Ferguson.

"I will do everything in my power to sign him," said the club's coach Soy Den. "I have watched him play three times in recent weeks and have been very impressed by what I have seen. I want to know everything about the man - to that end I have even bought a book about him."

Although the Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is short of funds, it is highly unlikely he would agree to sell Ferguson, whose partnership with Alan Shearer has flourished in recent weeks.

fields.headline: Hartson move collapses
fields.trailText: John Hartson's "dream move" from Wimbledon to Tottenham turned into a nightmare yesterday when Spurs pulled out of the £6m deal after the striker failed a medical on his left knee.
fields.body:
John Hartson's "dream move" from Wimbledon to Tottenham turned into a nightmare yesterday when Spurs pulled out of the £6m deal after the striker failed a medical on his left knee.

While Sam Hammam gleefully declared that "God must be on the side of Wimbledon", Hartson's agent, Jonathan Barnett, failed to see the divine hand at work. He described Spurs' decision as "potty" and warned that Hartson would head elsewhere before long.

"It was just a routine medical and Tottenham were not happy with it," Barnett said. "It's related to the cartilage operation he had over Christmas.

"John is very upset but I think he will prove them wrong. He'll score a lot more goals for Wimbledon and maybe then for another club. This is not the end for John.

"It's Tottenham's loss and it's not the first player they'll have made a mistake about. With all the problems they have had [with injured players] I think they've gone overboard. They've gone potty."

Spurs' announcement that they would not "proceed at this moment" hinted at a possible return for the player. But Barnett said: "As far as we're concerned the deal with Spurs is completely dead; there's no chance of resurrecting it."

Hartson has not played since mid-December because of a cartilage problem. For two weeks before he had surgery his left knee had been swelling so painfully after matches that he said he could "hardly walk down the stairs". When he had the operation the surgeon said further delay could have threatened his career.

The 24-year-old has suffered knee problems before but had agreed personal terms and was looking forward to joining up with George Graham, who took him to Arsenal from Luton for £2.5m in 1995. Now he will look to another club.

"John knows that Wimbledon are willing to let him go, so I should think it will be very hard for them to keep him," Barnett said. "John would love to go now."

Barnett insisted Spurs' proposal happened so quickly that "we have not had the chance to look around at other clubs". But the Wales striker should be playing again in a fortnight, much to Hammam's delight as the relegation battle deepens.

"It's providence," said the Wimbledon director. "I'm delighted but sad for John Hartson. Every man and his dog knew I was not at all happy with John leaving and perhaps some prayers have been answered.

"We believe he will be fine. It appears John will have some arthritis when he's in his 40s or 50s, but show me a footballer who doesn't.

"His sale would not only have had catastrophic and negative consequences on the pitch but it could have had an irrevocable, devastating effect on other senior players.

"While we respect Tottenham's medical advisers' opinion, we do not share their views. They might be getting tentative because of experiences they've had with Les Ferdinand, Darren Anderton, John Scales, Steffen Iversen and a few other players."

Emile Heskey's transfer from Leicester to Liverpool moved a step closer yesterday when the England forward told his club's management that he wants to move to Anfield. Although Leicester's manager Martin O'Neill is still trying to persuade him to delay the transfer until summer, a deal is thought to be imminent.

Having agreed more than six months ago to sign Heskey for £10.75m at the end of the season, Gérard Houllier has spent the past three weeks attempting to bring the deal forward.

O'Neill will permit Heskey to leave ahead of schedule but he is seeking an extra £2m. If Liverpool fail to land him this week they will put his transfer on ice until summer.

 Stephen Hughes will move from Arsenal to Everton today, subject to a medical.

fields.headline: Goater's World Cup hat-trick
fields.trailText: Manchester City's Shaun Goater scored a hat-trick as Bermuda beat the British Virgin Islands 5-1 as qualification for the 2002 World Cup got under way in the Caribbean over the weekend. Stoke City's Kyle Lightbourne opened the scoring for the visiting Bermudians.
fields.body:
Manchester City's Shaun Goater scored a hat-trick as Bermuda beat the British Virgin Islands 5-1 as qualification for the 2002 World Cup got under way in the Caribbean over the weekend. Stoke City's Kyle Lightbourne opened the scoring for the visiting Bermudians.

Another British-based player, Chester City's Marvin Andrews, scored the tournament's first goal as Trinidad and Tobago beat Netherlands Antilles 5-0.

"We started a bit shakily," said Trinidad's Scottish coach Ian Porterfield, who was appointed only two days before the match. "But we improved as the game went on and we scored some good goals."

The Crewe striker Rodney Jack hit a hat-trick in St Vincent's 9-0 rout of the US Virgin Islands. But the Caymans lost 4-0 in Cuba after Fifa ruled their team's seven British-based players ineligible at the last minute.

Two of Everton's most promising youngsters, Michael Ball and Richard Dunne, have placed their futures at Goodison Park on the line after appealing to the Premier League about the severity of a punishment handed down by the manager Walter Smith.

The two players were fined a fortnight's wages - about £15,000 - after failing to report for training on New Year's Day. A Premier League panel is scheduled to hear the case in London on Thursday.

webTitle: NTL ups the ante on internet access

fields.headline: NTL ups the ante on internet access
fields.standfirst:
No going back for free access

Key players
fields.trailText: In the boldest move yet to grab customers in the internet market, NTL, the cable TV operator and telephone company, today unveiled plans for Britain's first totally free service.
fields.body:
In the boldest move yet to grab customers in the internet market, NTL, the cable TV operator and telephone company, today unveiled plans for Britain's first totally free service.

The company said subscribers to the service - to be called ntlworld - would pay no subscription fee, no fee for connection to the net and no phone charges. Barclay Knapp, chief executive of NTL, said: "ntlworld will help the UK in a drive to lead the world in making e-commerce, e-entertainment and e-education available to everyone."

NTL's announcement came just one day after AltaVista, the US internet search engine, promised unlimited access for an initial fee of no more than £50, with no phone charges. These two initiatives, coming in quick succession, underline the quickening pace of competition to get people online, and they coincide with a promise by prime minister Tony Blair for every British citizen to enjoy unhampered access to the internet within five years.

"There was a lot of talk that the telecommunications business was holding back the internet," Mr Knapp said, "our announcement today proves that is just not true. We can economically provide this service on a free basis to the British consumer."

NTL said "ntlworld" would start on April 17 for net access via personal computers, with a TV internet service coming soon after. Homes in areas covered by NTL cable will get net access as part of a package of phone and TV services that starts at £9.25 a month.

Other users with British Telecommunications phones will pay a one-off charge of £10 for an adapter and would be required to spend at least £10 a month on voice calls via NTL. NTL's acquisition of Cable and Wireless Communications is pending government approval and NTL said CWC customers would be covered by the offer if the takeover goes through.

The offerings from NTL and AltaVista set a new standard for cheap web access in the UK, which the government says lags the US for internet use because people have to pay phone charges for every minute online. Analysts believe that unmetered access could treble the time UK users spend online.

The plans for unmetered access plans are likely to spark a price war among internet service providers (ISPs), causing pain for established players, such as Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider (ISP). Freeserve's stock fell 13.4% to 762 pence in morning trading, extending a loss of 5% on Monday in reaction to AltaVista's move.

But Freeserve and American Online UK, its nearest rival, are understood to be working on plans to match AltaVista's commitment to offer unlimited access to the web in return for an upfront fee. The big two players could have their offerings in place by the time AltaVista's package is expected to come on stream in June. But now they have to contend with NTL's gambit.

webTitle: Blair wants internet access for all

fields.headline: Blair wants internet access for all
fields.standfirst:
Tony Blair's full speech
The issue explained: free internet access
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has responded to fears of a growing divide between the information-rich and the information-poor by announcing his intention to ensure everyone in Britain has internet access within five years.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has responded to fears of a growing divide between the information-rich and the information-poor by announcing his intention to ensure everyone in Britain has internet access within five years.

In a speech today designed to boost his government's internet credentials, the prime minister told Knowledge 2000, a joint CBI/TUC conference, that "the knowledge economy must be an economy for the many and not the few".

"Universal internet access is vital if we are not only to avoid social divisions over the new economy but to create a knowledge economy of the future which is for everyone," Mr Blair said. "We cannot accept a digital divide for business or for individuals."

For people who cannot afford internet access via a PC, mobile phone or digital television, the prime minister promised to "ensure there is a nearby public access point".

Highlighting the government's energetic approach to new internet technology, Mr Blair outlined a number of Labour's commitments including:
 A national grid for learning, connecting schools and libraries to the internet by 2002;
 1,000 information technology learning centres;
 100,000 refurbished computers for low income families;
 Discounts of 80% on basic information technology courses by September this year.

One in six people in Britain already had access to the internet, a 200% increase in a single year, and were spending on average 12 hours a week online, more than their continental counterparts.

Britain headed the European "e-league" of countries using the new technology, the prime minister declared, pointing to a report by management consultants Booz, Allen and Hamilton showing Britain carried out e-trading worth $1.89bn, compared with £1.65bn in Germany, £1.2bn in France and a European average of $484m.

The education and employment secretary David Blunkett also announced to the conference the government's plans for an online service linking vacancies, skills programmes and careers advice.

Mr Blunkett said jobseekers would be able to look for work by surfing the internet either at home or in shopping centres and pubs through the Learning and Work Bank.

The scheme, to be launched later this year, will include a website with hundreds of thousands of vacancies from jobcentres and recruitment agencies.

"The bank has the potential to revolutionise the labour market by matching jobs to workers, taking learning out into the community and eventually giving people access to jobs throughout Europe, all at the click of a button.

"It promises to be the most comprehensive dot.com jobs, skills and careers service in the country," Mr Blunkett said, although the service would rely on the more old-fashioned telephone call to follow up any jobs.

fields.headline: AltaVista 'free calls' start online war
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, and AOL UK, its nearest rival, are understood to be working on plans to match AltaVista's commitment to offer unlimited access to the web in return for an upfront fee.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's largest internet service provider, and AOL UK, its nearest rival, are understood to be working on plans to match AltaVista's commitment to offer unlimited access to the web in return for an upfront fee.

Analysts believe that the heavyweight duo could have their offerings in place by the time AltaVista's package is expected to go live in June, heralding a war of attrition between the leading internet service providers and cheaper net access for consumers.

AltaVista said yesterday that it will connect people to the net via a freephone number for a one-off joining fee of £30 to £50 and an annual renewal charge of £10 to £20. It hopes 1m customers will sign up for the service within a year, citing the cost of calls as one of the biggest obstacles to people connecting the the internet.

Merrill Lynch analyst Peter Bradshaw said the dominant operators were unlikely to let their positions be eroded. "The other free ISPs are likely to come out with similar or improved packages within the next few weeks," he said.

Miles Saltiel, technology analyst at West LB Panmure, echoed his sentiments. "It puts all the big ISPs on their mettle," he said. "Those with the deepest pockets will win."

Freeserve admitted that it was working on its own low-cost packages and ways of reducing its 4p per minute call charges. "We have always said that connectivity will become a less significant contributor to revenues," a spokesman said. "We welcome any moves that get more people in the UK online." Its shares closed down 47p at 873p, however.

Oftel, the telecommunica tions watchdog which has asked internet service providers to lower subscription costs and call charges in an attempt to encourage more people online, said the news was "excellent".

Tony Blair, who has called on British Telecommunications to lower the cost of its internet call charges and help prevent the web from becoming the preserve of the wealthy, also welcomed the move.

BT is committed to launch unmetered access but is still negotiating terms with the regulator and other ISPs.

Around one quarter of the British population is online but in the US, where local calls are free, the figure is closer to one half. Durlacher analyst Nick Gibson believes unmetered internet access could treble the amount of time British users spend online.

Mr Bradshaw said AltaVista's move signalled the death of access-only internet service providers and switched the focus towards the content, community and commerce. "It's all in the portal now and not the connectivity," he said.

However details of the AltaVista package remain sketchy. Rivals suggest that users who sign up are likely to be heavily targeted by advertisers.

MCI Worldcom has been rumoured to be the company's chosen telecommunications provider, but AltaVista's European marketing director, Vesey Crichton, refused to confirm or deny whether a partner had yet been found.

Advertising and e-commerce revenues will offset the cost of subsidising calls, Mr Crichton said. Subscribers will be limited to 500,000 so AltaVista can cope with demand.

The managing director of one of Britain's largest ISPs estimated that if AltaVista customers follow the pattern of US users and spend an average of 15 hours a month online, and the company attracts its targeted 1m users, the exercise will cost upwards of £50m in call charges alone in year one. "They're going to subsidise the hell out of this," he said.

AltaVista has attracted 2m users in the US since launching the same model there. However, AOL UK's Matt Peacock questioned whether advertising and e-commerce revenues were enough to sustain AltaVista's model.

fields.headline: Women's unpaid work: some statistics
fields.trailText:
Unwaged work
• Recent estimates show unwaged work contributes as much as £739 bn to the British economy (Office of National Statistics [ONS], October 1997).
fields.body:
Unwaged work
 Recent estimates show unwaged work contributes as much as £739 bn to the British economy (Office of National Statistics [ONS], October 1997).

 Two-thirds of women working out of the home full-time do most of the housework. (Red magazine, Jan 2000) 45% of women work over 40 hours a week doing waged jobs. 10% work over 50 hours. (Guardian,4 Jan 1999)

 Women in waged work with young children do 46 hours a week of housework (childcare, cooking, cleaning, laundry, shopping, gardening/DIY) compared to 25 hours by men. (Omnibus Survey, ONS, 1995)

Wages/incomes
 Women's average full-time weekly earnings are 72% of men's. (New Earnings Surveys 1978 & 1998, ONS)

 Black women earn up to 32% less than white women. (Unison, 1995)

 28% of white households live on less than half the average household income; in contrast, 84% of Bangladeshi households in the UK live on less than half. (Policy Studies Institute, 1998)

 The average weekly income from all sources (benefits, wages, pensions etc) of women aged 30 to 70 was less than half that of men in the same age range. (Women's Individual Income 1996/97, Women's Unit, prepared by DSS Analytical Services Division 1999)

 There are 1.7 million single parents (one in five of all families) caring for 2.9 million children (Times, 11 Feb 1999), the majority of whom are on benefit and living on an average income of £106 a week. (Women's Individual Income 1996/97, as above)

 51% of Afro-Caribbean, 30% of African, and 8-10% of Asian families are single parent families (Policy Studies Institute, 1998)

 1.2 million people hold down two waged jobs, two thirds of them women. (Guardian, 4 January 99)

 Women with two jobs work 30-60 hours a week for an average of £100. Some do three jobs for little more than £100 a week. (Guardian, 24 October, 1994)

 2.45 million people mostly women earn below £64 a week. (The New Review, Low Pay Unit, March/April 1999)

Carers
 14% of women over 16 in Britain are carers for people with disabilities. A third of women carers spend over 20 hours a week in unwaged caring work. (Social Focus on Women and Men, ONS 1998) This caring work has been valued at £39.1 bn a year. (British Medical Assocn report Taking Care of the Carers, 1995)

 Formal and informal voluntary work is estimated to be worth at least £68bn a year. (National Centre for Volunteering, 1997).

Pensioners
 66% of pensioners claim Income Support because they have no or a very low pension in their own right as women. They live on £75 a week. (Government paper Partnership in Pensions Dec 1998)

Money
 The British government collects £79m a year from the poorest and most indebted countries, nearly all in Africa. The UK government uses our money to underwrite business deals, often for the arms trade, and then claims it back from the poorest countries' health and education budgets. (Figures for 1998/99, Jubilee 2000)

Compiled by the Global Women's Strike campaign

(Women's Individual Income 1996/97, as above)  51% of Afro-Caribbean, 30% of African, and 8-10% of Asian families are single parent families (Policy Studies Institute, 1998)  1.2 million people hold down two waged jobs, two thirds of them women. (Guardian, 4 January 99)  Women with two jobs work 30-60 hours a week for an average of £100. Some do three jobs for little more than £100 a week. (Guardian, 24 October, 1994)  2.45 million people mostly women earn below £64 a week. (The New Review, Low Pay Unit, March/April 1999) Carers  14% of women over 16 in Britain are carers for people with disabilities. A third of women carers spend over 20 hours a week in unwaged caring work. (Social Focus on Women and Men, ONS 1998) This caring work has been valued at £39.1 bn a year. (British Medical Assocn report Taking Care of the Carers, 1995)  Formal and informal voluntary work is estimated to be worth at least £68bn a year. (National Centre for Volunteering, 1997). Pensioners  66% of pensioners claim Income Support because they have no or a very low pension in their own right as women. They live on £75 a week. (Government paper Partnership in Pensions Dec 1998) Money  The British government collects £79m a year from the poorest and most indebted countries, nearly all in Africa. The UK government uses our money to underwrite business deals, often for the arms trade, and then claims it back from the poorest countries' health and education budgets. (Figures for 1998/99, Jubilee 2000) Compiled by the Global Women's Strike campaign

webTitle: Stop the world and change it: the global women's strike

fields.headline: Stop the world and change it: the global women's strike
fields.standfirst: Global women's strike website
fields.trailText: Aims of the strike
fields.body:
Aims of the strike

 Abolition of "Third World debt". Women in the South are owed billions for centuries of work.

 Accessible clean drinking water and ecologically sound appropriate technology for every household.

 Affordable, and accessible, housing and transport.

 Protection against violence - at home, in factory or office, on the farm, on the street.

 Pay equity for all - equal pay for work of equal value - internationally.

 Decent wages for caring work, whether in the family or outside.

 Paid maternity leave and breastfeeding breaks at paid employment.

 Increased pensions, child benefit and other benefits paid to mothers and other carers.

 Implementation of the UN decision (Beijing 1995) to measure and value the unwaged work done by women and men in national economic statistics.

Planned events around the world

UK London, 1-11pm, Union Chapel, Compton Avenue, Islington, N1 (Highbury & Islington tube). Women are invited to be "audacious and bodacious" at a day of celebration and protest, films and live performances by women singers, dancers and poets, from a range of countries. Star guest Redjen, (former lead singer of The Bellestars) whose original track "Strike 2000", is the strike's theme song. Full wheelchair access; childcare; food & refreshments.

Spain Women stop across Catalonia: women from churches, trades unions, local government and feminists are calling a stoppage of women (and men supporters) at 12 noon for a millennium without poverty or violence.

India Women will do no housework or other work in the villages of Madhya Pradesh; thousands will march in three large Districts: Raipur, Ragard, Mahasmund. Deputations led by Chhattisgarh Women's Organisation will go to Bhopal to meet officials and to Delhi to lobby the government chief minister, pressing demands to end violence and poverty.

Ireland The Women Count Network will be striking for a change in any way they think appropriate and, along with the National Women's Council, is pressing for a National Paid Holiday on 1 February to Value Women's Work.

Burkina Faso: Rural women are "striking to exist", demanding money for birth certificates and identity cards which most can't afford.

Philippines Community groups will lobby the president to issue a presidential proclamation making 8 March a paid holiday; women's parties and picnics in communities and villages; a "no shopping day" to protest against the consumer industry's profits at women's expense.

Canada Raging Grannies holding a workshop and a news conference publicising Women Take Off March 8 and asking "Are you March 8 compatible?"

Mexico Daughters of the Corn Women's Collective holding a strike day with public meeting, debate and celebration in Mexico City.

Trinidad & Tobago National Union of Domestic Employees will lead a women's march and rally in the capital, Port of Spain.

Nigeria The Grassroots Women Foundation is demanding that 8 March be declared a national public holiday and that breastfeeding working mothers be paid a special allowance.

USA Events in several major cities including Los Angeles, New York, Philadelphia, San Francisco, Washington DC, co-ordinated by US Wages for Housework. The Welfare Warriors (Wisconsin) gathering women's Bills for Billy (Clinton) - outlining what welfare they're owed for their unpaid work. Bills to be presented on 8 March.

Women are planning events in: Albania, Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Brazil, Cameroon, Chile, Ecuador, Finland, France, Germany, Ghana, Greece, Guyana, Hong Kong, Hungary, India, Iran, Ireland, Italy, Kenya, Korea, Kurdistan, Kyrgyzstan, Malawi, the Netherlands, Nicaragua, Pakistan, Panama, Peru, Puerto Rico, Romania, Rwanda, Senegal, Sweden, Switzerland and Taiwan.

webTitle: Former Welsh Labour leader to quit assembly

fields.headline: Former Welsh Labour leader to quit assembly
fields.trailText: March 7 2000: Alun Michael, the former Welsh secretary and home office minister, is to resign his seat in the Welsh assembly and stay on as an MP in a bid to pick up the threads of his Westminister political career.
fields.body:
Alun Michael, the former Welsh secretary and home office minister, is to resign his seat in the Welsh assembly and stay on as an MP in a bid to pick up the threads of his Westminister political career.

His decision, announced in Cardiff yesterday, comes just five weeks after his dramatic resignation as Labour leader in Wales and will make him the first assembly member to stand down since devolution less than a year ago.

Under assembly rules Mr Michael's departure will not trigger a byelection.

He was elected under the proportional representation system used to choose top-up candidates from regional party lists and will be replaced by the second name on Labour's list for mid and west Wales, Delyth Evans, a former BBC and HTV journalist. Ms Evans worked on the BBC's World at One and PM programmes before becoming a policy adviser and speechwriter to the former Labour leader John Smith. She will take her seat in the assembly from May 1.

Mr Michael, who has represented Cardiff South and Penarth since 1987, has been considering his political future since resigning as first secretary of the national assembly during a no confidence debate on Labour's handling of European funding for Wales last month.

The general committee of his constituency party have been urging him to stay on as their MP and Mr Michael consulted widely with family, friends and party workers before deciding to return to Westminster.

The decision marks the end of an often turbulent chapter in his political career after being pressed by Downing Street to take on the job following the downfall of the former Welsh secretary Ron Davies.

Mr Michael said yesterday that he remained a passionate advocate of devolution and that he was leaving the assembly without bitterness.

He added that while he could make a continuing contribution in the assembly there was always a danger that a former leader could become "an irritation and a negative force".

Rhodri Morgan, who took over as first secretary following Mr Michael's resignation last month, said: "Alun has done an enormous amount to getting the assembly up and running, very often working under great pressure."

webTitle: Banderas in front row for Phantom role

fields.headline: Banderas in front row for Phantom role
fields.trailText: Antonio Banderas is reported to be the first choice to star in the big-screen version of Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Phantom of the Opera. The Spanish actor would take the role of the disfigured, dementedly romantic composer at large in Victorian London opposite an as-yet-undecided actress as the imperilled (but oh so beautiful) Christina.
fields.body:
Antonio Banderas is reported to be the first choice to star in the big-screen version of Andrew Lloyd Webber's The Phantom of the Opera. The Spanish actor would take the role of the disfigured, dementedly romantic composer at large in Victorian London opposite an as-yet-undecided actress as the imperilled (but oh so beautiful) Christina.

Since its London premiere in the mid 1980s, The Phantom of the Opera has bloomed into history's most successful stage musical. For Banderas, the role would be his second Lloyd Webber collaboration. The actor co-starred as a fiery revolutionary in Alan Parker's 1997 adaptation of Evita.

webTitle: Why he decided to go it alone

fields.headline: Why he decided to go it alone
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Extracts from an article by Ken Livingstone in yesterday's Evening Standard
fields.body:
Extracts from an article by Ken Livingstone in yesterday's Evening Standard

Tony Blair became leader of the Labour party promising one member one vote and saying that the candidates we put forward should be acceptable to the electors. We were urged to listen to the voters. Yet quite clearly on the issue of who should be Labour's candidate and the issue of the tube, the government is refusing to listen to Londoners.

I took the view that it was in the best interests of London and the country if the government and those currently running the Labour party could be persuaded to listen to Londoners. By the end of last week it had become crystal clear that they had no intention of doing so.

Disraeli once said: "Damn your principle. Stick to your party." I do not agree with that. I have been forced to choose between the party I love and upholding the democratic rights of Londoners. I have therefore concluded that defence of the principle of London's rights to govern itself requires that I stand as an independent candidate for London mayor on May 4.

I shall use the next eight weeks of this campaign to mobilise every vote possible against the partial privatisation of the tube and, if elected, will do everything in my power to keep the underground as a unified service in the public sector.

I want to make it absolutely clear that I do not want anybody to leave the Labour party. Members who have been appalled by the conduct of Labour's selection must stay and fight to ensure that nothing like this ever happens again. I am standing as an independent solely in order to ensure that we have real devolution to London. I will not be setting up a new political party and I still hope one day to be able to return to the Labour party. The past two weeks have been the most difficult of my life. For those who denounce me for breaking my commitment not to leave the Labour party I offer no weasel words of equivocation and I apologise. But what I do not intend to do is take any lectures from those who have set new standards in ballot rigging.

Unlike the other candidates, I will not have a slick party machine or a team of spin doctors.

To win against these odds, I will need the support and donations of millions of ordinary Londoners. It will be hard to reach every voter individually. It will be a campaign funded by ordinary Londoners. But I believe that if we work together we can overcome these obstacles. If we do, we could achieve something that has never been done before in British politics.

fields.headline: Tearing up the rulebook
fields.standfirst:
Ken's challenge goes beyond Dobson

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: We are now in uncharted territory. Never before has Britain seen an electoral contest like the one unfolding in London: a four-way battle of individuals with an independent as the front-runner, and all under a new system which could make voters' second preferences decisive. Yesterday's declaration by Ken Livingstone, along with our poll this morning showing him with an extraordinary 55 point lead, threaten to rewrite some of the rules of British politics.
fields.body:
We are now in uncharted territory. Never before has Britain seen an electoral contest like the one unfolding in London: a four-way battle of individuals with an independent as the front-runner, and all under a new system which could make voters' second preferences decisive. Yesterday's declaration by Ken Livingstone, along with our poll this morning showing him with an extraordinary 55 point lead, threaten to rewrite some of the rules of British politics.

The rulebook say that a politician who breaks his word will be punished by the voters. Mr Livingstone offered commitment after commitment that he would not run as an independent against the official Labour candidate. Yesterday he reversed that position. Admirably, he did not try to "weasel" out of it, preferring to admit that he has broken his word and apologised for it. Will the voters overturn the conventional wisdom and forgive him? The Livingstone camp have taken their own soundings and say most people believe that politicians should do what they believe is right - even if that means breaking a previous promise. Are they right? Are voters that forgiving? Between now and May 4 we will find out.

Another political truism holds that Labour hates apostates. The former GLC leader has been alive to this point and may have worked out a clever way round it. First, he is explicitly urging Labour members to stay inside the party. Indeed, his aides say he cancelled last night's planned rally of Labour activists because "it wouldn't have been right" to link them to what is now an official challenge to the party. What's more, Mr Livingstone has said he will cast his own second preference vote for Frank Dobson. This offers diehard Labour tribalists a way of voting for Ken - and voting Labour. They can live with their consciences knowing that they did vote for the party... sort of.

The second nugget of Labour folklore states that defectors always fail. Ken Livingstone is going the way of Oswald Mosley, David Owen and Derek Hatton, chorus Messrs Prescott and Dobson. But this is slightly wishful thinking. For Ken is not heading off to form his own party or promising to "break the mould of British politics." Instead he is seeking to win a specific contest governed by a politics all its own. He does not want to replace or remake Labour. He just wants to catch his moment and win a London-wide election. This is another unforeseen consequence of devolution: there can now be new formations without challenging the entirety of UK politics. That is why it would be a mistake to read the Livingstone candidacy as the first step toward a new left party or as a test of strength for the British left. As evinced by his unpopularity with many of his fellow left-wingers, Ken is a loner - and his campaign is a one-off.

There is one last rule which Mr Livingstone is testing: the one that says politics requires organisation. He enjoys a phenomenal lead this morning, but none of the door-knockers and leafleteers whose unglamorous work tends to win elections. Can Ken overturn that iron law, winning the mayoralty on media-attention alone without the nuts and bolts of old-fashioned machine politics? And what of the Tony Benn maxim, which states that policies not personalities are what really matter? Will Mr Livingstone's programme stand up to the laser scrutiny which lights upon any frontrunner? These are the questions the next eight weeks will answer. It is Ken Livingstone's entry which has triggered them - and which will enliven this experiment in British democracy. That is why we welcome him to the race.

webTitle: Poll exclusive: Livingstone surges into huge lead

fields.headline: Poll exclusive: Livingstone surges into huge lead
fields.standfirst:
Dobson campaign in deep trouble as he trails by 55%

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone, who yesterday broke with 31 years of Labour to declare his independent candidacy for the post of London mayor, has surged ahead to take a 55-point lead over his official Labour opponent, Frank Dobson, according to an exclusive Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.
fields.byline: Alan Travis, Seumas Milne  and  Michael White
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, who yesterday broke with 31 years of Labour to declare his independent candidacy for the post of London mayor, has surged ahead to take a 55-point lead over his official Labour opponent, Frank Dobson, according to an exclusive Guardian/ICM opinion poll published today.

The survey's results show that voters in London were electrified yesterday by Mr Livingstone's announcement that he is to stand as an independent candidate, even though it will mean his expulsion from the Labour party. The poll, taken after his 10am declaration, gives him the support of 68% of London voters.

Mr Dobson, who polls only 13%, appears to face an impossible task in stopping Mr Livingstone despite the fact that Labour, from Tony Blair downwards, last night expressed the belief that his overwhelming lead can be eroded before the May 4 election.

The Guardian/ICM survey shows that Mr Livingstone commands the support of 75% of all Labour voters in London. The clear implication is that if Tony Blair goes to war against Mr Livingstone, he will be fighting not only his party activists in the capital but also the overwhelming mass of the party's voters in London.

The poll shows that Mr Livingstone's cross-party popularity is quite unprecedented. Some 70% of all Liberal Democrat voters in the capital say they intend to vote for him but even more astonishing is the result that 48% of Conservative voters are prepared to back the man once vilified as Red Ken. This is an even bigger share of the Tory vote in the capital than the 40% of Conservative voters who say they will support the official candidate, Steve Norris, and indicates that Tories are preparing to vote tactically on a massive scale.

But when the ICM pollsters asked Mr Livingstone's supporters why they were backing him, the decisive factor proved to be his popularity rather than the perception that he had been unfairly treated or a desire to "kick Tony Blair". Some 72% simply believe he is the best candidate.

After a day of ferocious official Labour attacks on the former Greater London council leader, he was formally suspended from party membership and had the whip withdrawn for behaviour "grossly detrimental to the interests of the party". Expulsion will follow the moment he files his nomination papers, which have to be in before April 4.

As he was branded a "traitor" and a "liar" by Mr Dobson and his supporters, the prime minister predicted the Brent East MP would be "disastrous" for London and the Tory leader, William Hague, called him a "far-left extremist who would be lethal for London".

Mr Livingstone said he had been "forced to choose between the party I love and upholding the democratic rights of Londoners. I have therefore concluded that defence of London's right to govern itself requires that I stand as an independent candidate for London mayor on May 4".

The "blatant ballot-rigging" that gave Mr Dobson the Labour nomination, while winning an estimated 22,275 votes to Mr Livingstone's 74,646, and the "massive support among Londoners that I should stand" had been decisive, despite earlier undertakings not to stand against Labour's official candidate.

Emphasising the "broad church", cross-party appeal he planned for his campaign, Mr Livingstone said he would be highlighting his demand for the Tube to stay in public hands.

Londoners would have to weigh his broken undertakings against the way Labour had conducted its mayoral selection and "choose which is the greatest crime".

His opponents predicted that his support had peaked, before last night's Guardian poll, and Mr Livingstone's campaign organisers said a fall in Mr Livingstone's opinion poll support from the 51% level in last month's ICM poll for the Evening Standard had been built into their calculations.

At the launch of his own campaign, overshadowed by Mr Livingstone's announcement, Mr Dobson sought to isolate Mr Livingstone on the left, accusing him of being "soft on crime", "anti-police" and "anti-business", with "ruinous policies" and "chat-show politics" that would saddle Londoners with debt and higher taxes.

Mr Livingstone countered that he had been "consistent in his support for the police" and said he would fight to reverse the cuts in spending on the Metropolitan police by both Labour and Tory government's and to increase the force from 26,000 to 28,000.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,003 adults aged over 18 by telephone yesterday. Interviews were conducted across London and the data has been weighted to the profile of all London adults.

Some 72% simply believe he is the best candidate. After a day of ferocious official Labour attacks on the former Greater London council leader, he was formally suspended from party membership and had the whip withdrawn for behaviour "grossly detrimental to the interests of the party". Expulsion will follow the moment he files his nomination papers, which have to be in before April 4. As he was branded a "traitor" and a "liar" by Mr Dobson and his supporters, the prime minister predicted the Brent East MP would be "disastrous" for London and the Tory leader, William Hague, called him a "far-left extremist who would be lethal for London". Mr Livingstone said he had been "forced to choose between the party I love and upholding the democratic rights of Londoners. I have therefore concluded that defence of London's right to govern itself requires that I stand as an independent candidate for London mayor on May 4". The "blatant ballot-rigging" that gave Mr Dobson the Labour nomination, while winning an estimated 22,275 votes to Mr Livingstone's 74,646, and the "massive support among Londoners that I should stand" had been decisive, despite earlier undertakings not to stand against Labour's official candidate. Emphasising the "broad church", cross-party appeal he planned for his campaign, Mr Livingstone said he would be highlighting his demand for the Tube to stay in public hands. Londoners would have to weigh his broken undertakings against the way Labour had conducted its mayoral selection and "choose which is the greatest crime". His opponents predicted that his support had peaked, before last night's Guardian poll, and Mr Livingstone's campaign organisers said a fall in Mr Livingstone's opinion poll support from the 51% level in last month's ICM poll for the Evening Standard had been built into their calculations. At the launch of his own campaign, overshadowed by Mr Livingstone's announcement, Mr Dobson sought to isolate Mr Livingstone on the left, accusing him of being "soft on crime", "anti-police" and "anti-business", with "ruinous policies" and "chat-show politics" that would saddle Londoners with debt and higher taxes. Mr Livingstone countered that he had been "consistent in his support for the police" and said he would fight to reverse the cuts in spending on the Metropolitan police by both Labour and Tory government's and to increase the force from 26,000 to 28,000. ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,003 adults aged over 18 by telephone yesterday. Interviews were conducted across London and the data has been weighted to the profile of all London adults.

fields.headline: When secrecy becomes tyranny
fields.standfirst: David Hencke argues that the government's obsession with secrecy is out of control
fields.trailText: David Hencke argues that the government's obsession with secrecy is out of control.
fields.body:
The outrageous questioning of student Julie Davies, by police for supporting a campaign to get the charges dropped against ex MI5 man David Shayler is the latest appalling move by the new Labour government. It suggests that anyone who believes that former agents should have the right to expose some of the more bungling aspects of our security service should immediately be investigated as a criminal.

This attitude reflects the current paranoia by Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, over national security. The current Freedom of Information bill bans the release of everything connected with the security service. Not only does it ban it - but it also prevents the authorities confirming or denying that the information even exists. How different to the United States where even when information requests on security are denied - the authorities normally tell you why the information cannot be released. They also occasionally release information - with agents names deleted - on bungled security operation -including one destined to protect Princess Diana.

It is no wonder then the home secretary will find that agents will occasionally blow a whistle. How else are they to complain? The committee which examines the security services in Parliament is appointed by Tony Blair, meets in secret and occasionally produces a heavily censored report. What is the goverrnment's answer? To repress anybody who supports openness; use ludicrous laws like the discredited copyright act to frighten newspapers from publishing information; and generally assume that the whole security apparatus of the state must always remain secret. Such an attitude would do credit to interior minister in the ill-fated Soviet Union. All that is missing is a convenient gulag to imprison these traitors. No doubt Jack Straw will soon find an excuse to set one up.

Britain is already one of the laggards in releasing information - with a freedom of information bill that is a misnomer and laughing stock to other western democracies. The government's attitude to protecting the security services is typical of their attitude towards the public's right to know - we don't want it, we don't need it and we are never going to give to you.

fields.headline: RBS proffers stock options
fields.trailText: The 94,000 staff of Royal Bank of Scotland and NatWest were given free stock options in the combined group last night as NatWest's top two executives walked away with £1m payouts after the £18bn takeover was finally completed.
fields.body:
The 94,000 staff of Royal Bank of Scotland and NatWest were given free stock options in the combined group last night as NatWest's top two executives walked away with £1m payouts after the £18bn takeover was finally completed.

Ron Sandler, parachuted in as NatWest's chief operating officer when the takeover battle began five months ago, can claim £1m after leaving yesterday while Sir David Rowland, the chairman and chief executive, can expect slightly less.

Royal Bank admitted yesterday that only two senior NatWest executives will remain: Gordon Pell, named yesterday as chief executive of the group's combined retail banking operations, including its small business division; and Richard Delbridge, the NatWest finance director whose position was not clarified yesterday although he is expected to take a similar role in the combined bank.

In a memo to staff, the victorious Edinburgh-based bank said each of them would receive 150 stock options in the new bank, whose shares closed last night at £8.82. The terms of the share deal is yet to be finalised.

Up to 18,000 of the 94,000 face losing their jobs as result of the takeover which will see the power base shift to Scotland. The new bank will be called the Royal Bank of Scotland Group, though the NatWest name will continue on the high street.

Royal Bank is now embarking on a 30-day programme to establish the top positions for each of the operations of the combined group of which Fred Goodwin is chief executive. He was deputy chief executive of the Royal Bank until yesterday.

Yesterday it named the chief executives of seven "customer facing divisions", with Mr Pell and Martin Wilson, chief executive of NatWest's Ulster bank. Royal Bank's Iain Robertson is to be chief executive of the corporate banking and treasury business, which is the biggest in the country.

During the next 30 days, the bank expects to name the heads of other major operations including a chief executive for what it describes as manufacturing, the support operations for the seven customer facing divisions which also include insurer Direct Line, the cards businesses, and Citizens, the US bank.
