webTitle: Weird or wonderful?  A weekly look at alternative therapies

fields.headline: Weird or wonderful?  A weekly look at alternative therapies
fields.standfirst: Colour therapy
fields.trailText: Colour therapy
fields.body:
I must confess to some timidity as I knock on Pauline Wills's door. Colour therapy, I think: she could well be barmy. She may well insist that I wear only flame red, or paint my kitchen green. The calm, middle aged woman who greets me, however, does not look crazed. As she sits me down in her neutrally decorated therapy room I realise she's already got me pegged. "Colour therapy," she tells me sternly, "is about the properties of light. It is not about pigment." It isn't, then, about how you paint your lounge? "No, it's about energy: colour is the visible part of the electromagnetic spectrum." This means that it's somewhere between radio waves and X-rays. Apparently, Hippocrates, Paracelsus and the ancient Egyptians all used colour for healing. I'm no physicist, but there could be more to colour than meets the eye.

Colour therapists believe you can heal the body by applying coloured light to it. This is because you have an "aura" (a coloured electromagnetic field that surrounds your body. The colours radiate from "chakras", or energy centres in the aura). Each part of your body, from its skeleton to its muscles and organs "vibrates to" one of these colours. When you're peaky it's because these vibrations have somehow gone off-kilter - an area of your aura will be either colourless, or vibrating to the wrong colour. So by applying the right colour to the bit of you that's unwell, you can readjust the vibrations and heal the illness.

Clearly, this isn't easily proven. But Pauline also uses reflexology, which has become so accepted that it's even used by many hospitals. Reflexologists believe that your feet are "mirror images" of your body. So each bit of your foot corresponds to a specific part of your body (by pressing part of the ball of your foot, for instance, you can ease a stiff neck). Reflexology can also be used to diagnose - the tender parts of your foot signal the weaknesses in your body. Pauline is, she tells me, going to assess what bits of me need help using reflexology, then use colour to treat them.

Pauline rubs my feet, asking sensitive questions about my life and health. Before long, I'm dying to unburden myself of every worry I've ever had. She's seen this before. Physical ailments, she believes, are rooted in emotional ones. And over her twenty odd years as an alternative therapist Pauline has become an excellent counsellor.

What my feet say about my emotional state is anyone's guess. But as she kneads away, a remarkably accurate map of my physical weaknesses emerges. She's particularly concerned about my womb, lower back and bladder, all of which would probably have been affected by a caesarean section I had a year ago. This diagnosis suggests either that Pauline is freakishly lucky or that reflexology works.

I honestly can't say whether colour therapy is effective or not. Pauline takes a plastic implement that looks like the injecting device from Star Trek. She fits an orange filter onto it, switches it on and holds it to the side of my foot. The colour will, she says, help strengthen and heal my womb. Finally, she suffuses my feet with orange then blue light from two large lamps. This is for general all over well-being.

If you're not persuaded by colour therapy it's worth remembering that hospitals often treat jaundiced premature babies with blue light (it destroys the excess bilirubin that the immature liver can't remove). So if you're willing to believe that other colours can do similar things, and don't mind having your feet rubbed, then a course of "colour integrated with reflexology" could do you the world of good. Apart from anything else, Pauline is a wonderful listener.

For more information contact Pauline Wills on 0181 204 7672 or email Pauline@oracleschool.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: End of the affair
fields.standfirst: Esther Addley explains how she (almost) said goodbye to a dear friend - and looks forward to spending No Smoking Day without a cigaretteSmoking: special report
fields.trailText: Esther Addley  explains how she (almost) said goodbye to a dear friend - and looks forward to spending No Smoking Day without a cigarette.
fields.body:
Almost a fifth of the year 2000 is already over. It is unlikely that this fact will fill you with joy. Yet there is a bunch of embattled masochists for whom every day into this year has been a small victory, a moment to be celebrated, another step towards a great goal.

They are the quitters, the ex-smokers. The healthy. Anti-smoking group ASH estimates there were over a million of them: brave souls who fought through the champagne fog at one minute past midnight on New Year's Eve to extinguish their last, 20th century, smoke. They don't have any figures yet on how many of them are still at it. But if other stats are anything to go by, their numbers lessen by the day. A third of all smokers try to stop every year, but only something like 4% make it.

I am not one of them, at least according to my critics. At some point between the start of January and the end I stopped buying cigarettes and, well, became someone who didn't buy cigarettes any more. I'm not allowed to go further and call myself an ex-smoker you see, because I have been known on occasion to pike one off a pitying friend or colleague.

To smokers and ex-smokers alike, this is the unforgiveable sin. Friends who recently congratulated me on having "given up" have shot looks of disillusioned scorn on catching me inhaling like blazes in the kitchen.

Giving up smoking is a bizarre ritual, subject to extraordinary peer pressure. Hell, even heroin addicts are allowed methadone. But the medicinal application of a Marlboro once a fortnight to remind you what a horrible habit it is? Suddenly you're Really Letting Yourself Down.

The thing is, it works for me. Like every last smoker on the planet, I have been consumed by racking coughs and self-loathing and have tried to quit on countless occasions. But such is the weight of expectation once one announces an intention to stop, any small lapse is absolute failure. There is no permissible third way when it comes to cigarettes.

This is partly because rational, grown-up debate on smoking is remarkably thin on the ground. Public pronouncements on the habit divide neatly into morbid statistics from the anti-smoking lobby, and a bloody-minded assertion from the libertarians that they will fight to the (cancer-riddled) death for the right to light up. Considering a third of British adults smoke, and 450 kids take up the habit every day, we would surely do well to consider in rather more rounded terms quite why so many of us enjoy sucking on burning leaves.

Addiction, of course, is part of it, but only part. Because there is a poetry to indulging in a cigarette that will never be found in having a cup of coffee. A fag cadged, or offered, is an intimate little exchange - somehow brotherly. And that sharing a cigarette has become such a cliche during the companionable, squidgy, slightly awkward post-coital moment is not surprising.

Of course, cigarettes also kill you, and in no uncertain terms. Which is why I quit, or cut down, or whatever it is I'm allowed to say about the fact that I'm now significantly healthier. Wednesday is National No Smoking day and a great opportunity - if landmark days work for you - to give "giving up" another try. If you decide to do so, best of luck - I can't recommend it highly enough. But you are allowed more than a pang of regret for the dear friends you are setting aside and the deep, deep joy they have brought you. Acknowledging that fact might just be the first step towards living without them.

webTitle: The definitive guide to treating common ailments

fields.headline: The definitive guide to treating common ailments
fields.standfirst: No 22: Migraine
fields.trailText: No 22: Migraine
fields.body:
The problem: One in 10 people are victims of migraine yet many suffer in silence, unaware that effective treatments exist. About 60% of sufferers never consult their GP, believing their complaint is too trivial or their doctor cannot help. Others are still not prescribed effective medication. Doctors may fail to diagnose migraine, not know which treatments work, or be reluctant to prescribe costly medication.

Symptoms: Symptoms and triggers of migraine vary significantly. People typically suffer throbbing headaches, but other symptoms include nausea and vomiting, flashing lights or tunnel vision, sensitivity to light, noise and smells, and pins and needles in the limbs. Attacks may be triggered by certain foods, stress, going without food and too little or too much sleep.

Treatment: There is no cure for migraine. Most people treat themselves with over-the-counter painkillers. Yet they are ineffective for many people. A worldwide review of migraine treatments by the pain relief unit at Oxford's Churchill hospital found that triptans - prescription-only drugs developed in the last decade - can effectively reduce and eliminate migraine pain. The review found that sumatriptan (brand name Imigran) by injection works best, curing headache for about half of sufferers within two hours. Of the tablets, rizatriptan 10mg (Maxalt) and zolmitriptan 5 mg (Zomig) work well, but are less effective at lower doses. Tolfenamic acid (Clotam) - not a triptan - appears to work equally well. Imigran 100mg tablets and Imigran nasal spray are fairly effective while the lower dose tablets are less so. There is less evidence for the effectiveness of two tablets, naratriptan (Naramig) and Cafergot (a different drug group), the review found.

Prevention: Avoiding triggers can help. If attacks are frequent, prophylactics, like Sanomigran and Deseril, can help but may have unpleasant side effects. The herbal remedy feverfew shows good results in trials but, on current evidence, homeopathic treatment works no better than placebos.

More information: Oxford's pain relief unit has a website with research on interventions for pain at www.ebando.com. Or send an SAE to Migraine Action, 178a High Road, Byfleet, Surrey KT14 7ED (01932 352468).

webTitle: Is it time for my Prozac, mum?

fields.headline: Is it time for my Prozac, mum?
fields.standfirst: Doctors in the UK have been warned that they are prescribing too many mind-altering drugs to children. Is your toddler's erratic behaviour just part of growing up, asks  Lucy Atkins, or is it a sign of psychological disorder?
fields.trailText: Doctors in the UK have been warned that they are prescribing too many mind-altering drugs to children. Is your toddler's erratic behaviour just part of growing up, or is it a sign of psychological disorder?
fields.body:
It is increasingly clear to me that my toddler lives in a perilous, experimental, illogical world. Her rules are not mine. Indeed, she may not have any rules at all. She is subject to sudden mood swings. She often doesn't listen when I tell her things. She has a short attention span. She is, as far as I know, a normal, healthy 15-month-old child.

These behavioural traits can, however, in the extreme, be signs of a psychological disorder called attention deficit hyperactity disorder (ADHD). In very young children the dividing line between an irrational and difficult toddler and one with actual psychological problems must, then, be pretty blurred. For this reason, a study published last week in the journal of the American medical association makes mind-boggling reading.

Researchers at the university of Maryland found that in the US many children as young as two years old are being prescribed mind-altering drugs for disorders such as hyperactivity, depression, insomnia or obsessive-compulsive disorder. And this trend is growing fast. The team found that between 1991 and 1995 the number of psychiatric drugs prescribed to these pre-school children rose by 50%.

So what's going on? Are American parents becoming more neurotic? Or are psychological illnesses in young children on the increase? And are things going the same way here?

Certainly, the trend towards giving children drugs for psychiatric reasons is not confined to the other side of the Atlantic. In Britain there was widespread concern last year when figures were released showing that prescriptions for Ritalin, used to treat children suffering from ADHD, had shot up. In England the number of prescriptions for this drug rose from 3,500 in 1993 to 126,500 in 1998. This increase has been so steep that it provoked the international drugs control board, a United Nations agency, to issue a warning last year that doctors in the UK are prescribing too much Ritalin to too many children.

But at least the vast majority of children in Britain who are taking Ritalin, or other psychiatric drugs, including the anti-depressant Prozac, are of school age. We are not - yet - doling out mind-altering pharmaceuticals to toddlers. Well, not in any significant numbers, anyway.

According to Professor Peter Hill, consultant child psychiatrist at Great Ormond Street hospital in London, psychiatric drugs are rarely prescribed for under-5s because "pre-school children show a variety of emotional and behavioural problems, most of which relate to their living situation." It is, he says, unwise to label a pre-school child as depressed, or hyperactive and use drugs to treat this. "I would be very, very cautious before deciding to make a diagnosis like depression, ADHD or obsessive compulsive disorder. And even if I thought a four year old was genuinely primary ADHD I wouldn't leap in with medication."

Dr Rea Reason, educational psychologist at Manchester univeristy, who chaired the British psychological society's 1996 working party on ADHD is similarly cautious: "Its nature and its definition keeps shifting." It is a "package of difficulties" and "diagnosis is a quagmire, at any age." It is, she believes, far more important to understand the child, than to label the disorder. "We need to examine different influencing factors for a child's behaviour," says Reason. There are "ethical issues to using medication to control childrens' behaviour."

And apart from the difficulties of "diagnosing" a toddler's erratic behaviour, there's also the fact that the drugs themselves may not work. "There is no evidence to show that psychotropic treatment in very young children actually does any good," says Malcolm Lader, professor of psychopharmacology at the Institute of Psychiatry. In fact, these drugs might actually do a child long-term damage. "If it was a grandchild of mine," says Lader, "I would not prescribe it. The human brain at this age is still developing and maturing and there have been no satisfactory clinical trials for the use of drugs like Ritalin on young children." Indeed, when in one study last year, researchers gave Prozac to baby rats of the same age as pre-school children, the drug produced long-standing changes in the brain.

There are, of course, guidelines as to how drugs such as Prozac and Ritalin should be used. Anyone prescribing these, or other such drugs to children, would have to justify their decision by citing a "reasonable body of medical evidence" if anything went wrong. These guidelines say that Ritalin should not be used on children under six and that Prozac is not recommended for children under 16. But strictly speaking there's nothing to stop a GP, paediatrician or psychiatrist from putting your difficult three year old on Prozac. In fact a recent government green paper on reform of the mental health act proposed that doctors should be able to drug children without parental consent if they have "any disability or disorder of the mind or brain, whether permanent or temporary, which results in an impairment of disturbance of mental functioning."

For some parents, of course, consent isn't an issue. They're desperate for anything that will help "normalise" their child. Most parents will at some point have watched in horror as their little force of destruction barrels through a room, rampages through a jumbo jet, or disrupts a checkout queue. And most of us have probably, in our darker moments, longed for a drug that will silence a hysterical, insomniac child. But in practice, few of us would resort to medication, least of all medication that might harm our child.

But then, this is probably because few of us have any concept of what it's actually like to bring up a child with what Peter Hill calls "a mental disorder." Gill Mead, founder of the ADHD family support group who talks to thousands of distressed parents a year, is adamant that the drugs can and do work.

Consider, for example, Joe. He is three and has already been expelled from two nurseries for hitting and biting the other children. He screams ceaselessly if his mother is out of his sight. He is hyperactive. He will tell his mother to "Fuck off, you bitch" (a sign, Mead believes, of Tourette's syndrome, often associated with ADHD). A spider, a trip to Tesco, even a loud noise can render him hysterical for hours. Mead believes that Joe is suffering from ADHD. "Ritalin would work," she says, "without a doubt."

But when, exactly, does a toddler leave "difficult" and become "disordered"? Critics of the drug trend believe that the rise in prescriptions for under-fives in the US can be put down to parents being unable to cope with difficult children, and not to a rise in mental disorders or the diagnosis of them. "In the US there is gross over-prescription in all children, for what is normal, boistrous behaviour," says Malcolm Lader.

Deborah Lobe, policy and information manager at the childrens' mental health charity Young Minds, believes that this is unlikely to spread to the UK: "The system here works well for under-5s at the moment." GPs, she says, would not prescribe drugs like Ritalin. They would refer the child straight to a paediatrician. Waiting lists, which can prove so destructive for parents of older children who might wait as long as a year for psychiatric referrals, are short for under-fives.

The youngest child she has recently come across with ADHD is 15 months old. He is already on Ritalin. That's the same age as my daughter. It seems inconceivable that anyone could diagnose my child, at this age, with any kind of psychological disorder. But then, she's not banging her head against things, compulsively, all day long; having to wear a crash helmet, and never sleeping.

But are drugs like Prozac and Ritalin really the answer? fields.bodyText: It is increasingly clear to me that my toddler lives in a perilous, experimental, illogical world. Her rules are not mine. Indeed, she may not have any rules at all. She is subject to sudden mood swings. She often doesn't listen when I tell her things. She has a short attention span. She is, as far as I know, a normal, healthy 15-month-old child. These behavioural traits can, however, in the extreme, be signs of a psychological disorder called attention deficit hyperactity disorder (ADHD). In very young children the dividing line between an irrational and difficult toddler and one with actual psychological problems must, then, be pretty blurred. For this reason, a study published last week in the journal of the American medical association makes mind-boggling reading. Researchers at the university of Maryland found that in the US many children as young as two years old are being prescribed mind-altering drugs for disorders such as hyperactivity, depression, insomnia or obsessive-compulsive disorder. And this trend is growing fast. The team found that between 1991 and 1995 the number of psychiatric drugs prescribed to these pre-school children rose by 50%. So what's going on? Are American parents becoming more neurotic? Or are psychological illnesses in young children on the increase? And are things going the same way here? Certainly, the trend towards giving children drugs for psychiatric reasons is not confined to the other side of the Atlantic. In Britain there was widespread concern last year when figures were released showing that prescriptions for Ritalin, used to treat children suffering from ADHD, had shot up. In England the number of prescriptions for this drug rose from 3,500 in 1993 to 126,500 in 1998. This increase has been so steep that it provoked the international drugs control board, a United Nations agency, to issue a warning last year that doctors in the UK are prescribing too much Ritalin to too many children. But at least the vast majority of children in Britain who are taking Ritalin, or other psychiatric drugs, including the anti-depressant Prozac, are of school age. We are not - yet - doling out mind-altering pharmaceuticals to toddlers. Well, not in any significant numbers, anyway. According to Professor Peter Hill, consultant child psychiatrist at Great Ormond Street hospital in London, psychiatric drugs are rarely prescribed for under-5s because "pre-school children show a variety of emotional and behavioural problems, most of which relate to their living situation." It is, he says, unwise to label a pre-school child as depressed, or hyperactive and use drugs to treat this. "I would be very, very cautious before deciding to make a diagnosis like depression, ADHD or obsessive compulsive disorder. And even if I thought a four year old was genuinely primary ADHD I wouldn't leap in with medication." Dr Rea Reason, educational psychologist at Manchester univeristy, who chaired the British psychological society's 1996 working party on ADHD is similarly cautious: "Its nature and its definition keeps shifting." It is a "package of difficulties" and "diagnosis is a quagmire, at any age." It is, she believes, far more important to understand the child, than to label the disorder. "We need to examine different influencing factors for a child's behaviour," says Reason. There are "ethical issues to using medication to control childrens' behaviour." And apart from the difficulties of "diagnosing" a toddler's erratic behaviour, there's also the fact that the drugs themselves may not work. "There is no evidence to show that psychotropic treatment in very young children actually does any good," says Malcolm Lader, professor of psychopharmacology at the Institute of Psychiatry. In fact, these drugs might actually do a child long-term damage. "If it was a grandchild of mine," says Lader, "I would not prescribe it. The human brain at this age is still developing and maturing and there have been no satisfactory clinical trials for the use of drugs like Ritalin on young children." Indeed, when in one study last year, researchers gave Prozac to baby rats of the same age as pre-school children, the drug produced long-standing changes in the brain. There are, of course, guidelines as to how drugs such as Prozac and Ritalin should be used. Anyone prescribing these, or other such drugs to children, would have to justify their decision by citing a "reasonable body of medical evidence" if anything went wrong. These guidelines say that Ritalin should not be used on children under six and that Prozac is not recommended for children under 16. But strictly speaking there's nothing to stop a GP, paediatrician or psychiatrist from putting your difficult three year old on Prozac. In fact a recent government green paper on reform of the mental health act proposed that doctors should be able to drug children without parental consent if they have "any disability or disorder of the mind or brain, whether permanent or temporary, which results in an impairment of disturbance of mental functioning." For some parents, of course, consent isn't an issue. They're desperate for anything that will help "normalise" their child. Most parents will at some point have watched in horror as their little force of destruction barrels through a room, rampages through a jumbo jet, or disrupts a checkout queue. And most of us have probably, in our darker moments, longed for a drug that will silence a hysterical, insomniac child. But in practice, few of us would resort to medication, least of all medication that might harm our child. But then, this is probably because few of us have any concept of what it's actually like to bring up a child with what Peter Hill calls "a mental disorder." Gill Mead, founder of the ADHD family support group who talks to thousands of distressed parents a year, is adamant that the drugs can and do work. Consider, for example, Joe. He is three and has already been expelled from two nurseries for hitting and biting the other children. He screams ceaselessly if his mother is out of his sight. He is hyperactive. He will tell his mother to "Fuck off, you bitch" (a sign, Mead believes, of Tourette's syndrome, often associated with ADHD). A spider, a trip to Tesco, even a loud noise can render him hysterical for hours. Mead believes that Joe is suffering from ADHD. "Ritalin would work," she says, "without a doubt." But when, exactly, does a toddler leave "difficult" and become "disordered"? Critics of the drug trend believe that the rise in prescriptions for under-fives in the US can be put down to parents being unable to cope with difficult children, and not to a rise in mental disorders or the diagnosis of them. "In the US there is gross over-prescription in all children, for what is normal, boistrous behaviour," says Malcolm Lader. Deborah Lobe, policy and information manager at the childrens' mental health charity Young Minds, believes that this is unlikely to spread to the UK: "The system here works well for under-5s at the moment." GPs, she says, would not prescribe drugs like Ritalin. They would refer the child straight to a paediatrician. Waiting lists, which can prove so destructive for parents of older children who might wait as long as a year for psychiatric referrals, are short for under-fives. The youngest child she has recently come across with ADHD is 15 months old. He is already on Ritalin. That's the same age as my daughter. It seems inconceivable that anyone could diagnose my child, at this age, with any kind of psychological disorder. fields.headline: Student arrested over Shayler link
fields.standfirst: University 'concerned' over suppression of free speech
fields.trailText: A student supporter of exiled former MI5 officer David Shayler was today released on bail after being questioned by special branch police over an alleged breach of the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
A student supporter of the exiled former MI5 officer David Shayler was released on bail today after being questioned by special branch police over an alleged breach of the Official Secrets Act.

Julie-Ann Davies, a 36-year-old mature student of aerospace engineering at Kingston university in Surrey, was arrested yesterday by officers with a warrant requiring the college to provide access to her computer, from which she was reported to have emailed Mr Shayler.

Ms Davies' solicitor Neil O'May, of Bindman & Partners, said she had returned to Kingston university today.

"She is astonished at being arrested without any warning in the way she was and very uncertain about what the allegations are and what she's done to be interesting to the special branch," he said. "She's rather worried about being on bail and facing further questioning."

Mr Shayler, now living in Paris, has been told he faces prosecution if he returns to Britain, after allegations he has made to newspapers about the security services, including the revelation that MI6 were involved in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader Colonel Muammar Gadafy. Ms Davies was said to have been active in the campaign to get charges against Mr Shayler dropped.

John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer and director of the civil rights group Liberty, said: "The arrest and prosecution of more people will do nothing to protect national security. The only solution is to negotiate with Dave to bring an end to this sorry saga."

Mr Wadham also expressed surprise at the student's arrest. "So far as I understand it, she was a researcher for the political satire programme the Mark Thomas Comedy Product," he told BBC Radio 4.

"I'm a bit surprised that we have special branch going around arresting those people involved in producing satire and comedy.

"The programme went out at the beginning of this year, and was a half hour discussion of David Shayler in a light-hearted and jokey fashion."

"A woman was arrested in Kingston by officers from special branch in connection with the Official Secrets Act," Scotland Yard confirmed. Ms Davies was arrested under section five of the act covering the receipt and disclosure of official information without authority.

Kingston university vice-chancellor Peter Scott said: "She is a second-year student in good standing with the university.

"The university is especially concerned because we understand she may have been arrested following contacts with David Shayler, the former MI5 agent whose extradition has been unsuccessfully sought by the British government.

"The university, as an institution committed to freedom of expression, would be particularly concerned if it turned out that a discredited piece of legislation, the Official Secrets Act, was being used to suppress legitimate journalistic investigation and the public's right to know about alleged abuse by the security services."

fields.headline: Take note
fields.standfirst: Visiting Yale history professor  Bernard Porter explains why he doesn't want to be represented on the net by a student's lecture notes - made for $8-$12 a go
fields.trailText: Visiting Yale history professor Bernard Porter explains why he doesn't want to be represented on the net by a student's lecture notes - made for $8-$12 a go
fields.body:
An academic legal battle is looming in America over the activities of an internet company called Versity.com. Founded by four University of Michigan undergraduates in 1997, Versity.com pays students a reported $8-$12 a time to take notes of lectures, which it then posts on the web. The service is financed by advertising, and so is free to its customers.

So far, 36 Yale courses have been included. Recently Yale's lawyers wrote to Versity.com to demand it remove these from its site, which it has done. The dean also wrote to all students pointing out that they were violating university regulations by working for a commercial company without permission.

There is concern on other campuses too. What has probably most annoyed the academic community is the covert nature of all this.

The first I heard of Versity.com was when I was alerted that notes of my lectures were on the site. I have no means of knowing which eager young entrepreneur was providing this service. Versity.com makes a strong point of guaranteeing its agents' "privacy".

I suspect the nerdish-looking guy in the front row with the lap-top who always arrived early and then scuttled out purposively at the end. What a shame for him if he is not the one. Mistrust between lecturer and students may be the most upsetting effect of this practice.

I told my class I regard it rather like spying. Since then my suspect has moved to the back row, and no more of my lectures have been posted. But it raises other issues. Some academics are offended by the blatant commercialism involved. (In America?!) Others fear that it will encourage students to skip lectures altogether.

Versity.com tells them its notes are no substitute for attendance, but that reads hollowly. Soon I could be declaiming to a single nerd.

But the issue most exercising the Yale authorities is that of "intellectual property". That is the ground of their complaint to Versity.com. A related concern is plagiarism. Versity.com specifically instructs its reporters to avoid "plagiarising a professor or any other source", but how can it be otherwise? (It also, incidentally, seriously warns them not to reveal "X-File secrets".) Often the notes are inaccurate.

Does that make the plagiarism less? My own reporter seems fairly competent, but even he has obviously heard some things wrong. One mis-statement - that black West Indians were better off under slavery - could actually get me into trouble over here.

One protection I have is that my lectures are nowhere attributed to me. Only the numbers and titles of the courses are given. Of course, any outraged PC reader would find it easy to trace me through this and Yale's own website. This anonymity, however, raises other concerns.

A basic rule we try to impress upon our students is always to cite their sources. Versity.com's practice offends against that. It also disables its customers from checking their sources. Behind this, however, lies a more worrying problem. When I first found my own anonymous notes on the internet, it had an odd effect on me. It made it appear as though what I had been offering as a personal interpretation, attached to me, had been transmuted into general, objective truth, a kind of impersonalised commodity.

Is this how today's students regard internet "knowledge"? Versity.com's publicity certainly implies this. One advantage, it claims, of the worldwide dissemination of our lectures this way is that "students can check out the best notes and explanations from around the country". You don't need to be an out-and-out postmodernist to cringe at the implications of that. Whatever happened to learning as analysis, debate, competing interpretations, uncertainty? As, in other words, an intellectually active not just receptive or consumerist enterprise?

Versity.com's response to criticism is aggressive. It defends its practice on grounds of "free speech". Lectures are in the "public domain". "Intellectual property rights do not exist," claims a spokesman.

"Someone taught the professors the material they're lecturing on; are they going to send their old professors a part of their pay check each year?" Besides, what Versity.com publishes on the web are not the lectures but the work of its note-takers, in whom copyright thus resides.

Those note-takers are carefully vetted, "trained", and monitored by means of feedback questionnaires issued to the customers (students), who are the best judges of how good the notes are. Versity.com is merely expanding the range of resources for students, and hence - this word appears often - "empowering" them.

The product is popular. Lecturers are just afraid of healthy market competition. If they are worried about mistakes, they have the solution in their own hands: come to an agreement with Versity.com to check the notes before they are disseminated. (What percentage of the $8-$12 will they be entitled to for that?) "Versity.com's philosophy is to work cooperatively with universities wherever possible." How that squares with its subterfuge before now is not explained. Besides, this would not address the major issues.

Lectures, of course, are not just ways of disseminating knowledge. Students can get that from books. Don't they know the difference? The best lectures are always in the nature of dialogues, even when there is no overt discussion, because they are prepared and often amended by the minute for particular audiences.

They introduce new ideas and approaches, sometimes ones the lecturer has not fully thought through but that he thinks might excite and stimulate. He will point out the provisional nature of these notions - caveats which, in my experience, never seem to get through to the internet notes.

This lecturer explicitly will not want his lectures to be published, for two reasons: the possibly ignoble one that he wants to develop his new insights himself before someone else seizes them ("intellectual property"); and the purer one that he does not want to commit himself and his reputation to a position before he is sure. When he is, he'll publish himself, and under his own editorial control.

Lectures are an entirely different animal. They are prepared and delivered on the understanding that they will not be published. They are not "public" in this sense, though if Versity.com wins the legal battle they may become so. The gain for students (and others) will be that they get access to a vast repository of lectures all over the world. (Versity.com is not the only outfit, incidentally, fishing in this pond.) But there may be a downside.

If I had known that my lectures were to be disseminated so widely, for example, I would certainly have given them differently. There would have been no speculation, improvisation, experiment; nothing I wouldn't want to be committed to, or could be taken the wrong way; probably no jokes. If lectures are public property, that is how they will all become. It is difficult to see what will be the special point of them then.

 Bernard Porter, of the University of Newcastle, is visiting professor of history at Yale University.

fields.headline: Resources on the web
fields.standfirst: Lee Elliot Major finds the net useful for researching courses
fields.trailText: Lee Elliot Major finds the net useful for researching courses
fields.body:
The website for the National Postgraduate Committee, the representative body for UK postgraduates, is as good a place as any to start a search for resources and services for postgrads on the internet. At www.npc.org.uk the committee offers information on postgraduate issues and facts, including a glossary of terms used in postgraduate education, common questions for prospective postgraduates, details of how to set up and run local postgraduate associations, and a summary of recent government policies affecting universities.

The site features links to listings of postgraduate courses and graduate job opportunities, individual university postgraduate associations and overseas postgraduate organisations. Users can also sample the committee's newsletter online, with discussions on every conceivable issue likely to arise during postgraduate study, from the development of robust postgraduate complaints procedures to the supervisor relationship for lesbian, gay and bisexual researchers.

The NPC site is part of PI-Net, the Postgraduates International Network (www.postgrad.org), which aims to encourage international cooperation between postgraduate student associations.

The NPC links are by no means exhaustive though, and it is worth searching on the web to find something relevant from the plethora of both national and local postgraduate websites emerging every week. Studying philosophy north of the border? Then try the Scottish Postgraduate Philosophy Association, an organisation which aims to serve the needs of philosophy postgraduates in Scotland, at: www.stand.ac.uk/~www_sppa/index.html.

Want to do an MBA course? Then check the website for the Association of MBAs at: www.mba.org.uk. The professional association for MBAs offers access to information on all aspects of MBA studies.

A new postgraduate disability web page meanwhile can be found at: www.student.city.ac.uk/~cx639 /pgdis.htm. It currently contains a disability legal brief applied to higher education from the student perspective. The government is currently developing new legislation in the area, and the site aims to provide information for students to play a proactive role in the development of new policies. It also contains a consultation document on the proposed working programme on the postgraduate disability issues in higher education.

For information on more formal matters such as grants and guidelines, the government's six research councils, which support masters degrees and PhDs across the sciences, all provide details on their websites. At www.esrc.ac.uk/postgrad.html, for example, the Economic and Social Research Council lists information on studentships in universities, advice for students on how to apply for studentships, postgraduate training guidelines, latest stipend levels and PhD submission rates.

The ESRC postgraduate training pages also include useful links to alternative sources of funding for postgrad students. Winston Churchill Travelling Fellowships, for example, offer support for individual projects undertaken overseas (www.wcmt.org.uk); Marie Curie Fellowships provide grants for young researchers to undertake research in another EU countries (www.dti.gov.uk/ost/ostbusiness/ihp/index.htm); Wingate Scholarships are awarded to individuals of great potential or proven excellence who need financial support to undertake creative or original work of intellectual, scientific, artistic, social or environmental value and to outstandingly talented musicians for advanced training (www.win-sch.demon.co.uk); Entente Cordiale Scholarships are awarded to outstanding British and French postgraduate students who wish to study in the arts, humanities and sciences (www.francealacarte.org.uk/entente).

The website for the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council meanwhile offers information on the research council's graduate schools programme, five-day workshops aimed at developing students' key skills. Details can be found at www.epsrc.ac.uk.

The Arts and Humanities Research Board supports three postgraduate schemes, studentships in the humanities, professional and vocational awards and awards for doctoral study in the creative and performing arts. All guides and details are available at www.ahrb.ac.uk/pshguide.html.

Users can also sample the committee's newsletter online, with discussions on every conceivable issue likely to arise during postgraduate study, from the development of robust postgraduate complaints procedures to the supervisor relationship for lesbian, gay and bisexual researchers. The NPC site is part of PI-Net, the Postgraduates International Network (www.postgrad.org), which aims to encourage international cooperation between postgraduate student associations. The NPC links are by no means exhaustive though, and it is worth searching on the web to find something relevant from the plethora of both national and local postgraduate websites emerging every week. Studying philosophy north of the border? Then try the Scottish Postgraduate Philosophy Association, an organisation which aims to serve the needs of philosophy postgraduates in Scotland, at: www.stand.ac.uk/~www_sppa/index.html. Want to do an MBA course? Then check the website for the Association of MBAs at: www.mba.org.uk. The professional association for MBAs offers access to information on all aspects of MBA studies. A new postgraduate disability web page meanwhile can be found at: www.student.city.ac.uk/~cx639 /pgdis.htm. It currently contains a disability legal brief applied to higher education from the student perspective. The government is currently developing new legislation in the area, and the site aims to provide information for students to play a proactive role in the development of new policies. It also contains a consultation document on the proposed working programme on the postgraduate disability issues in higher education. For information on more formal matters such as grants and guidelines, the government's six research councils, which support masters degrees and PhDs across the sciences, all provide details on their websites. At www.esrc.ac.uk/postgrad.html, for example, the Economic and Social Research Council lists information on studentships in universities, advice for students on how to apply for studentships, postgraduate training guidelines, latest stipend levels and PhD submission rates. The ESRC postgraduate training pages also include useful links to alternative sources of funding for postgrad students. Winston Churchill Travelling Fellowships, for example, offer support for individual projects undertaken overseas (www.wcmt.org.uk); Marie Curie Fellowships provide grants for young researchers to undertake research in another EU countries (www.dti.gov.uk/ost/ostbusiness/ihp/index.htm); Wingate Scholarships are awarded to individuals of great potential or proven excellence who need financial support to undertake creative or original work of intellectual, scientific, artistic, social or environmental value and to outstandingly talented musicians for advanced training (www.win-sch.demon.co.uk); Entente Cordiale Scholarships are awarded to outstanding British and French postgraduate students who wish to study in the arts, humanities and sciences (www.francealacarte.org.uk/entente). The website for the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council meanwhile offers information on the research council's graduate schools programme, five-day workshops aimed at developing students' key skills. Details can be found at www.epsrc.ac.uk. The Arts and Humanities Research Board supports three postgraduate schemes, studentships in the humanities, professional and vocational awards and awards for doctoral study in the creative and performing arts. All guides and details are available at www.ahrb.ac.uk/pshguide.html.

fields.headline: Masters lose status
fields.standfirst: Proposals are afoot to apply the masters title to postgraduate courses only. Lee Elliot Major reports
fields.trailText: Proposals are afoot to apply the masters title to postgraduate courses only. Lee Elliot Major reports
fields.body:
University quality watchdogs in the UK are threatening to kill off the MBA title as part of a drive to make the thousands of postgraduate degrees on offer to students clearer and more consistent. Proposals to apply the masters name to postgraduate courses, and not further specialised undergraduate study, could sound the death knell for the MBA, honorary MA, and Scottish MA titles.

MBA representatives, though, have argued that the proposals are misguided and would, in fact, lead to confusion over one of the most renowned brand names in the postgraduate market.

The recommendations to rename and reorganise postgraduate degrees come from the UK Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education which is attempting to tidy up a postgraduate sector, which many believe has grown out of control. A boom in postgraduate courses, particularly taught masters degrees, over the last decade has seen a plethora of qualifications introduced by universities. But while many degrees share similar titles, they can have very different aims and standards.

In its response to the QAA proposals, the National Postgraduate Committee, which represents postgraduate students, said: "We believe postgraduate qualifications must be clarified and reorganised to allow comparability and consistency within the higher education sector. We further believe it is essential that the issue of nomenclature is addressed and the sector accepts its responsibilities to provide clear, unambiguous information to students, employers and the wider public."

Last year, the proposed reforms hit the headlines as they set the agency on a collision course with Oxford and Cambridge universities, which award honorary masters degrees to undergraduate students who have only finished their first degrees. There would be no place for such awards under the new postgraduate framework. But if ratified by universities and the government, the proposals would also mean specialist masters courses, such as the Masters in Business Administration, would also lose their masters status.

Already the proposals to restrict the masters title to postgraduate level courses only have received the backing from postgraduate representatives. "We hope that the QAA will not shy away from the more contentious issues that this principle implies such as Scottish MA qualifications, DPhils and honorary MAs from Oxford and Cambridge and anomalous qualifications such as MEng or MBA which are essentially undergraduate level courses," said the NPC. "If the new framework is to command respect and be consistent then the titles of qualifications such as those mentioned must be changed to reflect the true nature of the qualification both in terms of level and credit."

The proposals, though, have received short shrift from the official accreditation body for MBAs, the Association of MBAs.

"Any change to the use of academic titles should be aimed at dispelling obfuscation, in the minds of the public, as to the nature of an individual programme of study," said Peter Callidine, the association's educational services manager. "The content of the MBA curriculum, and the new-found skills of MBA graduates, are known quantities for the end users, the MBA graduate and his/ her employer. To change the title would cause unnecessary confusion."

Callidine said that over 17,000 new students enrolled on MBA programmes from UK universities in 1998, making it the most popular postgraduate qualification. The MBA is a huge revenue earner for British universities, probably bringing in over £200m per year. "Even if the MBA title ceased to exist in the UK, the demand would not. Overseas students in particular would still recognise the MBA qualification, but they would have to study at a non-UK institution. More British students would study outside the UK. A Pyrrhic victory for the QAA, indeed."

The association believes that arguments suggesting that MBAs are masquerading behind an inflated title are ill-founded. The MBA is seen as a vocational degree and both a post-experience and postgraduate qualification. As part of its accreditation criteria, the association stresses that students should have a minimum of two years' work experience. "It is specious to argue that this quality of learning is not, somehow, equal to that offered at masters level in, say, a humanities subject," argued Callidine.

The QAA is expected to publish its final proposals later in the year.

 Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight

fields.headline: How to be a postgraduate
fields.standfirst: Embarking on a course of higher education should involve a lot of careful thought and research. Jeremy Hoad offers some advice for would-be postgraduates
fields.trailText: Embarking on a course of higher education should involve a lot of careful thought and research. Jeremy Hoad offers some advice for would-be postgraduates
fields.body:
Postgraduates are about as easy to define as collecting steam in a bucket. Courses can be vocational, for training purposes, as pure research, as a training for research or a combination of these. Also you can choose between full-time and part-time. Increasingly the approach to postgraduate study is becoming modular. The vast majority of postgraduates are doing short taught courses many of which provide specific vocational training.

There has been a 400% increase in postgraduate numbers in the UK over the last 20 years. Current figures stand at just under 400,000 with a high proportion studying part time.

People undertake postgraduate study for many reasons. These may be academic (intellectual challenge, development of knowledge), vocational (training for a specific career goal) or only vague (drifting into further study). It is absolutely essential that you determine the reasons you want to become a postgraduate. If you have clear goals and reasons for studying, this will enhance your learning experience and help you to remain focused and motivated throughout your course.

Where you study should be based upon much more than the course you want to do. For some courses you are likely to be there for several years and it is important that you will be happy living there. Check also what type of accommodation is available and whether the institution provides any specifically for postgraduates.

Choosing an institution and department is a difficult process. To determine quality, do not rely on the reputation of an institution but find out what the ratings are from the most recent assessment exercises (Research Assessment Exercise, Teaching Quality Assessment, Audit of the Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education). Find out about the staff, their reputation, competence, enthusiasm and friendliness.

For research students it is absolutely essential to determine the quality of supervision you are likely to receive as this working relationship will be a major part of your life for several years. Visit the department if possible and talk to existing postgraduates about their experience, satisfaction, comments and complaints. Also check what facilities are available, both at an institutional level (eg libraries, laboratory and computing facilities) and in the department (eg study room, desk, photocopying, secretarial support etc). Your working environment and the support available to you plays an essential part in making your work as a postgraduate a positive experience.

Life as a postgraduate can be very different to your other experiences of education. Things that can distinguish your experience are the level of study, independence of working, intensity of the course, the demands on your time, your role within the institution and often simply the fact that you are older than the majority of students.

These factors can contribute to making you feel isolated. However, there are several ways you can make sure that this is either short-lived or does not happen at all.

Many student unions have postgraduate societies which organise social events and may also provide representation for postgraduates to both the student union and the institution. Graduate schools are also becoming more common and provide a focus for postgraduates. These vary enormously in what they set out to do and may be institution-wide or specific to particular subjects, so it's a good idea to check what is available.

Departments can also help to create a sense of identity and community and often have discussion groups available. Don't be afraid to talk to staff about any difficulties you may be having. Better still, talk to other postgraduates who may have faced similar difficulties. You will not be alone if you have difficulties in adjusting to life as a postgraduate but make the most of the opportunities available and you will find both your experience as a postgraduate one of the most rewarding experiences of education you have ever had.

Financial planning is essential since the government excludes postgraduates from student loans and it can be difficult to maintain your student status with banks. This has implications for free banking and overdraft facilities. Do not underestimate your living costs including food, accommodation and travel and be careful not to budget for everything except a social life. If you do get into financial difficulty you may qualify for Access Funds which are to alleviate student hardship although the amounts of money available are small and you must be a full-time student to qualify for them.

Funding a course is one of the most challenging things people face when considering postgraduate study. Most postgraduate students are self-financing. They pay (often very large) fees to the institution and receive no maintenance income to support their study. Make sure you know exactly what your costs will be as institutions often hide extra fees for laboratory costs or department research costs behind the headline fee rate advertised (£2,740 for 2000-2001).

Funding can come from various sources. Research councils, charities, trust funds, institutional scholarships, local education authorities and professional bodies and organisations all offer various levels of funding. Ask about funding when contacting departments and check with a university careers service for information. Career development loans are also available from high street banks. The best advice on funding is to be proactive, persistent and patient.

Because of the funding and financial pressures facing postgraduate students it is often realistic (or essential) to work while you are studying. If you do this be sensible about balancing this work with the demands of your course.

An obvious opportunity for work is teaching while studying. However, teaching should not be undertaken lightly. It can be very time-consuming and sometimes stressful. Nevertheless, it can help you with your study both financially and intellectually and in a good session the satisfaction you get can seldom be bettered.

The postgraduate community in the UK is multinational, has a wide range of experience of life and work and an exciting mix of goals, both career and academic. Being a postgraduate student should be a productive and fulfilling thing to do and you will become part of a diverse, motivated and sociable group.

 Jeremy Hoad is general secretary of the National Postgraduate Committee

fields.headline: Saddam plays politics with suffering
fields.standfirst: Peter Hain MP, minister of state at the foreign office, argues in support of the sanctions on Iraq
fields.trailText: Of course sanctions are not a neat solution. The truth is that the critics have no alternative except one which would leave Saddam free to do as he likes. That is a risk we cannot take, argues Peter Hain MP, minister of state at the foreign office
fields.body:
Many people are angry about the suffering of the Iraqi people. So am I. That is why we negotiated a new UN Security Council resolution to help their plight. Unfortunately, our critics have a blind spot about the culprit. Saddam Hussein plunged into war with Iran causing more than a million deaths, slaughtered thousands of his own people for "disloyalty" and invaded Kuwait. Because of the resolute action of the international community - liberating Kuwait, sanctions and the disarmament programme - Saddam has been unable to threaten his neighbours in the 10 years since. The lesson is clear.

No one (with one exception) could be immune to the suffering of the Iraqi people. We have done our best to relieve it. There is no limit on Iraqi oil sales to pay for "oil for food". Iraq is the world's second-biggest oil producer so more than $8bn a year is available for foods, medicines, clean water, electricity and educational material. There is no block on Iraq ordering them.

"Oil for food" has been working for three years and could have operated since 1991 had Saddam not blocked it. The Iraqi people have never seen the full benefits. Recently, the UN recommended that Iraq set aside $91m for nutrition. The Iraqi regime allocated only $24m. John Pilger's documentary on Carlton TV on 6 March showed harrowing pictures of Iraqi children in a cancer ward. The doctors said they could not get the drugs they need. This is a scandal. The fault lies with the Iraqi government. They fail to order enough medicines and fail to distribute them properly. Around 25% of medicines imported into Iraq lie in warehouses waiting for the government to ship them to the hospitals where they are needed.

Why? Because Saddam plays politics with suffering. He believes that TV pictures of malnourished Iraqi children serve his interests so he makes sure there are plenty of malnourished children to film. In northern Iraq, where Saddam's writ does not run, the situation is much better.

What is the alternative that John Pilger, George Galloway and others advocate? Abandon sanctions. Trust Saddam to improve conditions for the people. Cross our fingers as he smuggles in a new stock of weapons. And wish the best of luck to the Kurds, the Shia and his neighbours.

Of course sanctions are not a neat solution. I remember apologists for apartheid arguing that sanctions hit black South Africans. Did that make them wrong? Like the Iraqi opponents of Saddam, they supported sanctions despite the cost to themselves. The truth is that the critics have no alternative except one which would leave Saddam free to do as he likes. That is a risk we cannot take.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Toy Story 2 stays on top, Thai protestors take it out on Leo, and, on the casting couch, Cate Blanchett, Eddie Murphy and Mike Myers's latest crazy cinematic comings and goings
fields.body:
Toy Story 2 continues to break box office records, and has remained the UK's most popular movie for the fourth week in a row. Buzz Lightyear and Woody's antics this weekend earned Disney £2.8m (a substantial drop from last week's school holiday high); the movie already taken nearly $60m (£37.5m) in the UK alone, and looks set to be the year's highest grossing movie.

It never rains but it pours on The Beach. As if plunging out of the US top 10 after just two weeks wasn't enough, Fox's much-hyped backpacker saga now finds itself under renewed attack from those pesky Thai environmentalists. Protesters are planning to burn an effigy of star Leonardo DiCaprio at tonight's Bangkok premiere to highlight what they claim to be the production's destruction of protected Maya Beach on Phi Phi Island. DiCaprio, needless to say, will not be attending the premiere.

Casting couch

Eddie Murphy has agreed to star in a remake of 1957's The Incredible Shrinking Man, directed by Peter Segal, who has just finished working with Murphy on The Nutty Professor 2.

Following the success of Austin Powers, Mike Myers is to recreate another of his Saturday Night Live characters for the big screen. Myers is to play Dieter - an avant-garde German talk show host with a passion for asking guests to touch his monkey - in Sprockets. Myers' decision is bad news for fans who were hoping to see him involved in the mooted Scooby Doo adaptation.

Cate Blanchett is in talks to star in Taking Lives, an adaptation of Michael Pye's novel about a female FBI profiler tracking a serial killer who assumes his victims' identities.

webTitle: What the US media is saying

fields.headline: What the US media is saying
fields.trailText: Mr McCain is running ads in California, Ohio and New York, touting the Arizona senator as "a Republican like Ronald Reagan" who gives the party its best chance to win in November. "I'm going to beat Al Gore like a drum," Mr McCain says in the ads.
fields.body:
Mr McCain is running ads in California, Ohio and New York, touting the Arizona senator as "a Republican like Ronald Reagan" who gives the party its best chance to win in November. "I'm going to beat Al Gore like a drum," Mr McCain says in the ads.

But Mr Bush sounds increasingly confident. He has begun a daily countdown on his campaign website. Yesterday it said there are 319 days "until the end of the Clinton-Gore era."
The Washington Times

All eyes - at least those watching early - were on the presidential contest. Officials from both major political parties, unaccustomed to primaries that matter, were out-crowing one another at the possibilities for their own advancement. The secretary of state's office, which each election cycle is called upon to parse why Californians don't vote, crossed its fingers and hoped for a big turnout.

"P.T. Barnum said it best," noted Bob Mulholland, the eminence grise of the state Democratic party. "If you want to build a crowd, start a fight."
LA Times

"For all its flaws, I believe our nation is chosen by God and commissioned by history to be the model to the world of justice and inclusion and diversity without division," Mr Bush said in brief remarks at the Simon Wiesenthal Centre and the Museum of Tolerance here. "These are American convictions. Defending them is America's calling, and they must be passed intact to America's children."

A heckler twice interrupted Mr Bush's speech by calling, "What about gay people?" and Mr Bush made no response. But in an interview published in The San Francisco Chronicle today, Mr Bush softened his previous opposition to a meeting with the Log Cabin Republicans, a national gay group. Last fall, Mr Bush said he would probably not meet with the group because, "I don't believe in group thought, pitting one group of people against another, and all that does is create kind of a huge political, you know, nightmare for people."
New York Times

Nierenberg, a third-generation Democratic activist, has been going to party rallies since she was a child. As the sun struggles to break through the clouds, literally and metaphorically, Nierenberg cheerfully plies the craft of persuasion, without illusions. Faced with Bradley's likely defeat, she's in a rebellious mood.

"This may be the last election that I'm a Democrat," she says, protesting the ease with which Al Gore and George W. Bush "locked up the support of the party machinery." Her seditious conclusion: "People are disgusted with entrenched parties. It's harder and harder to tell the parties apart."

What's different this year is that hundreds of thousands of Democrats and independents have put this thought into action. They've crossed into Republican primaries to vote for McCain. Though rank-and-file Republicans resisted the invasion by moving in large numbers to Bush, the spirit of rebellion will not easily dissipate.
The Seattle Times

McCain's success in winning the votes of Democrats and independents in open primaries in New Hampshire, Michigan and elsewhere bodes ill for the Democratic Party. Even if Al Gore were to win the presidency, the prospects of a new Democratic majority look much weaker, thanks to McCain's campaign.

Here's why: American politics is tribal majorities of Yankees and Southerners can never be in the same party. They hate each other so much that they fought a civil war. From the administration of President Washington to the administration of President Clinton, the Yankees have been in the party that was the rival of the one that had most of the Southrons, and vice versa. If a Yankee comes into a room, the Southron will leave.
Salon

In the NBA what they call "garbage time" comes late in the fourth quarter of lopsided games, when scrubs are sent into the game so the starters can rest their aching knees for the next game. But in a political campaign there is no substitution, so Bill Bradley, who must by now be one large ache, has to play out the clock, which probably will run out Tuesday.

Since he was in high school, people have been saying he would be president. He will not be in 2001, and this year may have lost for reasons that suggest a second attempt would be futile. Having failed with his full-court press in Washington state, Bradley faces a continentwide crushing on Tuesday.
Capital Hill Blue

Don't the presidential candidates give you the feeling that you've seen it all before? It's not because of their endless debates, or their lousy TV commercials, or their continual name-calling. These guys themselves strike a distant chord of recognition because they've been around for eons. Not since the Clinton sex scandals, which was an all-Greek frolic (see "The Sex God"), have so many public figures corresponded so closely to figures from mythology.
Slate

fields.headline: Super Tuesday explained
fields.trailText: What is Super Tuesday?
fields.body:
What is Super Tuesday?

It is the biggest vote so far in the race for the White House. Since February 1, the would-be presidential candidates, both Republican and Democrat, have been fighting it out for their party's nomination in individual or small batches of states sometimes with a tiny electorate. On Super Tuesday more than a dozen states vote on the same day.

Why Super and why Tuesday?

It's always held on a Tuesday. Journalists tried mega and titanic to underline its significance, but super was the tag that stuck. It was a creation of the southern states of America, which decided in 1988 to lump all their primaries on to the same day in March, because they felt northern states, like tiny New Hampshire which votes first, were having a disproportionate influence on the presidential race. Super Tuesday gave the south has its own marker, and now polls are held on that day in states in almost every region of the country.

Why is it so important?

The sheer scale of voting means today is make-or-break for the presidential hopefuls. Around 39 per cent of the national electorate votes on Super Tuesday. More than half of all the delegates needed to win the Democrat and Republican nominations are up for grabs. For the Democratic contenders, Al Gore and Bill Bradley, that means 1,315 of 2,170 delegates in 15 states. For Republicans George W Bush and John McCain, 605 of 1,034 delegates in 13 states.

Which are the states to watch?

The states with the biggest populations - California, New York and Ohio.

What is the betting on the winners?

Barring a miracle, Bradley is likely to be out of the running after today. Gore has been consistently outscoring him in the opinion polls and is likely to sweep the board. Bradley has had a haunted look about him of late. He has taken to addressing schoolchildren, pleading with them to go home and tell their parents to vote for him. The Republican race is tighter. Although Bush leads in the number of delegates he has under his belt, McCain has not given up, hoping the Super Tuesday states will buy his alternative message.

What happens next?

The Democrat battle will almost certainly be over. The focus will then be on the Republicans. The candidate coming out of Super Tuesday best will be hoping to use the momentum of victory to spur him on in the closing stages. The final primaries will be held on June 6 in Alabama, Montana, New Jersey, New Mexico and South Dakota. The Republicans then hold their national convention between July 31 and August 3, the Democrats between August 14 and 17. Election day is on November 7, 2000.

webTitle: Two umpires with one thing in common

fields.headline: Two umpires with one thing in common
fields.trailText: The second Test between Pakistan and Sri Lanka at Peshawar is being umpired by two former Test players - John Hampshire (eight Tests for England as a middle-order batsman) and Mohammad Nazir (14 Tests for Pakistan as an offspinner).
fields.body:
The second Test between Pakistan and Sri Lanka at Peshawar is being umpired by two former Test players - John Hampshire (eight Tests for England as a middle-order batsman) and Mohammad Nazir (14 Tests for Pakistan as an offspinner).

It's rare enough for two former Test players to stand in the same game - although Peter Willey (26 Tests for England) and, notoriously, Javed Akhtar (one for Pakistan) joined forces at Headingley in 1998 for the series decider between England and South Africa, and met again later that year at Rawalpindi for the first Test between Pakistan and Australia.

But what is more remarkable is that both Hampshire and Nazir enjoyed outstanding Test debuts in the same year - 1969. Hampshire hit 109 against West Indies at Lord's in June, while Nazir took 7-99 against New Zealand at Karachi in October.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: 'Death on the Nile' poisoner jailed for life

fields.headline: 'Death on the Nile' poisoner jailed for life
fields.trailText:
An industrial chemist was jailed for life today after being found guilty of poisoning 
his wealthy solicitor girlfriend with cyanide while they enjoyed a luxury holiday in Egypt.
fields.body:
An industrial chemist was jailed for life today after being found guilty of poisoning his wealthy solicitor girlfriend with cyanide while they enjoyed a luxury holiday in Egypt.

John Allan, 48, of Birkenhead, Wirral, killed 43-year-old Cheryl Lewis with a dose of cyanide in an attempt to inherit her £400,000 fortune.

Her death was initially a mystery to police and Ms Lewis' family but Allan was ultimately caught out by a series of lies and a forged will.

After the jury of five men and five women returned their majority verdict at the end of a seven-week trial at Liverpool crown court, police revealed that they feared Allan might have killed again had he not been arrested.

It is thought that within weeks of killing Ms Lewis he had already lined up his second victim -a new girlfriend - whom he tried to poison.

Earlier the court had heard how Allan murdered Ms Lewis in October 1998 by slipping the poison into her gin and tonic nightcap as they prepared to go to bed in the New Winter Palace in Luxor. As she lay sweating and barely breathing Alan asked for a doctor to be called, saying: "I think she's dying."

A US tourist asked him to try to save her with mouth to mouth resuscitation, but he refused, apparently fearing fumes from the poison. Allan had forged Ms Lewis' 1993 will, leaving himself as the sole beneficiary. He blamed drug dealers, arms runners or diamond smugglers for her killing, linking it with his own invented past as a mercenary, Secret Service agent and diamond dealer.

After his arrest, police found four briquettes of sodium cyanide, one with an amount carved off, stowed in Ms Lewis's car, which he had continued to drive after her death.

The judge, Mrs Justice Smith, told Allan: " This was a cruel and pre-meditated killing.

"In the privacy of your hotel room you abused the trust and confidence which Cheryl Lewis placed in you as her partner and in my view you tricked her into taking cyanide.

"You must then have watched her suffer until she was beyond making a complaint."

The judge said she would recommend to the home secretary that Allan should stay in prison "for a very long time".

Outside court Ms Lewis' father, Eric Lewis, said: "All we as a family wanted was justice for Cheryl and thank God justice prevailed.

"As we all know Allan was a self-confessed liar, forger and an evil man and of course he has been found guilty of committing the ultimate crime.

The jury had taken more than 17 hours to reach its verdict since first retiring last Thursday.

As Allan was led away to begin his sentence, police said they were convinced his arrest and conviction had prevented a potential serial killer from carrying out more murders.

Within weeks of killing Ms Lewis, with whom he had a relationship for seven years, Allan had befriended one of her golfing partners, 53-year-old Jennifer Hughes and, police believe, had already given her a dose of cyanide causing her to fall ill.

Detective Superintendent Dave Smith, who led the investigation, said after the case: "I feel the sentence makes the community a great deal safer. He is a very dangerous man.

"We believe Jennifer Hughes was the next victim."

webTitle: Lebanon: what the regional press is saying

fields.headline: Lebanon: what the regional press is saying
fields.trailText:
Syria should now understand that Israel's commitment to withdraw from Lebanon, with or without an agreement on the Golan, has graduated from a frayed campaign promise to a broad-based government decision.
Jerusalem Post, Israeli daily
fields.body:
Syria should now understand that Israel's commitment to withdraw from Lebanon, with or without an agreement on the Golan, has graduated from a frayed campaign promise to a broad-based government decision.
Jerusalem Post, Israeli daily

The public has realized that the losses wrought by the invasion of certain parts of Lebanon are far larger than any possible gains Israel may reap.
Ha'aretz, Israeli daily

As fighting between Israel and Hizballah (sic) in the South Lebanon security zone heated up in February, Israeli media broadcast unprecedentedly graphic TV footage of wounded soldiers being evacuated after an attack and radio interviews with soldiers giving vent to reservations about their service in the zone. Does such coverage help or harm Israeli interests?
Jerusalem Report, Israeli news magazine

How, in God's name, could we express solidarity with a beleaguered Lebanon without supporting the lawful resistance mounted against Israeli forces of occupation there?
Al Akhbar, Egyptian daily

fields.headline: The agony of south Lebanon
fields.standfirst: Former Guardian middle East correspondent Derek Brown on the background to today's violence in Lebanon
fields.trailText: Former Guardian middle East correspondent Derek Brown on the background to today's violence in Lebanon.
fields.body:
Two South Lebanon Army militiamen were killed this morning, in a grim foretaste of what many fear will become an orgy of revenge when Israel ends its occupation of the region this summer.

The SLA was formed in the early 1980s by renegade Christian officers of the Lebanese army. It quickly became a client militia of the Israeli army, which invaded in 1982 and established a so-called security zone in south Lebanon.

In reality, the 440 square mile zone - about a tenth of Lebanon's territory - is occupied territory; a battleground over which the Israelis and their allies have fought a bitter and bloody war against Islamist guerillas. The most determined and successful of the latter is Hezbollah, a Shia group backed by Iran.

For more than 15 years, the Israeli Defence Force (IDF) has held the inhospitable scrubland of south Lebanon, ostensibly as a buffer zone to protect the towns and farms of northern Israel. The strategy has been a palpable failure. At regular intervals, Hezbollah units operating within the zone have launched Katyusha rockets at Kiryat Shmona and other northern Israeli settlements. Each time the Israelis respond with devastating air and artillery attacks deep into Lebanon, driving more young men to join the guerrillas.

Though the occupation is seen in Kiryat Shmona as a vital defence against Hezbollah, it is hugely unpopular in the rest of Israel. For more than 15 years a largely conscript army has been exposed to attack by the most ruthless guerillas in the region, losing some 20-25 men each year. The SLA has taken far greater casualties, and Hezbollah even more, but in Israel, naturally, it is the IDF body count which matters.

One of Ehud Barak's most potent election promises was to pull the IDF out of Lebanon. On Sunday, that pledge was endorsed by a unanimous cabinet vote.

Crucially, the Israelis are no longer making withdrawal dependent on a prior peace agreement with Syria, the dominant political and military power in Lebanon. Unless there is a dramatic change in the situation, the IDF pull-out should be complete by the end of July.

That will leave the 2500-strong SLA exposed to revenge attacks by Hezbollah, and possibly to prosecution by the Lebanese government, which regards the militiamen as traitors. For many months there has been a steady stream of desertions from the renegade 'army'. Many Israelis believe that the recent spate of successful attacks on SLA posts and patrols owes much to information passed on by deserters anxious to curry favour.

Israel has vaguely suggested that SLA fighters will be protected after the withdrawal, but has not said how. The country's supreme court this week turned down an application for political asylum by a group of militiamen.

In the beginning, most SLA men were recruited by the promise of effective protection against Islamist forces during Lebanon's savage civil war. More recent recruits - including many Muslims - have been lured by the promise of regular wages. Other privileges include permits for family members to cross the border each day to work in the factories and on the farms of northern Israel. All that is about to end forever.
