fields.headline: Immoral, ineffective and counterproductive
fields.standfirst: The sanctions against Iraq must now be lifted, says Victoria Brittain
fields.trailText: The sanctions against Iraq must now be lifted, says Victoria Brittain
fields.body:
The UN economic sanctions programme against Iraq is immoral, ineffective and counterproductive. After nearly a decade in which half a million children have been killed by sanctions it is time for Britain and the US, the only supporters of the UN programme, to admit this and lift the sanctions.

Three senior UN officials have resigned rather than continue to work for a programme which one of them, Denis Halliday, former coordinator of humanitarian relief to Iraq, describes as a genocide which has killed more than a million people.

Sanctions have not hit the Iraqi leadership. They were supposedly intended to shift Saddam Hussein from power, but in fact have so ground down the society in its isolation that he is actually less contested today than at the end of the Gulf war. The US and Britain, meanwhile, have made themselves into the enemies of the Iraqi people and the Arab world in general. There will be a future price to pay for this.

Under the UN's oil for food programme which allows Iraq to sell a proportion of its oil to meet humanitarian needs, 30% of the receipts go for reparations, mainly to Kuwait, and around 10% to the UN for the costs of administering the programme. According to the UN's own officials Britain and the US are the dominant players in the sanctions committee in New York, where vital chemotherapy drugs, painkillers, chlorine and equipment for rehabilitation of the infrastructure are blocked or delayed over and over again.

Iraq gets less than 60% of the revenue from all oil sales under the deal. Even if every cent were spent on food and medicines, expenditure would not even approach the pre-1990 level. And anyway, to spend all the available money on food would be unrealistic when the country has such a devastated physical and educational infrastructure that power and sewage plants may be more essential to health than actual medicines.

The gruelling sanctions programme is backed by almost daily bombing by the US and Britain. This is to intimidate the regime into allowing back UN weapons inspectors. Even Scott Ritter, famously the American hard man of the last UN weapons inspection team, says now that Iraq has no capacity to manufacture weapons of mass destruction. It is absurd to pretend that Iraq is a threat to its neighbours when it is on its hands and knees - while Saudi Arabia, Iran and Israel are all armed to the teeth with weapons of mass destruction.

It is absurd to pretend that Iraq is a threat to its neighbours when it is on its hands and knees - while Saudi Arabia, Iran and Israel are all armed to the teeth with weapons of mass destruction.

fields.headline: Tony Blair's full speech
fields.standfirst:
'The e-generation is with us,' Tony Blair proclaimed at the Knowledge 2000 conference
Blair wants internet access for all
The issue explained: free internet access
fields.trailText: Today's conference is an important initiative. Not just because it is government, business and employees   coming together in partnership to look at a key economic issue. But because of what we're here to look at -   the new, knowledge-based economy, and its importance to Britain's future.
fields.body:
Today's conference is an important initiative. Not just because it is government, business and employees coming together in partnership to look at a key economic issue. But because of what we're here to look at - the new, knowledge-based economy, and its importance to Britain's future.

I strongly believe that the knowledge economy is our best route for success and prosperity.

But we must be careful not to make a fundamental mistake. We mustn't think that because the knowledge economy is the future, it will happen only in the future. The new knowledge economy is here, and it is now.

This new, knowledge-driven economy is a major change. I believe it is the equivalent of the machine-driven economy of the industrial revolution.

But our job is to help people with that change. Not to resist it, and so suffocate opportunity. But not just to let change happen, regardless of the consequence. Our approach, what I call the Third Way, is to manage that process of change to extend opportunity and prosperity for all. To find a way which provides for efficiency in the knowledge economy, and ensuring that everyone feels its benefit. Enterprise and fairness. That is our goal.

For some people, the advent of the new economy may be a matter of nervousness - even fear. Whole countries may be staring at the prospect of being outpaced, and left behind.

For Britain, the new economy is unquestionably a challenge. But it is a challenge we are now better equipped to face with confidence because of the tough decisions we have already taken to secure a sound economic base - an economy based on a platform of stability, and steady growth.

Because macroeconomic stability is the first key element of the new economy. Without stability in the economy, businesses - particularly businesses in rapidly-moving areas like E-commerce - can't plan and can't invest and can't grow. Stability is not an optional extra. It is central to the new economy.

The second element is the revolution in technology - and especially information technology. Britain has long been a pioneer in advanced forefront of technology and scientific development. But science and technology is advancing faster than ever before. For business the key to success is how fast they can adopt and adapt these new technologies.

IT and communications are vital parts of this. Businesses based on or using IT are at the cutting edge of the new economy. E-commerce and the Internet are already changing business fast. Transaction costs are tumbling. One US bank estimates that the effect of e-commerce is to reduce its cost per transaction from $1 to 1 cent. Astonishing.

The Internet is dissolving physical barriers, and levelling the business playing field. It doesn't matter how small a company you are. You have the choice now of defining your business as global. Standard business thinking used to see big as inevitably beating small. Now fast beats slow. The opportunity is there for business to take.

E-mail and the Internet may still be a closed world to some people. But especially for the new band of young e-entrepreneurs, and indeed for many young people generally, the Internet is a normal part of life. The e-generation is with us.

Unleashing the full potential of people - our most valuable resource - is the third element of the new, modern economy. In one respect, that means reforming welfare, making work pay, establishing the work ethic for the whole of society. Tackling exclusion. In another, it means an endless emphasis on education, and on skills - a ceaseless focus on driving up standards in order to ensure that opportunity for all is real.

I want Britain to be at the forefront of the knowledge economy. Europe too.

Britain was the first industrial power. Our role as the workshop of the world stemmed from our character as a creative and hard-working people. The combination of adventure and application was a potent mix for Britain. And it still is.

For businesses, the challenge they face is widening the reach of the new economy.

Many of the British companies already involved in E-commerce are eagerly embracing the opportunities the new economy holds out. But we know we have a good way to go. The new knowledge-driven economy is not just about the new, high-tech industries like biotechnology or software development - companies which have built directly on the UK's university and science base. The new economy isn't either just the new technologies like IT and the Internet.

It is instead about new sources of competitive advantage. The ability to innovate. To create new products. To exploit new markets. Using whatever means which are appropriate, including IT and E-commerce. And that applies to all businesses, in all sectors. High-tech and low-tech. Manufacturing and services. Businesses in long-established sectors can find ways of using these new approaches to refresh and revitalise their operations. The knowledge economy can become an indivisible part of the way all businesses work.

For individuals, the opportunities and benefits the new economy offers must not be the sole domain of elite knowledge workers.

Learning is the key to individuals succeeding in the new economy. At school, in further education, throughout people's working lives. The key capability for people to survive and thrive in the new economy is their capacity to learn, and then to apply that learning.

So we have to make sure that the new economy is not just for a privileged few - for the relatively small number of companies working in the world of E-commerce, for example, and for the relatively tightly-drawn social grouping which tends to use the Internet today.

Looking just at the Internet, currently half the people in Britain who are online come from the very top social groups. Almost forty per cent are in a single age band of 15-24. We have to make sure people are not excluded from this revolutionary technology.

Over the last few days, we have seen a number of important announcements about how people can best use the Internet. My point is this: this technology is revolutionising the way we work, the way we do business - the way we live our lives. Our job is to make sure it is not the preserve of an elite - but an Internet for the people.

We have to democratise the new economy. We must ensure that it is open to all.

But it's not only Britain which needs to embrace the new economy fully. Europe needs to as well.

We're privileged to have Antonio Guterres with us here today. He will address you shortly. He and I and other European leaders will be meeting in Lisbon in a few weeks' time for a European Council.

A decade ago, a European Council on economic and social policy would have been all about regulation. Now, there is a transformation.

We are meeting in Lisbon with a clear strategic goal in mind: to make the European Union the most dynamic and competitive area in the world.

We want to see a Europe of full employment in modern labour market conditions. A Europe based on an innovative and knowledge-driven economy. We want a Europe with macro-economic policies which will give sustainable growth. We want to ensure people have the skills they need. And we want to see a reformed economy which will promote competitiveness.

I know this is a challenging agenda. But I know if we can achieve it, the Lisbon summit should come to be seen as a landmark in modern economic and social policies for Europe for the next decade. The prize is great: better growth, better employment and better social cohesion.

We want to see as well the remaining barriers to e-commerce removed. We want to see fast and cheap access to the Internet. Britain is now leading Europe in the new Internet economy. Looking at E-commerce trading, we are ahead of Germany and ahead of France. Four times the European average.

Over one in six homes in Britain now have access to the Internet. A quarter of our businesses are online.

Other areas, like Scandinavia, have seen remarkable growth too in communications technology and e-business. But Britain is undoubtedly doing well in the European E-league.

But that is no reason for complacency. With a technological revolution on this scale, we have to try harder. We have to maintain and enhance our performance.

That's why I've set the goal of Britain being the best place for e-commerce by 2002.

We already have a bold programme for Internet access:

 We will connect all our libraries and schools to the Internet by 2002  We will have 1000 IT learning centres open by next year  We are leasing inexpensive refurbished computers to 100,000 of our poorest families  We are giving through learning accounts an 80% discount on the cost of basic IT courses

But we want to do more. Because, the one clear lesson of the Internet is you can't stand still.

We will get costs down, through competition. When we published our strategy for e-commerce in the autumn, we were told the key barrier was the cost of Internet calls. Americans used the Internet for longer, mainly because most of them don't pay a per-minute charge.

Gordon Brown has challenged the industry to get internet access prices down. Ministers have been working with Oftel and the telecommunications industry to overcome that barrier.

And we're seeing change. New proposals for unmetered access have been announced by two major companies - BT and Telewest. As we've seen this week, Altavista is now offering Internet access on the basis of relatively low subscriptions.

I'm pleased to see this progress. Our goal must be to see prices comparable with anywhere in the world - including the USA.

And today there is a new and further step forward. Another major cable company, NTL, is announcing a new offer - the chance for their customers to use the Internet entirely for free.

I'm sure that others, including BT, are now ready to break new ground themselves.

Obviously, I am not endorsing any of these companies' products. Different products will suit different customers. But the key point is that we are pursuing policies to get prices down. Giving people a choice. Putting consumers first.

And I'm delighted to say this. The Americans have been predicting entirely free Internet access for a while. But Britain has got there first.

Today I want to raise our aspirations again.

Today I want to announce a new goal. I want Britain to aim for universal access to the Internet by 2005.

Making sure everyone has access to the Internet will both improve our competitiveness and reduce social exclusion. Policies of enterprise and fairness - working together.

I am today publishing a report by the management consultants Booz Allen which explains the case for this policy. But there is no one-technology solution to deliver it.

Some people will access the Internet, as now, through a PC. Others through a mobile phone or digital television. Some will do so at work, others at home. For those who can't afford any of these technologies, we will ensure there is a nearby public access point.

Universal Internet access is vital if we are not only to avoid social divisions over the new economy but to create a knowledge economy of the future which is for everyone. Because it's likely that the internet will be as ubiquitous and as normal as electricity is today. We cannot accept a digital divide. For business. Or for individuals.

Knowledge and skills, creativity and innovation, adaptability and entrepreneurship are the ways by which the winners will win in the new economy. We all have a responsibility to ensure that we are all equipped to succeed in it. That way we can all prosper. All our people. And all our businesses. For the benefit of Britain.

webTitle: 'The enticing goods today are at Livingstone's'

fields.headline: 'The enticing goods today are at Livingstone's'
fields.standfirst: Guardian columnist David McKie on the electoral mountain facing Frank Dobson
fields.trailText: Guardian columnist David McKie on the electoral mountain facing Frank Dobson
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has a 55 per cent lead over the official Labour contender Frank Dobson in the race for the London mayoralty, according to an ICM poll for the Guardian taken on the day when he committed himself to stand. Two immediate questions sugbgest themselves: Can Livingstone keep this astonishing lead right through till the poll in May? And can anyone else stop him winning? The answer to both is the same: almost certainly not.

It is no use looking for precedents. All previous records are largely irrelevant to what is happening in London. That's for two reasons. First, this is a new kind of contest: it is not like a local election and not like a general election. Indeed, there is something more of a race for a presidency in it than either of those. Personality will count for more and party labels for less than in any conventional contest. Second, the nature of the electorate in Britain has anyway changed, as the 1997 general election showed beyond doubt. Old ideological alignments, old largely unthinking party allegiances, are more and more being binned. Going out to vote is like going out shopping: people choose the store with the most enticing goods on its shelves, even if it is one they have not shopped at before - or even crossed the road in times past to avoid.

The enticing goods today are at Livingstone's. It's a new independent outfit with plenty of colour and plenty of swagger. It offers novelty, excitement, fun - not a claim you could make for Dobson's across the road. It doesn't have the kind of promotional machine which official Labour has at Millbank: but given the free TV time and headline appeal it commands, Livingstone should not need that. He is selling direct, not through intermediaries. So why expect Ken's lead to come down? Mainly because there seems to be in it an element of novelty, of fashion, a tinge of hysteria even, almost as if he were some kind of tamagotchi.

This morning's poll shows an extraordinary 11 per cent swing to Ken since the previous one. What goes up that fast can come down just as fast and probably will. But when all the reservations are made, it is hard to see a lead as mighty as this evaporating in eight weeks. Livingstone has too much momentum: no one else in the field has any momentum at all. The prime minister's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, has backed Frank Dobson to win, which sounds like a sign of confidence. But the stake turns out to be only £5. Sensible fellow.

fields.headline: Lola rennt nach Hollywood
fields.standfirst: Despite the Berlin film festival there are few box-office hits by German film companies.  Nicole Prestle asks cinema buffs why
fields.trailText: Hollywood ist auch in Deutschland. Das meiste, was die Traumfabrik produziert, kommt irgendwann in die Kinos der Bundesrepublik - davon kann man ausgehen. Womit man selten rechnen darf: daß ein deutscher Streifen die Kassen im Ausland klingeln läßt.
fields.body:
Hollywood ist auch in Deutschland. Das meiste, was die Traumfabrik produziert, kommt irgendwann in die Kinos der Bundesrepublik - davon kann man ausgehen. Womit man selten rechnen darf: daß ein deutscher Streifen die Kassen im Ausland klingeln läßt.

Sicherlich, einige deutsche Schauspieler und Regisseure haben sich auch in anderen Ländern einen Namen gemacht. Jürgen Prochnow, der mit "Das Boot" bekannt wurde, zum Beispiel. Oder Roland Emmerich, der mit "Independence Day" einen Angriff Außerirdischer filmische Wirklichkeit werden ließ. Und dann wäre da noch Wim Wenders. Mit seinem neuesten Werk "The Million Dollar Hotel" gewann er auf der Berlinale den Silbernen Bären. Und für "Buena Vista Social Club" wurde er jetzt auch für den Oscar nominiert.

Dennoch haben es durch und durch deutsche Filme - Streifen deutscher Mache mit Schauspielern aus der Bundesrepublik - noch immer schwer im Ausland.

Wie ist Deiner Ansicht nach das Ansehen deutscher Filme im Ausland?

Fred (16): Das ist natürlich schwer zu sagen, wenn man nicht im Ausland lebt. Ich habe allerdings noch kaum in Zeitungen gelesen, daß Filme aus Deutschland woanders großes Aufsehen erregt hätten.

Ulrich (19): Ich habe einmal für ein halbes Jahr in Amerika gelebt. In den großen Kinos lief in dieser Zeit kein einziger Streifen, der in Deutschland oder in deutschsprachigen Ländern entstanden ist. Nur ein ganz kleines Kino hat ab und zu Filme aus dem Ausland gezeigt.

Lara (17): Deutsche Filme werden, glaube ich, von Fachleuten immer ziemlich zerpflückt. Mir scheint es manchmal, als wären sie da kritischer als zum Beispiel bei Hollywood-Schinken. Ich finde es schon komisch, wenn bei guten deutschen Filmen immer so getan wird, als wäre das etwas ganz besonderes. Warum sollten wir keine super Geschichten verfilmen können?

Warum sind Filme, die in deutschsprachigen Ländern entstehen, Eurer Ansicht nach so selten Kassenschlager im Ausland?

Ulrich: Das liegt wohl an der Machart. Die meisten Filme, die in Amerika gemacht werden, richten sich nach dem Geschmack der breiten Masse. Ein bißchen Action, ein bißchen Sex, tolle Effekte. Die deutschsprachigen Werke sind oft tiefgründiger, man muß genauer aufpassen, um ihren Sinn zu verstehen. Das kommt nicht überall an.

Armin (17): Deutsche Filmemacher haben oft weniger Kohle, um ihre Arbeit zu vermarkten. Doch wenn man nicht laut genug trommelt, ist in dem Geschäft wohl nicht viel zu holen. Vor allem wenn da einer kommt, der noch nie einen guten Film gelandet hat, hat er's beim ersten Mal natürlich doppelt schwer.

Lara: Vielleicht, weil bei uns nicht so ein Kult um Schauspieler gemacht wird. Hollywood zum Beispiel ist ja eine Welt für sich. Da wird jeder vergöttert, der irgendwann einmal in einem Film mitgespielt hat. Bei uns finde ich das nicht so heftig. Aber wenn schon wir viele unserer eigenen Schauspieler nicht kennen, warum sollte man sie dann außerhalb der Grenzen kennen?

Wim Wenders hat auf der Berlinale den Silbernen Bären gewonnen, jetzt ist einer seiner Filme für den Oscar nominiert. Was sagt ihr dazu?

Fred: Ich glaube, das könnte den Experten im Ausland wieder einmal beweisen, daß ein deutschsprachiger Filmemacher auch tolle Ideen haben kann. Obwohl: Bei Wenders' neuestem Film spielt ja Mel Gibson eine große Rolle. Und der ist so bekannt, daß wahrscheinlich eher sein Name zieht als der von Wenders.

Lara: Ich finde das super. Ich habe da einen Bericht gelesen, daß in Berlin sogar Bono von U2 und Naomi Campbell da waren, um Wenders' Film zu präsentieren. Das ist doch die beste Reklame: Zwei Leute, die jeder kennt, rühren die Werbetrommel für einen deutschen Filmemacher.

Ulrich: Ich befürchte, daß der Film zwar Erfolg haben wird, daß viele ihn aber nicht als deutschen Film sehen werden. Er wurde in Amerika gedreht, mit Schauspielern, die nicht aus Deutschland stammen. Außerdem lebt Wenders ja auch in Amerika, auch wenn er viele seiner Streifen in Deutschland gedreht hat.

Was haltet Ihr selbst von Kinofilmen, die nach deutscher Machart entstanden sind?

Fred: Ich habe "Lola rennt" gesehen und den fand ich total scharf. Die Vermischung von realen Szenen und Zeichentrick hat mir gut gefallen. War außerdem eine neue Idee.

Ulrich: "Schtonk" habe ich im Kino gesehen. Diesen Streifen mit Götz George, in dem es um die gefälschten Hitler-Tagebücher ging. Ich fand sowohl das Drehbuch als auch die Schauspieler hervorragend. Eine Sache, die wirklich passiert ist, wurde in diesem Streifen amüsant auf die Schippe genommen. Diesen Humor schätze ich.

Armin: Was ich absolut dick habe, sind Emanzen-Filme. Solche, in denen die Männer immer übers Ohr gehauen werden. Doris Dörrie zum Beispiel finde ich darum nicht so toll. So'was würde ich mir aber auch nicht anschauen, wenn es in Hollywood entstanden wäre.

fields.bodyText: Hollywood ist auch in Deutschland. Das meiste, was die Traumfabrik produziert, kommt irgendwann in die Kinos der Bundesrepublik - davon kann man ausgehen. Womit man selten rechnen darf: daß ein deutscher Streifen die Kassen im Ausland klingeln läßt. Sicherlich, einige deutsche Schauspieler und Regisseure haben sich auch in anderen Ländern einen Namen gemacht. Jürgen Prochnow, der mit "Das Boot" bekannt wurde, zum Beispiel. Mit seinem neuesten Werk "The Million Dollar Hotel" gewann er auf der Berlinale den Silbernen Bären. Und für "Buena Vista Social Club" wurde er jetzt auch für den Oscar nominiert. Wie ist Deiner Ansicht nach das Ansehen deutscher Filme im Ausland? Fred (16): Das ist natürlich schwer zu sagen, wenn man nicht im Ausland lebt. Ich habe allerdings noch kaum in Zeitungen gelesen, daß Filme aus Deutschland woanders großes Aufsehen erregt hätten. Ulrich (19): Ich habe einmal für ein halbes Jahr in Amerika gelebt. In den großen Kinos lief in dieser Zeit kein einziger Streifen, der in Deutschland oder in deutschsprachigen Ländern entstanden ist. Nur ein ganz kleines Kino hat ab und zu Filme aus dem Ausland gezeigt. Lara (17): Deutsche Filme werden, glaube ich, von Fachleuten immer ziemlich zerpflückt. Mir scheint es manchmal, als wären sie da kritischer als zum Beispiel bei Hollywood-Schinken. Wim Wenders hat auf der Berlinale den Silbernen Bären gewonnen, jetzt ist einer seiner Filme für den Oscar nominiert. Was sagt ihr dazu? Fred: Ich glaube, das könnte den Experten im Ausland wieder einmal beweisen, daß ein deutschsprachiger Filmemacher auch tolle Ideen haben kann. Was haltet Ihr selbst von Kinofilmen, die nach deutscher Machart entstanden sind? Fred: Ich habe "Lola rennt" gesehen und den fand ich total scharf. Die Vermischung von realen Szenen und Zeichentrick hat mir gut gefallen. War außerdem eine neue Idee. Ulrich: "Schtonk" habe ich im Kino gesehen. Solche, in denen die Männer immer übers Ohr gehauen werden. Doris Dörrie zum Beispiel finde ich darum nicht so toll. So'was würde ich mir aber auch nicht anschauen, wenn es in Hollywood entstanden wäre. webTitle: Your music at the BBC Proms

fields.headline: Your music at the BBC Proms
fields.trailText: Let the drums roll and fanfares begin! Stand by, all young music lovers, for very exciting news. If you are aged between 12 and 16 and you get a kick out of creating music - in any style - we have the ultimate opportunity for you to show what you can do.
fields.body:
Let the drums roll and fanfares begin! Stand by, all young music lovers, for very exciting news. If you are aged between 12 and 16 and you get a kick out of creating music - in any style - we have the ultimate opportunity for you to show what you can do.

Today the Guardian, the national newspaper with the best education coverage, is joining forces with BBC Proms, the world's greatest music festival, to launch a unique competition for young composers.

There are plenty of competitions for young painters, poets, writers and scientists, and for instrumental performers. But there has been precious little, if anything, on a national scale for youngsters who write music.

We reckon it's high time you composers enjoyed the same opportunities as your fellow artists. After all, the future of music is in your hands. Before we explain the rules, let's say something about prizes.

What's the one thing above everything else - yes, including wealth and fame that the true composer craves? To be performed, of course.

If you are one of our three winners, more people will listen to your piece than have ever heard your music before. How come? Because it will be broadcast. BBC Radio 3 will devote a programme to the top three entries and the competition. This will go out on air during the interval of the Prom concert on Tuesday July 18.

And Yamaha has generously donated six keyboards - one each for the three winners, and one for their schools.

When the BBC Proms organisers unveil their programme for the 2000 season in May, we will give you details of the music that will be performed at the July 18 concert and of how your schools can get tickets.

When the Guardian and BBC Proms ran a similar competition for the 8-12 age group two years ago, it became obvious we had tapped a big demand. Teachers said how thrilled they were that somebody had at last come up with an opportunity for young people who write music.

So here is your chance. And if you fancy having a crack at it, please tell your music teacher at school as soon as possible - all entries must be signed by a music teacher.

Apart from that, the rules are pretty straightforward.

The rules

* The competition is open to young people aged 12 to 16 who are attending a UK school during the current academic year.

* Entries (classical, jazz or pop, for any combination of voices/instruments) must be no longer than five minutes submitted on audio cassette, CD, DAT or minidisc (two copies) with an accompanying, written-out version, either using standard or graphic notation. They can involve texts which, if not original, must be out of copyright.

* The programme about the three winners will use submitted recordings - whole or excerpts - if they are broadcast quality.

* Entries must be sent to: Young Composer Competition, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Entries MUST include name, address and phone number of the school, age of the entrant, and be signed by the entrant and music teacher.

* Winners will be judged from all entries received by June 1.

* Winners will be notified via their schools by June 21.

* Composers aged 16 or under or 12 or over on September 1 are eligible.

* The judges are: the composer Gary Carpenter, Peter Kingston of the Guardian and Andrew Kurowski, who is in charge of BBC Radio 3's contemporary music output.

The Yamaha PSR-340, specially designed for educational use, has a 61-note touch-sensitive keyboard with 100 panel sounds. For further details: Yamaha online

fields.headline: Hollywood celebrates its grass roots
fields.trailText: It may never gain as much press acreage as the Oscars, but it's a good deal less starchy. Announced at the weekend, the first annual 'Stony Awards' pay tribute to the movies of 1999 that "treat pot-smoking in a realistic way".
fields.body:
It may never gain as much press acreage as the Oscars, but it's a good deal less starchy. Announced at the weekend, the first annual 'Stony Awards' pay tribute to the movies of 1999 that "treat pot-smoking in a realistic way".

Organised by High Times magazine, the Stonys are divided into a bundle of eccentric categories. Best Stoner Movie went to Being John Malkovich, best re-release to the Beatles's lurid, LSD-themed Yellow Submarine. Best Tripping Scene went to a rave sequence in Doug Liman's Go, while the prestigious award for Best Pot Scene fell to a moment in the upcoming Dick in which a fictionalised Richard Nixon (played by Dan Hedaya) scoffs himself with some spiked girl-scout cookies.

Even the already award-laden American Beauty didn't miss out on the fun: Kevin Spacey was granted a cursory nod for his performance as the pot-smoking Lester Burnham. Even if Spacey misses out at the Oscars, then, he will always have his Stony.

webTitle: Garbo letters hint at lesbian affair

fields.headline: Garbo letters hint at lesbian affair
fields.trailText: A selection of intimate letters from screen legend Greta Garbo could soon be exhibited publicly at a Philadelphia museum. Throughout the 1930s, Garbo wrote some 55 letters to female playwright Mercedes De Acosta. This correspondence was later donated by Acosta to the Rosenbach Museum and Library on the condition that they not be published until 10 years after the death of both women. De Acosta died in 1968. A New York-based recluse in her later years, Garbo died in 1990. The letters could now be exhibited as soon as next month
fields.body:
A selection of intimate letters from screen legend Greta Garbo could soon be exhibited publicly at a Philadelphia museum. Throughout the 1930s, Garbo wrote some 55 letters to female playwright Mercedes De Acosta. This correspondence was later donated by Acosta to the Rosenbach Museum and Library on the condition that they not be published until 10 years after the death of both women. De Acosta died in 1968. A New York-based recluse in her later years, Garbo died in 1990. The letters could now be exhibited as soon as next month

As yet unseen, the correspondence is rumoured to reveal a charged love affair between the two women. The imperious star of movie classics like Anna Karenina, Grand Hotel and Ninotchka, the enigmatic Garbo has long been the subject of whispered gossip over her fiercely protected private life. Acosta, meanwhile, was a more upfront and fiery character, who was also rumoured to have had a brief affair with Marlene Dietrich.

The proposed publication of the Garbo letters is opposed by Gray Reisfield, Garbo's neice and heir. In a wonderful example of legalise, Reisfield argues that while the Rosenbach Museum owns the actual letters, she herself owns the content of the letters. No word can be quoted or exhibited, Reisfield contends, without her express permission.

webTitle: Affleck signs for Pearl Harbor picture

fields.headline: Affleck signs for Pearl Harbor picture
fields.trailText: Ben Affleck is the latest big name to be drafted into Disney's gargantuan Pearl Harbor, reported to be shaping up as Hollywood's most expensive movie ever
fields.body:
Ben Affleck is the latest big name to be drafted into Disney's gargantuan Pearl Harbor, reported to be shaping up as Hollywood's most expensive movie ever. Affleck will take a leading role in the ensemble saga as a young-buck fighter pilot. Budgeted at $135m, Pearl Harbour revolves around the Japanese attack of 1941 which triggered America's entry in World War 2. The film is to be directed by Michael Bay and produced by Jerry Bruckheimer.

But despite the mushrooming budget and sprawling crew-list, Affleck's arrival lends an almost family atmosphere to the production. The 27-year-old star collaborated with Bay and Bruckheimer on 1997's summer hit Armageddon, and is regarded as a personal friend of both men. Affleck joins other cast-member Cuba Gooding Jr, who is a member of Brukheimer's weekend hockey team, while there are rumours that Gene Hackman (who worked with Bruckheimer on both Crimson Tide and Enemy of the State) is also poised to join the project.

Affleck must be strongly convinced of Pearl Harbour's success. The film's budget might be a record-breaker, but the actor isn't seeing a penny of it. Affleck has agreed to sign on for no money up-front, but a cut of the profits once the film is released. Of course, if the movie performs below-par (like, for instance, Steven Spielberg's unloved Pearl Harbour comedy, 1941), the hot-property star could walk away with empty pockets.

fields.headline: Zodiac Mindwarp and beyond
fields.standfirst: Mark Manning's tales of rock'n'roll antics are scarier than fiction,  Will Hodgkinson finds
fields.trailText: Mark Manning's tales of rock'n'roll antics are scarier than fiction, Will Hodgkinson finds
fields.body:
On the morning of our interview Mark Manning, formerly known as Zodiac Mindwarp of 80s psychedelic biker band Zodiac Mindwarp and the Love Reaction, is being told off by his daughter. She's having a party to celebrate her 14th birthday, and her dad keeps nicking her vodka. "I'll just take a bit more for me guest," says Manning, submissively. "Give us a couple of fags and I'll be off."

"Give me that bottle!" she screams. We escape from the kitchen so that one of rock's most debauched monsters, famous for anthems like Wild Child and Tattooed Beat Messiah, can get a bit of peace. "I've been told to leave them at it until midnight," he explains. "It'll be me who has to clean up the puke tomorrow, though."

Now 41, Manning has long since given up rock'n'roll oblivion for a louche lifestyle of writing, drinking, and intermittently looking after his three kids and three ex-wives. With the KLF's Bill Drummond, he wrote Bad Wisdom, a fantastical account of the pair's attempts to place a statue of Elvis at the centre of the North Pole; and The Wild Highway, a travelogue about a trip along the Congo to battle-scarred Zaire.

Now he has struck out alone with Crucify Me Again, a collection of stories that document his delinquent schooldays in Armley, Yorkshire, years on the road and troubles with women, switching from nuggets of wisdom to sleaze to poetic vision within a couple of sentences. Boastful accounts of sexual conquests are interspersed with tales of breakdowns and broken hearts.

"The only prize I ever won was in religious education for reinterpreting parables," says Manning. "This book is made up of little parables. It's not fiction per se, but it's an interpretation of the truth, and the truth is never black and white."

Some of the tales of excess are hard to believe, such as the time the band's roadie Gimpo bought a van that had no brakes, and dealt with the problem by removing the ones from the van of a local primary school. "That's true," sighs Manning. Another story recounts how a girlfriend carved "pig" into his front door, threatened him by knifepoint until he slept with her, then attempted to get him beaten up by accusing him of rape. She turns out to be a well-known journalist.

"I didn't change the names, so the book's like Truman Capote's Answered Prayers, although being blanked by the Armley cognoscenti isn't quite as bad as being blanked by New York society. Your reality has changed after 10 or 15 years in a band, where you're encouraged to be a nutter. You invent your world and it's as good or as bad as you want it to be. I can see it in Liam Gallagher, he's got this look in his eyes that says he's on the same trip, although he doesn't know it yet."

Does he miss life on the road? "Absolutely. It's this humongous fishing trip, where there's free booze, free drugs, and girls who want you to shag 'em. But it takes its toll. You inevitably end up in smoky rooms, drinking tea from plastic cups, telling a group of idiots how long you've been an alcoholic."

It all went pear-shaped when Manning decided that Gimpo would make a good manager. "That was the beginning of the end. He's a lovely guy but he's not management material. But the band would never last - real rockers get filtered out because they're not interested in making money for the record company. It's sad because we were so good - although not in the later manifestations, when we all got fat."

One of the finest chapters from Crucify Me Again, "Germaine Greer's Bumhole and the Psychology of Wanking", compares Greer's diatribe against "tuggers" in her book The Whole Woman to "laughing at spastics", and describes how Greer's insults could never match the masturbator's self-disgust caused by a reflection on a television screen: "Pants around ankles, soggy tissue in trembling hand_ and you catch sight of your revolting self reflected on the blank screen."

As our interview ends, Manning's daughter bursts into the room holding a pile of "adult" magazines, and shouts: "What are these?" "It's my pornography," says Manning with a look of resignation. Such honesty is at the heart of Crucify Me Again: the tales of excess and bravado are imbued with a self-deprecating wit. It isn't the book of a man searching for respect, which might explain his daughter's manner. "She has no respect for me whatsoever," says Manning, "which is how I like it."

 Crucify Me Again is published by Codex, price £8.95.

Your reality has changed after 10 or 15 years in a band, where you're encouraged to be a nutter. You invent your world and it's as good or as bad as you want it to be. I can see it in Liam Gallagher, he's got this look in his eyes that says he's on the same trip, although he doesn't know it yet." Does he miss life on the road? "Absolutely. It's this humongous fishing trip, where there's free booze, free drugs, and girls who want you to shag 'em. But it takes its toll. You inevitably end up in smoky rooms, drinking tea from plastic cups, telling a group of idiots how long you've been an alcoholic." It all went pear-shaped when Manning decided that Gimpo would make a good manager. "That was the beginning of the end. He's a lovely guy but he's not management material. But the band would never last - real rockers get filtered out because they're not interested in making money for the record company. It's sad because we were so good - although not in the later manifestations, when we all got fat." One of the finest chapters from Crucify Me Again, "Germaine Greer's Bumhole and the Psychology of Wanking", compares Greer's diatribe against "tuggers" in her book The Whole Woman to "laughing at spastics", and describes how Greer's insults could never match the masturbator's self-disgust caused by a reflection on a television screen: "Pants around ankles, soggy tissue in trembling hand_ and you catch sight of your revolting self reflected on the blank screen." As our interview ends, Manning's daughter bursts into the room holding a pile of "adult" magazines, and shouts: "What are these?" "It's my pornography," says Manning with a look of resignation. Such honesty is at the heart of Crucify Me Again: the tales of excess and bravado are imbued with a self-deprecating wit. It isn't the book of a man searching for respect, which might explain his daughter's manner. fields.headline: Pinochet wins further £500,000 costs battle
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: General Augusto Pinochet yesterday won a final order for the British taxpayer to pay another £500,000 of his legal costs, at the end of a saga which has cost the public purse millions of pounds.
fields.body:
General Augusto Pinochet yesterday won a final order for the British taxpayer to pay another £500,000 of his legal costs, at the end of a saga which has cost the public purse millions of pounds.

Two judges at the high court in London ordered that all the former Chilean dictator's legal costs for the extradition hearing at Bow Street magistrates' court and preparation for a high court habeas corpus hearing, which had been scheduled for this month, should be met from central funds. The costs ruling means that, in effect, Pinochet is considered to have won the case by avoiding extradition, even though the magistrate ruled against him.

Geoffrey Bindman, a solicitor who acted for human rights groups in supporting Pinochet's extradition to Spain, said he was "astonished" that the general's costs should be paid when he had lost the extradition case at Bow Street. "It seems to me quite extraordinary. Senator Pinochet has not escaped extradition as a result of any defect in the ruling by the magistrate, before whom he failed.

"The prosecution did not drop the case. The proceedings were terminated because the home secretary exercised a discretion on compassionate grounds."

Pinochet's lawyers were preparing to argue in the habeas corpus application that he should not be extradited to Spain, but the application was short-circuited when Jack Straw decided the general,84, was unfit to stand trial.

Yesterday, Clive Nicholls QC, for Pinochet, told Lord Justice Schiemann and Mr Justice Douglas Brown that there had been "enormous pressure" on the lawyers to continue preparing the application right up until last Thursday's decision to allow the general to go home.

Lord Justice Schiemann, sitting with Mr Justice Douglas Brown, agreed that a costs order should be made and the matter brought to an end.

The amount of the costs awarded yesterday was unspecified but is expected to add around £500,000 to the bill for the 16-month saga, variously estimated at between £7m and £15m. Pinochet was detained under house arrest while a series of costly legal battles were fought over whether he should be extradited to Spain for trial on torture charges.

He was awarded legal costs for his original victory in the high court, when the court ruled that former heads of state were immune from prosecution in the courts of other countries, and for the first two hearings in the House of Lords. Though he lost at first in the lords, the law lords had to hold a second hearing after it emerged that Lord Hoffmann, one of the original five who heard the appeal, had close links with Amnesty International. Pinochet was granted costs of both hearings.

fields.headline: A bit of a perfectionist
fields.standfirst: Australia's captain recently said she'd be the first name in her World XI. Tanya Aldred talks to New Zealand stalwart Debbie Hockley and discovers a woman driven by her passion for the game
fields.trailText: Debbie Hockley is happy. Stephen Fleming and Chris Nevin have finally got the better of Australia, in the last match of the antipodean one-day clash. "At least they won a match," she deadpans. But she can afford a wry smile. New Zealand women avenged a 3-0 defeat at the hands of Australia with a 5-0 demolition of England.
fields.body:
Debbie Hockley is happy. Stephen Fleming and Chris Nevin have finally got the better of Australia, in the last match of the antipodean one-day clash. "At least they won a match," she deadpans. But she can afford a wry smile. New Zealand women avenged a 3-0 defeat at the hands of Australia with a 5-0 demolition of England.

Hockley, 37, made her international debut 21 years ago, and in February became the first woman to play 100 one-day internationals. The New Zealand board are cherishing those weary limbs - they have given her a (first-ever) part-time contract until next January. She also has to fit in her job as a physio in a Christchurch hospital.

Health problems affected her decision to step down from the captaincy after leading New Zealand to victory in the Rosebowl Trophy against Australia last year. While still smarting from defeat, Belinda Clark, the Australian captain, said Hockley would be the first name on her team-sheet for a women's World XI. Greater admiration hath no Australian.

You've just played in your 100th one-day international - what's your secret?

First and foremost I really love the game, and have a burning desire for success. Once you have won a few games, winning becomes a drug.

Do you still enjoy playing as much now as you did when you made your debut in 1979?

I have probably enjoyed myself more over the last five or six years than I ever have. Experience counts for a hell of a lot and my contract with the Board has allowed me to work part-time.

How much longer will you play for?

I'm not sure. I was quite disappointed with my form against England [she was second in the averages], but I scored more runs against Australia than I've done for a long time. My goal is the World Cup and then I'll see how I go.

Do you think New Zealand's 5-0 victory over England was a fair result?

Yes. England's batting was pretty disappointing. They've got a pretty handy bowling line up though - Nicki Shaw, the quick, is an outstanding prospect. Their fielding too has vastly improved from 1996 and Jane Cassar had a good series behind the stumps.

What can England do to improve?

They need batsmen who can bat. Charlotte Edwards and Claire Taylor looked pretty handy but not many others stayed with them.

Did you fraternise much?

We had a barbecue after the game in Hamilton, and after the last match in Napier we had a fairly jovial night in an Irish bar. It must have been the best Tuesday night in the bar's history. We've always had a good social thing going with England. It is different with Australia.

Just how good are Australia?

There's no doubt they are the best side in the world at the moment, even though we underperformed against them this summer. They aren't unbeatable, but any other team will have to play pretty damn well to topple them. They are difficult customers and you have to admire them for that. It is tough out there.

Do the Australian women have the same attitude to winning as the men?

Yes, and there is nothing wrong with that. They are not very good losers and they were bruising from losing to us in the Rosebowl last year. They were always going to work damn hard to regain it, and their 3-0 victory over us this summer was pretty conclusive.

Who are New Zealand's main rivals for the World Cup?

I would look at Australia and India. India are always difficult customers and I get nervous playing them. They have good spin bowlers and some of their batsmen are very aggressive. If England work hard on their batting this summer, they too will have a chance.

Have there been many changes to the women's game during your career?

Lots. The style of play has changed a lot: it is much more athletic, aggressive and committed - lots of girls are making sliding saves now. And thanks to the amalgamation of women's cricket into the NZC in 1992, we now have training camps and more money. It is pretty phenomenal really. When I first started we had to make our own travelling uniform - cut from a pattern (my mum made mine) - and pay to go away.

Can you see women's cricket going professional?

I can't, because I don't think it will ever create enough revenue for players to be paid. But it will be interesting to see what happens five years down the road.

What size crowds do you get for your matches?

In small grounds we sometimes get a couple of thousand which makes a nice atmosphere, but it is nothing like the men's game.

How much media coverage do you get?

I think we do pretty well here, certainly far better than they do in Australia. It is probably because we have the whole of the New Zealand Board's marketing department behind us.

Do you have much to do with the men's team?

We don't often run into them but I've talked to Craig McMillan and Chris Cairns about batting.

What more do you want to achieve before you retire?

I had always wanted to make a hundred against Australia, which I managed this summer. And of course winning the World Cup would be pretty nice - I'm hoping it will be third time lucky for me. It could be the last big series I play in, so a win would be the icing on the cake.

Will you stay involved with cricket when you retire?

I'm not sure. I'll have to be a full-time physio again and I'll probably have a bit of a break from cricket for a while. Then maybe I'll get involved with coaching or management. But you need a good few years out of the game before you can do that.

What one thing in cricket has given you the greatest pleasure?

I have to say the camaraderie. We've had good times and not such good times, but the games that we have won have been pretty sensational and I've made some fantastic friends.

Which cricketers have you most admired?

Ken Wadsworth, who played for New Zealand in the 1970s and who died tragically of cancer at 29, was a gutsy, fighting, determined cricketer who never, ever, gave up. Martin Crowe was pretty damn sensational and then there is Jan Brittin. I first saw her in 1984 - she was a really elegant, classy cricketer and I loved watching her bat, even when she was getting runs against us.

Who have you learnt the most from?

Probably Catherine Campbell, one of my best mates [and a team-mate]. I hate to think how long we have spent talking cricket together.

What do you do to relax?

I live about half a km from the sea in Sumner, Christchurch. I love the outdoor life here. I also love reading. At the moment I'm trying The Courtship Gift by Julie Parsons. I also watch a fair bit of cricket on TV and spend time with my cat Jessie.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Internet wars: the key players
fields.standfirst:
NTL ups the ante
No going back for free access
fields.trailText: Freeserve
fields.body:
Freeserve

Britain's biggest internet service provider (ISP) was launched on in September 1998 by Dixons, the electronic retailer, as the UK's first major free internet service. There are no registration or set-up fees and no monthly subscription charges. But you have to pay the local phone rate, which can add up. Freeserve has 1.6m users.

BT

Britain's dominant telecommunications giant offers free internet access weekends and weekday evenings, for £9.99 per month. It is committed to launching unmetered access but is still negotiating terms with Oftel, the telecommunications watchdog, and other ISPs. BT has come under government pressure to lower the cost of its internet call charges.

AltaVista

This California company began life as search engine, helping users to find sites and information on the net. It was sold last year by Compaq, the computer manufacturer to CMGI, an investment group. It has galvanised the internet market in the UK with a plan to scrap phone charges for customers using its internet services. But they would have to pay an upfront fee of up to $50, and a renewal fee every year.

America Online UK

The British offshoot of America Online, the world's biggest ISP, has 1.2m subscribers, making it the second biggest internet player in Britain behind Freeserve. It is said to be working with Freeserve on plans to match AltaVista's scheme to scrap phone charges for internet access.

Telewest

Telewest Communications is a leading provider of cable television and residential and business cable telephony services in the UK.

As of December 31, 1998, TeleWest and its franchises provide cable services to approximately 33% of the homes in Britain for which cable franchises have been awarded. Telewest last week suspended registrations for its £10-a-month 'SurfUnlimited' tariff - which offered free unmetered calls - after access problems led industry publications to damn it as 'SurfVeryLimited'.

fields.headline: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: • Two most intriguing letters fall into our possession. They are from the Whinge Twins themselves, the one-time Maxwell lackey Alastair Campbell and Millbank's zany Lucille Ball wannabe Margaret McDonagh. Both are complaints to BBC news chief Tony Hall about Vivian White's excellent Panorama of last week about the various devolution fiasci.
fields.body:
 Two most intriguing letters fall into our possession. They are from the Whinge Twins themselves, the one-time Maxwell lackey Alastair Campbell and Millbank's zany Lucille Ball wannabe Margaret McDonagh. Both are complaints to BBC news chief Tony Hall about Vivian White's excellent Panorama of last week about the various devolution fiasci.

Ali's letter (alluded to on yesterday's media pages by Roy Greenslade) asks: "Can I make it clear that my concern in this is the prime minister's integrity" The prime minister's what ? Do grow up, Ali, for God's sake. As for Margaret, I haven't the strength for too much detail, save to correct her for retelling Ian McCartney's much-loved whopper about how the failure to force all unions to ballot narrowed Dobbo's lead. The truth, as Christine Mabey - that's Dr Mabey OBE, by the way, former Birkbeck College chief administrator and one-time Blairite loyalist - told us, is the precise reverse. Now, to borrow from John Prescott, stop whining the pair of you.

 Meanwhile Dirty Frankie ("Go ahead, punk, make my, err, make my, um, make my _ oooh, now what was that wretched punchline?") went on BBC1's lunchtime bulletin yesterday to brandish his Magnum .44 at Ken again. "And it's quite clear even when he was dithering about standing," said Dobbo, "that companies who were contemplating investing in London and creating jobs were already reconsidering their position."

Perhaps Frank would mention some of these jittery firms, so that we can confirm this claim for him. Oooh, go ahead, Frank, amaze us and make our, um, our, er

 In the Sun, lovable lard-bucket Richard Littlejohn hits top form. With startling originality, Richard adopts an "if it's over there, it's not our concern" line about Mozambique. "The last time I looked," observes the sage, wondering after Lisbon's response to the crisis, "Mozambique was a former Portuguese colony." Indeed so. The last time I looked, meanwhile, it was also a current member of the Commonwealth .

It's not that Richard is ignorant, of course, for he proves the depth of his foreign knowledge in a separate item about Pinochet. "If Spain has a problem with him," Richard observes, "that is between Madrid and Buenos Aires." Magnificent work, of the kind you simply could not make up.

 Leader of the Lords Margaret Jay receives a heart-wrenching plea from Lord Swansea concerning July's Lords v Commons rifle match at Bisley "for which I have captained the Lords for many years". Reminding her that the fixture stretches back to 1862, he adds: "My problem is that nearly all my regulars are hereditary peers, and if I am not allowed to include them in the team that will in all likelihood put an end to the match."

Lord Swansea, who lives in Chelsea, begs Margaret to allow outcast hereds to participate on July 21 - and we ask that the Baroness shows compassion. Chucking them out done quite enough harm already, thank your ladyship very much, without ruining a decent day's shooting.

 It was good of the Guardian readers' editor to include a correction to my old friend Paul Routledge the other day, after that great working-class warrior rang to deny being the landlord of several properties. Perhaps Paul would be good enough to ring again if we're wrong to suggest that all of the relevant properties are, for some reason, registered in the name of Mrs Routers.

 For obvious reasons, I cannot replicate any of the reminiscences over which the Blairs injuncted the Mail on Sunday in the early hours of Sunday. Having said that, and at some personal risk, I gather that one of the things that understandably distressed Mr Tony and Cherie was the nanny's revelation that the couple use curtains and - in several rooms - carpet.

fields.headline: The best changing scene
fields.standfirst: Show me love
fields.trailText: Show me love
fields.body:
Åm l, Sweden. Fourteen-year-old Elin (Alexandra Dahlstrom) and her older sister Jessica (Erica Carlson) are getting ready to go out. Elin is trying to see her reflection in the tiny bathroom mirror - but it's no good. She leaves the flat, waits for the elevator and, when it comes, scrutinises herself in the full-length mirror inside. She calls to her sister,

"Jessica? Fetch my skirt, I can't wear these."

She takes off her trousers, leaving her in her underwear in the lift. Jessica comes in, looks at herself in the mirror and fusses with her hair.

"Oh God," she exclaims, " I don't know how to have it."

Both girls preen in the mirror.

"Oh my God, I'm so beautiful!" shouts Elin, pressing the lift button to keep the door from closing.

"I'm going to be Miss Sweden."

"You're too small."

"Why, how old do you have to be?"

"You're too small - you're too short."

"I'll do it anyway."

The lift door closes - Elin isn't quick enough to stop it descending.

"Shit", she panics. "Where's my skirt?"

"What skirt?"

"My skirt, didn't you bring my skirt?"

The doors open to reveal Elin trying to hide behind Jessica. Waiting on the ground floor is their mother; she is, momentarily, stunned into silence.

fields.headline: I'm backing the Pope
fields.standfirst:
The Catholic church still knows a thing or two about keeping the troops on message

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II is very active. He has appointed a new archbishop in Britain, recently beatified a large number of historical figures, and only the other day apologised for the church's past treatment of a famous heretic.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II is very active. He has appointed a new archbishop in Britain, recently beatified a large number of historical figures, and only the other day apologised for the church's past treatment of a famous heretic.

I imagine my editor making theatrical gestures with his hands. "The Archbishop of Westminster - who is he? Why has the Pope apologised for the burning of Giordano Bruno but reiterated that Bruno was wrong? What does it all mean?"

As a Catholic I should know, but my first answer is "um". I'm thinking: it means the church represents a touchstone in any discussion on morality in Britain.

I have two piles of papers in front of me. On one side are profiles of the 16th-century Neapolitan philosopher and one time Dominican monk, Giordano Bruno. On the other side, profiles of our 21st-century archbishop, the Rt Rev Cormac Murphy- O'Connor.

Bruno was known as an original and independent thinker. A little too independent for his own good. His views are dismissed in the Catholic Encyclopaedia as "incoherent materialistic pantheism". They earned him a heretic's end at the stake.

Meanwhile Murphy- O'Connor's newspaper profiles remind me of a Private Eye spoof news story: "Cardinal a Catholic Shock". How can I describe him beyond "a bachelor who believes in God and - er - safe pair of hands - liberal - conservative - is this ok?"

A Catholic priest is a Catholic priest. While the church no longer burns defrocked Dominicans, it can still teach even this government something about continuing to keep the troops on message.

The individual under the cassock does have a name, of course. In the case of the archbishop, an Irish one. According to one profile, "British Catholicism [by which the writer means 'English'] has traditionally been rent into two groups: a slender line of posh old English families and a mass of mainly working-class Irish immigrants".

This ignores the other slender line of working-class old English Catholics (particularly in Lancashire). It also ignores generations of converts, the Catholic progeny of mixed marriages and the very large number of middle-class British Catholics of Irish descent.

Since the Saxon Celtic Catholics cross the class divide, they go to the same schools and are bound by friendship as well as faith, blood as well as belief. The archbishop - who regards himself as an Englishman of Irish parentage - represents this hybrid culture.

But this individual background is not what he means or who he is. He means what he says as the voice of the church in England. This is why he is of such interest.

While the Anglican church bends over forwards to accommodate fashionable thinking and gets royally stuffed for its trouble, the church that was built on the rock of St Peter attracts outsiders keen to test their beliefs. Love it or hate it, you know where it stands - or thought you did before the Pope started regretting the brutality of the crusades, the subjugation of women, the church's failure to prevent the Holocaust and the burning of philosophers. Admissions of error don't sit comfortably with the image of an infallible papacy.

But in fact only certain core beliefs have been expressed infallibly. Our new archbishop quotes the phrase " ecclesia semper reformanda " - the church must always reform itself. This recognises both that our understanding of God changes over time and that priests have done things which are to be regretted. The present Pope saw the church's bi-millennium as a time to ask forgiveness for past wrongs and to seek reconciliation with those with whom it has quarrelled. The first part is not difficult to understand when you consider Catholic attachment to the sacrament of confession. But the reconciliations may be less so.

How can the Pope regret the burning of Giordano Bruno, then imply he had it coming by adding, as he did, that his ideas remain unacceptable and that the Inquisitors who condemned him cannot be judged by modern criteria?

Because in the 16th century those who attacked the established religion (be it Catholic or Protestant) were regarded as so dangerous to society they had to be executed. The Pope understands that. He opposes capital punishment now that it is so clearly an unnecessary evil. This doesn't make Bruno's New-Age-style ideas more acceptable now than they were 400 years ago. If he was a 21st-century monk he would not be executed. He would be defrocked.

While our prime minister can say GM food is good one day and bad the next, without giving reasons for his change of view, the Church's opinions are always supported by careful argument. They may change, but they are never frivolously arrived at. That is one reason why the Church is so important to us.

There is another. The archbishop admits there are times when he too thinks it's all a load of twaddle. Those who see themselves as convinced atheists don't differ from him much. Curiosity about the church, even a powerful antipathy to it, mark people out as seekers of The Truth.

fields.headline: Picture this
fields.standfirst: Children's Laureate Quentin Blake talks to Donald MacLeod about drawing stories with paint
fields.trailText: Children's Laureate Quentin Blake talks to Donald MacLeod about drawing stories with paint
fields.body:
The orderly rows of brushes and pencils and his air of quiet reserve give no hint of the comic anarchy that bursts across the page when Quentin Blake gets going.

A national institution long before he became the Children's Laureate, he has peopled the consciousness of generations of children and parents with a cast of vivid characters - most famously Roald Dahl's grotesques.

He is delightfully un-grand about all this.

Blake is so popular as a children's illustrator that it is easy to overlook how good he is, how rare it is to be able to dwell on the happy and optimistic without becoming saccharine.

He works in tiny bursts and has evolved a method that allows him to "rehearse" a picture without losing spontaneity. He draws a rough sketch on transparent paper (it looks like kitchen greaseproof paper) and then places it on a lightbox under the paper for the finished version. He can see the outline of the rough and the placing of the elements of the picture - but not too clearly. "If you trace, it just dies. The lightbox is a technique for planning while not squeezing the spontaneity out of it.

"Some things are more critical than others, particularly gestures and expressions, which I get very concerned about. It is often something quite slight - wide eyes or eyebrows or what the hands are doing."

Readers will be familiar with those crooked smiles or looks of bemusement that recur in his drawings. A lot of wise and amusing tips have gone into Drawing for the Artistically Undiscovered, a book that comes complete with pencils.

The famous collaboration with Dahl began with the Enormous Crocodile and Revolting Rhymes. His sunny, optimistic approach was the perfect foil for Dahl's dark imaginings - the ghastly Twits who play cruel practical jokes on each other, the bestial giants in The BFG and the deliciously scary Witches. He says it was like acting. "You have to discover things in yourself that you might not think you could or should have done. The Twits is quite dark and menacing in its way; I rather liked it for that reason.

"I think you can tolerate more in words than in pictures. You can say something and move on from it and you don't have to look at it every time. A good example is Three Blind Mice. I thought it would be interesting to draw it using different techniques with more or less blood. You could make it absolutely horrific if you wanted to," he chuckles.

The early drawings of The BFG had him in boots and apron, as Dahl had described. But when he saw Blake's drawings, Dahl didn't like them. A couple of days later a large Norwegian sandal arrived in the post from Dahl (one of his own). Sandals were perfect for the rather earnest vegetarian giant.

He is now halfway through a busy two-year term as Children's Laureate and is planning a party to celebrate. Excerpts from his 50 favourite children's books - the Laureate's Party - will appear in June. He has helped prepare the children's section of the British Library's exhibition Chapter and Verse, which opens this week. He is also choosing pictures for an exhibition at the National Gallery, opening in February 2001, called provisionally Tell Me a Picture, in which each painting tells, or at least suggests, a story. It is to be alphabetical: one artist per letter. "That means it's me or Botticelli," he remarked to the organisers. Blake will be supplying the drawings for the foyer and the letters of the alphabet.

Blake can't help drawing stories himself. On his table is a recently completed watercolour for a magazine for teachers: two children and a monkey cling to a horse's back as it gallops beneath stormy skies. The horse is a typical creation, determined but happy.

A longtime francophile, Blake is currently working with a group of teachers in the Charente region, where he has a home, on a project to produce a book involving 1,500 children. The story revolves around two children in a flying boat, which gets them into difficult situations where they confront problems like bullying and pollution. The local children are contributing by suggesting colours, storylines and so on from which Blake will then, in his words, "cook" the book. They are getting used to the man with the strange waistcoat and the stranger accent.

One of the principal influences on Blake is the 19th-century French artist and satirist Honoré Daumier. Several of the original reviews to which Daumier contributed hang in his hallway. Characteristically, they are not his most savage political inventions but more subtle send-ups of the bourgeoisie he made when censorship prevented him from direct attacks. One of his stock characters, Monsieur Prudhomme, pops up in Blake's version of Hilaire Belloc's Cautionary Tales, looking pompous as he delivers the moral "Always keep a hold of nurse/For fear of finding something worse."

George Cruikshank, another eminent 19th-century political cartoonist and a hero of Blake's, also turned to wry social commentary, including illustrations for Dickens's Sketches by Boz.

Among more than 200 books Blake has worked on are Cervantes' Don Quixote and Cyrano de Bergerac's Voyages to the Moon and the Sun (clearly one his favourites) and The Hunchback of Notre Dame. (The latter was the result of an offhand remark to the Folio Society which was taken up -"I had never even read the book!"

"I do belive in drawing and pictures as a form of celebration, even of awful things. With painters like El Greco there is plenty to write about, whereas with Veronese, whose paintings are beautifully calm - there is a wonderful original quality in favour of life - there is not much to write about. It is something drawing and pictures can do - they are good at dealing with positive things."

Drawings and paintings are life-enhancing, Blake says, just a little bit embarrassed by the phrase. "It's a term that has been well thumped, but I think you need it."

Quentin Blake - a man who is good at dealing with positive things.

fields.headline: Humorous reading
fields.trailText: It is a well known fact that the things that make small children shriek with laughter all too often make their accompanying adults groan (especially if it's a knock knock joke). But some books make everyone giggle - and if it's Giggle Bugs by David A Carter (Simon and Schuster, £6.99), the book will even giggle for you.
fields.body:
It is a well known fact that the things that make small children shriek with laughter all too often make their accompanying adults groan (especially if it's a knock knock joke). But some books make everyone giggle - and if it's Giggle Bugs by David A Carter (Simon and Schuster, £6.99), the book will even giggle for you.

Read the joke (and there are some stunningly good ones as well as the awesomely dreadful ones), press the button - and Abracadabra! - instant electronic hilarity.

If you prefer to make up your own jokes, try Buzz Buzz Bumble Jelly (Scholastic, £9.99). Nick Sharratt's clear bright pictures in zinging colours are instantly recognisable by even the smallest reader (Miaow! A tabby cat; Yippee! A wibbly wobbly jelly), but the real fun starts with the split pages. You can mix and match the top and bottom halves into all sorts of rib tickling combinations.

Shark-Mad Stanley (ticktock publishing, £9.99) by Griff is even more educational because it tells you a lot about sharks - but it is also one of the funniest books I've read in ages.

The stylish illustrations are a delight, and the information is delivered with wonderfully deadpan humour - "Brain: A small brain leaves more room for teeth. Teeth: Some sharks have rows and rows of teeth, just in case some fall out." And there's a wealth of witty detail in the pictures - check out the ingredients in the Shark Food advertisement. Oh - and there's a free CD, too.

There aren't any fish in Farmer Brown Goes Round and Round (Dorling Kindersley, £9.99), but there are loads of farm animals in a whirlwind story of mixed identities. "His cows oinked, The pigs moo'd, His sheep clucked, The cat coo'd."

If you think you've heard this idea before think again; this is the best version, and there's a neat twist in the tail. Teri Sloat writes glorious read aloud rhyme, and Nadine Bernard Westcott deserves to be much better known. Her animals (especially when wearing Farmer Brown's checked underwear) kept all my testers in hysterics all the way through the story.

So did Charlie the Chicken, a pop-up book for the very young (although I noticed older siblings cackling away merrily as well.) The words - minimal, but just right - are by Nick Denchfield, and the pictures of Charlie's big fat tummy and great big feet are by Ant Parker.

It's a splendid example of how something very simple can also be very funny - and good enough to stand a lot of repetition. After the first reading there were squeals of delight at the anticipation of the big fold out at the end of the book - a great introduction to the excitement to be found in literature! (Macmillan, £5.99).

And, finally, there is A Squash and a Squeeze (Mammoth, £4.99). First published in 1993, Julia Donaldson's rhyming version of an old folk tale has become a bit of a classic. Axel Scheffler's illustrations of the little old lady who thinks her house is too small make children laugh from the front cover on, and the chaos caused by the animals when they are invited into the house is almost too much for toddlers who are constantly exhorted to Tidy Up.

A goat on the bed and a cow on the table tapping out a jig? My readers collapsed in heaps, and then had to have it read again. And again.

 All books above are available at a discount from the CultureShop on 0800 3166 102 or by sending a cheque to Guardian CultureShop, 250 Western Avenue, London W3 6EE. Prices are as follows: Giggle Bugs, £4.99; Buzz Buzz Bumble Jelly, £7.99; Shark-Mad Stanley, £7.99; Farmer Brown Goes Round and Round, £7.99; Charlie the Chicken, £4.99; A Squash and a Squeeze, £4.00. Add 99p p&p per order.

fields.body:
Two British women writers have made the shortlist for the Impac Awards, the world's richest fiction prize.

Jackie Kay, who won the Guardian Fiction prize last year with Trumpet, has made it to the last seven along with Londoner Nicola Barker, who has been nominated for her latest novel, Wide Open.

They face the twin giants of modern American letters, Toni Morrison and Philip Roth, for the £70,000 prize which will be presented in Dublin in May.

Trumpet, the story of a female jazz musician who lives her life as a man, is Edinburgh-born Kay's first novel. Wide Open, set on the Isle of Sheppey in the Thames estuary, is Barker's third novel.

The other shortlisted authors are New Yorker Michael Cunningham for The Hours, Irish-American Colum McCann for This Side Of Brightness and American Alice McDermott for Charming Billy. Morrison is nominated for Paradise, which has already won several awards, while Roth makes the list for McCarthy era book, I Married a Communist.

fields.headline: Growing star quality
fields.standfirst: John Crace visits Capel Manor College, nursery to the tv gardeners
fields.trailText: John Crace visits Capel Manor College, nursery to the tv gardeners
fields.body:
In the 1930s they used to say that when Yorkshire were short of a fast bowler someone would just shout down the nearest pit. These days, when TV producers are short of someone to present a gardening programmer they go beating a path to Capel Manor College. Now you could say this has something to do with the inability of TV bods to conceive of life outside the M25 and Capel Manor's convenient location 200m south of junction 25, but it is also a fair reflection of the college's reputation as one of the leading centres for horticulture, arboriculture, floristry and equine studies.

At the present reckoning, four of the college's recent alumni have gone on to become TV celebs.

Anne-Marie Powell is presenting Channel 4's Real Gardens; Kim Wilde - yes, the Kim Wilde - is appearing with Carol Vorderman on Better Gardens; Jane Sweetser is helping out Charlie Dimmock on Charlie's Garden Army; and Julie Dellow - who Steve Dowbiggin, Capel Manor's principal, tips to be the biggest star of the lot - makes her debut with Alice Beer on Real Rakeovers later this spring.

Only the most cynical of people would suggest that age, sex and appearance could have had anything to do with the producers' selection, and Dowbiggin is at pains to suggest that other criteria came into play.

"Producers come to us because they know our students are well-qualified," he says. "They are terrified of being caught out by the public with a presenter who can't really do the job."

To prove the point, Dowbiggin goes on to cite two other male students who have gone on to top jobs. Though not, I might add, in TV.

There's Darren Baldwin, 27, who has one of the toughest jobs in football working with the demanding George Graham at White Hart Lane as the head groundsman.

And there's David Mole, the senior environmental consultant for London Transport.

But Dowbiggin does have a point. Capel Manor College is a centre of excellence and is one of the few further education colleges that has been known to turn students away because its courses are oversubscribed.

The college offers everything from day-release NVQ courses to full-time three-year BA and HND courses. Most of the 1,800 students are there as part of a career change, and the enthusiasm and commitment are tangible. And that goes for the staff, too.

Pottering around the 30-acre site is a bit like being at the Chelsea Flower Show. The landscape changes constantly; there's the walled garden, the Gardening Which? trials garden, the historic garden, the topiary garden, the wilderness garden, and there aredozens of smaller themed gardens sponsored by names such as Tesco, M&S and Mazda.

The smell of commerce is never far away from Capel Manor. Nothing in the garden comes cheap and the DfEE only provides about 59% of the funding to enable the college to offer top class facilities. Dowbiggin freely admits that a large amount of his time is spent rustling up cash from the business sector - not just to maintain the level of opportunities but to expand them.

In this he is lucky to have Dave Hessayon, author of the gardening "expert" series that has sold nearly 40 million copies, and the Duchess of Devonshire as keen supporters of the college. These connections have helped ensure over £2.5 million of private money.

Some of Capel Manor's students go on to jobs at the large estates, but most go into private business, and the college places great emphasis on gardening for all. Hence the design courses spend a lot of time focusing on smaller town gardens and their problems. These may include space, light, and poor soil, but they can also include theft. Which is why the college has also done a deal with the Met to design the crime prevention garden.

A large number of students are already working in the landscaping business and are taking a day out per week to improve their skills. The economics are simple; a jobbing gardener can earn £14 per hour; someone with know-how cancharge £25 and if you're Alan Titchmarsh...
