fields.headline: Keeping up with the Joneses
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones  pays tribute to the unsung heroes of further education
fields.trailText: Janet Jones pays tribute to the unsung heroes of further education
fields.body:
The thing about further education..." Mr Jones had his hands in the sink. He paused. He stopped washing up. He sighed under the weight of his experience.

"The thing about further education..." Mr Jones' experience is indisputable: he has listened to me telling him about further education for years and years and years. He has seen the chalk dust. And the ink. Even, on a couple of occasions, the blood.

I waited for his wisdom with interest. He shook his head over the saucepan and the scourer.

The time has come to pay tribute to all those Mr Joneses out there. To those unsung stalwarts of our further education system. To those who partner us who work in further education. To those who sustain us day by day. To those who listen and listen and listen. To those who take our rap. And those who take our flack.

Your Mr Jones may, of course, be your Aunt Sally, or your faith, or your game boy, or the dog, or the bottle, or the racket, or the ball, or the sound system, or the punch bag, or the skittle alley, or the garden, or the mountain, or the paintbrush, or the pen. Or all of those. Mr Jones does not have to be a person. But every one of us has need of our Mr Jones.

If ever you have found yourself cast in the part of a Mr Jones you will know the extent of its demands; you have been thrust into the jaws of the lion of education. You know the beast. You know the score. You know its power to consume. It's no joke being a Mr Jones.

"The thing about further education is..." my Mr Jones repeated himself. He shook his head again. He gestured with a soapy hand.

What picture has he gathered from listening to me for all these years?

One problem that evolves from the listening marathons is that the Mr Joneses become inured to the floods of anecdote. Doubting Thomases worm their ways into the Mr Joneses' souls. It is hard for them to believe what they are hearing. Their dilemma is whether to doubt the messenger - Ms Jones - or the message - Ms Jones's story. In the interests of balance, Mr Joneses reason, to preserve sanity, they should hang a question mark over the discourse. A note of scepticism. They come to see themselves as the keepers of objective truth.

This is frustrating for Ms Joneses. Another Ms Jones told me of the relief with which she read my recent book. She is giving it to her Mr Jones. At last, she hopes, he will believe what she has been telling him all these years.

My Mr Jones appears as himself in my recent book, but it was in his less emancipated role that he pronounced his verdict on further education the other evening:

"The thing about further education is, it's like washing up ..."

I waited again. My Mr Jones tends to qualify what he says. He is not one to give gratuitous offence.

"... necessary. But without romance".

He turned back to the suds and grease. I was left to raise a damp and solitary tea towel in a salute and a cheer.

webTitle: TECs hang on to their kecks

fields.headline: TECs hang on to their kecks
fields.standfirst: The government may plan to ditch TECs, but, says  Nick Tester, they won't go quietly
fields.trailText: The government may plan to ditch TECs, but, says Nick Tester, they won't go quietly
fields.body:
Divorce can be very messy. In fact, few problems in David Blunkett's in-tray are proving knottier than the break-up with the Training and Enterprise Councils, or TECs.

In 12 months, the 72 TECs in England plus six in Wales will cease getting government funding to the tune of almost £1bn a year.

Their goose was cooked a year ago. A critical review concluded that their performance as lightning conductors for retraining and for regional regeneration did not justify continued cash support from the Department for Education and Employment.

Their fate was announced when Blunkett launched his plans for a complete shake-up of the organisation and delivery of post-16 education and training, and said that "accountability, efficiency and probity should be promoted at every level".

The TECs' particular problem, the education secretary said in the white paper that preceded the learning and skills bill, was that each of them had different funding and administrative systems, with long chains of intermediaries tagging along. This had resulted in "a bureaucratic minefield that is confusing, difficult to negotiate and often impedes rather than encourages the learner".

Which all, no doubt, adds to the current problem: how to uncouple the TECs from the public purse.

No matter how diplomatically Blunkett approaches the task, this divorce will get messy. Already there is deep disagreement between him and the TEC bosses over who owns what and how the spoils should be divided.

A lot is at stake - at the last count, at least £283m worth of accumulated surpluses across the country, mainly in the form of buildings and equipment bought with both public and private money, but also cash acquired through efficiency savings.

In an uncomplicated world the assets and reserves generated by public funds would simply be returned to the education department. But TECs are pointing to "non-attributable elements" in their accounts and some maverick ones may refuse to cooperate.

To make matters even worse, a number of powerful TEC bosses are taking legal advice and may challenge Blunkett in the courts over apparent anomalies in the process of winding down.

The expectation is that about 5,500 of the total 9,500 people employed by all TECs will transfer to the new Learning and Skills Councils (LSCs), with 500 located at the central office. These will be middle and junior ranking staff. Senior officials in TECs that are closing will either have to apply for similar jobs in the LSCs or pocket a pay-off.

Tim Boswell, the shadow further education minister, warns: "We need to make sure some TECs don't blow all the money on extremely generous redundancy payments or a weekend in the Caribbean."

The Tories, he recalls, faced similarly sticky problems over disputed assets when they cut further education colleges free from local authorities in 1993.

Boswell, who has been asking searching questions about the issue in the Commons recently, added: "There's considerable dispute over ownership. It is difficult to know what is private and what is public. So the potential for monkey business is enormous."

He is also suspicious that Blunkett will try to seize assets gained by TECs' legitimate private operations. "We need to know where any remaining private surplus should go. Certainly the government should not be allowed to collar it."

Dr John Brennan, director of further education development at the Association of Colleges, points out that TECs have been legally obliged to distinguish between private and public monies in their accounts. "But any accountant worth his or her salt will be creative with their accountancy," he says.

TECs' limited company status means they can't just be closed down by the education department. And not all the TECs plan to quietly fade away next spring.

Many will transmogrify as slimmed-down, private-sector providers, ready to take their chance in the open market and compete for lucrative training contracts. Others might re-emerge in completely new clothes doing other things. Several have already merged with local chambers of commerce and Business Link, the Department of Trade and Industry scheme.

North Nottinghamshire TEC Business Link, near Mansfield, has pledged to battle on, even though it is going to lose its annual £18m government grant and is to shed over two thirds of its 100 staff.

Pat Richards, its chief executive, says the TEC has generated "significant money from commercial activity" in recent years. Some of this was used to buy the HQ of British Coal, for £700,000, two years ago. Today, the building is home to the TEC and also to 25 commercial organisations and 40 start-up groups.

"The title deed belongs to the TEC," she said, "and we are discussing with the DfEE about the use of this building after next year."

She firmly rejects suggestions that her TEC might be tempted to squirrel away some of the prized possessions.

"We are definitely not in the business of asset-stripping. There are not many of us going into the private sector who'll not pay heed to our original mission to help retrain and re-skill people."

College principals are anxious that when the education department turns off the TEC tap, the money will be re-routed to them, as promised, via the new LSCs. The government's announcement that these councils will have "significant local discretion over funding" - perhaps up to 15% of their average £100m budgets - has failed to allay fears of an imminent shambles.

Jim Aleander, principal of West Nottinghamshire College, likens the predicament facing the government to "unscrambling eggs". Aleander says his local TEC has been a valued partner in the quest to reverse the ailing fortunes of this blighted part of the north midlands.

But by and large, TECs have rarely been embraced warmly by the education community, mainly because so much public money - about one sixth of the entire further education £6bn annual budget - was being handed to private organisations.

The one shred of comfort for Blunkett as he mulls over the impending divorce is that, once it is through, he could have up to £300m at his disposal. Now, let's see, what would that buy - a 7% pay rise for all lecturers, or the creation of 16 new colleges, perhaps?

What TECs did

 National Traineeships and Modern Apprenticeship programmes in line with government priorities and national targets

 discretionary funding of local retraining projects

 providing business support advice

 providing work-based non- academic learning for adults

 lead bodies for economic development

fields.headline: Thumbs down
fields.standfirst: Parents may be happy with schoolteachers, but schoolteachers are far from happy.  John Carvel reveals the second part of our poll results
fields.trailText: Last week we reported the overwhelmingly positive views of parents about rising standards in schools, with more than 90% expressing satisfaction about the state education being provided for their own children. This week we turn to the teachers in primary and secondary schools, where a much more gloomy picture emerges.
fields.body:
A mismatch at the heart of education has been identified by the Guardian's ICM poll of opinion among parents and teachers.

Last week we reported the overwhelmingly positive views of parents about rising standards in schools, with more than 90% expressing satisfaction about the state education being provided for their own children. This week we turn to the teachers in primary and secondary schools, where a much more gloomy picture emerges.

Just over half say the general quality of their jobs has declined over the past two years and another third think it has stayed the same. That leaves only 16% detecting improvement since Labour came to power.

The negative feelings are greatest in primary schools, where 55% of teachers say their jobs have deteriorated, compared with 48% in secondary. Yet it is in the primary sector where parents are expressing the most satisfaction, with 51% observing an improvement in their own children's school, compared with 7% reporting a decline over the past two years. The parents are delighted and the teachers are distressed. What is going on?

The answer is that teachers think they are paying a heavy personal price for the improvement in standards that the parents believe their children are enjoying. More than 90% of teachers say there is more bureaucracy attached to their jobs than there was under the last government. This problem is identified by slightly more primary teachers than secondary.

Overwhelmingly, they blame the government for this development (88%), rather than their own school (3%) or local education authority (6%). Two-thirds of teachers think the government is too hard on the profession, with only 2% saying it is too soft.

The findings come from ICM interviews with representative samples of 500 parents, 500 teachers and 100 university lecturers across England last month. And the most dramatic conclusion from the research is that large numbers of teachers are so fed up with the downside of the job that they are getting ready to quit.

Among primary teachers, 31% say they expect to leave the profession in five years, 56% in 10 years and 77% in 15 years. When asked an unprompted question about the main reasons for leaving, the most common answer was age. But more than a third of under-35s are also expecting to leave teaching within 10 years and nearly half within 15 - well before normal retirement.

After age, the most frequent unprompted reasons given for leaving were heavy workload (26%), stress (16%) and bureaucracy (10%). These came over as more important than getting a better job outside teaching (9%), poor pay (6%) or discipline problems (2%).

When the potential quitters were prompted with reasons why they might leave, 91% said heavy workload would be important, 88% said bureaucracy, 86% stress and 53% pay. Secondary teachers were a little less likely to expect to quit, but the reasons they gave for doing so were similar.

And this exposed a second mismatch. The government is rushing through plans to introduce performance-related pay for experienced teachers and fast-tracking for more recent recruits. The scheme will cost £1bn over the next two years.

Yet 72% of teachers said performance pay was a bad idea and 51% were against fast-tracking, with only 29% in favour. It seems that the government is spending a lot of money on an unpopular method of raising salaries, while doing little on cheaper initiatives to reduce bureaucracy that would satisfy teachers more.

That conclusion came through forcefully during focus groups of primary and secondary teachers conducted by ICM on the fringes of Birmingham and London.

Most said they entered the profession because they liked working with children and, in the main, that was what they still enjoyed. Secondary teachers spoke of contact with pupils keeping them young. "When a child had been difficult and you've somehow got through, that's very, very rewarding"; "There's a real buzz in the classroom, it's wonderful"; "The kids are the best bit"; "The sanity is the classroom - you get so fed up with everything else the government throws at you, the greatest thing is to go into a classroom and actually teach your subject."

But the subject that dominated discussion was all the bureaucracy inflicted by government: administrative paperwork and repeated changes to the syllabus. "If they doubled the salary, it would not take away the stress. It might make the stress a little more bearable. But if someone gave me the choice between increasing my pay and taking away some of the nonsense we have to put up with, I would prefer to keep my pay as it is and get rid of the nonsense."

The secondary teachers who voted Labour in 1997 felt let down. The mention of David Blunkett aroused little enthusiasm. "When he talks about these wonderful kids who have been failed by schools, that makes me see red." Mention of Chris Woodhead aroused outright antagonism, but there was little fear of Ofsted inspectors. Teachers in the group thought they were out of touch. "Twice now we've pulled the wool over their eyes."

Words used by the secondary teachers to describe their profession were: "fun", "frustrating", "satisfying (or unsatisfying tomorrow maybe)", "weary", "enjoyable", "rewarding", "challenging". They thought the ideal secondary school of the future would be on the smallish side, with class sizes of no more than 16 and a lot of equipment available. "But anything that costs money isn't going to happen, and it's going to cost a lot to have smaller classes."

Primary teachers appeared more pressured than their secondary colleagues. "The paperwork really gets you down"; "I don't want them to cut down another rainforest for teachers"; "The worst thing is trying to fit a social life around all the paperwork."

Last week we reported the overwhelmingly positive views of parents about rising standards in schools, with more than 90% expressing satisfaction about the state education being provided for their own children. This week we turn to the teachers in primary and secondary schools, where a much more gloomy picture emerges. Just over half say the general quality of their jobs has declined over the past two years and another third think it has stayed the same. That leaves only 16% detecting improvement since Labour came to power. The negative feelings are greatest in primary schools, where 55% of teachers say their jobs have deteriorated, compared with 48% in secondary. Yet it is in the primary sector where parents are expressing the most satisfaction, with 51% observing an improvement in their own children's school, compared with 7% reporting a decline over the past two years. The parents are delighted and the teachers are distressed. What is going on? The answer is that teachers think they are paying a heavy personal price for the improvement in standards that the parents believe their children are enjoying. More than 90% of teachers say there is more bureaucracy attached to their jobs than there was under the last government. This problem is identified by slightly more primary teachers than secondary. Overwhelmingly, they blame the government for this development (88%), rather than their own school (3%) or local education authority (6%). fields.headline: All fall down
fields.standfirst:
Parents naturally assume that their children are safe at school. But in reality, this is far from true. Phil Revell asks what can be done to improve safety
More information on school security from the DFEE
fields.trailText: Parents naturally assume that their children are safe at school. But in reality, this is far from true. Phil Revell asks what can be done to improve safety
fields.body:
On December 10 last year, Paula Lewis was having an uneventful afternoon when a telephone call plunged her into 28 hours of chaos. Waddon Infant School in Croydon wanted her to get down to the nursery as soon as possible. There had been an accident. Harry, Paula's third child, was in "a bit of a mess".

Paula bundled her baby into the car and got to the school in 10 minutes.

"He was sitting down," she said, "I thought 'Oh, he's OK' but then he opened his mouth and the blood went everywhere. I was stunned." Harry had fallen over in the playground and smashed his teeth. Paula was advised to take him to St Helier's hospital in Carshalton. She loaded Harry and his brother Dale into her car and set off on a nightmare journey through traffic.

"I was hysterical, crying, trying to drive the car. Harry's crying, he's still bleeding and Dale is asking what on earth has happened to his brother." Paula's arrival at hospital didn't end her problems. St Helier's couldn't treat Harry. One tooth was gone, four others would need to be extracted and there was damage to the mouth and gums.

Harry would need a general anaesthetic and a bed. He was transferred across London, ending up at St George's in Tooting, where he was operated on the next morning.

Like many parents, Paula thought her children were safe at school. "The only time my children are not with me is when they're at school," she says. But the facts are that school is the place where children are most likely to suffer a non-fatal injury, and that the true situation across the country is unknown, because no one collects the figures.

Details of work-based accidents are held by the Health and Safety Executive, which has the main responsibility for enforcing safety legislation. Unfortunately, as a recent parliamentary select committee discovered, the executive is grossly under-resourced and only investigates a proportion of the most serious cases.

MPs on the commons environment select committee were told that the HSE investigates 6% of accidents. Jenny Bacon, head of the HSE, told MPs: "We do not intend to investigate every accident, only those where there is a substantial breach." This policy leaves schools largely unvisited by HSE inspectors. Schools have few deaths and are categorised as low risk by the HSE.

But, even when compared with similar low-risk employment sectors, schools have a higher rate of accidents. The figures, which relate to teachers' accidents and include colleges and universities, show that education premises are more dangerous than shops and garages, hotels and restaurants, and the health sector. Education has a rate more than double that for small offices and five times the rate for bank.

But schoolchildren aren't employees and lie outside the HSE's area of responsibility. Accidents only have to be reported if an ambulance takes an injured child to hospital and in the statistics they are included with all other visitors to the building - along with trespassers, parents, contractors and Ofsted inspectors. Those inspectors do have a brief to report on health and safety issues and in this year's annual report, Chris Woodhead drew attention to inspectors' concerns about health and safety.

In over a quarter of secondary schools, inspectors identified health and safety issues and in one in 10 there were "a significant number of such problems". More than a quarter of schools are failing to carry out the regular risk assessment procedures which experts argue are essential for accident prevention.

Ofsted does not collate statistics of injuries, nor does the organisation have any formal liaison channel with the HSE or with other safety authorities to pass on concerns about a particular school. A spokesperson claimed that concerns would be passed on to the appropriate authority, but the Guardian has been unable to identify any instances when this has happened.

In its annual report, the HSE gives a figure of 9,238 accidents to members of the public on school premises. This represents just 0.2 accidents per school per year. It's a figure the Child Accident Prevention Trust would regard with some incredulity. The trust's research, based on statistics from the Department of Trade and Industry relating to accident and emergency admissions, suggests that schools have nearly 400,000 accidents a year resulting in a visit to hospital, a rate of 11.6 accidents per school.

The director of the trust, Carol Sherriff, argues that accidents at school are often seen as unimportant.

"The low-level nature of the problem keeps it hidden," she says. The most common injuries result from simple "slip and trip" accidents, which are often seen as the injured child's fault.

Sherriff says that the other thing we don't know "is how many school days are lost each year through accidents. We estimate that it could be as many as six million days a year."

The trust was set up by paediatricians working in accident and emergency departments who "saw the result of childhood injuries and recognised that a lot of the injuries could be prevented".

Some of it is down to a lack of a safety culture, according to Sherriff. She says that there may be a culture of sympathy in schools, where victims are well looked after, but safety management involves more than just well-meaning concern. "If you do not know where, when, how often" she says, "it's difficult to break the cycle and prevent future accidents".

Studies of school accidents in Newcastle by paediatrician Asir Maitra revealed "a small number of the schools accounted for many more injured children than the others", indicating that the problem is a matter of resources and management. Dr Liz Towner at the department of child health at Newcastle University, who has carried out similar work in Gateshead for the local health authority, argues that prevention is a matter of better management of children's free time.

"Separate active games from quieter ones," she advised. "Manage the age groups in primary schools. Walls and steps can be zoned off. The important thing is to realise that children have to learn how to play with each other."

Lunchtime assistants, who often have the main responsibility for supervision at playtimes, are obviously key players in preventing accidents. Yet many are parents brought into the school on a minimum wage with no specific training in their role.

"Some schools do very well in this area," says Harry Tomlinson, professor of education at Leeds Metropolitan University. "Lunchtime assistants actually direct the playtime activities by refereeing football games."

But overall Tomlinson was sure that very few part-time supervisors had any relevant training, "which is a pity, because lunchtime supervisors who do the job well will be contributing to children's informal education, preventing bullying and, by implication, making school a more enjoyable experience".

Other areas of employment have seen a big growth in health and safety training since 1992 when new legislation required employers to carry out risk assessments.

Yet this is the period when schools have been faced with a plethora of initiatives ranging from the national curriculum to devolved budgets. Schools that fail to keep up with the targets set by government risk being named and shamed. Observers suspect that some aspects of management - including safety - have slipped off the agenda.

"Lack of management awareness is reported back to us time and time again," says Sharon Liburd at the Association of Teachers and Lecturers. "Union safety reps are often asked to take responsibility for safety, because they are the only ones to have had any training."

Margaret Tulloch at the Campaign for State Education argues that as more and more is delegated to schools, they are finding it difficult to take a long-term view about dealing with repairs. Faced with competing demands, heads are likely to spend on the more public areas, or on the curriculum. Playground maintenance, along with repairs to corridors and stairwells, may well come low on the list of priorities.

Fairfunding, introduced this year, will deliver even more spending into the hands of untrained heads and governors, leaving local authorities with the legal responsibility for safety, but little power.

"When funding is brought down to school level, governors are very conscious of the reputation of the school," says Tulloch. "They don't want to make a fuss, and the weaker the local education authorities become, the more this is an issue."

Harry Lewis is faced with several years of speech difficulties at a crucial stage in his development. In the future, he is likely to need more orthodontic surgery to correct the damage caused by the accident. He's already a quieter and more withdrawn child than he was before Christmas. His mother took him to hospital, which means that under current regulations there would be no requirement to report the accident to the HSE. Under current policy guidelines, the HSE would be unlikely to investigate anyway. The education department keeps no figures on pupil accidents because "that is a matter for the HSE".

"If it had happened at home," says Paula Lewis, "I would have had the whole world banging on my door - police, social workers. They'd want to know how a child lost five teeth in my care. Yet when it happens at school, no one's interested."

fields.headline: Pay scale on scrap heap
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston reports on a radical review of college pay rates
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reports on a radical review of college pay rates
fields.body:
The national further education pay scale, which unions say many colleges misuse to depress wage levels, is to be scrapped.

A radical review of the whole further education salary system is being launched jointly by unions and employers in the hope of clawing lecturers' pay back up to some sort of parity with schoolteachers'.

Both sides accept that the necessary root and branch review of the disparate pay structure which has resulted since colleges won autonomy when they were incorporated in 1993 is unlikely to be completed in time for the 2000-01 pay round.

Natfhe, the lecturers' union, is to go ahead with lodging a flat-rate demand of £2,500 on the table for all its further education members on April 6 when formal pay talks begin with the Association of Colleges.

Meanwhile research by the Association of Colleges suggests that two-thirds of colleges this year honoured its recommendation of a 3% pay rise for all staff.

Jocelyn Prudence, the Association's director of employment policy, said: "We are of course heartened that the majority of colleges surveyed have been able to meet or exceed the national recommendation on pay this year.

"However, pay rates for college staff are still significantly behind school teachers."

Recruitment and retention problems were getting worse for colleges and were going to damage their ability to deliver the government's widening participation agenda. The sector has got to recruit another 700,000 students.

"We are committed to an extensive programme of joint work with the nationally recognised trade unions, which includes looking at a new pay framework and major pay research," Prudence said.

Just over half - 233 colleges - of the Association's 450-strong membership responded to the latest annual survey. Of these, 156 - 67% of respondents - had honoured the 3% award.

Eleven per cent of colleges (25) gave their staff no pay award this year. Of these, nine reported that their poor financial position prevented them increasing their employees' pay.

Of the other colleges not paying the 3% recommended by the AoC, which colleges are in no way bound to observe, 23 had given lecturers more than the 3% and 26 less than the recommended figure.

In April the new joint forum of employers and the five recognised unions for managers, lecturers and support staff will begin trying to thrash out next year's award.

As a prelude to reforming the sector's salary system, the forum has commissioned OCR International, which has carried out extensive research in public sector pay to take an in-depth look at 30 colleges.

"We want them to undertake case studies in each to produce the fullest possible picture on pay," Prudence said.

"The objective is to look towards coming up with a new model that could be commended to the sector."

Sue Berryman, head of Natfhe's colleges department, said colleges often put their own bands onto the Association of College's current pay scale. This effectively imposed ceilings on many staff's salaries.

"That means, for instance, that someone hired on a point within a £11,000 to £14,000 band couldn't get above that upper figure," she said.

"If you're a schoolteacher you know the scale you've been appointed to and you know the reason why you're on it and what you can do about it. In further education there isn't a rationale and many staff don't know why they've ended up in the band they are in."

Natfhe wanted a more transparent salary system. "We want it to be seen to be fair."

fields.headline: Qualified success
fields.standfirst: Chris Hughes  argues the case for colleges to give their own unique qualification
fields.trailText: Chris Hughes argues the case for colleges to give their own unique qualification
fields.body:
Words, words, words. For a start, why do people sometimes use the word "college" to mean university?

You know how it is: for 51 weeks of the year, there is a pecking order. Universities, even ones that used to be called polytechnics, set a (world-class) standard, and the rest of us know our place. Then, some time in September each year, the sons and daughters of middle England "go to college". No they don't. They go to university.

Have you ever tried this one: hail a taxi in any provincial town and ask the driver to take you to "the tec". How often do you end up at the TEC? Or are you driven to a general further education college - which hasn't called itself "the Tech" for a generation?

Saatchi & Saatchi who, for the benefit of younger readers, used to be a famous advertising agency, were reputed to have a phrase for the communications advice they gave their clients: brutal simplicity of thought.

Simplicities are very important. People think in shorthand, and, if the customer reigns supreme, then clear, straightforward images are crucial.

The government has taken this thinking to heart, and it looks as though we shall see radical changes in the way further education is presented.

First up: the vocational A level. The GNVQ has posed one question too many for the minds of teachers, for the belief of students, and for the credibility of employers. It's the old opinion-polling thing again: never mind what they say, watch what they do!

They may say that UK industry needs a state-of-the-art work-based qualification. They may say that it should be a first-rate option for 16 to 19-year-olds. But if employers still look to the gold standard when it comes to recruitment, then that is how the GNVQ must be labelled.

Next up: the "Foundation degree". Many of us in further education have long felt that we needed a distinctive qualification. The thinking goes like this: perhaps educational institutions are defined by the qualifications they give. Schools have A levels, universities have degrees. But what about further education?

As a matter of fact, the Further Education Development Agency put on a seminar last year to identify, define and make a case for a signature qualification. One that would value lifelong learning properly - a sort of college diploma. It could be modular, we thought, to make it accessible, and pitched, maybe, like an American Associate Degree. (By the way, have you noticed that Americans continue to "go to school" for their whole academic career, even if that means Harvard or Yale?)

As it happens, the format and content for the new Foundation degrees is rather different, but I'm not advocating a particular solution here, just making the point that labels do matter.

They certainly matter to the learner. In the real world, nothing is quite so straightforward (or important) as their results. Success or failure, ticks in boxes, marks-out-of-ten, assessments and grades. Qualifications count.

So should we be trying to make these new offerings synonymous with further education colleges?

Or must we be more fatalistic, and see our role simply as the delivery mechanism for qualifications which have been endorsed by employers? (And will these eventually be proprietary commercial products: MS Office 2010, and the like?)

I think not. I am unreservedly positive about all this. The government is re-branding learning and linking it to skills for employment as never before. David Blunkett has delivered the cash. And taxi drivers still know where the Tech is, even if educationalists don't.

What all this says to me is that we need to rediscover vocational education. And make it central to the mission of colleges in the new Learning & Skills world.

It's time we lost the identity crisis, folks. Back to the future!

fields.headline: Words from the heart
fields.trailText: Few would associate the realities of the inner city with a thriving community of young poets. But thanks to headteacher Dawn Peters, the collaboration of the Arvon Foundation and the sponsorship of author Susan Hill, this is what visitors to Ducie High School in Manchester's Moss Side can expect.
fields.body:
Few would associate the realities of the inner city with a thriving community of young poets. But thanks to headteacher Dawn Peters, the collaboration of the Arvon Foundation and the sponsorship of author Susan Hill, this is what visitors to Ducie High School in Manchester's Moss Side can expect.

Peters first took a group of 16 boys from the school to Ted Hughes' former home, Lumb Bank, in west Yorkshire in the early 80s. Lumb Bank is one of the Arvon Foundation's residential creative writing centres. She was overwhelmed by the effect that the surroundings and the focus on poetry had on these youngsters: "It was one of best teaching experiences of my life," she says. There is a need, she argues, "to encourage young people to look outside of the city".

In 1993, a boy was shot in Moss Side, almost certainly in a drug- and gang-related incident. It caught the attention of Hill. Although the boy was not a pupil of the school, she spoke to Peters and was impressed by the role Lumb Bank had in Ducie High School's academic life. She has sponsored it ever since.

"There has been absolutely not a shadow of a doubt for any of us that it has been 2000% worthwhile, and not only for the individual groups of young people, but for Lumb Bank itself, for the staff, and for the general cultural life of Ducie High School," Hill says.

Peters is equally convinced. Literacy levels are below average in the school, and she believes poetry is an imaginative way for pupils to improve their literacy: "Poetry breathes life into children and really concentrates their minds into thinking about how they use words and see themselves."

The visits to Lumb Bank are a tradition the school is proud of. On their return, pupils compile an anthology for use throughout the school, and poetry workshops are regular. The school has strong links with local poets and recently ran a competition to coincide with Refugee Week.

Such experiences are useful on a day-to-day basis as well. "I walked out of my office a couple of weeks ago," says Peters, "and there was a group of quite tough lads hanging around, unashamedly composing poems for Valentine's Day!"

The Arvon Foundation runs similar courses in Scotland, and is opening a new centre in John Osborne's old house in Shropshire.

 The Arvon Foundation: 01422 843714. If you know a school going through interesting times, or pioneering an important initiative, contact amanda.roper@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Internet know-how
fields.standfirst: Book bargains
fields.trailText: Book bargains
fields.body:
Even if adults end up throwing away their paperbacks and downloading novels as electronic books, it will be a long time - if ever - before children's titles go the same way. Think of Eric Carle's Very Hungry Caterpillar with its vivid, punched pages or the large- format adventures of Dr Seuss. Books for older children are a badge of maturity and reading confidence. If you don't think that a book's cover matters, have a look at the special editions of Harry Potter which Bloomsbury published for adults.

Kate Agnew, of the Children's Bookshop in north London, doubts that the web will crush books. "There's so much one needs to see in order to choose. If anything, the web increases information about books."

For example, one of the current hot debates on the web is about the title and release date of J K Rowling's next instalment of Harry Potter , but Agnew warns readers that they shouldn't believe every rumour.

Indeed, some of the most successful websites exploit fictional characters that are familiar to children. "What has tended to happen in the past," says Agnew, "is that the web's been used to build characters that are fairly well established. Increasingly, I think that it will be used for less well known characters too."

There's already an excellent site (www.randomhouse.com/seussville/) where children can play rhyming games with Sam, green eggs and ham; very young children may also enjoy Tom Kitten's Playground (www.peterrabbit.com)

As for non-fiction, troubled publisher Dorling Kindersley is considering a major expansion on the web. For the moment, you can find the Eyewitness Encyclopaedia series at www.dk.com and search it by keyword - it's a useful project resource.

The web also makes it much easier for authors to reach out to their readers. Both Eric Carle (www.eric-carle.com) and Paul Jennings (www.pauljennings.com.au) have their own web pages.

Puffin Books has created a cheerful site (www.puffin.co.uk) with plenty of activities and a teacher's section which could prove useful for literacy hour activities. The Young Book Trust (www.booktrust.org.uk/ybt.htm) will also make recommendations online, if you're prepared to join.

The site that everyone in children's publishing recommends is Achuka (www.achuka.co.uk). Reviewer Michael Thorn started work on it in 1997. With authors' interviews, news and monthly special guest feature, Achuka sometimes receives 4,000 page views a day.

Far from being a threat to children's books, Thorn says, the web opens them up. "Unless parents take children into a big bookshop, they don't know how many books are available."

fields.headline: SATs blues
fields.standfirst: My seven-year-old is getting anxious about SATs. I have tried to reassure him that it is not the end of the world but he still seems to be feeling the pressure. What do I do?
fields.trailText: My seven-year-old is getting anxious about SATs. I have tried to reassure him that it is not the end of the world but he still seems to be feeling the pressure. What do I do?
fields.body:
The expert view

 Alison Gauntlett is headteacher of Harvey Road Primary School in Croxley Green, Hertfordshire.

"Many parents and guardians of seven-year-olds will be finding themselves in a similar situation over the coming month, as the key stage one standard assessment tasks and tests begin.

Try to find out exactly what is causing the child's anxiety. Sometimes you may have inadvertently created the pressures they feel. There is a great deal of media coverage of SATs and their results, and this can cause parents and guardians themselves stress and concern. Your child could simply be picking up on this.

Meet with your child's teacher to discuss their worries about SATs. Not only will this give you more information about the SATs but it will also allow you to gauge how the school approaches the process.

When we have had such discussions with parents and guardians we have always found that they are reassured by the information and more confident about dealing with these issues at home. Make sure your child is not getting mixed messages between home and school about the significance of SATs.

Emphasise to your child that the tasks and tests are intended to show what they can do. They can be a very useful diagnostic tool for teacher and parent/ guardian alike, in helping to inform future learning needs and to assess current progress.

Don't forget that it is in the best interest of schools to make this process as stress-free as possible to allow pupils to perform to the best of their ability, and that in the long run this will lead to better results. Most schools will do their best to fully prepare their pupils by looking at past papers, so that children will know what to expect "on the day".

As assessment will form a regular part of children's lives as they move through the educational system, familiarity is one of the key objectives in alleviating the pressure felt towards it.

By making sure they feel comfortable in assessment situations, children often quite enjoy the experience!

Finally, make sure you are aware of when tasks are taking place. Give them a chance to tell you how they went and take every opportunity to bolster their confidence with praise and encouragement. You may want to plan something for once the tasks are over as a reward for your child's hard work and effort.

Alison Gauntlett's tip

Get to the bottom of the anxiety. Work in partnership with the school so that mixed messages are not given out. Explain that the SATs can be a positive process. Above all, emphasise that this is just a part of a rich educational process and that achievement is not always academic - a good school will celebrate a child's achievement in all walks of life.

 Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about your school? Can you help other readers from your experience? In our interactive advice column, we pose a reader's problem and publish answers from the public along with an expert view. Please send your queries and answers, marked "If you ask me", to the address at the end of Letters.

Next week's query

Our daughter is in her first year of secondary school and is finding it hard to settle in. In some subjects especially, she seems completely at sea and not getting much help from the teachers. With a parents' evening approaching, how should we broach the subject without appearing as whining parents?

fields.headline: The Guv'nor
fields.trailText: Your school has just been judged by Ofsted to have serious weaknesses. Like the rest of the governing body you are probably in shock. "Why us? We have been religiously attending meetings once a term. We've been to the concert and the sports day."
fields.body:
Your school has just been judged by Ofsted to have serious weaknesses. Like the rest of the governing body you are probably in shock. "Why us? We have been religiously attending meetings once a term. We've been to the concert and the sports day."

The vital thing is to prioritise what is important and not to worry about the legal niceties until the school is back on an even keel. There may be committees that are not functioning or properly constituted, you may not have established policies on x,y or z - but Ofsted has spoken and that's what you have to listen to.

As the governing body you will get help from the local education authority to draw up an action plan. Your first job is to get this action plan working. If it doesn't happen you have serious problems. You have got to focus your time on what can be of most use to the school.

You can't do everything, so establish priorities, and when Ofsted is breathing down your neck you have got to demonstrate your commitment to the main issues at hand. That does not mean you have done your bit if you attend the meeting that approves the action plan. You haven't even started yet. The governors are expected to monitor progress for themselves and that means classroom visits. When Ofsted comes back in six months to check on improvements they will ask "Where's your evidence?"

Some governors make the mistake of trying to be a second head. You have to learn to work as a team. No one person, the head or anyone else, can do it all without having a nervous breakdown.

But when the governors and the headteacher work as a team, it's great and when governors are doing a good job it can be easy to recruit.

 Fred Browning is senior governor development officer for Essex local education authority.

fields.headline: Babies are for keeps
fields.standfirst:
Why does Britain have the largest number of teenage births in western Europe? Jerome Monahan reports

Learn more at the First Edition Quiz
fields.trailText: Why does Britain have the largest number of teenage births in western Europe?
fields.body:
An alarmingly high level of pregnancies among young teenagers has led to the launch of a new government information campaign on the risks of under-age sex. Television soap operas are also tackling the subject by introducing controversial story lines about youngsters having illegal sex. But despite all this, many young people are still badly informed about the issue and Britain continues to top the western Europe league table for teenage births.

What is the problem with Britain?

Children in the prosperous West seem to be experiencing puberty much earlier in their lives. They also experience sex for the first time at a younger age. But parental embarrassment and poor sex education has often left children in the dark about what is happening to them or how to handle relationships. Teenage births in Britain are twice as high as in Germany and six times greater than the Netherlands where the age of consent is much lower than in the UK.

Is the problem getting worse?

No. The number of conceptions among the under-16s is fairly constant. It has fallen slightly since 1971 from 8.8 to 8.2 girls per thousand in 1997. Numbers of pregnancies among 12- and 13-year-olds are very small and also slowly falling. In 1997 there were 378 pregnancies among all girls under 14 in the UK.

Is pregnancy the only risk young people run?

No. Many young girls do not fall pregnant from unprotected sex but they and their partners are still taking big risks. The number of sexually transmitted infections among teenagers is rising. This is not surprising when between a third and a half of teenagers do not use contraception the first time they have sex and many carry on without it.

When should sex education begin?

The National Children's Bureau says children as young as three can be curious about sex. By the time most young people go to secondary school they are aware of a wide variety of issues including divorce, rape and prostitution. This suggests wide-ranging sex education cannot wait until key stage 3 when many children can be quite fixed in their behaviour and attitudes.

Should sex education just be about sex?

Critics such as the Sex Education Forum feel the topic is poorly taught in many schools since it is given too little importance in the timetable. In their view, effective sex education must tackle pupils' self-confidence, help them develop their relationship skills and deal with their confusions. This is also the government's view and new guidelines about sex education are expected in schools before Easter.

Does sex education encourage children to have sex?

No, research in 1995 by the National Health Service showed that young men are far less likely to have sex before 16 when the major source of their information on the subject came from specific school classes. Girls' behaviour did not alter either way after sex education classes.

Is teenage pregnancy only a matter of poor education then?

Poverty and lack of career opportunities are an important factor. Childcare can seem very fulfilling when there are few other options. But most young women do not plan to get pregnant.

What happens to teenagers who get pregnant?

Under-age girls may well miss out on the antenatal (before birth) support that is available to women with planned pregnancies, according to the Brook sexual health charity. This can make birth an extremely scary and painful event. The new baby will then totally change the girl's life. In such cases, teenage fathers rarely help bring in their child - this is sometimes because of hostility towards them from the girl's family. Most girls will have to leave school once they have given birth. Some young mothers are lucky enough to continue their education in special centres such as the Bristol Unit for School Girl Mothers, but there are few such places. A baby's birth signals the end of formal education for young mums and the start of a life of poor job prospects.

What changes are ahead?

The Government has promised to halve the number of under-18 conceptions before 2010. It is suggested their strategy has three messages: under-age sex is not a good thing; if you have sex use contraception; and if you have a baby when you are young you will get support to continue your education. Campaigns are being launched to help parents and teachers develop better communication about sex and education.

 Further details: The Brook charity is the UK's leading provider of services offering fee, confidential sex advice and contraception to young people. Helpline: 0207 284 6040

 First Edition is a current affairs series for schools on C4 presented this week by Jon Snow and produced in association with Guardian Education. It is transmitted every Tuesday morning at 11am and repeated on Wednesday at 11am.

Critics such as the Sex Education Forum feel the topic is poorly taught in many schools since it is given too little importance in the timetable. In their view, effective sex education must tackle pupils' self-confidence, help them develop their relationship skills and deal with their confusions. This is also the government's view and new guidelines about sex education are expected in schools before Easter. Does sex education encourage children to have sex? No, research in 1995 by the National Health Service showed that young men are far less likely to have sex before 16 when the major source of their information on the subject came from specific school classes. Girls' behaviour did not alter either way after sex education classes. Is teenage pregnancy only a matter of poor education then? Poverty and lack of career opportunities are an important factor. Childcare can seem very fulfilling when there are few other options. But most young women do not plan to get pregnant. What happens to teenagers who get pregnant? Under-age girls may well miss out on the antenatal (before birth) support that is available to women with planned pregnancies, according to the Brook sexual health charity. This can make birth an extremely scary and painful event. The new baby will then totally change the girl's life. In such cases, teenage fathers rarely help bring in their child - this is sometimes because of hostility towards them from the girl's family. Most girls will have to leave school once they have given birth. Some young mothers are lucky enough to continue their education in special centres such as the Bristol Unit for School Girl Mothers, but there are few such places. A baby's birth signals the end of formal education for young mums and the start of a life of poor job prospects. What changes are ahead? The Government has promised to halve the number of under-18 conceptions before 2010. It is suggested their strategy has three messages: under-age sex is not a good thing; if you have sex use contraception; and if you have a baby when you are young you will get support to continue your education. Campaigns are being launched to help parents and teachers develop better communication about sex and education.  Further details: The Brook charity is the UK's leading provider of services offering fee, confidential sex advice and contraception to young people. webTitle: Bullied nine-year-old sues her primary school for failing to protect her

fields.headline: Bullied nine-year-old sues her primary school for failing to protect her
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A girl of nine is to take legal action against her primary school for its alleged failure to protect her from 18 months of bullying by fellow pupils.
fields.body:
A girl of nine is to take legal action against her primary school for its alleged failure to protect her from 18 months of bullying by fellow pupils.

Solicitors acting for Verity Ward said they have secured legal aid to seek a high court enforcement order obliging Bramcote Hills primary school in Nottingham to enforce its declared anti-bullying policy.

The girl said she was slapped and kicked by a gang of bullies, had her fingers trapped in a door, and faced a daily barrage of verbal abuse. "I cannot take it any more," she said.

Her mother, Dena Trossell, said: "Verity has been the victim of the school's failure to protect her. Nothing else has worked and this is the only option left to us."

Andrew Pearson, the headteacher, said: "All reported incidents of bullying are investigated thoroughly and action taken in line with the school's anti-bullying policy." He was supported by the Nottinghamshire education authority. "We issue comprehensive guidance to schools on reducing bullying. This requires ... specific reference to measures aimed at tackling and reducing bullying in their behaviour policy," a spokesman said.

But Mrs Trossell said the school failed to separate the bullies and instead moved Verity into a different class.

"Moving Verity gives the message to others that it's OK to bully. It says to the victim they are not important," Mrs Trossell said.

According to the family's account, the bullying started in September 1998 when Verity joined the school. Mrs Trossell said her daughter started coming home with bruises.

"She had been saying for a few weeks that the friends she had didn't like her any more. Then she started saying that she wasn't very well and didn't want to go to school. She wasn't sleeping well and the slightest falling out with her sisters made her cry," Mrs Trossell said.

She said her low point came when Verity began talking about suicide, as they walked across a high motorway bridge near their home in Sandiacre, Nottingham.

The Nottingham-based solicitors French and Co said that, in addition to the enforcement order, the family was planning a damages claim in the civil courts alleging physical and psychological injury.

"She has suffered physical injury as a result of bullying and some mental trauma which looks likely to require psychiatric treatment," the firm said.

fields.headline: Fiscal steps
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair wants to see our universities working in partnership with business. Donald MacLeod reports on the economic demands being made on academia
fields.trailText: Tony Blair wants to see our universities working in partnership with business. Donald MacLeod reports on the economic demands being made on academia
fields.body:
Ministers will today demand to know what academics are doing for the economy, following the allocation of £4.38bn of tax-payer's money for the coming year.

Institutions are increasingly stressing the broader economic value of their teaching and research in everything from dance to DNA. But the gap between the prime minister's vision of universities as drivers of the knowledge-based economy and current practice in higher education is highlighted in research published today by the Association of University Teachers and the University of London Institute of Education.

The Knowledge 2000 conference will be addressed by the prime minister; Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary and his education and employment colleague, David Blunkett.

But although the general academic activities of teaching and basic research feed indirectly into the economy, more than half the academics surveyed do not spend time on activities directly linked with the economy. Only 7% of academics spend more than five hours a week on activities linked to the local or national economy.

Attitudes to business links are mixed. A quarter of the academics surveyed were against moves to foster a new entrepreneurial spirit in universities and yet over 40% were in favour.

The research reveals problems within higher education that need to be addressed if universities and colleges are to take up full partnership with business in the knowledge-based economy. These include the conflict between the academic tradition of early and widespread publication of research results, and the desire of businesses which sponsor research to protect commercial confidentiality.

Among scientists there is often a conflict between carrying out pure research which will earn a high rating - and vital funding - in the influential research assessment exercise, and applied research for business which is unlikely to get a high research assessment exercise rating.

The lack of recognition and rewards by university employers for staff who get involved with the business community is another stumbling block. One staff member told the survey: "Academics are encouraged to get involved in work with business, but they don't necessarily receive any rewards for doing that. There is no extra money, no promotion, no career progression as a result of being involved."

Despite these inherent problems, more than a third of academics said their work had involved developing links with local or regional business, and one third said they had provided services for them.

A quarter had been involved in developing business ventures outside their main activities of teaching and research, and a fifth had had contact with university business activities such as science parks, business incubator units and innovation centres.

More than 85% favoured making their services available to businesses, and around two thirds felt their teaching had benefited through links with business.

Stephen Court, the association's senior research officer, said: "If university staff are to play a full part in the knowledge-based economy, as we believe they should, these issues need to be addressed as a matter of priority."

Last week's allocations from the Higher Education Funding Council for England showed a continuing erosion of basic teaching funding, although Sir Brian Fender, the chief executive pointed out that capital resources were better than for several years.

The injection of an extra £100m paid by students themselves will help the expansion of student numbers although it is unlikely to ease the pressure from the leading Russell group universities for much higher fees.

Expanding numbers have brought increases to a number of colleges and universities catering for areas of the country like Cumbria and Wiltshire which have had few places available. Specialist colleges such as the Northern School of Contemporary Dance and Harper Adams agricultural college also did well.

But failure to recruit promised numbers has been punished by holding back grants - more than £1m in the case of Thames Valley University which is challenging the funding council's decision. Other institutions which have suffered severe cuts include London's Institute of Education, the School of Oriental and African Studies, the London School of Economics, Keele and Northumbria (see the Guardian'sEducation Unlimited site for the top 20 winners and losers).

 A condensed version of the report: University staff and the knowledge-based economy is available on the Association of University Teachers' website at: www.aut.org.uk

fields.headline: Nothing like a free market
fields.standfirst: Should universities set their own fees and student intake?  Lee Elliot Major touches a red-hot issue
fields.trailText: Should universities set their own fees and student intake? Lee Elliot Major touches a red-hot issue
fields.body:
Allowing universities to control the number of students they recruit and the tuition fees they charge would deepen the educational divide between the rich and poor, officials have warned, as the debate intensifies over the future funding of the academic sector. University heads last week decided to commission a wide-ranging study of funding "taking account of" the Russell group work on differential fees. After meeting in private in Edinburgh, the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals said: "The study will consider the implications of various funding options for students and their families, for universities and the higher education sector as a whole."

Ensuring that students from underprivileged backgrounds are not excluded from top universities has emerged as the key issue in the radical funding reforms being considered by the 20 elite academic heads known as the Russell group. The proposals, which include deregulating tuition fees and allocating core government teaching grants through open competition, prompted some fierce exchanges behind the scenes among vice-chancellors as they gathered for their residential meeting last week.

One funding council official argued that a free-for-all competition for student numbers and fees would send the university sector on a spiralling path towards further ghettoization, with social backgrounds determining where students enrol for degrees.

"It is no surprise at all that the Russell group would argue for this as they will be sitting pretty," he said. "It will enable them to charge what they like and take as many students as they like. But you end up exposing the other end of the market - the further-education colleges and access-oriented former polytechnics currently struggling to fill student places. They are the ones who are going to have to find ways to fill places by offering discounts. It just reinforces the whole divide."

Yet the Russell-group heads have stressed that the funding schemes being investigated by a group of academic economists have both financial and social goals: they aim to solve the funding crisis in universities, but also improve the low uptake of poor students on degree courses. The proposals are unlikely to retain the backing of the prime minister's policy advisers if they fail to produce a system where academic talent is rewarded irrespective of students' backgrounds.

Sir Brian Follett, vice-chancellor of the University of Warwick, said: "The economists will undertake a detailed appraisal of these and the practical implications of how you put them into place, and the social consequences of putting them in place. The only system acceptable would be one that guaranteed access to higher education for all students, regardless of circumstances."

Few disagree that the current funding arrangements for universities are failing on all fronts. Chancellor Gordon Brown is convinced that universities are the breeding ground for high-tech businesses generating money and jobs in the future.

Yet a survey published by university heads last week highlights growing problems in filling poorly paid academic posts. In terms of the gross domestic product, the UK lags far behind other western countries in government support for universities. And academic institutions remain shackled by government controls over the teaching income they can generate.

The government has unveiled apparently ambitious targets to expand the numbers benefiting from post-school education. Yet its abolition of maintenance grants , against the wishes of the Dearing review, means degrees are likely to remain the preserve for the middle classes.

This is why there are plans to reintroduce bursaries and delay fee payments north of the border. Universities represent a system where society as a whole subsidises the rich, ensuring that they secure the best paid jobs. If graduates enjoy lifelong financial returns for their university education, why shouldn't they pay for the privilege?

The problem facing economists who draw on the US experience of charging fees is that UK universities do not have the multi-billion endowments and alumni donations associated with the top Ivy League institutions. The most likely models for Russell group universities are Ivy League institutions such as Cornell, funded by state and private funds.

Yet even with their reserves, and claims that student admissions are "need blind", Ivy League enrolments are dominated by white middle-class Americans. So much so that a row now rages over "affirmative action" - schemes exclusively geared to recruit other ethnic groups.

One of those weighing up the options for the Russell group, Professor Andrew Oswald, argues that it is in the interests of the universities to recruit gifted students from poor backgrounds. "It will not be that the top half-dozen universities in Britain turn their back on very clever people from ordinary homes, because these are the people that go on to change the world and will benefit most from their university education."

Whatever their final form, the proposals promise to be radical. "Let us be un-British enough to accept that taxpayers should not have to subsidise the learning and earning of youngsters who had the luck to be born clever," Oswald wrote in a recent letter to the Financial Times. "Let us announce that from the year 2015, each British university will become a charity whose capital stock is the property of all of its past students still alive, that there will be a guaranteed level of public funding until then, but that after 2015 all public money except some scholarships and research grants will cease; and that from 2010 all universities can do whatever they wish (including charging fees) to cope with the cut-off point five years later.

"This horizon would allow Britain's parents a decade to make sensible plans."

fields.headline: How good is your Japanese?
fields.standfirst: A translation competition aims to focus attention on Japan's modern literature
fields.trailText: A translation competition aims to focus attention on Japan's modern literature
fields.body:
Good young translators can win a prize worth 1m yen and a year's study in Japan, thanks to an extraordinary initiative by the Shizuoka region to make its literary culture better known.

In the third year of its competition, the Shizuoka board of education is offering prizes for English and German translations of Japanese modern short stories or literary criticism.

The competition is not open to professional translators but is aimed at encouraging interest abroad - the Japanese are well aware that although they have produced Nobel Prize-winning authors, their literature is still little known overseas.

Shizuoka, about the size of Switzerland, lies between Tokyo and Osaka and is home to Mount Fuji. It is proud of its reputation as a home for poets and writers. Toshi hisa Matsuda, executive officer of the translation competition, said: "This is something that the Japanese government should do but we wanted to do something very special. We feel if we do something innovative many people will respect our prefecture and exchanges will take place with the rest of the world."

Besides the top prizes in English and German there will be awards of 300,000 yen and 100,000 yen. Deadline for submissions is December 15.

Entry forms and copies of the texts to be translated are available from: Executive Committee, Izu Literature Festival, Culture Department, Shizuoka Prefectural Board of Education, 9-6 Otemachi, Shizuoka-shi, Shizuoka-ken, 420-8601, Japan; website: www1.sphere.ne.jp/shizuoka or email:shizuoka@po.shere.ne.jp

fields.headline: Feeling the pinch
fields.standfirst: Lee Elliot Major  reports on measures to make the poorest students pay tuition fees
fields.trailText: Lee Elliot Major reports on measures to make the poorest students pay tuition fees
fields.body:
The government is clawing back bursary funds for poor students to force them to pay university tuition fees, it has emerged. The policy has enraged academic leaders at the University of Cambridge who have complained that the mean-minded regulations fly in the face of efforts to widen access to universities, and will create a new poverty trap for cash-strapped students.

Education minister Baroness Blackstone has written to universities confirming the current student support regulations whereby students with bursaries and benefits over £1,820 are forced to start paying tuition fees.

Baroness Perry, who is president of Lucy Cavendish College at Cambridge, said that bursaries to help needy students would be rendered worthless by the ruling. "We are encouraged to increase access and take more people from poorer homes and backgrounds. To help do this some colleges offer bursaries. Now we are told that a large chunk of the bursaries is going to be deducted from their allowance so they can pay it back in fees. It is absolutely mad."

Baroness O'Neill, president of Cambridge's Newnham College, said that the very students for whom bursary support is most vital would gain least by receiving it. Charities and companies, meanwhile, will now be deterred from offering support for poorer students.

The row has come to light amid the first signals that demand for higher education is faltering. English uni versities and colleges failed to fill 14,000 full-time and part-time student places for which they received grants in 1999-2000. Unveiling the latest teaching and research grants last week, the Higher Education Funding Council for England announced that institutions would be allowed a second chance to fill places this academic year.

Overall the council is funding an extra 37,000 student places in 2000-2001, which have to be filled to keep in line with the government's target of 35% of young people participating in higher education by 2002.

Sir Brian Fender, the council's chief executive, insisted the sector was on course to meet the government's target of 100,000 extra students in higher education - part of the 500,000 additional students demanded by the Prime Minister. "There was some under-recruitment last time because the allocation of numbers was quite late and colleges and universities did not have much time. There are students out there to get."

 Sussex University last week became the first in recent years to discipline students for student protest. Seven undergraduates faced possible expulsion for their part in a 40-strong sit-in protest against tuition fees which led to the cancellation of a fundraising dinner with guest Cherie Booth QC last November, writes Helene Mulholland.

They were charged with taking part in the action and refusing to leave when asked to do so, and bringing the university into disrepute. One student had all charges against him dropped, and three have recently faced the panel, walking away with a £200 suspended fine. The remaining three, who face a further charge of joining with others to gain forcible entry by breaking a fire door, are still waiting. Their hearing was delayed as a result of a now concluded police investigation.

Students, who held an 11-day occupation there last summer, believe last year's 18% drop in mature students' applications to Sussex is a direct result of tuition fees and loans. Since 1996, a university renowned for its large mature student population has seen its numbers drop by 9%.
 Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

The remaining three, who face a further charge of joining with others to gain forcible entry by breaking a fire door, are still waiting. Their hearing was delayed as a result of a now concluded police investigation. Students, who held an 11-day occupation there last summer, believe last year's 18% drop in mature students' applications to Sussex is a direct result of tuition fees and loans. Since 1996, a university renowned for its large mature student population has seen its numbers drop by 9%.  Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

fields.headline: Oxford hits the biotech jackpot
fields.standfirst:
Behind the dreaming spires, university is rolling in money after healthcare shares boom

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Threadbare gowns and rusty bicycles could become a thing of the past for Oxford university - the place is suddenly rolling with money after the explosion in the shares of biotechnology companies in the City of London.
fields.body:
Threadbare gowns and rusty bicycles could become a thing of the past for Oxford university - the place is suddenly rolling with money after the explosion in the shares of biotechnology companies in the City of London.

Five of the soaraway healthcare companies on the stock market began life at Oxford. When they became independent, the university was shrewd enough to insist on an equity stake in return for its intellectual property. Those stakes are now worth more than £55m.

The dons are surprisingly coy about their sudden success. Decisions are taken by an investment committee of five eminent fellows, chaired by William Hayes, the president of St John's College. "We own a substantial amount in share value," Dr Hayes admits guardedly. "If the university ever needed a chunk of money, it's there to be cashed in."

The university's biggest success so far is Powderject Pharmaceuticals, which has developed a needle-free injection system under which drugs are blasted through the skin at supersonic speeds by a pen-like device, powered with compressed gas. The idea was hatched at Oxford's Medical Engineering Department, by a group headed by Professor Brian Bellhouse, who is still on Powderject's board.

Analysts believe it could prove a moneyspinner, offering an alternative to patients who have phobias for traditional needles, and getting round the problem of jabs passing on HIV.

Since flotation in 1997, the shares have tripled and the university's 3.7% stake is now worth £20m. So when might the university cash in its stake?

"We wouldn't do anything in the early stages to disturb their share price," says Dr Hayes. "We keep a friendly eye on them to begin with - we know all the people involved, they're all Oxford people." However, he adds: "Once these companies are firmly established on the stock market, we would look at them and decide when to exit."

Among his colleagues on the committee is Earl Cairns, chairman of Allied Zurich. He provides a City view, as a former chief executive of the investment bank SG Warburg. Making up the numbers are two more senior dons and Sir Philip Jones, who is "curator of the university chest".

The university's other growth stocks include a chunk of Oxford BioMedica - a business conceived by husband and wife team Alan and Susan Kingsman. They have developed new gene therapy techniques while working as academics in Oxford's biochemistry department. With treatments for breast and ovarian cancer in the pipeline, it has surged in value to £179m amid genetics enthusiasm.

Oxford BioMedica's finance director, Andrew Wood, says: "The university is a fairly passive shareholder. They've given us freedom to operate - they've allowed the management to manage the business."

Oxford Glycosciences, which develops protein-based medicine, has done equally well, as has Oxford Asymmetry - a specialist in combinatorial chemistry. The only disappointment is Oxford Molecular, a chemical services business which is struggling so much that it has put itself up for sale.

The proceeds from any share disposal would be split three ways. Some would go to the department in which the company originated, some would fund more technology transfer programmes and the rest would go into the university's central funds. But, will the biotech boom benefit Oxford's financially struggling students?

John Clements, the university's director of finance, says: "That's a very difficult question to answer. There isn't a direct link between a particular source of money at one end and specific spending at the other. The whole university community will benefit, though."

The most likely course of action would be for some of the proceeds to be put into an endowment fund, with the interest used to support students. The value of the shares is significant for the university's finances - the institution's income last year was £319m. The government's efforts to end special treatment for Oxbridge has meant a squeeze on funding. So much so that Cambridge is green with envy. Richard Jennings, of Cambridge University's industrial liaison office, says: "None of the companies we've set up here have floated yet. We'd certainly like them to."

The closest yet is Cambridge Display Technology, which makes innovative light-emitting devices which could replace the technology in television sets. The business has just been through a refinancing valuing it at £81m.

"It's probably worth much more than that," says Mr Jennings. "If there was a public offering, we would consider realising some value."

The boom looks set to continue - hi-tech biotechs have replaced "dot.com" companies as targets for many small investors. Just yesterday, the value of Oxford university's shares increased by nearly £3m, as the drugs sector surged further. Enough to fund a few more library books, surely? Dr Hayes is yet to be convinced that it is time to take profits. "Not in the short term," he says. "We will treat these shares just like any other investment organisation would, though." If the university's portfolio keeps soaring, he may find it hard to resist the temptation to get out at the top.
