fields.headline: Literacy on the web
fields.trailText: Surfing with the Bard
fields.body:
Surfing with the Bard

www.ulen.com/shakespeare/

Star rating ***

Aimed at: teachers and pupils

As sexy as Baz Luhrmann's Romeo and Juliet, this US site is genuinely enthusiastic and should be particularly useful for students tackling their first play - not so much for the amount of content but the inspiring "can-do" attitude to studying Shakespeare.

Writers Online

www.yearofreading.org.uk

Star rating ***

Aimed at: everyone

By far the most useful part of the Year of Reading site, Writers Online has invited children's authors to contribute extracts from their books and suggest a follow-on activity. Children can then email their contributions to be read by the authors (who include Anne Fine and Michael Morpurgo) which will be posted on the site. A great idea that should continue.

Wacky Web Tales

www.eduplace.com/tales/

Star rating: ****

Aimed at: everyone

For young budding storytellers, here's a simple idea that helps builds confidence along with an appreciation of parts of speech. Fill in each blank with a word to create an online story; great fun and a good warmer activity.

Wilfred Owen Archive

www.hcu.ox.ac.uk/jtap/

Star rating: ****

Aimed at: teachers

A wealth of primary sources for Owen's poetry: extensive video clips of the first world war, the battlefield sites today, photos, audio clips and Owen's manuscripts, contemporary cartoons and newspapers from the time. The compilers suggest that you create a "path" through the resources to suit your needs; a few exist already and can be browsed online. It takes a bit of time to navigate the archive but it's worth the effort.

Books Unlimited

www.booksunlimited.co.uk/authors

Star rating: ***

Aimed at: everyone

Good reference site including brief but authoritative author biographies with hundreds of links to quirky, interesting sites dedicated to novels and poetry. A good starting-point for research on a particular author.

GCSE Answers

www.gcse.com/recep.htm

Star rating: **

Aimed at: everyone

Not an alternative to revision, unfortunately, but to get an idea of what examiners are looking for, tune in. If you're looking for inspiration or topic-specific help, however, try elsewhere. Full details of syllabi, some good tips for revising and lists of common pitfalls make this useful for pupils who need to build their confidence.

A-level English

www.ndirect.co.uk/~sapere/Alevel/

Star rating: ***

Aimed at: students, teachers

Don't expect ready-made lesson plans or instant advice, but the site does augment school study by pointing you in the direction of other inspiring sites, such as the History Channel archive of famous speeches (www.historychannel.comspeeches/archive.html/).

Poem of the Day

www.poems.com

Star rating: **

Aimed at: everyone

A beautifully minimalist site with an archive of those poems you may have missed. (See also www.sonnets.org if teaching/studying this verse form).

 You can find more English sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Testigo
fields.standfirst: Mikel Torras was with Basque politician Fernando Buesa hours before his murder
fields.trailText: Cinco minutos después del atentado me llamaron al trabajo. Me informaron de la explosión de un coche bomba en el campus universitario de Vitoria. Me dijeron que la víctima era probablemente Fernando Buesa.
fields.body:
Cinco minutos después del atentado me llamaron al trabajo. Me informaron de la explosión de un coche bomba en el campus universitario de Vitoria. Me dijeron que la víctima era probablemente Fernando Buesa.

Me parecía imposible. Tres horas antes había estado con él preparando un mitin para la campaña electoral. Salí corriendo para Vitoria convencido de que la víctima era otra persona. Cuando llegué la zona estaba acordonada y allí había centenares de personas. El sentimiento general era de indignación y rabia. Me confirmaron la mala noticia. Fernando Buesa, el portavoz del partido socialista en el Parlamento Vasco, era la víctima.

Inmediatamente empecé a preparar la manifestación de repulsa al atentado para el día siguiente. "Basta ya. Eta no" fue el grito desde el campus universitario hasta la plaza del Ayuntamiento. Eramos miles de jóvenes en contra de la violencia de Eta. Luego, en la capilla ardiente, rabia contenida y lágrimas era la expresión de las miles de personas que visitaron los restos de Fernando Buesa. Por la noche, unas 60.000 personas acompañaron con aplausos y lanzando flores al féretro la comitiva fúnebre hasta la catedral. Yo creo que nuestra generación verá el final de la violencia de Eta, pero si los partidos políticos no llegan a un acuerdo la solución es muy difícil.

Se trata de un problema de vascos con vascos. Nos conocemos todos. Hemos estudiado juntos en los colegios. Ellos hablan de una opresión del estado español, y que en toda opresión hay lucha, y en la lucha víctimas. Cuando las personas son fanáticas y sus posiciones son fanáticas es imposible cambiar su opinión.

Glosario/Glossary

acordonado cordoned off

el atentado outrage

basta ya that's enough

la capilla ardiente funeral chapel

la comitiva fúnebre funeral procession

el féretro coffin

el grito the shouting

el portavoz spokesperson

la rabla anger, fury

 Mikel Torras was talking to Eulàlia Furriol

fields.headline: Nannying
fields.standfirst: A weely guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: Nannying
fields.body:
What is . . . (sniff)? A nanny?

Yes, but please tread softly with this one. Why?

Memories, old bean, just memories (sniff). Sure. Have a good blow. Feeling better now? Brave soldier!

Yes. Do go on. A nanny is a nursery nurse who is based in a private home rather than a nursery.

Apart from being utterly fantastic . . . (sniff) . . . are there any particular qualifications? No. There are no set qualifications for being a nanny, although most employers will prefer a childcare qualification of some sort.

Making perfect soldiers for dipping in eggies? Picking the best conkers? (sob) That sort of thing? Possibly. The various national nanny agencies have different registration requirements, but basically, a nanny with childcare qualifications can command a higher salary than one without.

Command. Quite so. And there are lots of opportunities for working nationally and internationally, via a relevant agency or as advertised in the national or local press.

Ah. What other talents do nannies need? To be a nanny you should obviously enjoy being with babies and children for more than just a short period of time. Nannies have enormous responsibility, including the physical and emotional development of any child in their care. Duties involve such activities as reading stories aloud . . .

Hurrah! I haven't finished.

Sorry. Assisting with reading and writing, and general educational encouragement . . .

Chiz! Look, don't interrupt . . . leisure activities, playing, feeding and other domestic duties relating to children's welfare. Hours are varied and often long, so energy and stamina are also essential. Being a nanny can be very demanding at times. It's not suitable for people who get stressed out easily.

Those qualifications you mentioned . . . There are a various childcare qualifications, which can be picked up through part-time or full-time study.

Such as. CACHE - that is a Certificate in ChildCare and Education. There are no set entry requirements although individual colleges may set their own.

And? A CACHE Diploma in Nursery Nursing (NNEB): there are no set entry requirements for this either, but many colleges ask for some GCSEs (A-C), often including English. The BTEC National Diploma/Certificate in Early Years, but that needs a minimum of four GCSEs or a relevant BTEC first award, such as the First Diploma in Caring, or an Intermediate GNVQ, or equivalent qualifications.

Specialist private Nursery Nurse/Nanny colleges:

Norland College, near Hungerford, Berkshire 01488 685082

Chiltern College near Reading, Berkshire 0118 947 1847

Princess Christian College near Manchester 0161 224 4560

Agencies include:

Elite Nannies : applicants must be 19 plus with childcare qualification or experience. Contact Robert Bannon on 01903 693718 or email: elite@lineone.net

Au pair International Employment Agency. Applicants must be 18 plus and should have NNEB or similar qualification. Contact 0161 612 2676

learndirect 0800 100 900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses

webTitle: Amid the filth, the first sign of disease

fields.headline: Amid the filth, the first sign of disease
fields.standfirst:
A strategy to lure Mozambicans to safer ground exposes them to other risks

Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: A United Nations strategy of withholding aid from flood-stricken towns and villages in Mozambique, in an attempt to pressure residents to move to refugee camps, has left thousands of people desperate for clean drinking water and food, and at risk from disease.
fields.body:
A United Nations strategy of withholding aid from flood-stricken towns and villages in Mozambique, in an attempt to pressure residents to move to refugee camps, has left thousands of people desperate for clean drinking water and food, and at risk from disease.

The UN fears that, with more heavy rains forecast in the next two days, floods could again swallow up areas hit by the torrent of water that swept down the Limpopo and Save rivers 10 days ago.

It wants people to move to camps on higher ground. But the policy is punishing residents of towns such as Chokwe, where thousands of people who survived the earlier flood in trees and on roofs are refusing to abandon their homes.

The UN and aid agencies are concentrating aid on a refugee camp at Chaquelan, 25 miles from Chokwe. But the town received its first food only yesterday. And while the camp has three water purification plants, none has been delivered to Chokwe, even though the scorching summer sun has returned and the only available water is from stagnant pools, some contaminated with human corpses.

At the Catholic church yesterday, hundreds of mothers queued with young children for two doctors giving rehydration fluid and treatment for malaria and tuberculosis. The babies' desperate cries mingled with ominous coughs. Some children begged for water. The mothers faced the awful choice of ignoring their pleas or quenching their babies' thirst with the filthy remnants of the flood.

The torrent of water has left a tide mark about 9ft-high on the walls of the church, which was home to many of Chokwe's Aids sufferers before the floods. The floor is thick with mud, some cleared to make way for the new patients. In the corridor, a young girl on a reed mat awaits treatment for malaria. Volunteers wash the mud from packets of medicines. Bandages caked in filth are laid out in the sun to dry alongside the tuberculosis records.

One doctor, Sister Elisa Verdu, despairs at a lack of assistance to Chokwe even though Mozambique is now the target of the biggest foreign aid airlift in Africa since the Rwanda crisis six years ago.

"There are a lot of people here with malaria. We don't even have enough of the basic medicines. We don't have drinking water. There's no food. There's nothing. No one has come here," she said.

The price of food has risen several times over. Without clean water, the threat of disease is as great as in the camps. Stagnant pools are a haven for mosquitoes.

The UN special envoy, Ross Mountain, is overseeing the policy of concentrating assistance on camps which he says house 250,000 refugees. "We have pleaded with people not to go back to their homes. If there is more flooding they will have to be rescued again and that will take resources away from getting food and water to people who need it," he said.

The World Food Programme finally delivered two tonnes of maize to Chokwe yesterday. But a WFP official, Lindsey Davis, said there were no plans to send purification equipment. "That's a problem. Water is a big problem," she said.

Felix Nacimiento is one of the die-hards refusing to leave Chokwe. He survived the flash flood by climbing on to a school roof, where he stayed for five days. Yesterday he sat next to a large pool of floodwater, washing the mud from a dismantled fan.

"We survived the floods. Why should we leave now?" he said. "Nothing will make me leave, even another flood. I will just climb up again, but this time I will remember to take some food."

Mr Nacimiento's house was shin deep in the mire when the waters receded. He shovelled out the dirt, washed the walls as best he could and put his furniture out on the road to dry. "Everything is destroyed in this town. Look at the school. They were repairing it and now all that work is wasted," he said.

The water tore down buildings and uprooted telegraph poles. Part of the town is under water, and the fields that fed its 60,000 residents have turned to marsh.

Near the school, a corpse lies in the middle of the street. Someone has covered it in leaves. Elsewhere, the dead have been buried in shallow roadside graves, but the stench of rotting bodies wafts from pools.

Reconstruction will take a while. The town centre was looted, partly for food and partly by opportunists. There is anger at "the pirates" - young men in boats who robbed houses during the floods. The only signs of contentment came from a few pigs, rooting in the sodden grass.

Help pours in as country counts cost

Refugees

The UN says at least 250,000 are being cared for in 64 makeshift camps, principally around the Limpopo and Save rivers. The government says 1m people have been driven from their homes or have lost their crops. They will need food aid for several months while they replant and gather a fresh harvest.

Rescues

14,204 people were airlifted to safety by the South African air force. Two Malawian military helicopters rescued 1,500 people. Hundreds more were saved by individuals in boats.

Aid

Yesterday 41 helicopters and 15 planes operating from Maputo and Beira airlifted food and medical supplies along a 1,000-mile front. The helicopters include four British Pumas. Five more are expected this week. Air traffic controllers in Maputo, who have no radar, are handling a record 200 flights a day. More than 100 boats, mostly from the UK, have also been delivered, along with RNLI crews and other volunteers. More than 500 British, German, Spanish, Portuguese and French troops are already in the country. About 100 American soldiers are in South Africa to prepare for another 600 US troops expected in Mozambique this week.

Donors

Britain is the largest donor, having pledged£3.6m,followed by Italy, the Netherlands and the US, which is giving £2m. The UN is paying £110,000 for disaster assessment staff.

Damage

One-third of Mozambique's staple maize crop has been destroyed and large numbers of cattle are dead or dying. Many asphalt roads are badly damaged or swept away, including the vital route to South Africa, which is now reduced to light traffic only. The main highway north from Maputo to the port of Beira is severed in places. The same is true of the railway. Aid and internal trade have to go by air. President Chissano said reconstruction will cost at least £160m, and pleaded with creditors to forgive the foreign debt.

The official death toll remains 200 but will rise once the full extent of the devastation is laid bare. Already dozens of bodies have turned up in individual towns. But the final toll is unlikely to be known, because it is believed many victims near the coast were washed out to sea.

The floods have also badly hit South Africa, Zimbabwe and now Zambia. Unicef says 600,000 people are homeless in Madagascar after last week's cyclone there.

webTitle: Six are injured by Basque bomb

fields.headline: Six are injured by Basque bomb
fields.standfirst: Bombs in Madrid: special report
fields.trailText: A car bomb exploded in the Basque coastal resort of San Sebastian last night, injuring two paramilitary civil guards and four civilians. The attack bore all the hallmarks of the separatist group ETA.
fields.body:
A car bomb exploded in the Basque coastal resort of San Sebastian last night, injuring two paramilitary civil guards and four civilians. The attack bore all the hallmarks of the separatist group ETA.

The civil guards, a man and a woman, were driving to the corps's main Basque headquarters when a parked car exploded, scattering debris over a wide area. Police believe the bomb was detonated by remote control, a technique used by ETA in two attacks this year.

The civil guards were saved by their vehicle's armour plating and suffered only light injuries. Four civilians travelling in a car behind them also suffered light injuries.

The bomb is almost certainly the third terrorist action by ETA since the group ended a 14-month ceasefire in December.

It comes just six days before Spaniards vote in a general election on Sunday. Herri Batasuna, ETA's political wing, will not be standing in the election, which it has urged voters to boycott.

"This is clearly the latest episode in a campaign designed to intimidate people and stop them voting," said Manuel Huertas, a local Socialist politician, said.

webTitle: Protocol on gene research at risk as firm demands exclusive rights

fields.headline: Protocol on gene research at risk as firm demands exclusive rights
fields.trailText: Secret talks between the private and public bodies racing to decipher the human genetic code collapsed yesterday when the US company involved insisted on delaying the release of important information for commercial reasons.
fields.body:
Secret talks between the private and public bodies racing to decipher the human genetic code collapsed yesterday when the US company involved insisted on delaying the release of important information for commercial reasons.

Celera, the US genetics company, and the Human Genome Project, a publicly funded multinational research group, started talking late last year about pooling research efforts in an attempt to speed up the process.

But the talks foundered on the company's insistence that publication of any information - expected to transform certain areas of medical research - was delayed for several years in order to prevent commercial rivals from using it.

Cracking the DNA code which maps human life is the holy grail of the scientific world. It is expected to introduce a new generation of drugs and treatments for a range of inherited illnesses.

The importance of the research prompted the establishment of the Human Genome Project in 1990. But in recent years companies such as Celera have moved closer to the goal of creating a complete map. Public campaigners fear that their control of the code, legally secured with patents, could impede breakthroughs by other researchers.

The extent of the differences between the two sides emerged in a letter to Celera marked "confidential", which was leaked over the weekend. In this letter, written at the end of February, leaders of the Human Genome Project accused the company of misusing its stranglehold over the industry.

"While establishing a monopoly on commercial uses of the human genome sequence may be in Celera's business interest, it is not in the best interests of science or the general public," it said.

The letter explained the reason for the talks by adding: "Humankind will be better served if we can find a viable way to join forces to produce a better product in a more timely fashion."

The Human Genome Project had been expected to decipher the code by 2003, but Celera, based in Maryland, expects to do so by June. The company could barely conceal its annoyance over the leaking of the letter the day before it was expected to give an official response.

Heather Kowalski, Celera's spokeswoman, said: "[This issue] is far too important to continue to be debated in the marketplace." Future talks between the two sides appear unlikely following the breakdown of the talks.

In two reports on the issue, Craig Venter, Celera's president and chief scientific officer, called the leaking of the letter "a low-life thing to do", while Tony White, chairman of PE Corp, Celera's parent company, described it as "slimy".

The letter, apparently leaked by the Wellcome Trust of Britain, reveals that the main stumbling block to any agreement was Celera's position on when the information would be released. The Human Genome Project has previously espoused the immediate release of information, but it had agreed for a delay of between six months and a year in its negotiations with Celera in order to safeguard commercial sensitivities.

But Celera had asked for five years of exclusive rights, arguing that it did not want the millions of dollars it had spent on research to benefit rivals. The company also wanted to publish the information on its website.

The US department of energy, which along with the Wellcome Trust was one of the main backers of the $3bn Human Genome Project, was unavailable for comment yesterday.

Celera has also created a database for the Drosophila, or fruitfly. It has already applied for more than 6,000 patents based on its genetic research.

webTitle: Tobacco company faces inquiry into smuggling

fields.headline: Tobacco company faces inquiry into smuggling
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers is poised to order an official Whitehall inquiry into British American Tobacco's exploitation of cigarette smuggling around the globe.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers is poised to order an official Whitehall inquiry into British American Tobacco's exploitation of cigarette smuggling around the globe.

The trade secretary is preparing to send inspectors into the company to investigate growing evidence that the London-based firm knowingly supplied smugglers.

Mr Byers is ready to send in a department of trade and industry (DTI) inspection team if a Commons health select committee report recommends the investigation.

A senior source in his department said last night: "We've always suspected this is what they were up to. If there's a clear recommendation from the select committee, then the DTI will act on that. The recommendation would be the trigger."

The secretary of state has the power to order an inquiry into the role of BAT's directors under section 432 of the 1985 companies act.

Inspectors can be asked to look at allegations of suspected fraud or misconduct or evidence that shareholders have been denied information they could have reasonably expected to receive.

The threat of a DTI investigation hangs over BAT, the world's second biggest tobacco company, selling 900m cigarettes a year, after the Guardian disclosed how it exploited smuggling in Latin America and Asia.

Mr Byers signalled his readiness to act in a letter to Clive Bates, director of Ash, the anti-smoking group.

"As you will be aware, this matter is now under consideration by the health select committee.

"I feel that it's appropriate that I should wait for their report and recommendations before deciding what action my department should take," Mr Byers wrote.

MPs on the health select committee will consider proposing an inquiry this Thursday after a bad-tempered hearing with Martin Broughton, BAT's chairman, and Kenneth Clarke, the company's deputy chairman.

Mr Broughton angered members by ripping up evidence and dismissing the session as a "kangaroo court" while Mr Clarke, a former Tory chancellor, claimed he had not read crucial documents despite giving the firm a clean bill of health.

Detailed evidence of BAT's involvement in smuggling was discovered in company documents lodged in its Guildford depository as part of the settlement to a US court case.

BAT has already been forced to initiate an internal probe headed by Rupert Pennant-Rea, chairman of the company's audit committee and a former deputy governor of the Bank of England.

The firm is signed up to the Turnbull Code on good corporate governance and Mr Pennant-Rea is expected to make an interim statement at the firm's annual meeting on April 27.

A BAT spokesman said it would not speculate on the health select committee's conclusions or possible DTI action.

"We have had no indication from them. I would not want to comment publicly on the DTI," he said.

A DTI inquiry would be highly embarrassing for BAT and might only be avoided if the all-party Commons committee fails to agree a unanimous report.

The two Conservative members will be under intense pressure not to back an inquiry into a company which employs Mr Clarke as a director.

Mr Bates, of Ash, who also gave evidence to the health committee, said: "Whether you think BAT are innocent or guilty, the right way to get an independent assessment of the evidence is for DTI inspectors to go through it with a fine tooth comb.

"I cannot imagine that anyone concerned about high standards of corporate conduct and governance would want anything other than a proper DTI investigation to clear BAT's name or throw the book at them."

fields.headline: Alba offers £199 online TV
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Plans to create millions of new internet customers via television sets costing less than £200 each were unveiled yesterday by Alba, the consumer electronics company.
fields.body:
Plans to create millions of new internet customers via television sets costing less than £200 each were unveiled yesterday by Alba, the consumer electronics company.

Shares in the London firm soared by almost a quarter as it revealed how the new TV will plug into the normal telephone line, allowing viewers to switch with a click of a button from Coronation Street to the Tesco website, for example.

The scheme comes after the net search engine company Alta Vista announced its scheme to provide free telephone calls to users for an annual fee.

Alba expects to sell 750,000 of its Bush television sets in the first 12 months but analysts believe that is a conservative figure.

The sets will double as a normal television receiver and internet access device, with built-in equipment and a £199 price tag. Set-top boxes which can plug into ordinary television sets will be even cheaper, starting at £99. Currently internet access is limited to customers subscribing to a digital television service or computer users. Getting online can be expensive and complicated but Danial Harris, chief executive of Alba, says his scheme makes the internet "open to all".

The Alba sets will be available in June from Bush retailers which include Argos and Woolworths. Alba's shares rose 195p to £10.25.

fields.headline: Pearson in education alliance
fields.standfirst:
Pact with AOL boosts shares
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Media group Pearson claimed yesterday it will become a key supplier of educational content on the web following a tie-up with internet service provider America Online.
fields.body:
Media group Pearson claimed yesterday it will become a key supplier of educational content on the web following a tie-up with internet service provider America Online.

The agreement with AOL builds on Pearson's Simon & Shuster division which the group bought in 1998 to make it the world's biggest educational publisher.

Pearson will become the preferred supplier of educational content to AOL and the pair will work together to develop original services aimed at primary school children through to adults. The business which will be licensed to schools may be spun off at a later date.

Shares in Pearson climbed almost 8% to £24.85 following the announcement of the deal and year-end results at the top end of expectations.

The educational network will begin in the US with content tailored to local curriculums. Pearson chief executive Marjorie Scardino, who is also a non-executive director of AOL, likened educational content at present online to rummaging through a car boot sale. "The quality is variable, you don't know if you can trust it or if it is related to your curriculum. We aim to change all that."

The plans are part of the internet strategy outlined in January when Pearson raised £250m to ease its passage on to the web. A handful of investments in dot.com compa nies already operating in the educational sector was also announced yesterday.

Among other plans, FT.com, Pearson's online version of the Financial Times will be relaunched with a marketing drive in the US next week while FTMarketWatch, the online service for retail investors, is poised for launch in Britain.

Last year FT.com tripled revenues to £6m and page views per month to 22m. "The internet is integral to everything we do," Ms Scardino said. "But we are not interested in it for itself but for what it can do for our customers." Pearson's incursions online have prompted a rerating of the group in the past six months and caused its share price to double.

Pearson reported a 15% increase in pre-tax profits to £402m on a 39% growth in turnover to £3.3bn. Revenues from internet-related ventures reached £500m last year.

The Financial Times newspaper raised profits by 33% to £56m but the wider FT group reported flat earnings of £114m after £36m of investment in online operations. Pearson Television increased operating profit by 11% to £68m and Penguin was 35% higher at £65m.

Education, which was transformed by the Simon & Schuster acquisition, is now more than half of the group and posted an operating profit of £257m.

The company announced plans to seek a dual listing for its shares on the New York stock exchange.

fields.headline: PlayStation sets new top score
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sony said yesterday it had sold 980,000 of its PlayStation2 video game consoles since the Saturday launch, nearly matching its sales target of 1m for the first two days.
fields.body:
Sony said yesterday it had sold 980,000 of its PlayStation2 video game consoles since the Saturday launch, nearly matching its sales target of 1m for the first two days.

That was more than 10 times the sales scored by the original PlayStation console in the same period when it was launched five years ago, the company said. The figures included consoles sold over the internet but not yet delivered to customers.

Sony's shipments seemed to have fallen short of demand and it admitted that production was 10 days behind schedule due to a shortage of memory cards.

Of 380,000 units sold online, only 120,000 had been delivered, the company said, adding that deliveries should be completed in two weeks.

Sony said it expected the memory card shortage to be solved by mid-March and for total PlayStation2 shipments to reach 1.4m units by the end of the month. It originally forecast shipments of 1.5m by that time.

It also said it had shipped 1.3m PlayStation2 games and that the console, which can play digital video discs, had boosted DVD sales, with video stores having ordered double to quadruple their usual number of DVDs since Saturday.

Many analysts have said the console, priced at ¥39,800 (£240), takes home entertainment to a new dimension with life-like animation as well as the capacity to play DVDs and surf the net.

The PlayStation and the games that go with it are a rich profit seam for Sony, which already holds 70% share of the world games console market.
fields.bodyText: Sony said yesterday it had sold 980,000 of its PlayStation2 video game consoles since the Saturday launch, nearly matching its sales target of 1m for the first two days. That was more than 10 times the sales scored by the original PlayStation console in the same period when it was launched five years ago, the company said. The figures included consoles sold over the internet but not yet delivered to customers. Sony's shipments seemed to have fallen short of demand and it admitted that production was 10 days behind schedule due to a shortage of memory cards. Of 380,000 units sold online, only 120,000 had been delivered, the company said, adding that deliveries should be completed in two weeks. Sony said it expected the memory card shortage to be solved by mid-March and for total PlayStation2 shipments to reach 1.4m units by the end of the month. It originally forecast shipments of 1.5m by that time. It also said it had shipped 1.3m PlayStation2 games and that the console, which can play digital video discs, had boosted DVD sales, with video stores having ordered double to quadruple their usual number of DVDs since Saturday. Many analysts have said the console, priced at ¥39,800 (£240), takes home entertainment to a new dimension with life-like animation as well as the capacity to play DVDs and surf the net. The PlayStation and the games that go with it are a rich profit seam for Sony, which already holds 70% share of the world games console market.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Speedster No 2 computer chip maker Advanced Micro Devices unveiled the first 1 gigahertz computer chip yesterday.
fields.body:
 Speedster No 2 computer chip maker Advanced Micro Devices unveiled the first 1 gigahertz computer chip yesterday, beating Intel to the punch. AMD said it had begun shipments of 1 GHz Athlon processors to Compaq and Gateway. Intel also is expected to follow shortly, perhaps later this week. "Achieving production of the gigahertz processor is the chip industry's equivalent of breaking the sound barrier," said Steve Lapinski of AMD, but industry analysts questioned how many of the new chips AMD would supply in the next few months.

 Jobs Recruitment firm Spring Group yesterday launched the Spring.com website and a Springtelligence web portal. Spring.com will enable IT professionals to submit job requirements and view skills and availability profiles of job seekers while individuals will be able to search for vacancies. Spring said it had allied with Legal & General , PHH , Bupa , Moat House Hotels and the Giant Group to offer Spring.com users a range of services.

 Debut Music site Online Classics said it had secured an agreement with tenor Jose Cura to film three operas to be staged specifically for the camera and for streaming live on the company's website.

 Sport Financier Netvest.com said it led a consortium to invest $2.5m (£1.6m) with CNBC Sports International to create a global internet sports business, eGolf . Netvest said eGolf would provide golfers with a "one stop shop" on the internet.

 Conceptual Desktop search tool Webcheck was launched by Dialog yesterday. WebCheck eliminates the need to open browsers, use search engines or type simple key word searches. It allows users to do concept-based searching as simply as spellchecking, Dialog said.

webTitle: Russians admit big losses in Chechen gorge

fields.headline: Russians admit big losses in Chechen gorge
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Almost an entire company of elite Russian paratroops was wiped out in a dawn ambush by guerrillas in the southern highlands of Chechnya, according to reports which reached the Russian capital yesterday.
fields.body:
Almost an entire company of elite Russian paratroops was wiped out in a dawn ambush by guerrillas in the southern highlands of Chechnya, according to reports which reached the Russian capital yesterday.

In the latest embarrassing setback for Moscow, which claims that it has won the war, the reports yesterday from the north-western Russian town of Pskov - home to the elite 76th airborne guards division - said that between 60 and 80 paratroops were killed in fighting in the Argun gorge.

The news came as 20 Russian police, killed in a Chechen ambush on a convoy outside Grozny last week, were buried outside Moscow.

The threat posed by the rebel hit-and-run tactics caused the government yesterday to call off two trips to Chechnya by Russian and international human rights monitors.

General Gennady Troshev, a Russian commander in Chechnya, admitted on Sunday that 31 paratroops were killed in the Argun gorge in battles near the villages of Ulus-Kurt and Selmentausen. "We couldn't avoid casualties," he said.

But yesterday Russian television and newspapers said at least 60 paratroopers had died in the fighting early last Friday. An officer in the Pskov division did not deny the higher figures.

The governor of the Pskov region, Yevgeni Mikhailov, said he had been told that 60 to 80 paratroops had been killed in the mountains.

"The Pskov paratroops, keeping up defences along a 300-metre stretch in the mountains, found themselves at the epicentre of a breakthrough by at least 1,500 fighters, a Pskov newspaper reported. "Two neighbouring companies also engaged in the unequal battle. The tragedy took place at 5am in thick fog." The dead were said to include at least nine officers.

Moscow has estimated that 5,000 Chechen guerrillas are trapped in the mountains in bleak conditions, and the Russian military is hammering them unremittingly with air and artillery strikes.

But the Chechens were also said to have captured the mountain village of Komsomolskoye on Sunday night, and were defying attempts yesterday to evict them. A Russian officer at a checkpoint near the village said up to 50 Russian troops had been killed in the fighting there.

Even in the destroyed Chechen capital Grozny, rebel snipers hiding in the ruins continue to kill Russians.

Russia's acting president, Vladimir Putin, claimed on Sunday that the guerrillas were no longer able to mount any resistance. "There is no guerrilla war on Chechen territory," the defence minster, Igor Sergeyev, declared.

The declarations of victory appear lamentably premature as the rebels launch their long-threatened partisan war.

Richard Norton-Taylor adds: Russian troops are supplying Chechen fighters with ammunition in exchange for money or household goods, Ilyas Akhmadov, the foreign minister in Chechnya's rebel government, said yesterday.

"As long as there are Russians in Chechnya, we will have no problem getting weapons," he claimed. "Russian military garrisons are in touch with Chechens." The rebels were also getting aid from other regions in the Russian federation, and were receiving money from "purely private sources", including Islamic communities in Turkey.

Mr Akhmadov is visiting Britain to drum up support for the Chechen cause. He is due to see foreign office officials later this week.

He dismissed Moscow's claims that its troops were in control in Chechnya. "They are like a wild boar bitten by lots of dogs [that] does not know how to attack," he said. He estimated that 4,000 Rusian soldiers had been killed since January, and up to 2,000 rebel fighters and 25,000 civilians.

The foreign office said it would question Mr Akhmadov about the deaths of three Britons and a New Zealander in Grozny in 1998. The men were telephone engineers employed by Granger Telecom, of Weybridge, Surrey.

Mr Akhmadov suggested that they were killed by bandits, two of whom were later murdered by relatives of the people who had promised the engineers safe conduct.

fields.headline: 'Tougher' rules for refugees delayed
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: In a climbdown over his "tough" treatment of asylum seekers, the home secretary last night delayed the system of national dispersal and vouchers for more than 60% of new arrivals.
fields.body:
In a climbdown over his "tough" treatment of asylum seekers, the home secretary last night delayed the system of national dispersal and vouchers for more than 60% of new arrivals.

Jack Straw has been forced into the delay because of the shortage of accommodation offered by local authorities and private landlords outside the south-east.

The change, under which new asylum seekers are banned from claiming welfare benefits and from living in London and the south-east, is to go ahead from April 3 but only for the 40% who claim asylum when they arrive at an airport or seaport.

The 60% who apply "in-country" after they have arrived in Britain will be able to claim a mixture of cash, social security and housing benefit and live in London and the south-east while their asylum claims are considered. About 41,000 of the 71,000 applicants last year fell into this category.

Local authorities had been asked for up to 40,000 bed spaces but have only come up with 4,000 places. Private landlords are offering to make up some of the difference but it is not enough to implement the change in one go. The new system will not affect asylum seekers who are already living in London and the south-east and are waiting for their claims to be determined.

The immigration minister, Barbara Roche, admitted the decision reflected on problems in the home office immigration and nationality directorate. "A phased implementation is the sensible course," she said.

"The arrangements have been tested in simulated trials. Bringing port applicants onto the scheme first will enable the national asylum support service to deal with any teething difficulties before rolling out the scheme fully."

She said those 40% of applicants who claimed asylum on the day they arrived after April 3 would be given accommodation "on a no-choice basis in cluster areas". Their essential living needs would be met either in kind or by the provision of vouchers and there would be a weekly £10 per person voucher "which can be exchanged for cash".

During the stormy passage of the asylum legislation through parliament ministers made the concession that families with children making asylum applications would not have to live on vouchers unless the government could guarantee them a decision and appeal result within six months.

Mrs Roche said last night it had been decided the new arrangements would cover those families. Of new family applications made in the eight weeks after November 1 more than 70% had received an initial decision within two months. The average waiting time at the end of January was, she said, 13 weeks.

In another exception, applicants who are taken to the Oakington reception centre, near Cambridge, to have their claims processed will be transferred to the voucher system regardless of where they lodged their asylum claim.

The Local Government Association last night said it was disappointed that the dispersal scheme was to be phased in. "Dispersal is more cost-effective and relieves the pressure on London, Kent and the surrounding authorities. This phased approach can only add to the financial and operational pressures on local authorities," said the LGA chief executive, Brian Briscoe.

"This can only mean one thing - either cutting back on frontline services like education and social services or hiking up council taxes."

fields.headline: Pinochet's lord and lady
fields.standfirst: Pinochet: special report
fields.trailText: Not since Sir Richard Grenville's heroic death on The Revenge 400 years ago has there been such a moving sacrifice for British imperialism against Spain than Lady Thatcher's gift of an "Armada plate" to Pinochet, the former dictator of Chile. She splashed out £500 for the silver plate, modestly inscribed it with her signature and satirically described it as "a rebuff to Spanish colonialism".
fields.body:
Not since Sir Richard Grenville's heroic death on The Revenge 400 years ago has there been such a moving sacrifice for British imperialism against Spain than Lady Thatcher's gift of an "Armada plate" to Pinochet, the former dictator of Chile. She splashed out £500 for the silver plate, modestly inscribed it with her signature and satirically described it as "a rebuff to Spanish colonialism".

Some cartoonists concluded from this story that Thatcher has finally lost her marbles, but I disagree. I regard it as a vindication of Salman Rushdie's characterisation of Mrs Thatcher in his 1988 novel The Satanic Verses as Mrs Torture. I thought this was a bit hard at the time, but her grovelling generosity to the ghastly old torturer Pinochet entirely vindicates Salman Rushdie. Even in his wildest moments the novelist could not have imagined a once-elected British prime minister signing silver plate for a dictator who seized power by force of arms from an elected government, and set about systematically murdering his elected opponents, burning their books and torturing their supporters.

The presentation of the silver plate should also be a warning to anyone who feels complacent about the strength of British democracy. Perhaps the most surprising hagiographer of Pinochet was the former moderate, Lord Lamont. At the numerous court hearings involving Pinochet, Lamont was treated as an honoured guest. A special seat was made available for him.

His theme in all his interviews was that Pinochet, who was never elected, was much preferable to Salvador Allende, the prime minister he toppled and killed, who was elected, twice. Lamont constantly referred to the apparently horrifying fact that a batch of rifles was found in Allende's presidential palace. It did not occur to him that these rifles may have been stored to protect the president from an armed coup of the type which eventually killed him.

Lord Lamont himself is no longer an elected MP. One of the more satisfying moments in the general election was his defeat at Harrogate - a once-safe Tory seat. The exquisite pleasure of such moments can only be marred by the fear that the defeated candidate may approach the CIA with a view to reinstating himself as MP for Harrogate and replacing the elected prime minister with Mrs Torture.

 Once, there was a Labour party, which came into existence to represent labour. Then came New Labour with a new plan: to represent labour and business. Now, in another turn hardly noticed in the press, Stephen Byers, New Labour's secretary of state for trade and industry, tells the House of Commons (on March 2): "We are a listening party, putting the interests of business first." Surely the time has come for another name change - to Business party, perhaps, or preferably, since we have at least two of those already, New Business party.

 The "revelations" last week about the refusal of a visa to the former leader of the Russian revolution, Leon Trotsky, seemed rather stale buns which could have been found in the Trotsky archives or in the third volume of Isaac Deutscher's biography of Trotsky, published in 1963.

There are some interesting lessons in the story for today's Labour government. Trotsky got the idea of seeking asylum in Britain from Sidney and Beatrice Webb who visited him in exile in Turkey in February 1929, and told him that Labour expected to win the general election later that year. They encouraged him to apply for asylum in Britain. They warned him, however, that a Labour government would probably have to rely on the support of the Liberals, who would almost certainly resist his application.

Soon after the Webbs got back to Britain, a Labour government was elected, and Sidney Webb, as Lord Passfield, got into the cabinet. The new government depended on the support of the Liberals. Trotsky applied for a visa. The Liberals vociferously supported his application. So did the Observer and the Manchester Guardian, Bernard Shaw, HG Wells, JM Keynes, Arnold Bennett, Ellen Wilkinson and even the Bishop of Birmingham. Sustained opposition came instead from Labour ministers, who were terrified of upsetting the Russian dictator Stalin.

The visa was refused, as were similar applications all over Europe. Trotsky was eventually hounded to Mexico where he was murdered by one of Stalin's agents.

Trotsky was both irritated and amused by his failure to get into Britain. "This one-act comedy on the theme of democracy and its principles might have been written by Bernard Shaw," he observed - and could not resist adding "if the Fabian fluid in his veins had been strengthened by as much as 5% of Jonathan Swift's blood".

fields.headline: No, minister
fields.standfirst:
A new report challenges the government to increase the powers held by select committees and bring them into the 21st century

Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: A new report challenges the government to increase the powers held by select committees and bring them into the 21st century
fields.body:
Consider the following list of ornaments of the House of Commons: Donald Anderson, Andrew Bennett, Archy Kirkwood, Peter Brooke, Sir Sydney Chapman, Robin Corbett. David Davis, Giles Radice, Gwyneth Dunwoody, Barry Sheerman, Derek Foster, Nicholas Winterton.

Recognise them? A couple, maybe three come somewhere near the threshold of public recognition. Yet these people ought to be pillars of democracy. That they labour in twilight is an indictment of our system of government.

They are chairs of various of the Commons's select committees, listed in the box, with the power to command ministers and their advisers to answer questions a lot more detailed than ever get thrown across the floor of the house. It is not just that they underperform in the task of subjecting the executive - ministers and their departmental officials - to tougher scrutiny. It is also that their impotence is a waste. Some of these leading backbenchers are experienced and probably as able as the people who do hold ministerial office. They could be put to better use. For the first time they have set out how they could be (see link at bottom of page).

This report from the liaison committee of chairs of select committees is important, not just as a public exercise in self-criticism. It is also a marker for the future of representative government. Giles Radice, the Labour MP and chief of the treasury committee who chaired the exercise, is modest. He and colleagues - Davis, Brooke and Winterton are Tories - are not asking for major changes in procedure, though they do want more staff, better publicity and a change of attitude towards their work on the part of civil servants. Their plea now disappears into the Bermuda triangle of Commons reform patrolled by arch-conservative Anne Taylor, Labour's chief whip, and Margaret Beckett, leader of the house. If it does not emerge, that will not just say that the Blair government is as executive-minded as its predecessors (with the exception of that brief honeymoon period in 1979 when Margaret Thatcher allowed Norman St John-Stevas to create the departmental scrutiny system we have got.) It will also show that 1997's MPs, newcomers, babes, Kilfoylites and all are a supine bunch who cannot even get it together to bring their own procedures within five decades of the 21st century.

Select committees have a pedigree going back to the grand committee on evils (1623) and the committee on the Queen of Scotts of 1572. (Are MPs more subservient to Tony than they were to Elizabeth of England? - discuss.) In the two decades of their modern form, the set of committees dedicating to individual Whitehall departments have become a fixture. "At a bargain price, it has provided independent scrutiny of government. It has enabled the questioning of ministers and civil servants, and has forced them to explain policies". Yet when Stuart Weir and David Beetham of Democratic Audit reviewed the evidence last year they found they had "little influence" on policy. Too often the committees are amateurish; members fail to turn up; reports are ignored. The public accounts committee has a special position as the employer of the comptroller and auditor general and his 800-odd staff in the national audit office. But its remit is public money after it has been spent. The paltry attendance at the annual debate on its work on the floor of the Commons shows how much MPs are engaged.

The usual case for beefing them up is (as this report puts it) to shift the balance between legislative and executive, so making the government of the country more accountable and maybe even more effective. If MPs were more involved in scrutinising bills before they entered the sausage machine of law-making, defects might be spotted and their stickability improved. But that (the report recognises) would require MPs to behave like professionals. When I worked in the US house of representatives for a congressman from Michigan, his Washington office was some half-dozen strong and for his contributions to the powerful ways and means (public finance) committee he could call on banks of experts. The American constitution is not a model for the UK; ways and means is far from an exemplary committee; but the operations of select committees in the Commons proves the old adage about paying peanuts. (Commons staff are generally good; there are just too few of them.)

The best case for reform, which the liaison report hints at, is that it would answer the question what should we do with all those lobby-fodder MPs. Those not sucked into the executive machine spend their time as glorified citizens' advice bureaux. Giles Radice and colleagues want to construct an "alternative career path". The question they do not directly address, however, is what happens to the bonds of party loyalty if backbenchers start to become powers in the land. They say outright that party whips should keep their noses out of how MPs are chosen to sit. But that bid for greater pluralism will reduce the potency of ministers, especially the prime minister. Under proportional representation such "weakness" might become the norm. Perhaps electoral reform is a precondition for resurrection of the back benches.

To make their mark, select committees are going to need disciplinary powers. The report hopes that "a sub-standard response" by a minister "should automatically result in [the offender] spending an uncomfortable morning or afternoon supplying what was missing". But that is only going to work inside a culture where cocking a snook at the Commons is actionable; that surely implies the Commons having power to make a minister pay, perhaps even to apply more regularly the threat of loss of office. But that in turns means the prime minister sharing power, maybe even co-ownership, of public policy making.

Commons select committees:

Fifteen scrutinise individual departments, from agriculture to Welsh affairs but not cabinet office, prime minister or security services.

Seven "cross-cutting" committees: Deregulation, Environmental audit, European scrutiny, Public accounts, Public administration, Science and technology, Statutory instruments

Select Committee on Liaison: Shifting the Balance. www.parliament.uk
fields.bodyText: Consider the following list of ornaments of the House of Commons: Donald Anderson, Andrew Bennett, Archy Kirkwood, Peter Brooke, Sir Sydney Chapman, Robin Corbett. David Davis, Giles Radice, Gwyneth Dunwoody, Barry Sheerman, Derek Foster, Nicholas Winterton. Recognise them? A couple, maybe three come somewhere near the threshold of public recognition. Yet these people ought to be pillars of democracy. That they labour in twilight is an indictment of our system of government. They are chairs of various of the Commons's select committees, listed in the box, with the power to command ministers and their advisers to answer questions a lot more detailed than ever get thrown across the floor of the house. It is not just that they underperform in the task of subjecting the executive - ministers and their departmental officials - to tougher scrutiny. It is also that their impotence is a waste. Some of these leading backbenchers are experienced and probably as able as the people who do hold ministerial office. They could be put to better use. For the first time they have set out how they could be (see link at bottom of page). This report from the liaison committee of chairs of select committees is important, not just as a public exercise in self-criticism. It is also a marker for the future of representative government. Giles Radice, the Labour MP and chief of the treasury committee who chaired the exercise, is modest. He and colleagues - Davis, Brooke and Winterton are Tories - are not asking for major changes in procedure, though they do want more staff, better publicity and a change of attitude towards their work on the part of civil servants. Their plea now disappears into the Bermuda triangle of Commons reform patrolled by arch-conservative Anne Taylor, Labour's chief whip, and Margaret Beckett, leader of the house. If it does not emerge, that will not just say that the Blair government is as executive-minded as its predecessors (with the exception of that brief honeymoon period in 1979 when Margaret Thatcher allowed Norman St John-Stevas to create the departmental scrutiny system we have got.) It will also show that 1997's MPs, newcomers, babes, Kilfoylites and all are a supine bunch who cannot even get it together to bring their own procedures within five decades of the 21st century. Select committees have a pedigree going back to the grand committee on evils (1623) and the committee on the Queen of Scotts of 1572. (Are MPs more subservient to Tony than they were to Elizabeth of England? - discuss.) In the two decades of their modern form, the set of committees dedicating to individual Whitehall departments have become a fixture. "At a bargain price, it has provided independent scrutiny of government. It has enabled the questioning of ministers and civil servants, and has forced them to explain policies". Yet when Stuart Weir and David Beetham of Democratic Audit reviewed the evidence last year they found they had "little influence" on policy. Too often the committees are amateurish; members fail to turn up; reports are ignored. The public accounts committee has a special position as the employer of the comptroller and auditor general and his 800-odd staff in the national audit office. But its remit is public money after it has been spent. The paltry attendance at the annual debate on its work on the floor of the Commons shows how much MPs are engaged. The usual case for beefing them up is (as this report puts it) to shift the balance between legislative and executive, so making the government of the country more accountable and maybe even more effective. If MPs were more involved in scrutinising bills before they entered the sausage machine of law-making, defects might be spotted and their stickability improved. But that (the report recognises) would require MPs to behave like professionals. When I worked in the US house of representatives for a congressman from Michigan, his Washington office was some half-dozen strong and for his contributions to the powerful ways and means (public finance) committee he could call on banks of experts. The American constitution is not a model for the UK; ways and means is far from an exemplary committee; but the operations of select committees in the Commons proves the old adage about paying peanuts. (Commons staff are generally good; there are just too few of them.) The best case for reform, which the liaison report hints at, is that it would answer the question what should we do with all those lobby-fodder MPs. Those not sucked into the executive machine spend their time as glorified citizens' advice bureaux. Giles Radice and colleagues want to construct an "alternative career path". The question they do not directly address, however, is what happens to the bonds of party loyalty if backbenchers start to become powers in the land. They say outright that party whips should keep their noses out of how MPs are chosen to sit. But that bid for greater pluralism will reduce the potency of ministers, especially the prime minister. Under proportional representation such "weakness" might become the norm. Perhaps electoral reform is a precondition for resurrection of the back benches. To make their mark, select committees are going to need disciplinary powers. The report hopes that "a sub-standard response" by a minister "should automatically result in [the offender] spending an uncomfortable morning or afternoon supplying what was missing". But that is only going to work inside a culture where cocking a snook at the Commons is actionable; that surely implies the Commons having power to make a minister pay, perhaps even to apply more regularly the threat of loss of office. But that in turns means the prime minister sharing power, maybe even co-ownership, of public policy making. fields.headline: Women's role in Kosovo
fields.trailText: While speaking of the rich contribution that Kosovan women can make to rebuilding Kosovo society, Lesley Abdela (Men with a mission: no women, March 2) makes no mention of the significant role women are playing  in the establishment of the joint interim administrative structures.
fields.body:
While speaking of the rich contribution that Kosovan women can make to rebuilding Kosovo society, Lesley Abdela (Men with a mission: no women, March 2) makes no mention of the significant role women are playing, and have been encouraged and supported to play in the establishment of the joint interim administrative structures. Nor does she recognise that many of our local partners and national advisers are predominately women.

While the security situation in Kosovo remains fragile, women are not being kidnapped at the rate of five per week in Pristina, nor have they ever. The victims of crime in Kosovo come from all sectors of society with the majority being male members of minority groups. Unmik police, Kfor and human rights organisations continue to closely monitor this situation.

The Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe is responsible for institution building activities in Kosovo and is dedicated to supporting women's issues, NGOs and women's participation in public life and civil society. We will continue to work with local partners such as Norma, the Center for Protection of Women and Children, the Council for the Defence of Human Rights and Freedoms and others to achieve equality for all people in Kosovo. Statements to the contrary fly in the face of the daily efforts of this mission and its personnel.

Ambassador Daan Everts

fields.headline: Justice after the floods
fields.trailText: It is quite likely that the floods in Mozambique are not a "natural" disaster at all, despite what the government's head of the crisis response team, Rob Holden, says (Keeping the British aid effort shipshape, March 4), but a human-made one.
fields.body:
It is quite likely that the floods in Mozambique are not a "natural" disaster at all, despite what the government's head of the crisis response team, Rob Holden, says (Keeping the British aid effort shipshape, March 4), but a human-made one - one of the extreme weather events that are the result of global warming. If so, then talk of "aid" to Mozambique is inappropriate. Mozambique should receive assistance as a matter of justice, not of charity compensation for the damage wrought upon the country by unsustainable western patterns of production and consumption.

Prof Andrew Dobson
Keele University

 You claim that Clare Short's outburst over the supply of aid "exposed her inadequate political skills". (Leader, March 4) On the contrary, she is obviously a principled politician who chose to put the people of Mozambique before the feelings of her cabinet colleagues. Geoff Hoon should be ashamed, when a humanitarian response was required he focused on the cost to the MoD. It was Clare Short who ensured the helicopters were sent, albeit too late.

Andrew Lewis
Berlin, Germany Andrewinberlin@aol.com

 The income from a weeks' lottery could go for the relief of the awful suffering in Mozambique. Camelot might even chip in their share of the profits. Some village halls, theatres, and sports grounds might have to wait another week or two... but so what?

Cllr Ian Bidgood
Winchester

fields.headline: More mayoral mayhem
fields.trailText: At the time I interviewed Ken Livingstone for the mayoral shortlist I thought that he would stand as independent if he didn't win the party's internal ballot. What other explanation could there be for any Labour party member consistently refusing to be bound by the Labour manifesto?
fields.body:
 At the time I interviewed Ken Livingstone for the mayoral shortlist I thought that he would stand as independent if he didn't win the party's internal ballot. What other explanation could there be for any Labour party member consistently refusing to be bound by the Labour manifesto? Ken has never been a team player, and his self-interest comes before that of the government or the Labour party. It's why those of us who know him don't trust him.

Clive Soley MP
Chairman, Labour party London selection board

 Those of us who argued with sceptical comrades that a Livingstone candidacy was always three parts opportunism and one part martyrology, ought, I suppose, to be glad that he has lived down to our expectations. However the decision he has taken will do both London and Labour grievous harm; many hands have contributed to this but it has taken one individual finally to bring it about.

Phillip Whitehead MEP
Derby

 Yesterday Frank Dobson said: "It is quite usual for the Labour prime minister to support the Labour candidate". However, Mr Blair actively campaigned against Ken Livingstone when he was seeking to be the official Labour candidate and this alone should justify his now standing as an independent candidate, irrespective of any assurances he may have given.

Many of the "weighted" votes that helped to ensure Mr Dobson's selection will not have a vote in the mayoral election, whereas the majority of the party members have already defied Mr Blair and the party heirarchy by voting for Mr Livingstone.

Simon Kahn
Lewes, East Sussex. simon@bitsandpieces.co.uk

 Margaret McDonagh (Letters, March 6) claims that the Labour party "elected Frank Dobson". As I understand, Frank Dobson won with 22,000 votes, Ken Livingstone lost with 74,000 votes. It would seem that the Labour party elected Ken Livingstone. Tony Blair elected Frank Dobson.

Liverpool
Ian Cracknell icracknell@hotmail.com

 Alan Millington (Letters, March 6) was not quite right about Leyton in 1964. As an active member of Leyton Labour party I was instrumental in the invitation to Patrick Gordon Walker and the recommendation that our much loved Reg (not Joe) Sorensen be ennobled - his general election majority had been less than 8,000, not 20,000. Patrick, who had lost his Midlands seat in a disgraceful racist campaign, proved to be a good constituency MP.

Dick Drew
Bristol DickDrew@aol.com

 So, Red Ken is going for it. I wonder how the mandarins of Millbank will manage to stitch this election up. Blair is finally under real pressure. Nancy Reagan said a woman is like a teabag, you only find out how strong she is when she's plunged into hot water. So, what kind of a teabag are you, Tony?

Laura Marcus
Leek, Staffs Lawls@compuserve.com

 As the word "mayor" is likely to be on many people's lips for a while, may I request that it emerge disyllabically? If Mr Dobson were to win, it would unbearable to hear him called "Dobbo" and the "mare" of London.

Michael Bulley
Ashford, Kent michael@ashford.hi-net.co.uk

 I have one thing to say to "splitter" Livingstone: "Ooh you dismay me!"

Paul Sceeny
Brackley, Northants psceeny@hotmail.com

fields.headline: How to bust sanctions
fields.trailText: One way to get humanitarian aid to Iraq is to take it there yourself (Foreign office bans Galloway's flight to Iraq, March 6). Over the past two years we have deliberately and openly broken the economic sanctions on Iraq by taking toys, medical supplies and medicines to Iraqi children's hospitals without applying for export licences.
fields.body:
One way to get humanitarian aid to Iraq is to take it there yourself (Foreign office bans Galloway's flight to Iraq, March 6). Over the past two years we have deliberately and openly broken the economic sanctions on Iraq by taking toys, medical supplies and medicines to Iraqi children's hospitals without applying for export licences.

Some of us have been arrested and threatened with prosecution. We do not accept the British government's right to a moral veto over our attempts to help individuals in Iraq and believe that breaking the sanctions is a valid act of civil disobedience against a criminal policy that kills thousands of Iraqi children every month.

Last month the UN humanitarian coordinator for Iraq, Hans von Sponeck, resigned in protest over the horrific impact that economic sanctions are having on the civilian population. Urging an end to economic sanctions, he said that he could not be silent in the face of "a true human tragedy". Neither can we.

Milan Rai and five others
voices in the wilderness uk voices@viwuk.freeserve.co.uk

 Your preview of John Pilger's ITV programme on Iraqi sanctions (Watch this, March 6), asserts that Robin Cook wanted an uncut 10 minute section to explain "why Pilger was wrong".

When Denis Halliday spoke about sanctions in a Commons' room over a year ago, no member of the foreign office attended, and not a single member of the government was available to meet Halliday. And when Tam Dalyell managed an adjournment debate on the effects of sanctions, barely a dozen MPs could be bothered to turn up: Robin Cook was not one of them.

Adrian Kozlowski
Birmingham

fields.headline: Nannygate
fields.standfirst:
Where's the public interest?

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It is a   damned sight easier to fight the cause of press freedom if there is an inkling of a public interest defence. With the gossip of Ros Mark, there is no such defence.
fields.body:
The great legal writer, Sir William Blackstone, argued eloquently against allowing the courts to impose "previous restraints" on publications. The freedom of the press, he stated in a much-quoted passage, lay in the undoubted right of every free man to "lay what sentiments he pleases before the public."

Sir William set out this defence of the Fourth Estate in 1765. It possibly did not occur to him that, more than 200 years later, the argument would be used by a Sunday newspaper to justify publishing the memoirs of a nanny about her time looking after the children of a prime minister. Nevertheless, we are told by the panjandrums at Associated Newspapers that "anyone who cares about press freedom" should fall in behind them as they fight for our right to know the bathtime secrets of Nicky, Kathryn and Euan Blair.

Well, up to a point Lord Rothermere. No one in newspapers finds it easy to defend the use of midnight ex-parte injunctions to stop the presses. But it is a damned sight easier to fight the cause of press freedom if there is an inkling of a public interest defence. With the gossip of Ros Mark, there is no such defence. On the evidence of the material published in the early editions of the Mail on Sunday, Ms Mark's proposed book contains nothing but intrusive tittle tattle.

This government is often clumsy - and worse - in its handling of the press. Its commitment to freedom of information is no more than lukewarm. But politicians and their families deserve some privacy. They should, at minimum, be free to hire people to look after their children without fearing that their intimate lives thereby become fodder for publishers and editors hoping to make a quick buck. Ms Mark signed a confidentiality agreement before agreeing to work for the Blairs. To argue that the breaking of that agreement is about the freedom of the press is worse than lame: it encourages cynicism about anyone relying on Blackstone's wise words in future.

webTitle: Surrogate army fears for future after Israel's Lebanon exit

fields.headline: Surrogate army fears for future after Israel's Lebanon exit
fields.standfirst:
Without a prior deal with Syria, the SLA faces severe reprisals from Beirut

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: For a country of such myriad faiths and sects, it is a strikingly ecumenical "martyrs' memorial" that is going up on a hill near Merjayoun, the "capital" of Israeli-occupied south Lebanon.
fields.byline: David Hirst in Merjayoun, south Lebanon
fields.body:
For a country of such myriad faiths and sects, it is a strikingly ecumenical "martyrs' memorial" that is going up on a hill near Merjayoun, the "capital" of Israeli-occupied south Lebanon.

A Druze-style sanctuary is flanked by two towers, one with crescents inlaid, representing Islam; the other with a cross, Christianity. Brass plaques record the names of 750 men, mostly soldiers of the South Lebanese Army (SLA), who have died since Israel entered the area 25 years ago.

"Let's hope", said the contractor who built the monument, "that they'll at least respect the dead, whatever the cause for which they died." For the danger is that the monument - begun three years ago - may be completed just in time to be ritually demolished, or at least consigned to official ignominy.

If Israel keeps to Sunday's decision to get out of Lebanon by July, there will soon be no more security zone, and maybe no more SLA. And the "martyrs" will be deemed by those who take Israel and the SLA's place to have been traitors, not patriots.

The pull-out will transform the lives of the region's 100,000 inhabitants, most drastically those who collaborated with the Israelis. Several thousand people - SLA soldiers, and those who work in Israel or do business with it - have already been condemned in absentia by Lebanese courts. Those with a vested interest in the status quo do not want Israel to leave. Others simply do not believe it will withdraw.

A local journalist, Ali Dia, said a withdrawal would occur only if there was a peace agreement between Israel and Syria. "Without one it will be just too dangerous for [Ehud]Barak," the Israeli prime minister.

Yesterday, as Israel continued its fourth consecutive day of air raids on targets north of the zone in reprisal for Hizbullah attacks, there was no sign of impending withdrawal. And "no sign that Israel has begun bolstering its border positions, as distinct from those inside Lebanese territory," said officers serving with the oldest United Nations peacekeeping operation.

On the contrary, the Israelis have bolstered their positions in south Lebanon. The latest refinement is wire netting draped around their perimeters; this is supposed to fend off the anti-tank missiles which Hizbullah has recently made very successful use of. Israeli soldiers in their bunkers can see and fire through the netting.

"But you wouldn't necessarily see any advance preparations [for a pull-out]," said Major Hervé Collet of France. "They could be out within three days if they leave their equipment behind."

But what Israel does about its SLA allies is a far trickier question: that does require advance planning.

Like Mr Barak, the SLA commanders cling to the hope that it will be a withdrawal by agreement. "They tell us that there is nothing to worry about," said an SLA spokesman, Raymond Abu Mrad. "But without an agreement it will be very bad for us, Lebanon, and the region."

For Israel to withdraw unilaterally would seem to make nonsense of the whole rationale which the security zone has embodied - to keep hostile forces away from the international border.

But the conditions on which it hopes to extricate itself from the so-called Lebanese mud have eroded drastically over the years. A UN peacekeeping officer said: "I believe Barak would be content with just a piece of paper from the Lebanese government guaranteeing the security of the frontier; then, with any violation of it, he would feel free to flatten Lebanon."

But, in the absence of wider agreement, Mr Barak is most unlikely to get this. There is no assurance that Lebanon would even send its army up to the frontier. It has not deployed in the Jezzin salient, from which the SLA withdrew last summer. And a Damascus newspaper, Tishreen, warned yesterday that the withdrawal decision "contains the seeds of war in the entire region".

It is Hizbullah's stated policy not to compete with the state in any evacuated areas. But state or no state, there would seem to be nothing to stop it from blending into the local population wherever it pleases - such as in the Shi'ite villages of Kfar Kela, almost within shouting distance of the Israeli settlement of Metullah.

Whatever the strategic risk Israel would be running, its soldiers would be getting out of their Lebanese hell-hole. But the SLA members have nowhere to go, except for their senior commanders, security men and prison administrators of ill repute. It is assumed that Israel would arrange a haven for those, perhaps 150 in all, who would face severe reprisals if they stayed behind.

The SLA's commander, General Antoine Lahd, sentenced to death by Beirut, now spends as much time in France as in command of his troops. "He's made his pile from all the taxes and duties he levies and can't wait to enjoy it," said a local businessman.

"God knows what will happen to us," said an official at the Kfar Tibnit crossing-point between the Israeli-occupied zone and sovereign Lebanon. He reflected the fears of all the rank and file, now plagued by demoralising, sometimes very improbable, rumours. The latest of them, from an Israel newspaper, is that they and their families will be shipped en masse to Turkish Cyprus.

The fate of the SLA, and its reaction, is what raises the greatest fears among the local population.

"We shall never let Hizbullah come here," said Mr Abu Mrad. "And have we been fighting and dying for 25 years, just to be packed off to exile? If the Israelis leave just like that, Gen Lahd couldn't ensure that his men obey him."

That was a broad hint at the dangerous state of mind which most people here agree would take possession of the SLA if it felt itself abandoned. Resentment would run deep, not only against Syria and Hizbullah, but even more against Israel.

Much of the SLA's rank and file, mainly Shi'ites, would probably offer themselves to Hizbullah, if they have not already secretly done so. Others, especially Christians, might refuse to disband.

"My fear is that the SLA will disintegrate, but not completely," said a leading resident of Merjayoun. It would, he said, be like the start of the Lebanese civil war all over again, with warlords staking out fiefdoms close to Israel's frontier. And they could be a very wild card indeed.

It is a very high-stake diplomatic poker game that Syria and Israel are now playing out over south Lebanon. Of the local players, the SLA has less independence of Israel than Hizbullah does of Syria and Iran. But if ever the puppets had a chance to dictate to the puppet-masters, in the interests of each other, it is now, as the game moves towards its climax.

Hizbullah - and in the absence of an agreement, Syria - would like nothing more than for the SLA to force Israel to retain a presence, however limited, in Lebanon.

"We doubt very much that Israel will withdraw completely," said the Hizbullah's second-in-command, Sheikh Naim Kassem last week. "And so Hizbullah will fight on."
