webTitle: MP secures aid flight to Iraq

fields.headline: MP secures aid flight to Iraq
fields.standfirst:
Foreign office drops opposition to sanctions-busting relief as Galloway cuts back passenger numbers

Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign office abruptly reversed its ban yesterday on a flight to take medical aid to Iraq, organised by the Labour MP George Galloway, after accepting a drastic reduction in the number of passengers.
fields.body:
The foreign office abruptly reversed its ban yesterday on a flight to take medical aid to Iraq, organised by the Labour MP George Galloway, after accepting a drastic reduction in the number of passengers.

Scores of aid workers, doctors, journalists, anti-sanctions campaigners and elderly Iraqis hoping to be reunited with their families will now be left off the Boeing 737. It will be the first direct civilian flight between Britain and Baghdad since sanctions were imposed on Saddam Hussain's regime at the start of the Gulf war in 1991.

The MP for Glasgow Kelvin had originally assembled a list of 207 passengers but that will be cut back to just 29. One of those still on the list is former Flight Lieutenant John Nicholl, who was shot down, captured and beaten by Iraqis during the war; he intends to use his visit as an act of reconciliation with his former enemies. The former UN official Dennis Halliday, who resigned in protest at the effects of sanctions, will also be on the plane.

Mr Galloway claimed yesterday that he had been in contact with the foreign office throughout the planning and there had been no objection until Flt Lt Nicholl's involvement became public last week. The foreign office, however, insisted its objections had arisen only because the large number of passengers was transforming the flight into an anti-sanctions "publicity stunt".

Mr Galloway is seeking judicial review of the foreign office's rejection of the initial flight plan but accepts that the courts are unlikely to deliver a verdict before the plane is due to leave on Saturday. It is scheduled to fly via Dubai carrying £150,000 worth of medicines; most of the seats will be empty.

Under the terms of the United Nations sanctions against Iraq, flights to Baghdad must be referred to a UN committee in New York. Without the support of a national government approval would not be given. The sanctions committee was due to meet late last night and expected to back Mr Galloway's revised plans.

Mr Galloway is a veteran campaigner against UN sanctions on Iraq, which he claims are killing 7,000 Iraqi children every month.

It was late on Friday that the foreign office minister Peter Hain informed Mr Galloway that the government could no longer support his application. "Peter Hain has now written to me saying that he has reconsidered after all," Mr Galloway said yesterday. "And we have shown flexibility and said that we will submit a list of 29 names. We have had to leave many journalists, doctors, international lawyers and social workers behind; also elderly and sick Iraqis who wanted to go back to their home to die.

"One of those left off is an octogenarian who cannot travel by road, another an Iraqi suffering from cancer and undergoing chemotherapy. They wanted to return to see their families for a last time. The suggestion that these seats would otherwise be full of medicine is nonsense.

"Decisions on humanitarian flights should not be a matter for committees in New York and we will take the issue to judicial review. It can be no coincidence that the foreign office only became concerned when it learnt last Thursday about the presence of Flt Lt John Nicholl."

In an earlier letter to Mr Hain at the weekend, Mr Galloway had scorned a foreign office suggestion that it would oversee the delivery of the medicine even if the flight was banned. "How are you going to achieve that?" he asked. "What mechanisms do you have to successfully deliver medicines to Iraq? I am sure you don't intend to use the RAF between the bombing runs?"

But the foreign office said yesterday: "There was never any question of us blocking humanitarian aid. We could send it in via Jordan. When the numbers of passengers suddenly went up first to 118 and then to 207, there was no way they could say this was a humaitarian flight.

"They were all journalists, political hangers-on and anti-sanctions campaigners. Mr Hain said that if the numbers were reduced we would approve it. We have. At least it's now only 29 people surrounding a George Galloway publicity stunt."

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Germaine Greer wrote in her latest polemic: "It's time to get angry again." But did the need ever go away?
fields.body:
Germaine Greer wrote in her latest polemic: "It's time to get angry again." But did the need ever go away? Women in cities across the UK were asked whether they agreed with statements made by Greer in her book The Whole Woman. According to the survey, working mothers in their 30s and 40s feel more than any other group that feminism still had a long way to go. So if post-feminism is the order of the day, Sidelines warns you not to be female, working, a partner, a mother or needing health care.

 Ever felt the urge to hurl a brick at the TV when yet another quiz show offers a smart-arse all-male panel, or a news programme features a string of ageing white male "experts"? Well, now you can have your fling AND do something practical afterwards. The Fawcett Society's Where Are the Women? campaign is providing handy credit card-size cards with the complaint lines of TV companies and broadcasting standards organisations. The campaign also includes postcards to be sent to the male-dominated organisation of your choice demanding to know what action is being taken to improve the situation. Call Fawcett on 0171-628 4441 or visit www.gn.apc.org/ fawcett.

 Help! It's over there and on its way here. Boy Crazy!, the American card game where players trade pictures of young men, is expected to arrive in Britain next month. Each card has a photo of a male aged between 12 and 22 with a biography, vital statistics, hobbies and preferences in girls. Scouts have been searching British shopping centres for boys. Players choose their favourite beaux and whoever guesses who picked whom wins the card. In Sidelines's day, Happy Families was enough to make you feel totally inadequate that your family didn't fit the definition of happy. Girls these days have the additional burden of having to desire 18-year-old rugby-loving boys if they're to be one of the gang.

fields.headline: McCain battles to salvage credibility
fields.standfirst:
Super Tuesday: The challengers of both parties have run out of momentum as they go into crucial primaries

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: John McCain goes into Super Tuesday today - the biggest test of presidential viability so far - needing to find a plausible definition of creditable defeat.
fields.body:
John McCain goes into Super Tuesday today - the biggest test of presidential viability so far - needing to find a plausible definition of creditable defeat.

The Arizona senator is behind George W Bush in all three key states - California, Ohio and New York - and only in the last of these can he hope for much support from the Republican members who will decide which man will be the party's candidate for president.

Mr McCain is unlikely to drop out of the race if he can continue to produce evidence that he would stand a better chance than Mr Bush against vice-president Al Gore in November's election. But in a week's time Mr McCain faces primaries in the unpromising southern states of Texas (governor, George W Bush) and Florida (governor, brother Jeb Bush).

"John McCain is not a viable candidate and has no chance of winning the nomination unless he wins the 162 delegates from California," said Ron Facheux, editor and publisher of Campaigns & Elections magazine.

"I don't see mathematically how he can come out of Super Tuesday with enough votes to survive is he doesn't win California. I think that's the key to the whole thing," he added.

Even Mr McCain's aides concede this will not happen in a state where the winner takes all the delegates and their man is trailing by about 20 points. Here only the votes of registered Republicans count towards deciding their candidate, but there is also a non-binding popularity contest that includes Democrats and independents.

The Vietnam war hero's most realistic target might be to lose the delegates but embarrass Mr Bush and claim a moral victory by winning the popular vote.

Mr McCain is even further behind in Ohio, which delivers 69 delegates, but he has some cause for optimism in New York, whose Republicans are considered more moderate and where he is only about four points behind. However, even that is a drop of nearly 10 in a week.

"This [New York] is still a horse race," said the pollster John Zogby. "It's very competitive, not only statewide but also because each candidate seems to have his own pocket of regional strength. Turnout is going to be critical here and I wouldn't even venture a guess as to the outcome."

But it would not be enough to take some of New York's 101 delegates, probably win the New England states of Massachusetts (37 delegates) and Rhode Island (14), and possibly Connecticut (25) and Maine (14).

Super Tuesday is the closest the United States has come to holding a national primary, with ballots in 16 states and New York and California voting together for the first time. More than half the delegates needed to win the nomination for either party will be chosen, determining the future for Mr McCain's underdog campaign. That of the Democratic challenger, Bill Bradley, who is trailing Mr Gore everywhere, has been decided already and it is only a matter of when he will withdraw.

John Weaver, Mr McCain's political director, said: "We have climbed steeper hills in this campaign than what we have to do Tuesday. Having said that, we have a difficult task ahead of us."

fields.headline: Reluctant fathers and feeble sperm
fields.standfirst: Week 12
fields.trailText: People say "congratulations", and "when's it due?". Most want to know how I'm feeling, and a very few how my husband is feeling. Some ask how my work will fit in. But only one woman actually asked me the crucial question, the one for the baby-boom generation, and she whispered it: "How did you get him to agree?"
fields.body:
People say "congratulations", and "when's it due?". Most want to know how I'm feeling, and a very few how my husband is feeling. Some ask how my work will fit in. But only one woman actually asked me the crucial question, the one for the baby-boom generation, and she whispered it: "How did you get him to agree?"

In my mother's generation the taboo question would surely have been, "Was it an accident?" The question then was how to stop babies and women were just getting hold of ways of doing so effectively. When pundits suggested - and they did - that the pill would mean that men would never commit to children and that women would lose a crucial means of enforcing marriage, feminists laughed merrily. In the new Utopia, men and women would choose to have children together and bring them up in equal partnership.

Thirty-five years on, Utopia seems a long way off. It's not just the fall in sperm counts, the endless tide of headlines about infertility and the ever more peculiar dilemmas thrown up by the cures. It's also Bridget Jones-ism - the seemingly inexorable rise in singleness. Bridget, at bottom, is worried about babies and whether she will have the choice to have them. This is the unmentionable subject among the girls, and the reason her age worries her. It is the anxiety that distinguishes her from her emotional-fuckwit boyfriends, and the reason they are able to find her "needy" and treat her with contempt.

Bridget is popular because she is typical. I identify with her, and know several versions of her. Demos has published a study saying that Bridget's plight is common and also explicable, because men won't marry up the social hierarchy and women won't marry down, and too many women, thanks to feminism, are now up. I don't know if this is meant to cheer us up or not.

But even suppose you have, by great good luck - and it is luck, I think, rather than anything to do with being sorted, clever or kind - found a loving partner, you may still be a good way from making that joint decision. A woman in her thirties may long for a child and/or fear horribly never having one. A man may think it's a fine idea, may long, even, but he is unlikely to feel that world is shutting down unless he acts immediately. Both men and women tend to progress in their careers in their thirties, and, in the professions, find themselves in jobs that eat up their time and emotions.

If the relationship is a loving one, the couple will want to spend time on each other. A child means that some of that will have to go. So even if a woman does decide it's time for a child - how does she get him to agree?

Maybe she doesn't. According to the most recent government figures, nearly half of pregnancies in Britain are "unplanned". Even allowing for a hefty proportion of the strictly religious, the blind-drunk, and teenagers who didn't know it can happen standing up, that seems an awful lot. Contraception is surely not so hard to manage - especially against ever-feebler sperm. Could it be that intelligent, educated, professional women are throwing away everything their mothers fought for and are forgetting to take their pills, or claiming to "know their bodies' natural cycle", simply in order to exert an old-fashioned imperative, and bring their partner to the sticking point?

I think it could. In fact, I can think of a few examples. Though, of course, such schemes can backfire. As single-motherhood gets more acceptable, so it becomes easier for a man to walk away from a child, especially if he did not agree to its conception. An estate agent in Texas actually sued his ex-girlfriend for the theft of his sperm. Even if a partnership lasts, the man may be permanently resentful of the child he never meant to have. If a woman takes the solo decision to start a child, she may feel she always has to take responsibility for it, and exhaust herself trying to protect her partner from nappies, broken nights and mashed bananas.

I feel a bit of this myself, just because a baby was my idea. But I'm thankful I didn't have to resort to snipping the nipples off condoms. "Congratulations" does indeed seem the right response to my happy, chosen, supported, pregnancy. It seems to me a Utopian and wildly unlikely event. I'm 34, in full working order, and he agreed.

webTitle: All over bar the counting as Bradley faces thrashing

fields.headline: All over bar the counting as Bradley faces thrashing
fields.standfirst:
The former basketball star's supporters know only a miracle will do

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: True to his unpredictable and maverick nature, Bill Bradley yesterday spent what may well have been the last hours of his bid for the Democratic party's presidential nomination talking to a room full of non-voters - 100 Bronx schoolchildren.
fields.body:
True to his unpredictable and maverick nature, Bill Bradley yesterday spent what may well have been the last hours of his bid for the Democratic party's presidential nomination talking to a room full of non-voters - 100 Bronx schoolchildren.

The event, at the Bronx School of Law, Government and Justice, was emblematic of both his baffling campaign tactics and the air of fatalism that has descended on it.

"It's very rare that history comes up and taps you on the shoulder and says here I am," a school official told the assembly. It was well meant, but drew attention to the fact that the rival to vice-president Al Gore looked distinctly like history yesterday.

The tall, avuncular former basketball star and senator stood before his young audience with his characteristic professorial detachment, one hand finding sanctuary in a trouser pocket while the other held the microphone.

He told a rather opaque parable about a hermit living in the woods, which apparently had the unhip moral that "you have to respect those that are in authority". He then narrated another tale about an athlete who had one chance to make the big time. The important thing, he told the students, was not that he made it, but that he did all he could to get there.

If that was a coded epitaph to his own campaign, Mr Bradley did not admit it, even though opinion polls predicted that he would lose to Mr Gore in all the 16 states which hold Democratic primary elections today.

Mr Bradley was lagging in New York by 56 points to 34. Even in New Jersey, which he represented as a senator, he was behind. And in the other crucial state, California, he was about as popular among Democrats as the Republican frontrunner, George W Bush, with 11% support. But he insisted yesterday that he was still a contender.

"People vote not by what's in the polls, but what's in their hearts," he said. "We need to win several states and I think we've still got a good chance."

But even Mr Bradley's most energetic cheerleader, the radical Democratic senator Paul Wellstone, who was with him to the end, conceded: "I think that Bill has a mountain a climb. There's no doubt about it. Clearly he's not met the challenge of connecting with people."

The past tense infused the edges of the campaign like an embarrassing stain yesterday, and it was all Bradley aides could do to keep it at bay, correcting "was" to "is" in any reference to the waning liberal effort to capture the Democratic party's presidential nomination.

Senator Bob Kerrey, another Bradley supporter, insisted that "a miracle could still happen", but then conceded that a victory in the rest of Washington state - following Mr Bradley's heavy defeat in partial elections there last week - "was his only chance".

In the Bronx yesterday, Mr Bradley's spokesman, Eric Hauser, denied mounting press reports that a speech to announce the candidate's withdrawal was already being written, blaming the suggestion on "people outside the campaign".

"People involved in the campaign, and the candidate, are focusing on tomorrow," Mr Hauser said. He said that Mr Bradley would have to win a "few" states to stay in the race, but refused to quantify that benchmark.

Mr Bradley said that if he lost the nomination he would throw his support behind Mr Gore, despite the bitter verbal exchanges between the two candidates earlier in the campaign. The former New Jersey senator had taken a stand to the left of the vice-president, offering more comprehensive state healthcare, and a tougher gun-policy control. But both men have steered away from criticism of each other in the last week, another telling sign that the Democratic competition was as good as over.

Mr Bradley insisted yesterday that he did not want to be considered as a potential running mate for Mr Gore, saying the presidency was the only job he was interested in. But Mitchell Moss, the head of New York University's Taub Centre think-tank, said that he believed Mr Bradley would not be invited on to the ticket. "Al Gore doesn't need him. He can't even win New Jersey for sure," he said. "Bradley isn't the kind of guy you want to have on your side."

The head of the Democratic national committee, Edward Rendell, who is supposed to be neutral in the Gore-Bradley contest, also slipped into the past tense while talking about Mr Bradley's challenge, explaining that "the reason he lost" was that the American people were content with the economic success of the Clinton-Gore administration.

But other pundits, as well as members of Mr Bradley's camp, said that they believed the ex-senator was his own worst enemy, often appearing aloof and making a string of strategic blunders. He ignored advice to concentrate his campaign on New York, and instead spent a full week in a futile bid to win Washington, a thinly-populated state with little influence on the nomination race.

"If you know why they are there, please let me know," Ed Koch, New York's popular former mayor and an important Bradley supporter, complained at the time.

Mr Bradley also took a risk in making an early joint appearance with the Republican outsider, John McCain, to promote campaign finance reform, in the hope that this show of bipartisanship would attract independent voters. But in the end it was Mr McCain, with his more forceful and populist campaign style, who vacuumed up the independent support.

The most optimistic Bradley aides said yesterday they thought that wins in a handful of Super Tuesday states would be enough to stay in the race, at least until the primary campaign swings south next week, when the Tennessee-bred Mr Gore will have an immense geographical advantage.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText:
Blairs make informal trip to see Putin
Tony Blair will fly to St Petersburg this weekend for an informal first meeting with Vladimir Putin, the former KGB chief who is rapidly emerging as Boris Yeltsin's hardline successor in Russia.
fields.body:
Blairs make informal trip to see Putin
Tony Blair will fly to St Petersburg this weekend for an informal first meeting with Vladimir Putin, the former KGB chief who is rapidly emerging as Boris Yeltsin's hardline successor in Russia.

Downing St last night announced that Cherie Blair, who is seven months pregnant, will accompany the prime minister for the 24 hour "Saturday with the Putins", which will include a visit to the opera. The Blairs will fly on from a speech on devolution in Scotland on Friday.

Mr Blair's main purpose will be to sound out the prime minister and acting president of Russia ahead of elections that look set to confirm him in power.

Downing St last night welcomed the invitation as "an opportunity to develop personal relations" with the leader of "a great power with an important role in the world" - words designed to soothe injured Russian feelings during the decade of growing American hegemony.
[Michael White]

Brady: I did not coerce Hindley
Moors murderer Ian Brady has said that his former lover Myra Hindley was lying in saying he forced her to take part in their killings.

In a letter to journalists, Brady, 62, also described her as an attention-seeker and a chameleon who would say whatever she thought would please. He wrote: "I discover that she has stooped to new depths, alleging I coerced her to serially murder by use of drugs, rape, blackmail, physical violence and practically every crime in the book."

The letter, written from Ashworth secure hospital on Merseyside, where Brady has been a patient since 1985, was prompted by a Modern Times documentary on BBC2 last week, and based around 150 letters sent by Hindley to a TV producer.

She claimed to have helped Brady out of love and fear of what he would do to her and her family. He had raped, beaten and drugged her during their relationship, she said, but she had continued to love him because she was emotionally immature and overwhelmed by his "powerful personality".

She is mounting a case in the Lords aimed at challenging the home secretary's right to decide she should never be freed.

In his letter, Brady, who is appealing to the high court in Liverpool for the right to starve himself to death, complained of Hindley's "fragmented personality". He said: "desperation to extricate herself from the past had finally driven her over the top, into a Victorian melodrama of hyperbolic fiction, in which all concrete evidence against her has been jettisoned in favour of transparent mendacity and evidential amnesia."

Mr Justice Maurice Kay is expected to rule on Thursday whether Ashworth should continue force-feeding Brady.
[John-Dominic Clare]

Drugs killed aristocrat in Burma
A British aristocrat has died of a suspected heroin overdose in a Rangoon hotel room less than a month after his father died.

The body of Hugh Fitzroy Newdegate, younger son of the late Viscount Daventry, was found by staff at the five-star Traders hotel on Friday after he failed to answer an overseas phone call.

Mr Newdegate, 38, had not been seen since noon the previous day. A packet containing 0.02 grams of heroin was found in the bedside drawer.

Mr Newdegate's brother James, 39, the 4th Viscount Daventry, declined to speak from Arbury Hall in Warwickshire, but in a statement the family said: "We are utterly devastated at reports of his accidental death in Rangoon."

Their father, 78, died in February after a long illness.

Mr Newdegate had been an aviation insurance broker with the London-based Aon Group Ltd, on whose behalf he was in Rangoon. Peter Tritton, an executive director, said: "We have been advised of nothing to suggest that this is anything other than a tragic accident."

Last night the foreign office said Burmese police were investigating the death. The results of an autopsy would not be known for at least two days. At Rangoon general hospital a drug overdose was found to be the cause of death, according to Kyemon Daily, the official newspaper.
[Sarah Hall]

Guardian website wins award
Guardian Unlimited, the Guardian's website, has won a prestigious award for best use of new media by a media owner in the Revolution Awards. The judges said: "The great advantage of the Guardian's strategy, with its Unlimited network of sites, is that it takes all the strengths of the Guardian and the Observer newspapers and creates something new.

"Guardian Unlimited's sites are united by an overarching brand identity. They have the newspapers' tone, but are arranged in a way that takes advantage of the interactive medium."

They added: "The company uses the web to give a greater depth of information than it can in print, but it also uses the immediacy of the medium to provide more up-to-the-minute news."

The awards are sponsored by the new media business and marketing magazine Revolution.

Supporter of Shayler questioned
A London student was being questioned last night after being arrested under the official secrets act in connection with the former MI5 officer, David Shayler.

Julie Ann Davies, 36, was arrested at Kingston university, Surrey, by special branch officers with a warrant requiring the college to provide access to her computer.

She is understood to have been active in the campaign to get charges dropped against Mr Shayler. She was arrested under section 5 of the act covering the receipt and disclosure of official information without authority.

Peter Scott, vice chancellor of the university, said: "The university would be concerned if a discredited piece of legislation was being used to suppress legitimate investigation."
[Richard Norton-Taylor]

webTitle: Everest scramble to find body of pioneer

fields.headline: Everest scramble to find body of pioneer
fields.trailText: A scramble to recover the body of Everest pioneer Sandy Irvine, the mountaineer who died alongside George Mallory in 1924, is expected when the Himalayan climbing season begins next month.
fields.body:
A scramble to recover the body of Everest pioneer Sandy Irvine, the mountaineer who died alongside George Mallory in 1924, is expected when the Himalayan climbing season begins next month.

A leading climber warned yesterday that it could lead to a race as record numbers for a single season attempt to conquer Everest this spring. More than 40 expeditions including around 500 climbers are lining up to scale the world's highest peak.

Graham Hoyland, a BBC producer and a member of the team that discovered Mallory's body last May, is returning to Everest at the end of this month in an attempt to find and bury Irvine's body. He will also be looking for the small Kodak Vest Pocket camera, given to Mallory by Hoyland's great uncle Howard Somervell, which he hopes may carry conclusive photographic proof that Mallory and Irvine reached the summit.

Mallory and Irvine's 1924 attempt has become the stuff of mountaineering legend, and the discovery of Mallory's body last May renewed interest in the mystery of whether they became the first climbers to reach the summit. "I'm afraid there will be an unholy scramble for Sandy Irvine's body next spring, with several teams racing to capitalise on the media exposure that poor old George [Mallory] got. I'm worried that in addition to being dangerous, it would also be insensitive to his memory and the family," said Mr Hoyland, who in 1993 became the 15th Briton to scale the peak.

"I'd dearly love to prove I'm actually the 16th or 17th by showing that Mallory and Irvine were successful. To do that I need to find my great uncle's camera," he said.

Mr Hoyland is concerned to avoid a repeat of events when pictures of Mallory's corpse were published without the permission of his family. Mr Hoyland was not present on the day the body was found, having been taken ill.

"The climbers who found Mallory were not used to dealing with media interest, and pictures were sold when perhaps they should not have been. I'm afraid that were another team to find Sandy's body they may realise they can make money from selling pictures of his ravaged corpse. The family are concerned it be handled sensitively," he said.

Irvine's body is believed to be further up the mountain from where Mallory's was found, frozen upright in a sitting position with his face exposed, making the issue of pictures sensitive.

In 1979 during a Sino-Japanese expedition to the summit, a Chinese climber, Wang Hongbao, told a Japanese teammate, Ryoten Hasegawa, that during a 1975 expedition he had discovered "two English dead" on the mountain, one of them sitting upright. The following day Wang was killed in an avalanche and the location of the corpses died with him.

"The concern is that the body will be found by someone who hasn't got the experience of handling any artefacts, and who hasn't asked us what our wishes are," said Julie Summers, Irvine's great niece and curator of the trust to protect his memory and estate. "We have great respect for Graham Hoyland. He has consulted us, sent us a copy of a service he wants to read over the body and we are very grateful to him."

The interest about Irvine's remains come at a time when a boom in the number of operators offering trips and an improvement in equipment have brought the summit within range of even moderately experienced climbers.

"$50,000 (about £31,000) will get any reasonably fit human being a one in five chance of scaling the summit," said Roger Payne, general secretary of the British Mountaineering Council. "You can buy into a system which will give you the world's most experienced high altitude sherpas and excellent support at base camp. As long as you can put one foot in front of the other you have a chance"

Mr Hoyland believes the mountain remains both an extreme physical test, and a theatre in which the best and worst of human nature is starkly revealed. For every five who reach the summit, one will die. "Everest brings out the best and worst in people," he said.

"You see some true modern-day heroes up there, but you also see people walk past dying climbers because they want a chance at making the summit. People are dying up there as a result, and sadly it's often a sherpa. They are the real unsung heroes of Everest."

"I'm afraid there will be an unholy scramble for Sandy Irvine's body next spring, with several teams racing to capitalise on the media exposure that poor old George [Mallory] got. I'm worried that in addition to being dangerous, it would also be insensitive to his memory and the family," said Mr Hoyland, who in 1993 became the 15th Briton to scale the peak. "I'd dearly love to prove I'm actually the 16th or 17th by showing that Mallory and Irvine were successful. To do that I need to find my great uncle's camera," he said. Mr Hoyland is concerned to avoid a repeat of events when pictures of Mallory's corpse were published without the permission of his family. Mr Hoyland was not present on the day the body was found, having been taken ill. "The climbers who found Mallory were not used to dealing with media interest, and pictures were sold when perhaps they should not have been. I'm afraid that were another team to find Sandy's body they may realise they can make money from selling pictures of his ravaged corpse. The family are concerned it be handled sensitively," he said. Irvine's body is believed to be further up the mountain from where Mallory's was found, frozen upright in a sitting position with his face exposed, making the issue of pictures sensitive. In 1979 during a Sino-Japanese expedition to the summit, a Chinese climber, Wang Hongbao, told a Japanese teammate, Ryoten Hasegawa, that during a 1975 expedition he had discovered "two English dead" on the mountain, one of them sitting upright. The following day Wang was killed in an avalanche and the location of the corpses died with him. "The concern is that the body will be found by someone who hasn't got the experience of handling any artefacts, and who hasn't asked us what our wishes are," said Julie Summers, Irvine's great niece and curator of the trust to protect his memory and estate. "We have great respect for Graham Hoyland. He has consulted us, sent us a copy of a service he wants to read over the body and we are very grateful to him." The interest about Irvine's remains come at a time when a boom in the number of operators offering trips and an improvement in equipment have brought the summit within range of even moderately experienced climbers. "$50,000 (about £31,000) will get any reasonably fit human being a one in five chance of scaling the summit," said Roger Payne, general secretary of the British Mountaineering Council. "You can buy into a system which will give you the world's most experienced high altitude sherpas and excellent support at base camp. As long as you can put one foot in front of the other you have a chance" Mr Hoyland believes the mountain remains both an extreme physical test, and a theatre in which the best and worst of human nature is starkly revealed. For every five who reach the summit, one will die. "Everest brings out the best and worst in people," he said. "You see some true modern-day heroes up there, but you also see people walk past dying climbers because they want a chance at making the summit. People are dying up there as a result, and sadly it's often a sherpa. They are the real unsung heroes of Everest."

webTitle: Killer seeks damages for abuse in care

fields.headline: Killer seeks damages for abuse in care
fields.trailText: A man convicted of the brutal killing of a seven-year-old girl is to seek £50,000 compensation for ill-treatment he claims he suffered at a children's home at the centre of the North Wales abuse inquiry.
fields.body:
A man convicted of the brutal killing of a seven-year-old girl is to seek £50,000 compensation for ill-treatment he claims he suffered at a children's home at the centre of the North Wales abuse inquiry.

Howard Hughes, 34, described by the judge as a "fiend", was jailed for life at Chester crown court in 1996 for twice raping and then strangling Sophie Hook, from Great Budworth in Cheshire.

Hughes, known locally as Mad Howard, had snatched Sophie as she slept in a tent in her uncle's garden in Llandudno in August, 1995.

After killing her, he threw her body into the sea but it was later washed up on a beach.

Hughes, who has never admitted his guilt, spent time as a child at the notorious Bryn Estyn home in Wrexham, the subject of 138 complaints at the 18-month inquiry chaired by Sir Ronald Waterhouse.

The inquiry's report, published last month, made it clear that children at Bryn Estyn suffered both sexual and physical abuse at the hands of sadistic paedophiles.

Hughes, now in Full Sutton prison near York, is claiming compensation from Flintshire county council, one of the authorities which succeeded the former Clwyd county council which ran Bryn Estyn. He alleges he suffered personal injury while in care.

Hughes is believed to have no lawyer acting for him. In his statement to the high court, he writes: "My claim includes a claim for personal injuries and the value of the claim is £50,000 or more."

A spokeswoman for Zurich Municipal Mutual Insurance, which handles all claims against Flintshire, said yesterday: "The case has been passed to us and we will be handling it. But the matter is confidential and we cannot confirm the size of the claim."

Hughes's move prompted angry responses in Llandudno yesterday.

The town's mayor Alan Guinn said: "Children in care were badly treated and deserve compensation but the day Howard Hughes killed Sophie he gave away his rights."

fields.headline: Lloyd's names 'fleeced in £4bn fraud'
fields.standfirst: Investors who owe £50m claim cover-up over asbestos
fields.trailText: Lloyd's of London operated a fraudulent cover-up to suck in thousands of new investors who it intended to fleece to   pay a £4bn bill for asbestos-related claims, the high court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Lloyd's of London operated a fraudulent cover-up to suck in thousands of new investors who it intended to fleece to pay a £4bn bill for asbestos-related claims, the high court heard yesterday.

Senior figures were involved in the decade-long conspiracy, including three former chairmen, it was alleged. The fraud ran from 1978 to 1998, said Simon Goldblatt QC, but it was in 1982 that the final decision was made to "play asbestosis very gently". He said that 1982 was a pivotal year.

Mr Goldblatt, appearing for 231 investors who are suing Lloyd's for damages in a multi-million pound action after being left with bills of more than £50m, said his clients had been "risking their fortunes at the invitation of Lloyd's". They had been told that the insurance market was prudent, well-regulated, ethical and profitable.

Nothing could have been further from the truth, Mr Goldblatt alleged. Throughout the 1980s Lloyd's was teetering on the edge of bankruptcy, as enormous claims for asbestosis insurance stretching back to the 1950s flooded in from the US. A secret project codenamed "Foldrug" was launched at the highest levels of Lloyd's, with the aim, in part, of bringing in new names to bankroll the Lloyd's insurance syndicates.

Mr Goldblatt named 33 top Lloyd's figures from the period 1978-88, including former chairmen Sir Peter Miller, Sir David Rowland, later of NatWest bank, and David Coleridge, and also former deputy chairman Stephen Merrett. Each, depending on his position on various committees and other bodies, was responsible to a greater or lesser degree for the fraudulent recruitment, he said.

Mr Goldblatt said that despite the recruitment drive the "huge backlog" of asbestos claims "did break the market", just as Lloyd's had feared, in 1993. Mr Goldblatt said asbestosis was actually the least serious of three conditions related to asbestos, the substance installed across the western world as fireproof installation. Unlike the other two conditions - mesothelioma and lung cancer - asbestosis was "not necessarily always fatal", although it is "disabling".

Lloyd's, he said, had been barred from direct insurance business in all but two US states and the US Virgin Islands, but in the 1950s and 1960s it had been allowed to write surplus business, in other words to go "only where the domestic insurer didn't want to travel".

Its underwriters signed up for large numbers of asbestos insurance policies in the US and, once problems with the material became obvious in the mid-1970s, they consistently failed to set aside the necessary reserves to cover likely claims.

This was not accidental, said Mr Goldblatt. For Lloyd's to have publicly faced up to the likely "avalanche" of asbestos claims may have put off new investors and caused an exodus of existing investors.

Mr Goldblatt said that hiding the losses was made easier by "dinosaur accounting" and by a culture within the market in which "secrets are kept close to the chest".

Lloyd's denies all the allegations.

The case continues today .

fields.headline: Milburn launches heart crusade
fields.standfirst: £50m campaign to cut one of worst death rates in Europe
fields.trailText: A programme to cut heart disease to be overseen by a "tsar" and pump-primed with £50m of new money, was launched by the health secretary Alan Milburn yesterday in the hopes of saving 20,000 lives a year.
fields.body:
A programme to cut heart disease to be overseen by a "tsar" and pump-primed with £50m of new money, was launched by the health secretary Alan Milburn yesterday in the hopes of saving 20,000 lives a year.

The UK trails most of Europe in death rates with about 110,000 dying every year. About 300,000 a year have a heart attack and over 1.4m suffer from angina.

Mr Milburn called the launch of the national service framework the start of a crusade which he has marked out as a personal priority.

"Coronary heart disease hits the poorest hardest. Death rates are three times higher among unskilled men than among professional men. Worse still, those areas in the country with the highest level often have the poorest provision of services. Our country has one of the highest death rates in the developed world, yet our heart services have suffered from years of neglect," he said.

The national service framework for coronary heart disease which has taken top clinicians two years to put together is a blueprint for best practice, laying down guidelines for the next 10 years. It aims to ensure that everyone receives equal and high quality treatment.

The man charged with implementing the reforms is Roger Boyle, consultant cardiologist at York district hospital and a member of the 40-strong team of clinicians and NHS executives who put the document together under the chairmanship of Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians.

Dr Boyle, whose official title is national heart director but who has already been dubbed heart tsar because of the similarity of his job to that of cancer tsar Mike Richards, acknowledged yesterday that shrinking the inequality gap would be "a formidable challenge". Death rates under the age of 65 from coronary heart disease are nearly three times higher in Manchester than in Kingston and Richmond, Surrey.

"My job is to make this paper a living document," he said. "We need more doctors, more surgeons, more nurses, more operations and shorter waits."

The document presents an ambitious agenda , from setting up fast-track pain clinics in hospitals to see patients with suspected angina within two weeks of referral from a GP to speeding up ambulance response times so that heart attack victims get the urgent treatment that can save lives.

There will be 700 defibrillators in public places to help anybody who has a heart attack; clot-busting drugs will be made available within an hour of anyone calling for help; GPs must set up registers of patients at risk and ensure they are prescribed aspirins, beta blockers or cholesterol-lowering drugs to stave off further trouble. An extra 30 training places for consultant heart surgeons, in addition to the 80 announced last November, will be set up.

But the National Heart Forum, while praising the document as much needed , was critical of the focus on treatment when most heart disease was preventable. The document proposes more clinics to help people give up smoking and calls for health authorities and others to tackle obesity, exercise, smoking and diet.

Imogen Sharp, director of the forum, said: "We'd like to see equal emphasis on prevention and treatment. It is absolutely essential that this is all backed by comprehensive strategies for increased fruit and vegetable consumption and increased physical activity."

Others warned that the money so far announced - £50m last year and another £50m yesterday - would not be enough. Mike Pringle, chairman of the Royal College of General Practioners, welcomed the document, but said: "Our initial concerns are that there will be insufficient resources to carry out the wide-ranging measures outlined by the government and that doctors' workloads do not increase unreasonably."

The British Medical Association was also concerned about resources but welcomed the government's commitment to training.

fields.headline: Police censured over pub clash
fields.trailText: Police in riot gear used excessive and unjustified force to clear a pub packed with rival football fans, the police complaints authority ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
Police in riot gear used excessive and unjustified force to clear a pub packed with rival football fans, the police complaints authority ruled yesterday.

The authority said some officers from the tactical aid unit of Greater Manchester police had hit drinkers over the head with batons during scuffles in Wetherspoon's in the city centre on successive nights in April 1998.

No prosecutions followed because the officers, some wearing flash hoods designed for fire protection, could not be identified. The authority also found that none of the officers who drew their batons had filled in "use of force" forms which the force requires to be completed after such confrontations.

"Officers trained in public order control and equipped for this must have a role in protecting the public and preventing violence," said Ian Bynoe, who reviewed the investigation for the PCA.

"However, these incidents show what happens when they exceed their powers. Such use of excessive force can never be tolerated and it is very regrettable that the officers responsible could not be identified."

The investigation, by a Greater Manchester police officer supervised by a PCA member, was launched after 12 people complained about how 16 officers dealt with two outbreaks of trouble between Manchester United and Newcastle United supporters. The inquiry found there was serious disorder in the pub on April 4, with glasses and bottles being thrown, and the deployment of "suitably equipped" TAU officers was appropriate.

However the PCA found that one or more officers used too much force. Complaints of three assaults, including one by a pub patron struck on the head by an officer with a baton, were upheld.

Trouble flared the following night, some of it caught by security cameras. The PCA said police at the exits and on the street injured three people.

It said "officers will be reminded that batons were illegally used by one or some of their number".

webTitle: Key ring 'left trail to killer's front door'

fields.headline: Key ring 'left trail to killer's front door'
fields.trailText: A jury heard yesterday how a key ring dropped near a semi- naked body in a copse led police to the home of the alleged murderer.
fields.body:
A jury heard yesterday how a key ring dropped near a semi- naked body in a copse led police to the home of the alleged murderer.

Bristol crown court was told that Jenny King, 22, failed to return to her Bristol home after going out on Friday night, October 30 1998.

She was reported missing the next day, and her body was found by police three days later, beaten and strangled and with muddy footprints on her abdomen.

Roderick Denyer QC, prosecuting, told the court that the police had made a "painstaking" search of the dense copse of ivy and brambles, known as the Den, where the body was found, and after two days had discovered two keys on a ring.

The keys were later found to fit the front and back doors of the house in Bristol where Paul Hunt, 22, a factory worker, lived with his mother, the court heard. He denies a charge of murder.

Mr Denyer told the court that on the night in question, after going into Bristol city centre with a friend Miss King made her way to Chasers nightclub in Kingswood by 1am. Her brother Andrew, who was in Chasers that night, gave her a fiver to take a taxi home.

Unfortunately, said Mr Denyer, she had not taken one.

"She never got home and her brother reported her missing later that Saturday afternoon. Her body was discovered on the following Tuesday."

Ray and Margaret King sobbed in court as the prosecutor showed the jury of eight men and four women photographs of the murder scene and their daughter's body.

Mr Denyer said that she was found naked from the waist down. She had been severely beaten round the face. "She died because she was strangled, but she was beaten before she died," he told the jury.

Hunt was arrested on November 11, the court heard.

Fibres from a green Ralph Lauren shirt seized at his house after the arrest were an exact match with fibres found on clothes Miss King had been wearing on the night she died.

A pair of Truka shoes bought for Hunt by his mother were examined, the court heard, and the pattern and wear on the soles corresponded with marks on Miss King's stomach.

And soil samples from the shoes bore "a most striking similarity" to that of the Den area where the body was recovered.

Mr Denyer said that on the night in question Hunt had been out to a Bristol nightclub with a friend but had left alone at about 1.30am, as recorded on video camera.

At around 3.30 that morning Hunt's mother was woken by her son banging on the back door of the house they shared.

"He says he has lost his key so she has to let him into the house," Mr Denyer told the jury. "We say that the keys found at the scene close to Jenny's body are the defendant's keys, dropped by him during the course of his assault."

Mr Denyer told the court there was no evidence of any sexual assault to tie the defendant to the crime, but he argued that the evidence of the keys was overwhelming and the fabric and shoe pattern evidence strong.

"Put these various things together, and you have an overwhelming case that it was this defendant who killed Jenny King, probably around three o'clock in the morning of Saturday October 31 1998."

The trial continues and is expected to last up to three weeks.

fields.headline: Eco-protester, 16, wins test case
fields.trailText: The teenage eco-protester, Christiana Tugwell, who abandoned an Essex heathland camp after a prolonged siege by developers, won a potentially far-reaching legal case yesterday in the court of appeal.
fields.body:
The teenage eco-protester, Christiana Tugwell, who abandoned an Essex heathland camp after a prolonged siege by developers, won a potentially far-reaching legal case yesterday in the court of appeal.

Three judges ruled that measures to exclude and remove protesters from Etheldore Heath at Hockley, where 60 houses are to be built, had been premature and illegal and awarded Miss Tugwell, 16, costs.

The court acknowledged that the issue was now academic as far as Hockley was concerned, since the protest camp was abandoned after the last campaigner was removed from a tree last week.

The developers, Countryside Properties, were also found to have full legal ownership of the 11 acre site, which entitled them to move against squatters like Ms Tugwell, who was arrested last week for allegedly obstructing clearance work.

But Lord Justices Waller and Aldous and Mr Justice Rougier ruled that earlier action taken against the camp, starting last autumn, had no legal basis because Countryside did not have full title to the property until February. They overruled a verdict at the county court at Cambridge and a subsequent case at the high court in London.

The appeal court ordered Countryside to pay the costs of the three hearings. Miss Tugwell's solicitor, Richard Buxton, said the decision was "nationally important in warning developers not to act prematurely against legitimate protest".

"Countryside started taking action when they only had a right of access to the Hockley site, something they shared with people picking daffodils or enjoying walks," he said.

A Countryside spokeswoman said there had been a delay over paperwork in the transfer of title. The company had been painstaking in safeguarding wildlife on the site and took pride in environmental awareness.

Last month protesters claimed they were being denied food, while the company counter-attacked over allegedly spurious claims about rare newts. Mention of newts yesterday prompted Mr Justice Rougier to comment: "Newts? Does this mean that Mr Livingstone is involved?"

They overruled a verdict at the county court at Cambridge and a subsequent case at the high court in London. The appeal court ordered Countryside to pay the costs of the three hearings. Miss Tugwell's solicitor, Richard Buxton, said the decision was "nationally important in warning developers not to act prematurely against legitimate protest". "Countryside started taking action when they only had a right of access to the Hockley site, something they shared with people picking daffodils or enjoying walks," he said. A Countryside spokeswoman said there had been a delay over paperwork in the transfer of title. The company had been painstaking in safeguarding wildlife on the site and took pride in environmental awareness. Last month protesters claimed they were being denied food, while the company counter-attacked over allegedly spurious claims about rare newts. Mention of newts yesterday prompted Mr Justice Rougier to comment: "Newts? Does this mean that Mr Livingstone is involved?"

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Boys questioned over girl's rape
fields.body:
Boys questioned over girl's rape

Two boys, aged 12 and 13, have been questioned about the alleged rape of a nine-year-old girl in Hendon, Sunderland, police said last night. Northumbria police said the boys had been released on bail while inquiries continued.

Label GM foods, say MPs

Meat, milk, cheese and other dairy products from animals reared on genetically modified crops should be clearly labelled to improve consumer choice , the all-party Commons select committee on agriculture said yesterday. The MPs said the government and the EU must do more to provide information on GM origins of foods.
James Meikle

Pop star's drugs charge dropped

A heroin possession charge against the former lead singer of the Pogues, Shane MacGowan, has been dropped at Highbury Corner magistrates court, north London, the crown prosecution service said yesterday. He was charged in January.

Crest off RUC vehicles

The RUC crest will not appear on new vehicles belonging to the force from April 1, it was confirmed yesterday The RUC will also phase out police crimestopper and confidential telephone numbers from markings on its fleet of 2,000 cars and Land-Rovers, assistant chief constable Alan McQuillan said.

Radiohead to play Meltdown

Acclaimed rock band Radiohead are to play at the Meltdown festival at the Royal Festival Hall, London, on July 1. It will be their first British show for nearly three years.

webTitle: GCHQ to get new headquarters for £800m

fields.headline: GCHQ to get new headquarters for £800m
fields.trailText: GCHQ, the government's electronic spy centre, is to spend over £800m on new headquarters, the centre announced yesterday.
fields.body:
GCHQ, the government's electronic spy centre, is to spend over £800m on new headquarters, the centre announced yesterday.

A bagel-shaped complex, the size of Wembley stadium, will be built in the next four years at an existing GCHQ site in Cheltenham. It would ensure the centre's "readiness for the hi-tech national security and intelligence-gathering challenges of the 21st century", it said.

About £400m will be raised on the bond market by Integrated Accommodation Services, a consortium of Carillion (formerly Tarmac), Group 4 and British Telecom, which has been awarded the contract under the government's private finance initiative.

This sum will include the capital cost of the building, estimated at £330m, and interest on the loan. Total capital and running costs are estimated at £800m at today's prices over the next 30 years, during which the consortium will manage the project.

GCHQ said ministers took the decision after a rigorous review of the costs and how best to keep the centre operational.

It had "one of the largest and most sophisticated computer systems in the world, supporting the vital contribution GCHQ makes to national asecurity," it said.

Francis Richards, the centre's director, described the deal as excellent, combining "maximum efficiency, better working conditions for our staff and excellent value for money".

Critics of the private finance initiative, however, argue that it would be cheaper for the government itself to raise money on the bond market, and that by leasing the building for 30 years from the private consortium it will be paying more than if it had simply been given the money by the treasury.

Parliament's intelligence and security committee said last year that GCHQ had already increased its original estimate, and expressed concern about the risks of further increases.

GCHQ described itself yesterday as Britain's signals intelligence agency, providing "vital services to government departments and military commands in support of the government's security, defence, foreign and economic policies".

What it did not say is that it works closely with the US national security agency eavesdropping on commercial as well as diplomatic and military communications through a worldwide network of satellites and ground stations.

The NSA runs Menwith Hill, near Harrogate, North Yorkshire, one of America's largest eavesdropping centres, officially described as an RAF station.

GCHQ, officially responsible to the foreign office, employs about 4,500 civilians and 2,000 military personnel. Its annual budget is estimated at £500m.

How the cost compares

Dome: £758m
Thames House MI5 HQ, and Vauxhall Cross MI6 HQ (joint cost): £547m
British Library: £520m
Portcullis House: £250m
Tate Modern: £134m

webTitle: Blairs sue nanny, agent and paper for £15,000

fields.headline: Blairs sue nanny, agent and paper for £15,000
fields.standfirst: Legal action over book showing life in 'extraordinary household'New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Cherie Blair is suing a former nanny, Rosalind Mark, her former literary agent Jonathan Harris, and the Mail on Sunday for £15,000, Downing Street said last night.
fields.body:
Cherie Blair is suing a former nanny, Rosalind Mark, her former literary agent Jonathan Harris, and the Mail on Sunday for £15,000, Downing Street said last night. Meanwhile Ms Mark issued a statement saying her book was meant to illustrate life in an "extraordinary household environment".

Extracts from the book were published in early editions of the Mail on Sunday before Mrs Blair obtained an injunction claiming their publication breached a confidentiality agreement between Ms Mark and the Blairs by revealing details of family life at Downing Street.

Ms Mark said her book was not intended to hurt the Blairs nor invade their privacy, and in a statement defended her decision to write about the Blairs, saying: "The book was written from a social history perspective as an account of an ordinary person living within an extraordinary household environment.

"I worked for the Blairs for four and-a-half years and I would never seek to invade their or their children's privacy. The book is purely a social history and, as previously mentioned, nothing would have been published without the Blairs' consent."

Ms Mark added she had terminated her agreement with her literary agent on February 24. She said she was contacted by the Mail on Sunday on Friday March 3 asking for her comments.

"I reluctantly gave them my account of the reasons why I was writing the book. I was subsequently offered by the paper a serialisation contract and fully expensed hotel accommodation which I immediately declined.

"I contacted Downing Street following my conversation with the Mail on Sunday and they said they were happy with my account.

"Downing Street were also contacted by the Mail on Sunday and at no stage did the Mail on Sunday reveal to myself or Downing Street that they had extracts from the draft transcript."

She said the book was "only to be published, if at all, with the full consent of the Blairs. I was never to make any money from this venture and any proceeds would go directly to the charity Refuge."

Apart from claiming £15,000 from the three defendants, Mrs Blair's statement of claim, lodged at the high court in London, also included demands for confidential material about the Blairs to be returned and for nothing further to be published.

A spokesman for Downing Street said the £15,000 figure was only a "technicality" to enable the case to proceed. "The question of actual damages is not one that Mrs Blair has addressed," he added. "At the moment she is more interested in seeing the injunction upheld and protecting the family's privacy."

Lord Falconer, a cabinet office minister and close family friend, said Mrs Blair had been extremely upset by the Mail on Sunday's story.

The newspaper - which was forced to withdraw the report from its later editions after the Blairs obtained a court injunction early on Sunday - has said it intends to defend the case "vigorously" in the courts.

Lord Falconer, however, stressed the Blairs' determination to protect the privacy of their three children. "It is quite an unusual job being prime minister, and therefore Tony and Cherie are quite determined that their children should lead as normal a life as possible," he said. "It is not very normal to see details of your life on the front page of the Mail on Sunday."

Downing Street said Ms Mark had signed a formal confidentiality agreement with Mrs Blair when she took the job. Mrs Blair's statement of claim alleges breach of the agreement and seeks the return of a 450-page manuscript and computer disk containing Ms Mark's account.

Although the injunction does not cover Scottish newspapers, Downing Street has indicated legal steps would be taken in Scotland if newspapers there attempted to publish information covered by the English injunction.

The prime minister's official spokesman said Ms Mark now wished she had never become involved in the whole affair. "The prime minister believes Ros is basically a good person and continues to believe it," he said.

Aides regard Ms Mark as "still a friend of the family" who, while "vain and naive", was out of her depth.

In a statement yesterday the newspaper said the privacy of the Blairs' children was not in dispute. The injunction was granted on grounds of breach of confidence, "another matter entirely".

The paper had taken "scrupulous care not to intrude on the Blair children's privacy in any way in its article. This would be plainly evident to anyone who has seen one of the 1.5m ungagged copies of the newspaper distributed this weekend.

"Although the terms of the injunction are so wide it is now impossible to spell out what the article did contain, we are convinced the issues it raised are of genuine political and public interest."

webTitle: New faces:  Hollywood's promising young actors pose in the name of Vanity

fields.headline: New faces:  Hollywood's promising young actors pose in the name of Vanity
fields.trailText: They may not look that familiar now - but chances are they will do soon.
fields.body:
They may not look that familiar now - but chances are they will do soon.

Vanity Fair, the American magazine which takes celebrity culture seriously, has anointed nine young actors as its stars of tomorrow.

Having spotted the likes of Leonardo DiCaprio, Cameron Diaz and Cate Blanchett early in their careers - and given a leg-up to a struggling, little-known Australian called Nicole Kidman a few years back - the Vanity Fair stamp of approval is said to be worth $1m on a star's fee.

The glossy, which combines copious amounts of "eye candy" starlet photospreads with wodges of intellectual roughage, so prides itself on its talent-spotting abilities that it devotes an issue every year to its young Hollywood pretenders.

The Class of 2000 includes two stars from the Oscar favourite American Beauty - Mena Suvari, who played the high school temptress, and Wes Bentley, the freakish teenage drug dealer - alongside the obscure Marley Shelton and Jordana Brewster.

The only halfway established name is Penelope Cruz, the Spanish model turned actress who played a nun who dies of Aids after having sex with a transsexual prostitute in Pedro Almodovar's All About My Mother.

All adorn the cover in a group shot by the celebrity photographer Annie Leibovitz, Hollywood's answer to Van Dyck, and an artist who could make Wilfred Bramble look handsome.

However, the Vanity Fair list is not infallible.

British actresses Thandie Newton and Anna Friel made it into the frame last year, and although both have had good years on stage and screen, neither has quite broken through.

Nor are their contemporaries - the likes of Omar Epps, Barry Pepper and Vinessa Shaw - quite household names either.

fields.headline: Passport Control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why.
fields.body:
Good cop, bad cop... Be aware that we're playing host to not one but two US cultural behemoths this week, in the rotund shape of cigar aficionado James Belushi, and the silver-haired form of walking deadpan masterclass Leslie Nielsen. The latter, in town right this moment, is preparing for his imminent performance in Clarence Darrow, the courtroom drama wherein the man best known as the Naked Gun series' Lt Frank Drebin will - implausible as it may sound - follow in the footsteps of Henry Fonda in essaying the title role. The play begins its residency at the Theatre Royal, Lincoln, before embarking on a UK tour which includes a London run in May. Belushi, meanwhile, is also resident as you read, having pitched up yesterday for a brief stopover plugging his latest vehicle, the straight-to-video cop-dog buddy flick K911: the original, you see, was called K9 - hence the multi-layered genius of the title. Fantastic ! Anyway, having regaled the press with countless hilarious anecdotes from the set (etc), he heads back to the States later tonight. Unfortunately, even in the age of pet passports, the likelihood of his more talented co-star, Mac the German Shepherd, arriving to carouse with the nation's journalists remains open to question.

Croon feeding... But let's not be guilty of neglecting another pair of giants among men currently en route to the UK. So yes, if you would ladies and gentlemen, please put your hands together for Englebert Humperdinck and Harry Connick Jr, independently dropping into London very soon indeed for respective performances at the Palladium (on Thursday) and the Albert Hall (next Monday). Sorry to be a party pooper again, but neither party will be sticking around long, although - just in case you were getting too downcast - Englebert will return in April for a full national tour. Sing Hallelujah!

fields.headline: Secret life of a nanny
fields.standfirst: They don't just look after children - they see their employers half naked, arguing and know just what's in the bathroom cabinet. No wonder boundaries are crossed, as the Blairs discovered. Sally Weale reportsNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: They don't just look after children - they see their employers half naked, arguing and know just what's in the bathroom cabinet. No wonder boundaries are crossed, as the Blairs discovered.
fields.body:
Nannies used to be cheery, pink-cheeked ladies, like Mary Poppins, who took themselves and their charges off to the nursery, reappearing only when the children were ready to be bundled off to prep school. Nowadays they are an integral part of family life. Nannies live with us, they work for us and in between there's a whole raft of slippery uncertainties to negotiate - with potentially disastrous consequences.

This week, the Blairs have found out just how tricky the relationship can be after the Mail on Sunday attempted to publish intimate details of family life apparently based on information obtained from Rosalind Mark, nanny to Euan, Nicky and Kathryn Blair for four years (a long time as nanny jobs go). The detail of the case is yet to be resolved but it highlights the level of trust which must exist between employer and employee and the complex intimacy that exists between them.

Few of us got the opportunity to read about the Blairs at home - even if we had wanted to - because publication was halted after Cherie Blair obtained a high court injunction. But we can all imagine what it might be like to have the mess and muddle of our private lives made public by someone with such an intimate knowledge of one's family life.

There can, after all, be few jobs in which you get to (accidentally, of course) read your employers' bank statement discarded on the breakfast table; share their bathroom; count up their condoms and witness their rows at first hand. But you do if you're a nanny. You see them in their dressing gowns, you have to flush the toilet after them, step over their toe-nail cuttings and make a hasty retreat when you walk in on them kissing or, worse, having sex.

"It does happen," says Sue Richney, 22, who has been a nanny since she was 16 and has been in her current post for 18 months, looking after two girls, aged two and five. "It can be very difficult. You are with them every day. You are living with them. You witness their personal lives at first hand. Of course you get to know them intimately, but you don't share it with anyone else outside the family.

"If there's a family feud going on for example, you just get out of the room and find yourself something to do. You know it's none of your business. If you come across the bank account of your employer and you suddenly notice that they haven't got any money, and you're worried about what that means for you, you can't get involved. You can't sit down and say 'I know you're having financial problems'. You have to wait for them to come to you.

"Then there are things you hear that you don't want to hear, like when they're arguing. But you just have to shut the door and keep out of the way.

"You see things around the house. You see everything. In previous jobs I've walked in on my employers kissing. The employers' bedroom is their own. You've got no place in that room, whether they're in or not . But it's hard if you have to share a bathroom and see all those normal things that people have in bathrooms. You see the Tampax and condoms. You think, I know what you've been doing last night. But you don't really want to know."

Confidentiality, according to Kay Crosse, principal of Norland College, which trains nannies, is central to the relationship between a nanny and her family. "We make it quite clear in our training that it's part of a code of professional conduct. There should not be any abuse of the privileged relationship which exists with their employer."

Many parents now include confi- dentiality clauses (the Blairs did, apparently) but the problems don't stop there. A nanny not only has to be equipped to look after the children, she also needs a PhD in social skills to negotiate the tensions and complexities of family life. One of the key difficulties for both nannies and employers is the blurring of the relationship. It's hard to maintain the purely employer-employee relationship when you're sharing the intimacy of a family home.

"It's a very personal, close relationship. That's the way it should be," says Richney. "But at the same time you have to keep a professional distance. It's when you start to become close friends and start to discuss personal issues that problems can occur. You gossip about your friends - you talk about them to other friends. You can't do that with your employer.

"I wouldn't discuss boyfriends with my employers, for example, and I don't hug my employers. It's not that I don't like them, but once you cross that border, it makes it difficult to bring up difficult issues like money and hours."

For some parents, the nanny is a godsend, for others she is little more than a necessary evil. "I think it's a doomed relationship," says Anne Smithey, whose two-year-old son is looked after by a nanny three days a week. "You can only hope to tolerate each other in the end. You couldn't invent a working relationship more likely to be stressful and at some point more abused by one side or another. It's unnaturally intimate. Who wants a strange person coming into your house first thing in the morning when you're still in your dressing gown? And there's this constant eroding of barriers between employer and employee.

"It means you can't deliver a straightforward request or some perfectly justified piece of criticism without it becoming an enormous emotional farrago. You're employing them on a proper basis, you're paying stamps and tax and all that, then all they do is talk back at you and argue with you.

"I think my nanny's really good, she's brilliant with my child, she works hard and plays hard with her, and I'd recommend her to anyone, but I hate her. Everything about her irritates me. It's inherent in the job. I've spent more time in the last three years burning with anxiety, resentment, fury about what the nanny's doing than I have with on any other subject," says Smithey.

"It's unbelievably stressful. It's such a competitive relationship. You desperately want your nanny to love your child because you want them to protect the child with as much ferocity as if it was her own. You want your child to feel completely secure, within a relationship of intimacy and love, but at the same time that excludes you." It is this kind of competitiveness which apparently led to tension between the Princess of Wales and her children's nanny, Tiggy Legge-Bourke.

"They treat you like a friend and discuss their intimate details with you, which I'm really not interested in. I know my nanny's menstrual cycle better than my own! They think they're part of the family. And that's the massive blackmail - once they are in your house and they get on with your child and your child likes them they've got you over a barrel.

"They know if you sack them you endanger your child's emotional health, plus you have to the whole rigmarole of going to an agency, paying out lots of money to find a new nanny who probably won't please you any more than the last."

The nanny mafia, the hand that rocks the cradle, the kiss 'n' tell nanny . . . it's a social minefield for people who may never have been employers before, and for nannies who are sometimes barely mature enough to negotiate relationships with their own families, let alone someone else's.

Where is Mary Poppins when we need her?
