Nowadays they are an integral part of family life. Nannies live with us, they work for us and in between there's a whole raft of slippery uncertainties to negotiate - with potentially disastrous consequences. This week, the Blairs have found out just how tricky the relationship can be after the Mail on Sunday attempted to publish intimate details of family life apparently based on information obtained from Rosalind Mark, nanny to Euan, Nicky and Kathryn Blair for four years (a long time as nanny jobs go). The detail of the case is yet to be resolved but it highlights the level of trust which must exist between employer and employee and the complex intimacy that exists between them. Few of us got the opportunity to read about the Blairs at home - even if we had wanted to - because publication was halted after Cherie Blair obtained a high court injunction. But we can all imagine what it might be like to have the mess and muddle of our private lives made public by someone with such an intimate knowledge of one's family life. There can, after all, be few jobs in which you get to (accidentally, of course) read your employers' bank statement discarded on the breakfast table; share their bathroom; count up their condoms and witness their rows at first hand. But you do if you're a nanny. You see them in their dressing gowns, you have to flush the toilet after them, step over their toe-nail cuttings and make a hasty retreat when you walk in on them kissing or, worse, having sex. "It does happen," says Sue Richney, 22, who has been a nanny since she was 16 and has been in her current post for 18 months, looking after two girls, aged two and five. "It can be very difficult. You are with them every day. You are living with them. You witness their personal lives at first hand. Of course you get to know them intimately, but you don't share it with anyone else outside the family. "If there's a family feud going on for example, you just get out of the room and find yourself something to do. You know it's none of your business. If you come across the bank account of your employer and you suddenly notice that they haven't got any money, and you're worried about what that means for you, you can't get involved. You can't sit down and say 'I know you're having financial problems'. You have to wait for them to come to you. "Then there are things you hear that you don't want to hear, like when they're arguing. But you just have to shut the door and keep out of the way. "You see things around the house. You see everything. In previous jobs I've walked in on my employers kissing. The employers' bedroom is their own. You've got no place in that room, whether they're in or not . But it's hard if you have to share a bathroom and see all those normal things that people have in bathrooms. You see the Tampax and condoms. You think, I know what you've been doing last night. But you don't really want to know." Confidentiality, according to Kay Crosse, principal of Norland College, which trains nannies, is central to the relationship between a nanny and her family. "We make it quite clear in our training that it's part of a code of professional conduct. There should not be any abuse of the privileged relationship which exists with their employer." Many parents now include confi- dentiality clauses (the Blairs did, apparently) but the problems don't stop there. A nanny not only has to be equipped to look after the children, she also needs a PhD in social skills to negotiate the tensions and complexities of family life. One of the key difficulties for both nannies and employers is the blurring of the relationship. It's hard to maintain the purely employer-employee relationship when you're sharing the intimacy of a family home. "It's a very personal, close relationship. That's the way it should be," says Richney. "But at the same time you have to keep a professional distance. It's when you start to become close friends and start to discuss personal issues that problems can occur. You gossip about your friends - you talk about them to other friends. You can't do that with your employer. "I wouldn't discuss boyfriends with my employers, for example, and I don't hug my employers. It's not that I don't like them, but once you cross that border, it makes it difficult to bring up difficult issues like money and hours." For some parents, the nanny is a godsend, for others she is little more than a necessary evil. "I think it's a doomed relationship," says Anne Smithey, whose two-year-old son is looked after by a nanny three days a week. "You can only hope to tolerate each other in the end. You couldn't invent a working relationship more likely to be stressful and at some point more abused by one side or another. It's unnaturally intimate. Who wants a strange person coming into your house first thing in the morning when you're still in your dressing gown? And there's this constant eroding of barriers between employer and employee. "It means you can't deliver a straightforward request or some perfectly justified piece of criticism without it becoming an enormous emotional farrago. You're employing them on a proper basis, you're paying stamps and tax and all that, then all they do is talk back at you and argue with you. "I think my nanny's really good, she's brilliant with my child, she works hard and plays hard with her, and I'd recommend her to anyone, but I hate her. Everything about her irritates me. It's inherent in the job. I've spent more time in the last three years burning with anxiety, resentment, fury about what the nanny's doing than I have with on any other subject," says Smithey. "It's unbelievably stressful. It's such a competitive relationship. You desperately want your nanny to love your child because you want them to protect the child with as much ferocity as if it was her own. You want your child to feel completely secure, within a relationship of intimacy and love, but at the same time that excludes you." It is this kind of competitiveness which apparently led to tension between the Princess of Wales and her children's nanny, Tiggy Legge-Bourke. "They treat you like a friend and discuss their intimate details with you, which I'm really not interested in. I know my nanny's menstrual cycle better than my own! They think they're part of the family. And that's the massive blackmail - once they are in your house and they get on with your child and your child likes them they've got you over a barrel. "They know if you sack them you endanger your child's emotional health, plus you have to the whole rigmarole of going to an agency, paying out lots of money to find a new nanny who probably won't please you any more than the last." The nanny mafia, the hand that rocks the cradle, the kiss 'n' tell nanny . . . it's a social minefield for people who may never have been employers before, and for nannies who are sometimes barely mature enough to negotiate relationships with their own families, let alone someone else's. Where is Mary Poppins when we need her?

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Avengers | Cry-Baby | Big Wednesday | Barry Lyndon
fields.body:
The Avengers

(Jeremiah Chechik, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

A flat Hollywood version (pictured) of the TV series, though there are things to enjoy. The plot has Sean Connery's evil weatherman Sir August de Wynter holding the British climate to ransom: an admirably loopy idea that would have appealed to the original's writers. But while Ralph Fiennes makes a decent John Steed, Uma Thurman's cat-suited Emma Peel lacks claws. The fleeting presence of Patrick Macnee, the original Steed is another reminder of just what a classy, charming act the small screen version was.

Cry-Baby

(John Waters, 1990)

10pm, Sky Cinema

Johnny Depp plays Wade "Cry-Baby" Walker, Elvis-like leader of rock 'n' roll crew the Drapes in 50s Baltimore; Amy Locane is the girl who revs his bike. The straighter-looking Squares are their sworn enemies in this brash and sexy ode to the teen movie, which sports a pop-icons' hall of fame: Iggy Pop, Troy Donahue, Patty Hearst; plus Joe Dallesandro and Willem Dafoe.

Big Wednesday

(John Milius, 1978)

10pm, FilmFour

Spanning 12 years from the late 60s to the mid 70s, this is a gentle and accurately observed study of the way friendships shift as the freedom of youth gives way to adulthood. It's also one of the greatest surfing movies. Gary Busey, Jan Michael Vincent and William Katt ride the Californian swells together over the years, building a sense of the unspoken loyalties and tensions between themselves.

Barry Lyndon

(Stanley Kubrick, 1975)

2.10am, FilmFour

Thackeray's story of an 18th century Irish lad making his way in the world by duelling, gambling and loving sounds a ripping yarn, but Kubrick turns it into a museum-piece. Full of exquisite images, presumably exact in every period detail, but the characters are reduced to decorative mannequins. Miscast Ryan O'Neal makes a sorry hero, while an estimable cast including Marisa Berenson, Patrick Magee, Hardy Kruger and Leonard Rossiter fare little better. But just marvel at the highly polished veneer.

fields.headline: The thieves of Baghdad
fields.trailText: Paying The Price: Killing The Children Of Iraq | Cry Wolf | Flying Vets
fields.body:
In a Baghdad cancer hospital, 200 patients share one bottle of aspirin. Morphine isn't available to alleviate the patients' pain, you understand, because of United Nations sanctions against Iraq. In place since 1990 and Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait, the sanctions mean that morphine, along with other medicines, clean water, fresh foods, electricity and soap have been out of the reach of ordinary Iraqi citizens. Pain is about all they have left. That, and a dignity which they displayed in abundance throughout John Pilger's heart-breaking film, Paying The Price: Killing The Children Of Iraq (ITV).

And if that weren't enough, they also have the hollow words of Tony Blair, Robin Cook and George Bush, who assured them - or rather, us - that the Iraqi people are not our enemy. Sanctions are designed, you understand, to bring down Saddam and not to bring misery to those already suffering under the despot.

While children die of diphtheria, women suffer terminal breast cancer and families auction their belongings to buy food, Pilger interviewed representatives of the West sitting in their plush offices, coiffed and well-groomed. They took issue with World Health Organisation figures which estimate 500,000 children have died in Iraq because of the embargo. They talked of the undesirable effects of sanctions, the tough choices that have to be made, the difficult position in which they find themselves. Yet in their offices with cheap-looking expensive artwork, it was hard to imagine them in a position quite as difficult as suffering the agonising pain of cancer with the only relief taking the shape of half an aspirin.

But hey, at least all this suffering means that Saddam can't get his hands on weapons of mass destruction. With vaccines for yellow fever banned, medical equipment unavailable and even toilet soap regarded as contraband, there was no chance of him developing chemical weapons, beating the world to death with an IV drip or, um, cleaning us to death. A hellish farce, to be sure.

Typically, Pilger's passion burned fiercely at the heart of this film alongside that of Dennis Halliday, a UN official who was so sickened by the sanctions, he resigned, though not before breaking the blockade himself to get vital drugs to an Iraqi girl suffering from leukemia. Through their words, and the pictures of children malnourished and bug-eyed with disease, children being punished for crimes perpetrated before they were even born, Paying The Price was a stark portrait of what our political masters think is a fair price worth paying for keeping the world safe for us.

If you didn't know better, you would think that the UN - benevolent, just, concerned - were deliberately trying to kill off Iraq and its culture, starting with its children. Halliday and Pilger do know better and that's what they think. It was hard not to agree with them. Paying The Price was the kind of film that should have us searching our souls but will probably have us flicking over.

It would have had us flicking over to Cry Wolf (BBC1).

From the cheeky oboe of the theme tune and the flimsy jokes and characterisation - which made the MDF set look like the Pyramids at Giza - watching this was like the 90s never happened: the spirit of Duty Free alive and well.

Dr Wolf - actually played by Dr Bramwell from ITV - had a fling with her boss-to-be and four months later, started work at his surgery. With the obligatory unsympathetic receptionist (see also My Hero and a couple of series of Casualty) and a dippy health visitor, the surgery was in Elephant and Castle, which required the schemey hypochondriac expectant single mum, Cherry, to say things like "Mel Gibson - gorgeous ain't he!" Poverty, worra larf.

Anyway, Dr Wolf was pregnant too and lo, the father was her boss, who, incidentally, lives on a houseboat. In the weeks to come, we will presumably be treated to clashes between Dr Wolf, all-glacial Penelope Keith, and her boss, the slightly giddy, older-man-becoming-a-father, Dr Hook. She says she doesn't love him now, but you can bet over the series, the will-they, won't-they thing will be milked silly.

Missy, the corn snake, had eggs stuck in her bits in Flying Vets (Channel 5) so Mark, the expert in lower vertebrates like fish and lizards, set about her with a scalpel. Then, he may well have been heading off the United Nations.

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Moby
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Moby
fields.body:
Full Name: Richard Melville Hall

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

See above, please. Actually, Moby is a name given to me by my parents, they tell me that I'm related to Herman Melville. Perhaps it's true. My e-mail pseudonym is Anne Onymousse - I think that's clever, but I'm simple, so what do I know?

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?

Yes - when I was young I used to lie about my age to get into concerts and clubs. Rather conventional, I'm afraid.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Bald musician who prefers giving oral sex to receiving it.

What was the last illegal thing you did?

It's sad, but I don't know. Any suggestions?

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Listened to a drunk tell me about spirituality.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Michael Patterson (also Beck and Puff Daddy's engineer).

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

I'm either lucky or pathetic, 'cause I can't think of anyone.

Has a critic ever made you cry?

With laughter?

What would you advertise without a fee?

The World Trade Organization.

What would you never advertise?

Sock puppets.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning?

Dreams of being buried alive.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

More things than I could possibly list here.

Moby's single Natural Blues is out now (Mute)

fields.headline: I'm a believer
fields.standfirst: Still saddled with their image as the prefab Fab Four, The Monkees have finally been given the ultimate celebrity accolade: a TV movie biopic. Maybe it's time we gave them the credit they deserve, argues  Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: Still saddled with their image as the prefab Fab Four, The Monkees have finally been given the ultimate celebrity accolade: a TV movie biopic. Maybe it's time we gave them the credit they deserve.
fields.body:
For the American famous, perpetuity comes one of three ways. Should your star finally ascend to the cultural firmament, you either get yellowed-up for a guest spot on The Simpsons; stick your hands in wet cement outside Mann's Chinese Theater; or - most grandly of all - find yourself the subject of a low-budget, late-night TV movie. It happened to Woody Allen, it happened to Letterman, it happened to Bill Gates, Roseanne and The Beatles. So it's only surprising it took 30 years to happen to The Monkees.

Which isn't to say Daydream Believers - tritely named after the band's most enduring number, and currently in production somewhere in Toronto - doesn't have the raw material. The premise alone (four random showbiz kids wind up in a slapstick sitcom about their entirely fictional pop group) is fertile enough. Throw in the wild disparities of the personalities involved, a backdrop of late 60s social hubub, and the seditious transformation from jobbing actors into proper musicians, gleefully banging out their own chipper tunes on prime-time, and what have you got? Pure narrative gold-dust: a reality far fruitier than fiction.

And, as such, there's a certain symmetry to the return to the small-screen. After all, while many of the records they produced both before and after the lunge for autonomy were great, it was as a totem of TV's spongy vulnerability to the world off-set that Messrs Dolenz, Nesmith, Tork and Jones made history. Because the show wasn't just hugely popular; in going from actors playing a band to a band playing actors (playing a band), they turned the entire medium in on itself - and, at least initially, took their hormone-loaded fanbase with them as they did so. The Monkees, in short, perfected postmodernism two decades before it was invented. All we need now is the cast of the biopic to start furtively practicing their instruments and the cycle will be complete.

Sadly, however, that looks unlikely. To wit, aping series creators Bob Rafelson and Bert Schneider, the producers of Daydream Believers recently held open casting calls across Canada and the US, appealing for unknowns to step forward and "Be A Monkee". What they found was the usual mob of waiters with pretensions and, less predictably, a yawning lack of awareness of the subject matter.

Said ignorance was perhaps best illustrated by one 25-year-old wannabe, Christopher Bernard, who reportedly seemed aghast at the discovery that - being African-Canadian - he might not be ideally placed for the role of Davy Jones. "Well," he countered, "I know the director probably has some preconceived notions of what he's looking for - but maybe if I don't get Davy, they'll keep me in mind for something else." Meanwhile, at least one bright young thing called to ask whether he should bring his own costume to try out as a monkey.

You can only hope such doziness is a demographic blip. Which isn't just nostalgia talking. True, for the generation in and around its late twenties, The Monkees (the show) will always be a memory lane riot of fireman's poles and woolly hats. Equally, yes, no matter how cheesy their baby got - meaning the obligatory wistful-Davy-on-a-beach scene - Schneider and Rafelson pulled off a format not even the US networks have had the chutzpah to attempt since (despite putative rip-offs involving the Beastie Boys, Supergrass, and, God forbid, Hanson).

But all that's beside the point: the crying shame would be if we lost touch with the band behind the funny costumes. What keeps The Monkees uniquely pertinent is that they give us a version of the 60s free of cliché and mawk. Notwithstanding the modish haircuts of '66, theirs wasn't an age of moptop naivety; in fact, they owed their very existence to the domestication of pop as (in the words of their seminal big-screen outing Head) "a manufactured image with no philosophies".

Yet, at the same time - notwithstanding the modish haircuts of '68 - their creative coup d'etat remained untainted by the gormlessness of flower power. Musically, what they turned out after their break from the session men was closer to the primal stew of garage than the whimsy of The Beatles (let's face it, it was Stepping Stone the Sex Pistols covered, not Ob-Li-Di-Ob-Li-Da).

And, more importantly, their mutiny involved risk. With Nixon newly installed at the White House, it was easy to flirt with the avant-garde and insurrectionary politics if you were John Lennon; if you were The Monkees, it meant biting the hand that fed you, while facing the derision of the same hipsters who would later give corporate America its next generation of downsize-happy execs. Neither cutie-pie innocents nor plastic revolutionaries, The Monkees simply went their own, always fascinating and frequently inspired, sweet way.

So, even if Daydream Believers proves every bit as shoddy as low-budget, late-night TV movies tend to be; even if it fails to cover anything beyond the filming of Head; and even if (and you can put money on this one) the cast look absolutely nothing like the people they're supposed to be playing, I don't care. If it means The Monkees and their brief stint as the most essential pop group on the planet live on, it's a price worth paying.

Then again, if it means another reunion album, maybe it's not.

Neither cutie-pie innocents nor plastic revolutionaries, The Monkees simply went their own, always fascinating and frequently inspired, sweet way. So, even if Daydream Believers proves every bit as shoddy as low-budget, late-night TV movies tend to be; even if it fails to cover anything beyond the filming of Head; and even if (and you can put money on this one) the cast look absolutely nothing like the people they're supposed to be playing, I don't care. If it means The Monkees and their brief stint as the most essential pop group on the planet live on, it's a price worth paying. Then again, if it means another reunion album, maybe it's not.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Carnaval 2000 | File On 4
fields.body:
Lord Reith, that grave Presbyterian, will doubtless spin even more vigorously at the prospect of five hours of BBC airtime pulsating with pre-Lenten jollity. Carnaval 2000 (7.0pm, Radio 2) is being transmitted live from Rio de Janeiro, scene of the world's largest and most flamboyant Mardi Gras celebration. Nick Barraclough (pictured) sets the scene for an evening devoted to live music with intermediate segments offering a brisk cultural history of Brazil, from Carmen Miranda to chorino.

The English Arts Council got a thorough drubbing from Parliament's Public Accounts Committee a few week's back, accused of wasting huge sums of lottery and taxpayers' money and of generally failing to put its house in order. The Scottish and Welsh councils have come under local fire on similar grounds. In File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4) Mark Whitaker surveys the ramshackle system of funding the arts in Britain and asks if we should now be looking for something entirely different.

webTitle: Official candidates eclipsed in survey confirms Ken's cross-party charm

fields.headline: Official candidates eclipsed in survey confirms Ken's cross-party charm
fields.standfirst:
ICM poll: Half of Tories would vote for Livingstone

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The breathtaking 55% poll lead that Ken Livingstone has built up in the battle to be the first elected mayor of London is reinforced by nearly every detail of the findings of the Guardian/ICM opinion poll.
fields.body:
The breathtaking 55% poll lead that Ken Livingstone has built up in the battle to be the first elected mayor of London is reinforced by nearly every detail of the findings of the Guardian/ICM opinion poll.

Mr Livingstone's cross-party popularity in London has become so great more than 70% of Labour and Liberal Democrat voters in the capital say they will support him against their party candidates - and an extraordinary 48% of Conservative voters say they will back him.

The poll shows that Livingstone's support is solid at over 60% among both men and women, across all social classes and all age groups.

Steven Norris, the Tory candidate, is humiliatingly eclipsed by Mr Livingstone among Conservative voters. Mr Norris, who has 11% support overall, secures only 40% of the Tory vote, compared with 48% for Mr Livingstone. The poll indicates that the Tory voters will be engaging in tactical voting on a scale unseen for more than 20 years.

The detail of the poll spells only despair for Frank Dobson. He might have hoped that those who were supporting Mr Livingstone - particularly Labour voters - were doing it only as a mid-term whinge at the performance of the Labour government.

But when those who said they intended to vote Ken were asked about their motives it was the personality factor that proved the strongest of all.

Nearly all Livingstone voters think he has been treated unfairly by Labour. Two thirds think that Frank Dobson is a weak candidate and want to give Tony Blair a kick by voting for Ken, but when they were asked to specify the principal reason for voting for him 72% said they believed he was the best candidate for mayor.

Even among that select group of Conservatives for Livingstone, 68% said they would back him because he was the best candidate, and only 13% said they were backing him mainly because they wanted to give Tony Blair a kick.

The only possible saving grace for Mr Dobson lies in the 18% who say they have not made up their mind. But even if the official Labour candidate were to sweep the board among these "don't knows", it seems inconceivable that he will be able to demolish Mr Livingstone's overwhelming lead in the next two months, given that he starts his campaign at such a low level of support - 13%.

But there must be disappointment for those who had hoped that a Livingstone bid for mayor would boost the turnout. Those who say they are certain to vote account for only 41% - about the same level as a similar ICM poll a fortnight ago.

As to the immediate future, the poll brings more bad news for Labour. The next few days will be dominated by the process of expelling Mr Livingstone from the party for standing against an official candidate.

The poll shows that this may bring even more unpopularity for the party. Some 59% believe that expelling him would be unfair, as against 27% who do not. Among Labour voters those who believe it would be unfair reaches 68%.

However much the question of expulsion might be understood and accepted by party activists, the poll shows that the reasons are not understood by London voters. They are even more hostile to the idea of other Labour members being expelled for openly supporting Livingstone. Only 12% of London voters believe this would be fair, and even 72% of those who say will vote for Frank Dobson think it would be unfair.

ICM Research interviewed a random sample of 1,003 adults aged over 18 by telephone on March 6. Interviews were conducted across London, and the data has been weighted to the profile of all London adults.

Ken Livingstone's biographer, John Carvel, will be live online on the Guardian network at 2pm today to answer your questions about Livingstone's mayoral bid.

webTitle: Millbank machine helps spread 'liar Ken' message

fields.headline: Millbank machine helps spread 'liar Ken' message
fields.standfirst:
Dobson camp: HQ gears up to fight for its candidate

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Millbank's army of spinners might have been tempted to maintain a low profile yesterday after their ham-fisted attempts to undermine Ken Livingstone backfired in such spectacular fashion.
fields.byline: Nicholas Watt, Kevin Maguire  and  Michael White
fields.body:
Millbank's army of spinners might have been tempted to maintain a low profile yesterday after their ham-fisted attempts to undermine Ken Livingstone backfired in such spectacular fashion.

Within minutes of his announcement, however, the Labour machinery rolled out the first phase of a lengthy campaign to discredit the former GLC leader, demonstrating that it was still spoiling for a fight.

Tony Blair, who sees Mr Livingstone as the personal embodiment of everything that made Labour unelectable in 1980s, did not mince his words when he warned that the leftwinger would be a "disaster for London".

The prime minister's attack was echoed by John Prescott, deputy prime minister, and by Frank Dobson who warned at the official launch of his Labour candidacy that Mr Livingstone was working in league with dangerous subversives such as the Socialist Alliance.

Labour strategists are painfully aware of the dangers of attacking Mr Livingstone after voters reacted against Millbank's recent efforts to remind them of his earlier record. But the party hierarchy has decided that remaining silent would be more dangerous.

"There is this sheen of romance surrounding Ken," one Labour source said. "Tory and Labour supporters have this stardust in their eyes about Ken because they think of chat show Ken and restaurant reviewer Ken. It is up to us to remind them what a lying bastard he is."

The campaign to paint Mr Livingstone as an untrustworthy maverick leftwinger will be run from Labour's Millbank headquarters with the full backing of Tony Blair. Mr Dobson recently made great play of his distance from Millbank, but the hierarchy believes he needs the full support of the machine.

"This is going to need all the professionalism of a general election-style operation," a senior party figure said. Daily strategy meetings and private polls are planned.

By last night three themes of the anti-Livingstone campaign had emerged. The leadership will concentrate on his trustworthiness, his competence and clear evidence that "Cuddly Ken" is an older, and carefully refined, version of "Red Ken".

The Labour source said the message will be "Livingstone lied to Labour, he'll lie to London" and his links to far left groups will be used to smear him.

Millbank will be scouring through its records to dig up dirt on Mr Livingstone. But one source said that Millbank did not have to look back too far in the light of some of his recent pronouncements.

"Once we remind people that this man prefers anarchists to coppers, people will be scared of him," one Labour source said, with reference to his infamous interview with The Face magazine about the Seattle rioters.

"During the past couple of weeks people have had to be a little bit cautious because Ken was still in the party, and there was a chance he might pull back," another source said. "Ken's support is at its peak and, though high, will go down once people see what he really stands for."

Mr Dobson kicked off the attack on Mr Livingstone's trustworthiness with a powerful assault on him for reneging on his written guarantee that he would never abandon the Labour party and stand as an independent. "Now he's turned out to be a liar," Mr Dobson said at his press conference.

Millbank has selected three policy areas to demonstrate to Londonders that Mr Livingstone would be a dangerous liability and a throwback to the carefree days of Labour in the 1980s. They are crime, transport and jobs.

Mr Dobson adopted classic Millbank scare tactics on crime yesterday. Echoing the rhetoric of Jack Straw, he warned that a Livingstone mayoralty would go soft on crime because supporters, such as the Socialist Alliance, want to disarm the police. "They don't want more police," he said. "They talk about 'stopping the war on drugs'."

In a sign of the ferocity of its campaign, Labour wheeled out Mr Prescott to warn voters about the dangers of Mr Livingstone's transport policy. He has set himself against the government's public-private partnership for the tube in favour of raising money through bonds.

"Ken's ideas would delay the upgrading of the tube and could cost Londoners billions of pounds more in taxes or charges," Mr Prescott said.

Labour spinners were congratulating themselves last night after turning the party's firepower on Mr Livingstone. But will it work?

"We will win the election, but we have a fight on our hands," said one source who believes that resignations from the party can be kept to "high hundreds" or "early thousands".

"Today's his big day; it's downhill from here," another source said.

webTitle: Cash plea to keep rebel's show on road

fields.headline: Cash plea to keep rebel's show on road
fields.standfirst:
Livingstone camp: Celebrities and public will be asked to bridge funding gap

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's final decision to break with Labour and challenge its machine in London head-on as an independent mayoral candidate was taken on Saturday afternoon, as the former Greater London council leader and Simon Fletcher, his political adviser of the past three years, sat in the cafeteria at the Royal Festival Hall on the south bank.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's final decision to break with Labour and challenge its machine in London head-on as an independent mayoral candidate was taken on Saturday afternoon, as the former Greater London council leader and Simon Fletcher, his political adviser of the past three years, sat in the cafeteria at the Royal Festival Hall on the south bank.

The pair had just emerged from a mayoral hustings meeting organised by the gay and lesbian umbrella group Gallon in the National Film Theatre next door, where the Brent East MP had been given a rapturous reception, even though Frank Dobson's campaign team had successfully demanded he be kept off the official platform. Their four-day old tactic of trying to build a campaign inside the Labour party to force Mr Dobson to stand aside was, they agreed, already running into the sand.

Equivocations
The way the Livingstone camp saw it, the party's Millbank's headquarters had been forced to drop the hopeful equivocations that followed his meeting with the deputy prime minister John Prescott and close down any further speculation about a possible deal.

From the Millbank perspective, Mr Livingstone had been "needled" into jumping by his portrayal as a man racked by indecision. "We bounced him into it," a senior official said yesterday.

Not that the MP, who was yesterday formally suspended from the party, needed much bouncing. "If there had been any question of the Labour party moving, we would have given as much time as possible," his spokesman said yesterday. But friends and campaign workers had found it increasingly difficult to restrain Livingstone and keep his frustration at his self-imposed Trappism from becoming public.

One evening a week or so ago, Mr Livingstone was getting into a cab with a group of supporters after a meal out when a passerby shouted out: "Go for it, Ken." Britain's most celebrated newt-fancier replied: "You know I will".

The former GLC leader's overall strategy has in fact remained remarkably constant since he first floated the idea of running as an independent more than a year ago. But it would be wrong to imagine that every move has been choreographed or that Mr Livingstone has anything remotely resembling an electoral organisation ready to take on Labour and Tories in the battle for 5m Londoners' votes on May 4.

While teams of MPs, campaign workers, spinners and Millbank apparatchiks have laboured to get Mr Dobson's campaign airborne, Mr Livingstone has had to rely throughout the past few months on the 31-year-old Mr Fletcher, his researcher, Mark Watts, and a handful of regular volunteers to keep his overstretched show on the road from a cramped two-room office near Oxford Circus.

On the day Labour's own selection ballot closed, hundreds of local supporters attended his end-of-campaign party in a City restaurant run by a Livingstone sympathiser. But most of these party activists are likely to keep their heads down, rather than risk expulsion.

Instead of a ready-made campaign organisation on the ground, Mr Livingstone is likely to have to fall back on his celebrity and the media, much of which can be expected to turn on him now that he has agreed to stand. He and his closest advisers, who have included other MPs as well as longtime Labour activists, have yet to agree on whether to stick to his original idea of a Livingstone list of fellow independents - including business people and even mavericks from the opposition parties - to run with him as Greater London assembly candidates. But he made clear yesterday he would be steering well clear of leftwing slates - notably that backed by the London Socialist Alliance, whose candidates include the journalist Paul Foot and comedian Mark Thomas - which Mr Dobson was at pains to link with the former GLC leader yesterday.

As Millbank and the Tory leader William Hague sought to paint the opinion poll favourite as a leftwing extremist, Mr Livingstone went out of his way to emphasise his support among London business people and insist that the issues raised by London's mayoral campaign went beyond traditional categories of left and right. His most immediate problem is how to raise the cash to run even a basic electoral campaign across such a vast constituency, including paying for the literature the government has now finally agreed will be delivered for free. His target is to reach the £420,000 spending limit set by the mayoral legislation, with just over £18,000 in his campaign kitty yesterday. The plan is to bridge the gap by appealing to the public and falling back where necessary on the enthusiasm of wealthy backers, notably in the music business.

Among his supporters are some of the country's most popular dance music acts, such as Fatboy Slim and the Chemical Brothers, as well as the Blur frontman Damon Albarn, who was last week publicly begging Mr Livingstone to stand.

Fatboy Slim and the Chemical Brothers have already agreed to a fundraising gig, while others such as the Pink Floyd guitarist Dave Gilmour have also offered their services. The actor Neal Pearson has agreed to be chief fundraiser.

webTitle: Dismay and some delight at stand

fields.headline: Dismay and some delight at stand
fields.standfirst:
Reaction: Labour anger at 'treachery'
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Politicians reacted to the news that Ken Livingstone would stand as an independent yesterday with a mixture of bitterness, anger, dismay and - for some - delight.
fields.body:
Politicians reacted to the news that Ken Livingstone would stand as an independent yesterday with a mixture of bitterness, anger, dismay and - for some - delight.

As Tories and Liberal Democrats at Westminster rubbed their hands with glee at the prospect of what one MP called "a Labour bloodbath", many on the Labour benches were angry at Mr Livingstone's "treachery" to the party.

Tony Banks, the former sports minister and West Ham MP, described the decision as "deeply sad" and "an enormous act of disloyalty". He said: "Ken's taking a big gamble and he's about to walk into oblivion. It's not about giving Londoners what they want, it's about giving Ken what he wants. In the end, he will always do what is in the interests of Ken."

Leftwing Labour backbencher David Winnick said: "This is outright treachery. I don't believe for a moment that he ever had any intention of keeping his promise not to stand as an independent. This is a man who's never had the slightest loyalty to anyone but himself. He's already being called 'Ramsay Livingstone' in the tearoom."

Stephen Pound, the Labour MP for Ealing North, added: "He has no idea of teamwork and would pick a fight with himself if there was no one around. Labour MPs are really angry about this."

Michael Foot, Labour's former leader, said: "I am very sad to hear the announcement ... especially in the light of the clear assurance he had made that he would not take such action against the Labour party."

But while many on the left blamed Mr Livingstone for the debacle, veteran leftwinger Tony Benn said: "This began with the sacking of Dobson, the fixing of the electoral system and the demonising of Ken. The responsibility lies 100% with Millbank and No 10. I feel this is a really sad day and this whole business will do terrible damage to the Labour party. Ken is the overwhelming choice of members of the Labour party in London and he is the best qualified candidate."

Martin Bell, the Independent MP for Tatton, said: "Ken is entitled to stand as a flat-earther if he wants. This is a democracy. If the voters believe he's disqualified himself by breaking a promise, that's up to them but he has name recognition and ample free media coverage so I think the prospects are quite good for him."

The disgraced former Tory mayoral candidate Lord Archer predicted a win for Mr Livingstone, adding: "There's a myth about him at the moment, which of course will burst after he's been there for a certain period of time, because he is human like anyone else."

Martin Bell, the Independent MP for Tatton, said: "Ken is entitled to stand as a flat-earther if he wants. This is a democracy. If the voters believe he's disqualified himself by breaking a promise, that's up to them but he has name recognition and ample free media coverage so I think the prospects are quite good for him." The disgraced former Tory mayoral candidate Lord Archer predicted a win for Mr Livingstone, adding: "There's a myth about him at the moment, which of course will burst after he's been there for a certain period of time, because he is human like anyone else."

webTitle: Send me your money, says the leader of the Stuff Blair party campaign

fields.headline: Send me your money, says the leader of the Stuff Blair party campaign
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson yesterday called for a new blitz on London. He was, of course, mistaken. The difference between Ken Livingstone and a doodlebug is that with Ken, the time to duck is when the whining noise begins.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson yesterday called for a new blitz on London. He was, of course, mistaken. The difference between Ken Livingstone and a doodlebug is that with Ken, the time to duck is when the whining noise begins.

Which it did yesterday afternoon when Ken launched his attempt to become mayor of London at a press conference. It should be re-named the Stuff Blair campaign. In the absence of a Conservative party, Ken is standing on behalf of everyone - right and left, black and white, sane and bonkers - who can't stand New Labour.

(A friend of mine was stopped in Richmond, Surrey, last week by a chap in Barbour, tweed jacket and cavalry twill trousers, a clipboard in his hand. She veered away, fearing something about field sports. Instead, the man said: "Will you sign our petition to persuade Ken to stand?")

Meanwhile, Labour MPs, who split roughly into two groups over Ken - those who loathe him and those who detest him - were asking: "What are the two worst things about Ken Livingstone?" Answer: "His face."

The launch was at Bafta, the film and TV association. There were posters for The Bridge On The River Kwai (man commits suicide rather than see his life's work destroyed) and Brief Encounter (after months of indecision, man decides to call it a day), so they seemed appropriate.

The microphones were many and highly sensitive and Mr Livingstone has a nervous way of grunting while he listens to a question, so the alarming effect was of a bear which has just spotted its lunch, hiding up a tree.

But there's no doubt about it: the man is a great performer. From the relaxed opener: "Is everybody ready? Then I'll begin" to the line near the end: "I've almost reached the Buddhist plane where there is no ego", he was calm and in control. He faced head-on the charge that he had broken his promise never to stand against an official Labour candidate. "It is for Londoners to decide which is the greater crime. I'm not looking for a weasel way out. I'm not hiding the fact that I am backing out of commitments I have made." This strategy - "Trust me, I admit I'm a liar" - may prove hard to break down.

Had he got a campaign in place? No, he said, there had been no plan B. He gazed openly and sincerely at us all; clearly he was going to reveal to us his inmost, his deepest political philosophy. "Most important of all: send me money."

Was he worried that Labour would make personal attacks on him? "I hope nobody tries to tar anyone with any brushes in this ... I just want to campaign on the isshoos, as that nice Mr Benn would say."

And would he be allowed back into the Labour party? He flashed us the sweetest of smiles. "I take heart from seeing all those people in Tony Blair's office who left to join the SDP and were welcomed back. I hope that generosity of spirit can be extended to me."

It will be hard for poor Dobbo to fight that smile.

fields.headline: Chris Balderstone
fields.standfirst: Sportsman of rare talent who mastered both cricket and football
fields.trailText: Chris Balderstone, who has died of cancer at his home in Cumbria at the age of 59, was a throwback to the days when, just about, football and cricket still knew their seasonal places in the sporting calendar.
fields.body:
Chris Balderstone, who has died of cancer at his home in Cumbria at the age of 59, was a throwback to the days when, just about, football and cricket still knew their seasonal places in the sporting calendar.

He was probably the last of a breed who were able to combine successful careers in both sports, although how much the one impinged on the other is impossible to say; in 1976, he played twice for England as a middle- order batsman while, two years previously, his studied inside-forward play had helped Carlisle United not just into the old First Division but, briefly, to the very top of it.

Born in Huddersfield, Balderstone played his cricket first of all for Yorkshire, before moving to Leicestershire, where he was a cornerstone of the title-winning side of the mid 70s. In 1976, he did the hat-trick against Sussex at Eastbourne; five years later, against Essex at Grace Road, Leicestershire's home ground, he shared an unbroken county record second wicket stand of 289 with David Gower.

He continued to play for Leicestershire until retirement after the 1986 season, by which time he was 45 years old, with more than 19,000 first-class runs and 300 wickets to his name. Thereafter, he augmented the county coaching staff, as well as joining the umpires' list in 1988, a profession he was still enjoying last summer.

Balderstone's football career began at Huddersfield and, after Carlisle, took in Doncaster Rovers and Queen of the South.

During the last 30 years, there have been a number of cricketers who have tried making a career out of cricket and football; direct contemporaries of Balderstone, at his best, were the likes of Jim Cumbes, who played cricket for Lancashire, Surrey and Worcestershire and football for Aston Villa (among other clubs), and Ted Hemsley, also of Worcestershire and Sheffield United. Later, Arnie Sidebottom, of Yorkshire, played one Test for England and, briefly, for Manchester United.

Alan Ramage also bowled aggressively for Yorkshire, while playing 100 equally fierce first-team games for Middlesborough and Derby; Ian Botham fleetingly played centre-forward for Scunthorpe, and, more recently, the Glamorgan and Sussex batsman Anthony Cottey played at Swansea, while still in his formative cricket years.

But for all-round sporting excellence, no one before or since - not CB Fry or Wilson of the Wizard - can have matched Balderstone's performance on September 15 and 16 1975. Playing for Leicestershire against Derbyshire, at Queen's Park, Chesterfield, he spent the early part of the second day in the field as his county secured the bowling points they needed to clinch the county championship to go with the Benson and Hedges Cup won earlier in the season. By close of play, with Leicestershire now batting, Balderstone was 51 not out.

He then hurried from the ground, made his way to Doncaster in time for a 7.30 kick off, and proceeded to score a goal against Brentford, before returning to his Chesterfield hotel. Next day, he completed his century before he was run out.

If Balderstone's football was what pundits would term "cultured", then so was his batting. He was never flamboyant, rarely ruffled, elegant, and, being tall, reliant on the front foot rather than back. He bowled left-arm spin at a pace so deceptively slow that it is surprising there was energy left on the ball ever to dislodge a bail. Against other international sides he might have played more Tests, for he was chosen on the strength of consistent quality performances for Leicestershire. It was his misfortune, however, to come up against the West Indies just as they were reaching that level of intimidation they were to maintain for the next two decades.

His first match, at Headingley, brought a ponderous 35 in the first innings followed by 4 in the second; the next, at a parched Oval, merely disaster, for he encountered Michael Holding and one of the finest fast-bowling performances in history. Twice his stumps erupted from the ground before he had got off the mark. He was never considered again.

He did manage a wicket in that game, however, during his only international bowl, when the middle-order batsman Collis King sent a delivery so high and far that on any other ground it would have been six. The whole area of the Oval was in use, however, and the fielder at long-on, myself, was able to take a shoulder-high catch. The delighted bowler ran to the fielder, and clapped him warmly on the back. "That," he said, "has put them in the shit." The scoreboard read 647 for seven.

fields.headline: M A Chidambaram
fields.trailText: The industrialist and philanthropist MA Chidambaram, who has died aged 81, introduced the motor scooter to India and, between 1960 and 1961, was president of that country's cricket control board.
fields.body:
The industrialist and philanthropist MA Chidambaram, who has died aged 81, introduced the motor scooter to India and, between 1960 and 1961, was president of that country's cricket control board.

In 1946 he founded Automobile Products of India. Later, seeing the success of the motor scooter in Europe, he arranged to produce the Italian Lambretta under licence , heralding a revolution in Indian urban transport. The Lambretta, he recalled, became "the common man's vehicle".

Chidambaram's tenure at the cricket board was marked by reforms. He introduced air travel for Indian Test cricketers, increased their match fees and launched a fund for retired players. His 30-year dream of a cricket stadium in Chennai was realised in 1972, when a massive, fully covered facility was opened, and named after him.

Chidambaram's interests ranged across sport, industry, the arts and the Tamil language. Born in Chettinad, in Tamil Nadu, he was the third son of Rajah Sir Annamalai Chettiar, founded the Tamil Music Organisation and was involved in family banking and finance businesses. The MCC gave him honorary life membership.

fields.headline: Frank Edmead
fields.standfirst: Leader-writer whose resignation over Vietnam and the Middle East split the Guardian
fields.trailText: Frank Edmead, who has died aged 80 was a good linguist, an omnivorous reader, a careful student and meticulous analyst of affairs, with a particular passion for Chinese history and culture. One of the most perceptive and well-informed Guardian leader-writers throughout a difficult post-war decade, his resignation as a matter of principle in 1967 was felt by many colleagues to be a tragedy for the paper.
fields.body:
Newspaper leader-writers have never had academia's comfortable pauses for reflection, but need something of the scholar's instincts and equipment if their judgments against the clock are to have weight and effect.

Frank Edmead, who has died aged 80, exemplified these special gifts: a good linguist, an omnivorous reader, a careful student and meticulous analyst of affairs, with a particular passion for Chinese history and culture. One of the most perceptive and well-informed Guardian leader-writers throughout a difficult post-war decade, and largely responsible for steering the paper's policy through the minefields of the Middle East and south-east Asia, his resignation as a matter of principle in 1967 was felt by many colleagues to be a tragedy for the paper, and perhaps for its editor, as well as for Frank.

How it came about is set out in Changing Faces, Geoffrey Taylor's history of the Guardian from 1956-88: "Before the start of the six-day war in June 1967 Frank Edmead had established an editorial line on Palestine against which all future comment would have to be measured. Most people on the paper would say he had done the same for Vietnam. The editor altered course on both subjects" - and within a space of less than three weeks.

On Vietnam, Edmead had argued a line of careful but consistent criticism of the American engagement, less emotional than, but consonant with, most reporting by the paper's staff and special correspondents, among them Clare Hollingworth and Martha Gellhorn. The editor, Alastair Hetherington, after a visit to Vietnam - during which he had been given free and welcoming access to the American generals - wrote endorsing the American presence as the force most likely to produce peace.

In the case of Palestine, Edmead, in a signed column on May 29, had produced what Taylor called "the dialectical half-nelson from which no subsequent Guardian leader-writer was able to escape". Why, if the Jews claimed the right to return after 2,000 years, had the Palestinian refugees no such right after only 20 years? Given that Muslims had not generally persecuted Christians, why should the Palestinians suffer for the wickedness of European Christians? "At the receiving end, Zionism looked like yet another European colonial movement; settlers flowed in, to acquire much of the land and all of the political power."

But again, in a long leader on June 12, Hetherington wrote that it would be "neither surprising nor wholly wrong" if Israeli policy were to include the keeping of the Old City of Jerusalem and most of the west bank.

When Edmead left shortly afterwards, the feeling of many colleagues was expressed in a letter that the then features editor, Christopher Driver, wrote to Hetherington. "We are shaking off irreplaceable individualists at an alarming rate and the latest and most lamentable departure looks to the rest of us directly attributable to the fact that generals and politicians have your ear more than historians or students of Asian behaviour. I doubt whether your arguments on Vietnam will outlast a year, let alone a decade."

Edmead and Hetherington had both joined the Manchester Guardian in 1950. Hetherington, who served through the war as an officer in the Royal Armoured Corps, made his name as defence correspondent, and defence remained an abiding interest. Edmead, a Quaker, had driven an ambulance across Europe following the Normandy landing (once crossing a minefield to rescue a wounded German soldier), and had been promoted from a talented reporters' room when Hetherington became editor in 1956.

Very different in many ways, each was a believing Christian, and each respected the other. Indeed, Edmead said later that he thought Hetherington, in his memoirs, had treated their differences with admirable fairness. History gives Edmead the better of the argument, but probably both of them could really be seen as victims of the cold war.

Frank was a Kentish man, educated at Borden school, Sittingbourne, and University College, London, where he read English. After his war service, he worked with German children evacuated to Austria (some of them from the Adolf Hitler school for the children of Nazi elite), shepherding hundreds back to ruined Germany in journeys that required resourcefulness and ingenuity.

After his break with the Guardian he returned to University College to do post-graduate work in conflict studies, eventually teaching systems science at the City University, where, unsurprisingly, he developed a special interest in catastrophe theory.

In retirement, this principled but gentle and sweet- natured man returned to his old love, China, spending every other year teaching at the universities of Shanghai and Xi-an and travelling widely in remote territories, intriguing people with his Shanghai accent.

No use asking him what he was going to write. Nothing, he said; he had undertaken not to. Anyway, he'd written enough, and there was so much to see and do. On a final trip to Yunan in 1996, he caught pneumonia, and several times nearly died following complications on his return. At the end, he seemed to be not much more than spirit. But frail as he was, he usually got to meetings at the old Friends' house in Hemel Hempstead; and was not to be discouraged from turning out on a cold day in January to attend Alastair Hetherington's memorial service.

His wife, Joan, died in 1974. He is survived by his daughters, Mary and Madeleine.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Blockade leads to border chaos
fields.body:
Blockade leads to border chaos

Queues of trucks formed on Serbia's border with Montenegro yesterday after Serb police imposed a blockade on the flow of goods between the two Yugoslav republics. Montenegro's pro-west government said the blockade was designed to destabilise it.

Meanwhile, a TV station said five men in police uniform raided its premises outside Belgrade yesterday, beating up two Studio B technicians and taking equipment.
AP, Belgrade

China holds US citizens

Chinese police have detained four US citizens and 12 others in a crackdown on members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual movement, a rights group reported yesterday.

Police rounded up the 16 on Saturday in a Beijing residence, the Information Centre of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said.
AP, Beijing

10 die in Nigeria village clashes

Ten people have been killed and hundreds injured in fighting sparked by a land dispute between two villages in south-western Nigeria, the country's Sunday Guardian reported.

At least 50 people have been reported missing since clashes broke out on Friday between the Modakeke and Ife villages, the report said.
AP, Lagos

Swiss to vote on joining UN

Advocates urging Switzerland to join the UN handed in a petition with more than 125,000 signatures yesterday, forcing a referendum vote.
AP, Bern

webTitle: Sultan of Brunei sues playboy brother

fields.headline: Sultan of Brunei sues playboy brother
fields.standfirst: Former richest man in world down to last £10bn
fields.trailText: The sultan of Brunei has lifted the veil of autocratic mystery that surrounds his tiny oil-rich kingdom and is risking personal embarrassment in an attempt to halt the decline of his own vast fortune and recoup billions of pounds allegedly embezzled by his younger brother.
fields.body:
The sultan of Brunei has lifted the veil of autocratic mystery that surrounds his tiny oil-rich kingdom and is risking personal embarrassment in an attempt to halt the decline of his own vast fortune and recoup billions of pounds allegedly embezzled by his younger brother.

Hassanal Bolkiah, the feudal monarch of the nation on the north coast of Borneo, has close links to Britain's royal family and to the owner of Harrods, Mohamed Al Fayed. He named 71 people on Sunday night as parties in a multi-billion-pound civil suit against his brother, Prince Jefri Bolkiah.

The playboy prince, whose assets include the Dorchester hotel in London and the jeweller's Asprey, is accused of "improper withdrawal and use" of state funds to prop up his company, Amedeo Development Corporation, when he was finance minister and chairman of the country's overseas investment agency in the mid 1990s.

It is alleged that more than £2bn was involved in the unsuccessful rescue operation.

The profligate Prince Jefri claimed he was the victim of palace intrigue when he was sacked in 1998, accusing Muslim conservatives "backed by shadowy foreign advisers with questionable motives" of plotting his downfall.

He is now staying conspicuously silent and is being advised by the high-powered, London-based, commercial lawyers Alan Gordon Pollock QC and Clare Patricia Montgomery QC, who arrived in the kingdom at the weekend.

No date has been set for a hearing and proceedings are being held in private.

The sultan has frozen his brother's assets at home and abroad. These include thousands of cars, dozens of houses, a luxury yacht named Tits and its accompanying speed-boats, Nipple I and Nipple II.

Public figures in Brunei say it would be "inappropriate" to discuss the case. Foreign diplomats believe that this is a clear sign that people, who are intensely loyal to the sultan, are afraid to rock an already delicate situation.

"Nothing like this has ever happened in Brunei," one diplomat said. "Everything has always been kept hushed up in the past. The sultan obviously feels the public ignominy is worth it."

The sultan, 53, is feeling the pinch. Five years ago he was worth more than £40bn and by far the world's richest man. Forbes magazine valued him last year at about half that and only number three in the world (the Microsoft founder, Bill Gates, was at number one).

The sultan's coffers are now thought to be even emptier, with one recent report putting his fortune at under £10bn.

Regal concern is also extending to the national economy. National growth in the nation of 300,000 people has averaged less than 2% over the last five years and the oil and gas that has fuelled the country's wealth is running out.

But there is little diversification. In his national address at the end of last month the sultan admitted that Brunei is still dependent on oil and gas. He then published a national economic plan which amazed people by its candour.

"Although Brunei still has the appearance of great affluence, there are warning signals of fundamental economic problems which threaten to undermine the prosperity and, with it, the social stability of the people," the report said.

"Such honesty is unprecedented," the diplomat said. "If the sultan thinks he's in trouble then it's easy to see why he's willing to go after Jefri."

King of the jungle: Sultan and his country

 Brunei is a jungle-covered sultanate on the north coast of Borneo. It is a little larger than Norfolk

 It was catapulted to the status of one of world's richest nations when a huge oil and gas field was discovered in 1929

 The Sandhurst-educated sultan, right, was the world's richest man, worth more than £40bn. He has lost at least half of it in the last few years

 But he still lives in a 1,700-room palace

 Adult literacy is 88%, among the highest in Asia. There is free education and healthcare for all

 Beer and even imported meat are banned on religious grounds. McDonald's is limited to serving egg sandwiches

webTitle: India is new loser in Asian Aids epidemic

fields.headline: India is new loser in Asian Aids epidemic
fields.trailText: The Aids epidemic is tightening its grip across Asia, with India now home to the largest number of HIV cases in the world, a new report aimed at promoting awareness among men revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The Aids epidemic is tightening its grip across Asia, with India now home to the largest number of HIV cases in the world, a new report aimed at promoting awareness among men revealed yesterday.

Some 3.7m Indians are HIV-positive or have full-blown Aids, according to the report by the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/Aids, although the sharpest increases in the rate of infection are to be found in Cambodia and Burma.

"Asia is at a critical point in the development of the Aids epidemic. In many countries, HIV is no longer a distant threat. It has arrived and it is our problem," Peter Piot, the programme's executive director, said.

"We do not know yet what kind of trajectory the Asian epidemic will establish. Surveillance now shows that the epidemic has reached the critical point where it spreads out into the population."

While Asian women are at special risk of HIV infection because of their apparent lack of power in determining the circumstances when sex takes place, the same cultural beliefs and expectations make men vulnerable too, the report says. More men than women are dying of Aids in every continent except sub-Saharan Africa, it says.

"The time is ripe to start seeing men not as some kind of problem, but as part of the solution. Working with men to change some of their attitudes and behaviour has enormous potential to slow down the epidemic," Mr Piot added.

The report paints a mixed picture. In China almost 500,000 people in a population of more than 1bn are estimated to be HIV-positive. Most have contracted the disease through sharing needles. The epidemic has not yet swept across to China's 4m sex workers.

In India the pattern is complex, with high rates of infection in the south and west of the country, including 60% of Bombay's prostitute population.

Official indifference during much of the 90s and a lack of sex education helped to fuel the rise. In some other parts of the country, the number of cases detected has been minuscule.

Rates of infection are stabilising in Thailand because of well-established prevention efforts, but the rates are rising steadily in Malaysia, Vietnam and Bangladesh, where half of all sex workers are also infected with syphilis because clients refuse to use condoms. The highest levels of infection are in Cambodia, where two out of every 100 pregnant women are infected. Some 3.7% of married women of reproductive age are infected.

"Burma is probably, if not the worst epidemic in Asia, close to what is going on in Cambodia," Mr Piot said. "Unfortunately, the data is quite outdated. We think things are bad because of reports from small studies being done in Burma."

Heterosexual sex is still the main means of transmission, with gay male sex, sex workers and drug users contributing to the problem, the report said.

webTitle: Rafsanjani inquiry puts Belgium in fear of fatwa

fields.headline: Rafsanjani inquiry puts Belgium in fear of fatwa
fields.trailText: Belgium has incurred Iranian fury after the launch of a criminal investigation into Iran's ex-president Hashemi Rafsanjani. The move has powerful echoes of the Pinochet saga.
fields.body:
Belgium has incurred Iranian fury after the launch of a criminal investigation into Iran's ex-president Hashemi Rafsanjani. The move has powerful echoes of the Pinochet saga.

Officials in Brussels confirmed last night that the same judge who sought to have the former Chilean dictator tried was investigating charges that Mr Rafsanjani was party to illegal imprisonment and torture.

With Belgium squirming as fellow European Union members beat a path to Tehran's door, the Islamic republic reacted furiously yesterday, hinting at the sort of consequences threatened in the Salman Rushdie affair.

Ayatollah Hassan Saneii, head of the semi-official Khordad Foundation - still offering a $2.8m (£1.7m) reward for the killing of the British author - warned Belgium to apologise immediately.

"Our reactions will not only be verbal," the Jomhuri Islami newspaper quoted him as saying. "If the Belgian government does not make up for this impudence of the Belgian court, it must await active measures from the Iranian nation, and especially the Khordad Foundation."

Iran's official news agency described the investigation as "insolent, vindictive and insulting" and said it was "in step with the evil aims of Israel and America".

The row threatens to cast a shadow over EU attempts to build a new relationship with Iran after the stunning performance of reformist candidates in last month's legislative elections.

Italy's foreign minister, Lamberto Dini, was ending his three-day visit to Iran yesterday, just as his German counterpart, Joschka Fischer, was due to arrive for a two-day stay. Britain's foreign secre tary, Robin Cook, is also due in Tehran to set the seal on a fresh relationship after the Iranian government formally dissociated itself from the threats to the Satanic Verses author in 1998.

Eyebrows were raised when Belgium - not previously known for its ethical foreign policies - seized the high moral ground in the Pinochet affair and demanded to see evidence of the medical tests that eventually allowed the general to go home.

It has also played a militant role in EU measures against the inclusion of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party in the Austrian government.

The examining magistrate Damien Vandermeersch launched the human rights investigation at the instigation of an unnamed Iranian living in Belgium, but embarrassed officials insisted last night that it had nothing to do with the government.

The Belgian foreign ministry said in a statement that the government had no power to intervene, but wished to maintain good relations with Iran.

More broadly, the case illustrates the change that the Pinochet affair has created by ending the sense that a former head of state enjoys automatic immunity for acts committed while in office.

On Sunday Mohammad Khatami, the reformer who succeeded Mr Rafsanjani in 1997, said the investigation against his predecessor was the work of "enemies of the Iranian nation" and warned that Iran would "spare no effort to defend its credibility, strength and dignity".

Mr Rafsanjani was seen as a moderate when he became president in 1989 and set about reconstruction after his country's brutal 1980-88 war with Iraq, but he was discredited by economic failures and increasingly associated with hardliners.

webTitle: Taiwan warning as China steps up defence spending

fields.headline: Taiwan warning as China steps up defence spending
fields.trailText: China's military leaders fired their heavy propaganda weapons across the Taiwan strait yesterday, counteracting the more restrained language used by the prime minister, Zhu Rongji, on the previous day.
fields.body:
China's military leaders fired their heavy propaganda weapons across the Taiwan strait yesterday, counteracting the more restrained language used by the prime minister, Zhu Rongji, on the previous day.

A thundering editorial in the Liberation Army Daily said that "millions of troops stand in combat readiness and are on high alert".

"We will adopt all measures to firmly crush any attempts to divide China and will realise the complete reunification of the motherland," it continued.

Significantly, the army paper repeated a warning delivered by Beijing two weeks ago that an "indefinite refusal" by Taiwan "to solve the reunification issue peacefully through negotiations" would constitute grounds for war.

Mr Zhu, in his report to the national people's congress, had merely stated that China would "not sit idly by" if Taiwan took serious separatist action.

The tougher stance was taken at the weekend in speeches by the president, Jiang Zemin, and the most senior Communist party general, Zhang Wannian.

The newspaper also clearly denounced the opposition leader Chen Shui-bian, one of the three main candidates in Taiwan's presidential election on March 18, despite Mr Chen softening his line on negotiations with Beijing last month.

Yesterday the Chinese finance minister, Xiang Huaicheng, told the NPC that China's defence expenditure would rise by 12.7% this year, to 120.5bn renminbi (£9.2bn). The figure is thought to exclude the cost of weapons development and other items such as its nuclear programme.

fields.headline: Plane narrowly misses petrol station
fields.trailText: A major disaster was narrowly averted yesterday when a 737 Southwest Airlines plane carrying 137 passengers skidded off the runway at Los Angeles's Burbank airport and just missed crashing into a petrol station. Six people were slightly injured.
fields.body:
A major disaster was narrowly averted yesterday when a 737 Southwest Airlines plane carrying 137 passengers skidded off the runway at Los Angeles's Burbank airport and just missed crashing into a petrol station. Six people were slightly injured.

The plane was landing in the early evening when it crashed through the barrier at the end of the runway. It skidded across Hollywood Way and crashed into a car with a woman and a four-year-old inside. Neither was hurt. The pilot suffered cuts to his head, and four passengers and one crew member were injured.

Passers-by ran for cover and drivers abandoned cars and sprinted out of the way as it became clear that the plane, which had 6,000lb of fuel on board, was unable to stop.

As passengers emerged from an emergency chute they hugged each other and wept. One, Kevin McCoy, said: "They told us it might be a rough landing." Another described the noise of the crash as like two trains colliding. They had been told to expect a "bumpy ride" when they set off late from Las Vegas.

A spokesman for the federal aviation administration said: "It's too early to tell [the cause], except perhaps that he [the pilot] landed too long."

Officials were at the scene last night as attempts were made to move the plane and restart traffic.

The crash followed the worst storms to hit the area this year, bringing widespread flooding.

fields.headline: No: 1588
fields.standfirst: Sue MacGregor
fields.trailText: Sue MacGregor
fields.body:
Age: 58.

Appearance: Genial headmistress who could floor a miscreant pupil at 20 paces with a carefully enunciated consonant.

Status: Consummate broadcaster.

Who says? Oh, everyone says. Most notably John Humphrys, her co-host on Radio 4's Today programme.

That's nice of him. What does she say about him? That he "oozes testosterone".

Stop! You're putting me off my cornflakes! Oh calm down, it's all entirely innocent. Though considering the post-vasectomy Humphrys is expecting a child, she might be said to be more prescient than most.

Investigative journalism at its highest . . . Yes, yes, very funny. Anyway, this journalist will only be with us for a little while longer. MacGregor has announced she is to retire.

Why? After 16 years getting up at 3am, she's reported to have told colleagues that she's tired of the punishing schedule.

That all? It might be the pay thing. A book published in 1997 revealed that MacGregor was being paid £20,000 less than her male colleagues Humphrys and James Naughtie. A "shocked and confused" MacGregor demanded parity from her bosses, but a small discrepancy is believed to have remained.

Or it could be . . . that, at 58, she is only a year younger than Peter Hobday was when he got the boot for being "too old" in 1996.

Who's going to get the job? That's what every broadcast journalist in the country wants to know. Hotly tipped are Sarah Montague, Winifred Robinson and Allan Little, three of the programme's current lesser stars. But since by general agreement her successor is almost certain to be a woman, the smart money, one could say, is not on Little.

Do say: " Sue MacGregor's career has been one resounding success after another. From her earliest days as a reporter on the World at One through her stint on Woman's Hour and on to Today, MacGregor has demonstrated . . ."

Don't say: " I'm sorry but we're out of time, I have to cut you off there. "
