webTitle: When everybody loses but the lawyers

fields.headline: When everybody loses but the lawyers
fields.standfirst: Lord Aldington is not alone in losing out on his £1.5m libel award.  Clare Dyer  says the law can make it hard to claim the cash
fields.trailText: Lord Aldington is not alone in losing out on his £1.5m libel award.  Clare Dyer  says the law can make it hard to claim the cash.
fields.body:
Eight years ago Lord Aldington complained that Count Nikolai Tolstoy, who hadn't paid a penny of the £1.5m libel damages he had been awarded three years before, was living the same lifestyle he had enjoyed before the action. A Volvo estate car was parked in the drive of Tolstoy's £300,000 Jacobean farmhouse, while Aldington had exchanged his "company Bentley for a two-year-old Ford Escort".

Now Tolstoy's Oxfordshire home must be worth nearer £1m. He still lives there and Aldington has still not received a penny of the damages, and only a tiny fraction of the £350,000 costs. But Tolstoy's lifestyle is about to get a significant boost: he has inherited half the £3m estate left by his stepfather, the writer Patrick O'Brian.

Tantalisingly, the inheritance - though it may be dented by tax - is near enough the sum Aldington still reckons he is owed after successfully suing Tolstoy over a pamphlet accusing him, then Brigadier Toby Low, of sending 70,000 Cossacks and Yugoslavs to their deaths in 1945. But Aldington cannot touch the windfall. Tolstoy, a historian and distant relative of the author of War and Peace, filed for bankruptcy in 1990 after losing the libel action. He has now emerged a discharged bankrupt, closing the books on earlier debts.

"In a sense the winner had lost and the loser remained unbowed," notes David Hooper in his forthcoming book Reputations under Fire: Winners and Losers in the Libel Business. "The case is likely to be remembered for the disproportionately large award of damages and the legal manoeuvring which deprived Lord Aldington of the fruits of his victory in court."

Both parties were backed by others: Aldington by Sun Alliance, the company of which he was then chairman, and Tolstoy by the Earl of Portsmouth, later to be Neil Hamilton's backer in his fight against Mohamed al Fayed, and the Forced Repatriations Defence Fund, set up to solicit money to fight the claim.

Tolstoy's house, owned jointly with his wife, was subject to a bank charge for an outstanding loan. Well-wishers set up a trust fund in his wife's name to pay the family's living expenses. The four children completed their educations at private schools, including Eton, and went on to university.

Aldington thinks he may be able to stake a claim to some of the legacy to recoup costs awarded against Tolstoy in later proceedings, but the sums will be comparatively small beer.

"Here we are nearly 10 years after he went bankrupt and the clock began ticking," said the 85-year-old peer yesterday. "I have not had a penny but I haven't given up and the lawyers are seeing what can be done. The law is meant to benefit the debtor rather than the creditor."

The libel claimant who loses ignominiously and faces debts of millions in damages and costs but still remains ensconced in an enviable piece of real estate is almost a cliché. Jonathan Aitken may have lost his furniture but he still holds court in the £1.8m house in Lord North Street, allegedly his wife's. Neil Hamilton last week won a stay on the enforcement of a £500,000 costs order by Fayed, and has so far not had to sell his old rectory - which his own solicitors wisely took a charge for their costs - or his pied à terre in central London.

Aldington is not the first winner in a defamation case to come off worse than the loser. Dr Malcolm Smith won a record £150,000 slander victory, plus costs, in 1991 against Dr Alanah Houston, his partner in a medical practice, who accused him in front of a few patients of sexually harassing her and their staff. Nine years later both doctors' lives have been devastated by the aftershocks of those few words, but Smith is the bigger loser.

He lost his home and surgery and is still embroiled in expensive legal proceedings. In 1998, when he successfully applied to the High Court to have Houston jailed for contempt of court, he was unemployed, living with his father and still caught up in spin-offs from the original case. His solicitor had sued him for fees and he had countersued, alleging the lawyer was negligent in not warning him how expensive the case could be. He lost and was ordered to pay the fees but the solicitor, Thomas Watts, said yesterday that he was still owed £200,000.

Houston declared herself bankrupt but was jailed for three months for disobeying court orders not to redistribute her assets, including a flat in Malta. Mr Justice Tucker said she was "exceedingly devious" after ruling that she had deliberately avoided paying the damages, reduced to £50,000 on appeal.

"Having won a decision in his favour and an award of damages to compensate him, he has been frustrated in his attempts to recover his damages or his costs and left with a very large bill for his legal fees."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our Guardian Weekend lead about Bono of U2, March 4, we quoted him on page 14 as saying, "I became a fan of club music, of drug culture, of everything that was going on at the time." What he actually said was, "I became a fan of club music, of club culture," not "drug culture". The mistake was ours and we apologise.
fields.body:
In our Guardian Weekend lead about Bono of U2, March 4, we quoted him on page 14 as saying, "I became a fan of club music, of drug culture, of everything that was going on at the time." What he actually said was, "I became a fan of club music, of club culture," not "drug culture". The mistake was ours and we apologise.

On page 12 of our Isa special supplement, March 4, we carried a headline on an article about Tessas saying, "Have you been kidnapped by a tax-exempt savings account?" We illustrated this with a two-column picture of a man holding a girl at knife-point. The picture related to an incident in Manila in the Philippines in August last year. The agency caption opened, "Drug-crazed suspect points a knife at the chest of his 11-year-old hostage, as he threatens to kill her..." (the hostage-taker was later shot in the head). Our caption read, "Millions have been taken hostage by the lure of a Tessa." A more inappropriate illustration would have been difficult to find. Its use was a lapse for which we apologise.

In a report of Prince Charles's Caribbean tour, headlined Prince beats drum for the Commonwealth, page 15, February 26, we attributed to a senior member of the Commonwealth secretariat, the remark, "What has he [the Prince] ever done for us?" The quote was not obtained directly by the Guardian, we were unable to check it reliably and should not have used it. We apologise for any embarrassment it caused.

John Beale, in the photograph on page 9, G2, yesterday, points out that he has been to court 34 times over contact with his son (the caption was slightly garbled).

One of the pictures illustrating our piece about the gorillas of the Uganda/Congo border area, pages 6 and 7, Travel, March 4, purported to show Dian Fossey with two gorillas. In fact it showed Birute Galdikas with orang- utans in Borneo (as one reader observed, wrong person, wrong animal, wrong continent). The picture belonged to a set wrongly identified and filed in 1998.

The elusive leopards on page 5, Travel, March 4, are cheetahs.

In the first question of our quiz, page 9, Sport, March 4, we asked which was the last leap year before 2000 ending in 00. In the solutions, page 11, Sport, we said 1600. In fact, 1700 was also a leap year.

We keep listing Tom Binns as the presenter of the breakfast show on XFM (radio, page 21, G2, yesterday). He last did that some time before Christmas last year.

Homophone corner, from page 4, yesterday, "She was warned that [he] had several friends in the classroom who were sewing the seeds of dissent."

webTitle: Canadian firm makes top mobile bid

fields.headline: Canadian firm makes top mobile bid
fields.trailText: Canadian mobile phone operator TIW weighed in yesterday with the highest bid in the first round of the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences with a punt of £170m.
fields.body:
Canadian mobile phone operator TIW weighed in yesterday with the highest bid in the first round of the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences with a punt of £170m.

The bids for the five licences ranged between £83.9m and £170m with the biggest price offered for licence A, the franchise reserved for new entrants. The reserve price was £125m.

Licence C, which offers the same spectrum coverage as licences D and E, failed to attract any bids. A department of trade and industry spokesman denied this was of concern and said it was "early days". The auction process is expected to last at least three weeks. The bids that won round one valued four of the five licences at a total of £456m.

Vodafone, BT and Orange all fought for licence B - the biggest of the four licences for which the existing mobile phone operators are allowed to bid. Winning licence B is critical for Vodafone and BT whose networks are already operating at capacity. Both operators bid the reserve price of £107.1m.

"There's a sense the licences C, D and E [for Vodafone and BT] are something of a comparative failure," West LB Panmure analyst John Tyso said.

Mr Tyso noted the Virgin-led consortium, SpectrumCo, also bid for licence B - which will probably achieve the the highest price.

The bid led by Richard Branson's team was dealt a blow yesterday when it emerged that three of SpectrumCo's original nominated shareholders had withdrawn from the consortium last week. Among the trio, the most noticeable drop out was Vulcan Ventures, the investment vehicle run by Microsoft co- founder Paul Allen. The other two members of the SpectrumCo team to depart were EMI and JP Morgan's private equity arm.

All bidders are entitled under the Government's rules to switch their bid from one licence to another. Patricia Hewitt, small business and e-commerce minister, maintained that the new licences, which will deliver services such as the ability to receive video, internet pages and per form simple computing tasks, would spur greater competition and lower prices.

However there is concern about how much customers will pay for third generation phones which begin operating in 2002, given the large funds spent on licences and infrastructure.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
Orange offsets Tyneside gloom

Former employees at the now-closed Siemens semi-conductor plant in North Tyneside are being given priority among applicants for the 500 jobs being created at mobile phone operator Orange's new £10.6m call centre in the area.

The centre, opened yesterday by local MP and trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, will employ 1,500 people. Orange originally planned to employ 1,000 at the site, the third the group is setting up in the north-east.

Orange, which will employ 4,500 people in the region, said the new centre would be an integrated multi-media facility rather than the traditional voice-only services offered to customers in older sites.

Marconi switch vindicated

Marconi, the internet and telecoms equipment supplier that sprang last year out of GEC, yesterday secured a three-year contract worth more than $100m (£60m) to provide Sprint, the US telecoms group, with broadband switches. The contract is Marconi's second US bridgehead after a deal last year to provide BellSouth with access equipment and cements the group's radical switch from heavy industry and defence into network solutions. Marconi last year spent $6bn acquiring Reltec, a regular Sprint customer, and Fore, which will (under the Marconi name) provide the new ASX-4000 switches.

Kiam sues over Slickers

Businessman Victor Kiam is suing the daily Mirror over an article which appeared in its City Slickers column in January last year. The hearing at the high court, which began yesterday, is expected to last three to five days.

Chez Gérard bounces back

Restaurants group Chez Gérard yesterday signalled it had turned the corner after a period of poor performance by producing a 6% rise in profits to £1.85m for the six months to December. Shares slipped by 1p to 196p although the company said demand had rebounded from the disappointing Christmas and new year period.

The outlook for its two core brands, Chez Gérard and Livebait, is improving and the problems with its Richoux outlets are being tackled. David Williams, the new chief executive, promised to reduce costs and implement a strategy which would mean focusing on growth.

fields.headline: CRS vote supports co-op merger
fields.trailText: Graham Melmoth, chief executive of the Co-operative Wholesale Society, looks set to win his battle to push through a merger with Co-operative Retail Services, following a near unanimous vote in favour of the deal by members of the retail organisation.
fields.body:
Graham Melmoth, chief executive of the Co-operative Wholesale Society, looks set to win his battle to push through a merger with Co-operative Retail Services, following a near unanimous vote in favour of the deal by members of the retail organisation.

More than 95% of delegates attending a CRS meeting on Saturday backed the deal, which will create a body with sales of more than £4.5bn. The show of support is likely to strengthen Mr Melmoth's hand ahead of a crucial meeting of the CWS's board tomorrow.

A CWS spokesman said: "There is cautious optimism on both sides, although we wouldn't want to pre-empt the decision of the board."

About 120 delegates from regional branches of the CRS turned up to vote at London's Regents Park Hotel. They listened to presentations by chief executive Andy Meehan and chairman Stephen Watts, before moving on to a debate. Most of those speaking were supportive of the move, although there was some dissent. One observer said: "There was some emotion. There's a certain amount of affection and attachment towards the existing structures."

The overwhelming vote is likely to bolster support for the tie-up among members of the CWS's 28-strong board. They will assemble at the organisation's Manchester head office, New Century House, to decide the future of the 137-year-old organisation. Insiders said yesterday that dissent had been largely squashed, following last month's resignation of Barbara Rogers - a director critical of the deal.

If the board meeting backs a deal, the decision is likely to be rubber-stamped by another special assembly of CRS delegates in two weeks' time. The CWS owns more than 600 supermarkets, a central buying organisation, the Co-op Bank and 80,000 acres of farmland. Mr Melmoth wants to combine it with the CRS's funeral homes, property and motor trading interests and 470 supermarkets.

He argues that a tie-up will create a stronger, larger force which will be better equipped to compete with profit-hungry supermarket chains such as Tesco and Sainsbury. However, critics claim the deal looks more like a takeover by the CWS - only eight CRS representatives would join an interim combined board.

Furthermore, there have been suggestions that political pressure could have played a part in the tie-up - the Co-op is a major donor to the Labour Party, which would be concerned to see the organisation fall victim of a private predator. Monaco-based entrepreneur Andrew Regan attempted to bid for the CWS three years ago but failed, and now faces an arrest warrant issued by the serious fraud office.

Among the issues the combined entity will face is whether to create a unified Co-op retail brand.

A CRS spokesman said: "There's no question of people patting themselves on the back and saying 'great, we're merging'. They've all started working very hard on savings, cost structures pricing and other matters."

webTitle: Somerfield admits to talks with potential buyers

fields.headline: Somerfield admits to talks with potential buyers
fields.trailText: Somerfield, the hard-pressed supermarket chain, yesterday sparked an auction for its mainstream grocery business by admitting it was holding talks with several groups which could lead to a takeover bid.
fields.body:
Somerfield, the hard-pressed supermarket chain, yesterday sparked an auction for its mainstream grocery business by admitting it was holding talks with several groups which could lead to a takeover bid.

At least two venture capital firms as well as one trade buyer have made tentative offers for the business.

The statement came in response to reports that chief executive David Simons has been asked to front a takeover bid even though he is widely regarded as architect of Somerfield's recent doomed strategy.

Investors were thrilled at the prospect of being offered an exit from the company which has seen its shares go from 460p in summer 1998 to as little as 50p, yesterday ending up 18p - 29% - at 79p. The company, whose sales total £4bn a year, is now worth £390m on the stock market.

Analysts said the price range which Somerfield might attract was huge. "This one has been cast adrift of the pack in terms of its valuation and the take-out price is likely to reflect that," said one.

Reports suggested the group has been offered about £735m but that was before the company flagged the sale of 350 of Kwik Save's outlets coupled with 46 larger stores, some of which are being acquired by John Lewis.

Somerfield, brought low by its over-generous and ill-advised takeover of Kwik Save, has appointed Deutsche Bank to mastermind a sale of the business. Those handling the disposal hope to conclude a deal by late spring.

Potential buyers for the remaining business are rumoured to include the venture capitalists Apollo and Oaktree Capital Management while Knutsford, the acquisition vehicle of entrepreneurs such as Archie Norman and Julian Richer, was being named as a possible contender. At least one of the bidding groups is understood to want to oust Mr Simons and his management team.

The flurry of interest in Somerfield comes after retail group Storehouse admitted receiving a takeover approach. However, New Capital Invest, an Aim-listed shell company, yesterday denied it intended to bid for all or part of that group.

Somerfield is the fifth-largest supermarket chain and has been losing out to larger rivals such as Tesco and Asda. Over the past year the group has lost 1.4% of market share and suffered a 44% drop in profits to £64m in the six months to last November.

fields.headline: Eurotunnel adjusts to loss
fields.trailText: Eurotunnel's lost income from duty-free sales in June will be fully compensated for within the financial year as the service increased fares for the cross-Channel traveller.
fields.body:
Eurotunnel's lost income from duty-free sales in June will be fully compensated for within the financial year as the service increased fares for the cross-Channel traveller.

Eurotunnel saw its share of the car Channel-crossingmarket in the summer top 60%. Christian Chazot, Eurotunnel's managing director, announced the year's full results yesterday, saying it had anticipated the loss of duty-free revenue well in advance.

In spite of an increase in average fare prices of more than 33% caused by down ward pressure on volume, the company increased its receipts on its shuttle service between Folkestone and Calais by 31%.

The introduction of three new shuttle trains for lorries increased the number of trucks using the shuttle by 19% to 868,776.

The company is also expanding its telecommunications business, both as an operator and a service provider. Its combined retail and telecommunications revenue accounts for 22.5% of its operating income.

fields.headline: Close profits from private investors
fields.standfirst: Merchant bank reports 126% rise
fields.trailText: Small investors' new found appetite for buying e-related shares shows little sign of being satisfied, Close Brothers, one the last independent merchant banks, said yesterday as it reported a 126% rise in profits.
fields.body:
Small investors' new found appetite for buying e-related shares shows little sign of being satisfied, Close Brothers, one the last independent merchant banks, said yesterday as it reported a 126% rise in profits.

The sparkling rise in interim pre-tax profits to £75.2m was largely due the performance of its Winterflood market making division that has reaped the rewards of massive share buying in smaller companies. Rod Kent, managing director of Close Brothers, insisted that Winterflood's performance was not fly-by-night, but acknowledged that it was difficult to predict whether the soaring demand for shares was sustainable.

After being forced to issue an unusual warning to the City last month about its better-than-expected six month results, Mr Kent said the bank's second half was already off to a good start. He pointed out that Winterflood, which is expanding into Europe, was one of three legs of the business.

The merchant banking division, which advises smaller companies on mergers and acquisitions, had achieved a 70% rise profits in the first six months.

By contrast, the bank's asset finance business saw profits slip, largely as a result of uncertainty in the used-car market where prices were falling.

Mr Kent lamented the city's rating of the bank's shares, which closed 27p up at £11.87 yesterday.

He said that, while not wanting to be a "moaning Minnie", the stock market was overlooking the value of Winterflood and the asset management business which recently bought Rea Brothers and increased its funds under management from £600m to £2.5bn.

Close will pay an interim dividend of 8p, a rise of 51%.

fields.headline: Car sales slump hits Inchcape
fields.trailText: The rip-off Britain campaign was blamed partly for driving down profits by 20% at Inchcape, the former conglomerate which jettisoned its shipping and bottling businesses to focus on car distribution.
fields.body:
The rip-off Britain campaign was blamed partly for driving down profits by 20% at Inchcape, the former conglomerate which jettisoned its shipping and bottling businesses to focus on car distribution.

A slump in British car sales as consumers wait for an expected drop in prices built on other difficulties for Inchcape, including a particular downturn in sales of Toyota and Mazda models in Britain.

Inchcape's annual headline pre-tax profits fell to £85.3m from £106.1m as turnover plunged to £4.45bn from £5.51bn. The profit figure was before exceptional gains of £214m for the sale of various businesses, while a dividend of 21p was paid for the 12 month period, compared with 67.2p last time.

But the company's battered share price took a turn for the better, rising 12p to 252p last night as the City welcomed management optimism about future trading opportunities outside Britain.

There are also hopes that ownership of internet car sales provider Autobytel UK will provide good results in future - although converting site "hits" to firm sales in the early months seems to have been sluggish.

Inchcape finance director Alan Ferguson said it cannot be sure whether the British importation and distribution business will bounce back given the uncertainty ahead of next month's Competition Commission report into the new car market.

But Inchcape believes that Toyota and Mazda sales in Britain should recover after a restructuring which affected last year's sales.

There are high hopes that a 45% sales increase in Greece last year plus 30% growth in Singapore will continue, however.

The important Hong Kong market, in which Inchcape controls 42% of sales and where margins are high at up to 7%, should also be stronger after a falling 20% in the first half of 1999 but growing 4.5% in the second half.

New car registrations in Britain fell to 73,737 in February, down 12.3% from the same month last year, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders has reported.

The SMMT had forecast 70,000 registrations for February and said the actual result was still encouraging, given expectations for a strong performance in March for the new W licence-plate car.

"This...gives us confidence to underline our 2.2m forecast for the year," the SMMT said.

Registrations had been expected to suffer some fall in February as a result of the move to the twice-yearly licence-plate prefix letter change system.

fields.headline: Colt's £716m to fire European growth
fields.trailText: A pan-European appetite for the new economy yesterday helped Colt Telecom raise £716m on the markets to fund its aggressive expansion plans.
fields.body:
A pan-European appetite for the new economy yesterday helped Colt Telecom raise £716m on the markets to fund its aggressive expansion plans.

The group, which placed 12.9m new shares, raised £116m more than it anticipated as institutions voted in favour of its growth strategy, enabling Colt to issue a further 3m new shares.

The new shares, priced at £38.52, brought in £497m while the group raised a further £219m through the issue of euro-denominated bonds which can be converted into stock. These notes have a cash coupon of 2% a year, mature in seven years but cannot be called during the first three years. They will be convertible into ordinary shares initially at £50.076 a share.

Colt, which provides high bandwith data, internet and voice services to business customers, seized the opportunity to unveil a faster roll-out of its European networks than revealed just two weeks ago.

The group now intends to expand its web-hosting centres to between 12 and 20 by the end of next year, with plans to raise this to 24 soon after. It is stepping up its investment in internet enabling and content distribution services.

By the end of this year Colt plans to launch digital subscriber line services in the UK, Germany, France and Holland but, given the pace of liberalisation in European networks (unbundling the local loop), now intends to extend these to Austria, Belgium, Italy, Spain and Switzerland.

Similarly, plans for an inter-city network of some 8,000km this year have been enhanced by new targets to 14,000km, bringing in parts of France, Spain and Scandinavia, by mid-2001.

Jim Curvey, Colt chairman, said: "We are sensing an accelerating pace of growth and development in the European market and have therefore decided to accelerate and expand our own plans to ensure that we are positioned to take advantage of these growth opportunities."

Paul Chisholm, group president and chief executive, added: "Our aim is to be the leading e-commerce distribution company in Europe." Colt shares fell 72p to close at £39.76.

fields.headline: Virgin planning 200mph trains
fields.trailText: Plans to build 128 miles of new rail track capable of carrying trains with speeds of up to 205 miles an hour depend on planning permission, Virgin Trains admitted last night.
fields.body:
Plans to build 128 miles of new rail track capable of carrying trains with speeds of up to 205 miles an hour depend on planning permission, Virgin Trains admitted last night.

The £4.7bn plan to run Europe's fastest trains on the east coast main line between London and Edinburgh is based on the company receiving the award for the 20-year contract from the shadow strategic rail authority later this year.

But Virgin conceded that it would have to obtain planning permission to build a two-track high speed line between Connington in Cambridgeshire and Hambleton in Yorkshire, and a 14-mile stretch by-passing Morpeth in Northumberland.

The shadow SRA will now have to consider whether Virgin's bid is more attractive than the one submitted by the present franchise operator, Great North Eastern Trains.

The new line would run through a largely rural area in eastern England, and properties would have to be demolished. The authority's main problem with Virgin's bid is that it is fraught with planning problems which will not be solved by the time the shadow SRA makes its decision.

The GNER bid is predicated on an upgrade of the existing line by Railtrack over the next 10 years, which will allow the company to run tilting trains at speeds of 140mph. Under the Virgin plan, the London-to-Newcastle journey would come down from three hours to two hours five minutes, London-Leeds would be reduced to one hour 25 minutes, and London-Sheffield to one hour 15 minutes. Will Whitehorn, a director at Virgin Rail, said that the company planned to compete head on with the airlines, which had taken traffic from centres like Leeds, Newcastle and Edinburgh.

He said that Virgin had teamed up with Bechtel, the American project management company, to formulate its plans. When the second phase of the Channel tunnel rail link was ready, Virgin could join the link at St Pancras.

Virgin said it did not think that GNER's proposals would work. Passenger numbers on the route have increased by 26% since GNER was awarded its seven-year franchise in 1996.

fields.headline: New Qwest talks threaten merger
fields.trailText: Qwest, the American telecommunications company, yesterday moved to placate its intended US merger partner after admitting that it was also flirting with someone else.
fields.body:
Qwest, the American telecommunications company, yesterday moved to placate its intended US merger partner after admitting that it was also flirting with someone else.

The company said that it was talking to a "major telecommunications company" about the "possible acquisition of both Qwest and US West" on Sunday night.

The announcement came after days of speculation, however, that it was preparing to do a deal with Deutsche Telekom, the German telecommunications company, that might not include US West.

It has also reportedly talked to Britain's Cable & Wireless about a possible merger. Such speculation prompted US West to threaten legal action.

Lawyers have argued that US West could claim billions of dollars in damages because the terms of its proposed merger agreement with Qwest barred both sides from talking with rival operations.

In a statement, Qwest said it had "no intention of entering into a transaction with the major telecommunications company unless US West reaches an agreement with that company for the acquisition of US West on terms acceptable to it."

Qwest won US West, which is also based in Denver, at the end of last year after a tense month-long takeover battle. Signs that tension was escalating between the two partners emerged on Friday, however, when Solomon Trujillo, the US West chairman, sent a message to all employees assuring them that he would continue to fight for them in spite of the fact that he had decided not to join the merging company.

"I may not have chosen to join the new Qwest, but I am not walking away from US West," he said in a syndicated voicemail. "But you will still be hearing from me. You can count on it."

Mark Roellig, US West's general counsel, indicated that the company knew of the talks but said: "We do not have any knowledge of the status or substance of the conversations."

The evidently fraught relationship between the two merger partners has surprised analysts at this late stage in the takeover proceedings. Qwest said that US West had been made aware of the talks.

webTitle: Reuters seeks to scrap share-option curbs

fields.headline: Reuters seeks to scrap share-option curbs
fields.standfirst: UK plc may be hurt warning
fields.trailText: It needed somebody with both clout and a clean record to say it: directives on the granting of company share options are so out-dated and parochial they risk damaging the standing of UK plc in the new-fangled global economy. So says Reuters, one of our few truly "international" companies which now seems ready to take on the institutional status quo to get things changed.
fields.body:
It needed somebody with both clout and a clean record to say it: directives on the granting of company share options are so out-dated and parochial they risk damaging the standing of UK plc in the new-fangled global economy. So says Reuters, one of our few truly "international" companies which now seems ready to take on the institutional status quo to get things changed.

The British approach to the subject could not be more British. Working on behalf of the major institutional investors, the Association of British Insurers, having taken soundings and lunch and noted the number of "fat-cat" stories in the press, from time to time publishes updates on its "Guidelines, guidance notes and other relevant material" covering everything from executive pay to voting at annual meetings. These do not amount to "rules" in the hard and fast sense, but woe betide any substantial British corporate which ignores them.

Yet according to page 24 of its freshly printed 1999 annual report, Reuters is now ready to do precisely this. "The competition for talent in the new economy is fierce and the pool limited ... ," begins a mince-free declaration of the company's remuneration objectives. It goes on to point out that pay at Reuters has to measure up to policy and practice in the US, the undisputed leader in all matters internet: "Both large and start-up companies in the US offer stock options which pay out on the basis of a company's stock price, with no other performance links. Reuters believes that, to compete, it must do the same."

What is more, companies outside the US are now adopting the American model and, in short, "the remuneration environment has become global, as is the challenge and the opportunity".

The ABI's guidelines on stock options state, categorically, that awards should in all cases be linked directly to clear performance targets (such as a rise in earnings per share over a specified period). But Reuters wants to adopt the US model, where, effectively, equity is handed out as another form of salary. There's no messing about - if the share price goes up, so does the manager's or engineer's take-home pay.

To back up its argument, Reuters points to Tibco, the specialist networking business, a third of which it floated on Nasdaq last year. It bought the whole thing for $125m (£78m) six years ago; today, its market value stands at $22bn.

"Reuters does not believe this would have been possible without the issue of options to those individuals responsible for creating this value," the company declares. Reuters' remaining stake in Tibco (even taking into account options waiting to be exercised) accounts for about a third of its £23bn group capitalisation.The ABI should sit up and take notice.

Net education

Having spent three years throwing out businesses, Pearson's Marjorie Scardino has suddenly got the company focused on four divisions, each with strong underlying growth and online potential.

There's the Financial Times - undergoing expansion geographically such as through the launch of FT Deutschland, while at the same time going through the painful rebirth of FT.com. Then there's the Penguin book publishing division, which has been aggressively building its stable (and doubled its presence in the Guardian Top 100 bestsellers list last year). Online communities are being built around sub-sectors such as Penguin classics and the Rough Guide travel series, while 5% of sales in the US are through online retailers.

Meanwhile, television production, can only go one way with the proliferation of channels, while the potential is there for interactive services which again generate e-commerce. After the acquisition of Simon & Schuster two years ago however, the main focus of interest yesterday was in educational publishing which now accounts for more than half Pearson's operating profits.

The internet has the potential to add substantial value to educational publishing. Pearson's Simon & Schuster and Longman brands have established trust and relationships with schools and colleges and the group is now well positioned to shift that relationship on to the web after agreeing a distribution deal with America Online, the world's largest internet service provider.

The division also seems to have a quantifiable means of generating revenues - whether it be through selling hard copy books which need to be used in association with the online services or charging access for schools and colleges in much the same way that they would buy-in text books. Outside of the school environment, the sites will carry e-commerce and advertising.

Much has been made of FT.com. FTYourMoney.com and MarketWatch, the online financial service for private investors which launches in Britain in June. Rich as the financial market is however, Pearson faces stiff competition while in the educational market it has a virtually clear path.

fields.headline: IMI
fields.trailText: Could we be seeing a turnaround in City sentiment towards the much-maligned engineering sector? Optimism was generated yesterday by a surge in the IMI share price after better-than-expected, but hardly sensational, annual figures.
fields.body:
Could we be seeing a turnaround in City sentiment towards the much-maligned engineering sector? Optimism was generated yesterday by a surge in the IMI share price after better-than-expected, but hardly sensational, annual figures.

Last week was a particularly frustrating time for the sophisticates of the metal bashing world, many of whose ratings are close to rock bottom. Good financial results from BBA and TI Group were met with a 4%-5% drop in shares while Rolls Royce announced double-digit earnings growth - but its shares were hammered down 8%.

So just what would please those fickle analysts, manufacturing bosses are asking. Well, IMI found a way despite pre-tax profits falling from £160.8m to £158.2m and with adjusted earnings per share down 30p to 28p. IMI shares increased 6% at one stage and closed up 5p at 218p. To be fair, IMI figures for the year to December 31 were affected by substantial restructuring and operating cash flow of £176m was up 18% on the 12 months earlier.

But the real share-mover was expressions of optimism about the speed of internal cost-savings and future market conditions. Orders are already up nearly 6% up year on year, and deputy chief executive Nick Paul says gearing has been brought down from 116% to 90%.

IMI has been tracking potential targets in the US with a £200m war chest and is brimming with confidence after the successful £337m purchase of plastic pipe maker, Polypipe.

Engineers have been toiling with future earnings multiples of nine and 10 times, while whiz-bang technology stocks are on 60 times. Companies such as IMI, which makes drinks dispensers and power units, are struggling to attract stock market attention generally, and are plagued by the cyclical nature of the business and the mature state of their markets.

But has the wheel of sentiment finally turned? Probably not yet; it is more about excitement over the prospects for IMI - and the fact its shares had been much lower than most of its rivals.

The sector will have to wait for investors to realise that engineers can exploit the internet as well as anyone else.

Well, IMI found a way despite pre-tax profits falling from £160.8m to £158.2m and with adjusted earnings per share down 30p to 28p. IMI shares increased 6% at one stage and closed up 5p at 218p. To be fair, IMI figures for the year to December 31 were affected by substantial restructuring and operating cash flow of £176m was up 18% on the 12 months earlier. But the real share-mover was expressions of optimism about the speed of internal cost-savings and future market conditions. Orders are already up nearly 6% up year on year, and deputy chief executive Nick Paul says gearing has been brought down from 116% to 90%. IMI has been tracking potential targets in the US with a £200m war chest and is brimming with confidence after the successful £337m purchase of plastic pipe maker, Polypipe. Engineers have been toiling with future earnings multiples of nine and 10 times, while whiz-bang technology stocks are on 60 times. Companies such as IMI, which makes drinks dispensers and power units, are struggling to attract stock market attention generally, and are plagued by the cyclical nature of the business and the mature state of their markets. But has the wheel of sentiment finally turned? Probably not yet; it is more about excitement over the prospects for IMI - and the fact its shares had been much lower than most of its rivals. The sector will have to wait for investors to realise that engineers can exploit the internet as well as anyone else.

webTitle: BT shares slide over price control fears

fields.headline: BT shares slide over price control fears
fields.trailText: There are regulators and regulators. Callum McCarthy at Ofgem believes that competition in the gas and electricity markets he oversees is so far advanced he can happily imagine lifting most of the price controls.
fields.body:
There are regulators and regulators. Callum McCarthy at Ofgem believes that competition in the gas and electricity markets he oversees is so far advanced he can happily imagine lifting most of the price controls.

But David Edmonds at Oftel is far from convinced that competition in the telecoms market is strong enough to end price controls on BT.

Ah, but, there must be an error here. BT has (nominally) faced competition since 1984 while the liberalisation of the domestic energy market has only been complete for a year or two.

Surely, BT has a compelling case that there are at least 150 indirect access providers of calls and hundreds of niche players already operating in the market. But Edmonds is likely to retain or even extend controls on BT prices for a further four years from July 2001.

All of this was enough to send BT's shares southwards after a strong fortnight in which they gained more than £3 on "news" of a radical restructuring, senior management shake-up and, the real McCoy, the eventual floating off of its juicy bits.

Edmonds' green paper on price controls, including one of three options which would extend these to all of BT's fixed line operations rather than the current low-spending 80%, helped send the stock down 15p to £12.88p.

Post-Christmas, BT's shares hit new lows after posting third-quarter results below expectations at £651m pre-tax - and blaming a sudden loss of business to indirect-access suppliers. Edmonds is unimpressed, believing BT retains more than 70% of the residential market and the competitors, including cable, are unlikely to make serious dents in this dominant position for some time - and certainly not by July 2001 when the local loop is "unbundled".

BT retorts that Edmonds is wrong, his perception of competition "lagging the market" and his first two options - retaining current controls and extending them to all customers - inconsistent with Oftel's strategy of exiting regulation a la Ofgem.

Faced with the likelihood that the third option of giving rivals cheaper access and broader interconnection rights will be imposed in nine months' time, BT had better come up with some genuine news if it is to satisfy investors.

fields.headline: Woodwind and brass neck
fields.standfirst: Magnus Lindberg tells  Andrew Clements about his taboo-breaking work for Simon Rattle
fields.trailText: There are no more than a dozen European composers working today whose premieres are must-hear occasions, and Magnus Lindberg is one of them. Tomorrow night at the Festival Hall his latest score, Gran Duo, will open Forward, the final instalment of Towards the Millennium, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's decade-by-decade survey of the music of the 20th century.
fields.body:
There are no more than a dozen European composers working today whose premieres are must-hear occasions, and Magnus Lindberg is one of them. Tomorrow night at the Festival Hall his latest score, Gran Duo, will open Forward, the final instalment of Towards the Millennium, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's decade-by-decade survey of the music of the 20th century.

This last tranche of concerts, conducted by Simon Rattle, will combine works from the 90s with special commissions, so that Lindberg's piece shares the programme with Mark-Anthony Turnage's Blood on the Floor. Rattle is one of Lindberg's foremost admirers, believing the Finnish composer is likely to become one of the great masters of Europe.

Born in 1958, Lindberg made his name in the 80s with a series of wonderfully crafted instrumental works that steadily grew in ambition and mastery. Over the next decade he transferred that vivid musical imagery to the orchestra. He'd studied first in Helsinki (with Rautavaara and Heininen) before doing the rounds of some of the European new-music gurus, working with composers such as Grisey, Donatoni and Ferneyhough.

Some of their preoccupations were reflected in his early works, but he soon began to hone a personal style. Now he's very much an independent spirit. He lives with his wife and children in Paris as one of those rare creatures: a composer who earns his living entirely through his music.

Lindberg had thought about Gran Duo for almost 10 years, since Rattle asked him to write something for Towards the Millennium. What began as an idea for a piece for almost full orchestra (Lindberg's first model for the scoring was Stravinsky's Symphony of Psalms) turned out to be a 20-minute work for woodwind and brass (the partners in the duo of the title), with a scoring that is almost identical to that of another Stravinsky work, the ground-breaking Symphonies of Wind Instruments.

So he has ended up with an ensemble that he admits is difficult to write for. "It's like writing for an organ - when nobody's playing you don't hear anything. Without any percussion there are no resonating instruments. Everything is very clean, all the articulation and the shape of every note is bare and immediate and you can't afford to make any mistakes.

"It's been so much a taboo in recent years to see the sections of the orchestra as different. Composers have been trying to mix things together, so in Gran Duo I liked the idea of just remembering that, after all, woodwind and brass instruments are very different from each other."

He says it was a good piece to write at this stage in his development. "Having put out quite a few big orchestral works over the past few years, I like the idea of facing an ensemble that is a sort of hybrid between the orchestra and chamber music. The next thing I intend to write is a string quartet, and this was a nice bridge to that world."

The way Gran Duo evolved could be seen as a paradigm for the way Lindberg's whole output has shifted over the past decade, refining and thinning down his musical language. The turning point was a majestic orchestral score called Aura, written in 1994. "Aura was a sort of milestone, a summation of all I had done in the 80s. After that, the idea of working slightly more linearly seemed to be the way forward.

"It's difficult to say how and why pieces turn into what they turn into. In the past I have consciously attempted to change direction, to do something radically different, but I think there is a stream underneath what you are doing, shaping the direction your music is going, and you have to respect that. The delicate balance for a composer is how to live with those two aspects of your work - one is the continuous evolution of your music, which has the danger that you will fall into mannerisms and start repeating yourself, and then there is the more rational approach of saying 'Let's try something completely different'. There are dangers in that too."

Getting the balance right, he thinks, is a question of total familiarity with the material the composer is working with. "I collect material over a long period, and then I choose what I need for the syntax of a particular work which may have some dramaturgical idea behind it, or a rhythmic idea or a specific interval flavouring the music. There are two processes: there is one where you just invent material without any pressure of deciding where it is going, and then the more difficult part, when you have to decide what you use for a certain piece."

Lindberg writes his ideas down on paper first, then analyses them with a computer that contains his earlier musical material. The computer doesn't invent anything, he insists, but it helps him to look at what he has written from different angles. Then he works at a piano. "I need to have physical contact with the sounds. I couldn't write a piece entirely on a piano, or entirely on paper.

"At my age, I feel I am in the middle of a process. I'm still very interested in music theory and research, and I am trying to arrange my schedule so that I have a couple of months clear each year for research, otherwise there's the real danger of finding yourself working on a production line."

The research explores the ways in which he can combine what he has already discovered into a single flexible musical language. In earlier phases of his career he has concentrated on different aspects of composition in turn; there are pieces that use what he now calls "new-music" gestures, and others based upon rhythmic ideas or particular systems of harmonic organisation.

The parameters he's interested in at present are more complicated. "Many people would still say that the ultimate object for a composer is the melody, but I'm not there yet. The goal would be to find a perfect diagonal between how the vertical and horizontal worlds of music interact; that's the tricky part and I'm into that process now."

webTitle: What's Eddie Grundy done to deserve this?

fields.headline: What's Eddie Grundy done to deserve this?
fields.standfirst: Fire, sick cattle, bankruptcy - and now the Grundys are losing their home. Why is The Archers' funniest family being treated so badly, asks  Chris Arnot
fields.trailText: Fire, sick cattle, bankruptcy - and now the Grundys are losing their home. Why is The Archers' funniest family being treated so badly?
fields.body:
And, lo, it came to pass on Sunday that Clarrie Grundy was bent in prayer in Ambridge's parish church, begging God to put an end to the misery heaped on her family. Last night we heard God's answer.

A plague of locusts rampaging through the Grange Farm kitchen wouldn't have surprised these poor tenant farmers after what's happened to them over the past three or four years of The Archers. Fire has destroyed everything they owned, and pestilence has smitten the herd of prime Jerseys they bought with the insurance money. BVD (bovine virus diarrhoea, if you must know), along with Eddie's tendency to shove unpaid bills into drawers, has now left them bankrupt.

So the farm stock went for a second time on Friday, in a dispersal sale. Ah well, we thought, at least they've still got the house. Then came last night's bolt from the blue. The Grundys are being evicted by Borchester Land, run by the dastardly Matt Crawford - the one who makes Brian Aldridge seem like a Guardian reader. So much for Clarrie's prayers.

It's almost as though the spirit of Thomas Hardy has seeped into the scriptwriting. Exile from Ambridge looms, and the 21st-century version of the workhouse beckons: a council flat in Borchester or even far-flung Felpersham. "Certainly, there won't be a cosy little council house around the green for them to drop into," says Archers editor Vanessa Whitburn, the one who plays God in the studio.

So what has Eddie Grundy done to deserve such retribution? OK, he's been a bit of a lad in his time, with his ferrets and his scams. And he once lifted the lid of the Bull's piano to be sick inside. Still, at least he provided light relief on days when Phil Archer was going on about the fat-stock prices and his nephew, Tony, was whingeing about his organic leeks. Why turn a mischievous character into a tragic figure?

Whitburn starts by disputing that Eddie's role has ever been entirely comic. "His ability to raise a laugh is one of the great things about him, but we've never needed head-on comedy characters. I like to think we can find humour in all of them, depending on the situation they're put in. And some of our most popular storylines, in terms of audience reaction, have come when characters like Eddie and Linda Snell reveal a serious underbelly."

Then there's Eddie's father, Joe Grundy, whose demeanour has become so serious - morose, even - that it's difficult to recall when we last heard his wheezy chuckle. He's taken to sitting on a cold, hard bench in the graveyard and, more recently, driving aimlessly round and round on a tractor. How long before he's found hanging from a rafter in the turkey shed? Whitburn won't be drawn on that: "They're all very popular characters and we'll be following the whole family in the future." But if the Grundys are so popular, surely she can't allow this persecution to continue. Eddie's going to win the lottery, right? Wrong. "There'll be no fairy-tale ending," she says. "Things are going to be tough for them over the next year or so."

In the context of a radio drama that's been running for nearly half a century, "a year or two" is but the blink of an eye. Storylines have been outlined as far ahead as January's 50th anniversary and the Grundys' fate was sealed at a script meeting six months ago. Whitburn denies that this everyday story of impoverished countryfolk is a BBC balancing act designed to butter up the farming lobby in the wake of grumbling from Tory backbenchers and the Countryside Alliance over "New Labour propaganda" in The Archers. The much-criticised "topical insert" about Tony Blair's speech to west country farmers was written long after the storyline about Eddie's downfall, Whitburn says.

Wastepaper bins in and around her office in Birmingham's Pebble Mill Studios overflow with mail from one lobby or another. But she is able to put her hand on a document from the National Farmers' Union that claims one in 12 jobs in agriculture was lost in the year to June 1999. "It's only realistic for a drama set in the countryside to reflect what's going on there properly," she says. "Even six months ago it was obvious that farming was going through its worst crisis since the 30s. And the most vulnerable, apart from hill farmers, are small-scale tenant farmers like the Grundys. This is what can happen to people like them."

One of the difficulties of dramatising their plight, she accepts, is the avoidance of sentimentality. "The writing has to become sparer to make the tone of these scenes effective. It's not to do with histrionics and tearful over-reaction to events. If we can avoid stereotypical over-reactions then the audience will feel for the characters. That's where the writers' imagination comes in."

The writer who delivered last night's coup de grace to the Grundys is Peter Kerry, who lives in Stockport and is also on the team producing scripts for Sooty. "Just when Eddie, Joe and Clarrie had lost everything, I came along and smote them another blow," he admits. "It's a bit below the belt. We discussed long and hard whether it would make the show too depressing. But because these characters are so strongly played, they can ride it. Mind you, comedy has always been the Grundys' staple diet and we've been under instructions to make sure there's some elsewhere."

Hence Sid Perks's fevered attempts to keep secret his affair with the statuesque line-dancer Jolene Rogers, she of the dysfunctional shower. "A fine figure of a woman," as Joe Grundy observed in happier times. "My Eddie had a thing for her once."

On top of losing his livelihood, his stock and his home, Eddie will one day discover that the land- lord of the pub where he can no longer afford to drink has been doing what he could only dream about. It's too, too cruel. "A hideous irony, isn't it?" says Whitburn, with almost sadistic satisfaction.

fields.headline: Home truths
fields.standfirst: Chardin was a painter of the humdrum and everyday, from game and fish to scullery maids. And yet, writes  Adrian Searle, his was a world of magnificent beauty
fields.trailText: Chardin was a painter of the humdrum and everyday, from game and fish to scullery maids. And yet, writes Adrian Searle, his was a world of magnificent beauty.
fields.body:
The Chardin exhibition at the Royal Academy should not shock you when you walk in, but it does. You are greeted by more or less brown paintings. Brown paintings gummy with grime and dirt-pocked, and paintings flattened by the unforgiving cold irons of conservators who relined them, ironing out the impasto along with the cracks. Other works have been over-cleaned, the paint looking scrubbed, sour and naked. Lots of little brown jobs, as we used to say in the restoration trade, alleviated by the fuzz of blue-grey rabbit fur, the crimson of flat-fish gut, red meat on a plate. I feel unexpectedly turned off by all the dead - more rabbits, hares, red-legged and grey-legged partridges, mackerel (some of which aren't mackerel at all) and rays - and the odd scavenging cat.

Jean-Baptiste-Siméon Chardin, however, proves anything but a disappointment. You just have to begin again, slow down, work at it, rediscover what it was that drew you here in the first place. Which is all to the good: Chardin's paintings require a certain accommodation, a suspension of expectations and of prejudice. They need time most of all.

This mental space is something the paintings have in them, and something the viewer must find within themselves. I worry that this isn't going to be possible at the RA, which has painted the walls of the Sackler Galleries a funny magnolia tint, to set off the brown, and installed a fancy crash-barrier in front of the paintings, expecting a full-tilt crowd. This exhibition is a stop-off for a touring show that began in Paris, travelled to Dusseldorf, and will go on to the Metropolitan Museum in New York. Chardin's works are dispersed in public and private collections all over the world, and this exhibition is undoubtedly the last opportunity we'll have to examine them en masse for years to come.

Chardin remains deeply, furtively, profoundly influential, even though there is much about the content and subject matter of his work that initially throws you. Forget the rows of hung-too-close, carved and decorated frames. Forgive the general brownness and look at the paintings. Even forget Chardin the French Academician fixer, who never forgot an insult and never stirred from Paris, and who painted fewer than 300 works in all his 80 years, a full third of them copies and replicas of themselves.

In fact, Chardin's work makes one feel that he rarely left his house. His early attempts at history painting were soon abandoned, and he never painted a landscape. Nor did he draw. There is barely a window, let alone a view, in all his paintings. The world was forever being rearranged on a table or against a wall in the studio. Chardin reminds me of Kafka's famous lines: "There is no need for you to leave the house. Stay at your table and listen. Don't even listen; just wait. Don't even wait; be completely quiet and alone. The world will offer itself to you to be unmasked; it can't do otherwise. In raptures it will writhe before you."

Chardin was a painter of closely observed reality, and a painter not so much of people or of things, but of paintings. For a man who focused on enclosed corners of the world - game, fish, fruit and bread for the table, a cellar boy scrubbing out a jug, a scullery maid drudging in a corner - Chardin has travelled a long way. We find him infiltrating the work of Cezanne, and in the Cubist still lifes of Picasso and Braque. Chardin is the hidden master of Morandi's desiccated little table-top world; he's there in Balthus's people, and in Lucian Freud.

He also turns up in less expected places. Chardin is as much a sculptor's as a painter's painter. His cut melon makes you think of Miro's bronze moons, just as inevitably as his eggs and garlic bulbs lead back to Velasquez and Spanish still lifes (and forward to a robust dinner). When Chardin painted collections of musical instruments, with their tubes, discs, ovals and slots, or arranged Seville oranges, sticks and slabs of bread resting precariously yet so artfully upon one another, he makes you think of the best of Anthony Caro's sculpture, with its rhyming, rhythmic syntax of interconnected, tilting and twisting steel shapes.

As Chardin leads your eye inward and around his paintings, from object to object - all of which, in a work like the grand Duck Hanging by One Leg, Paté, Bowl and Jar of Cherries, partially overlap and take you on a journey through the painting - the experience is as much physical and sculptural as it is pictorial. All this, in a work that also makes one think of Cézanne, of the broken forms in a Cubist painting, resolving themselves as they flatten out to meet the picture plane. What holds both the painting and one's thoughts in place is the orange, a still centre of gravity, the painting's generative core.

Chardin's paintings of people also find an echo in some of today's best figurative sculpture. This is as much to do with atmosphere and presence as it is to do with form. Certain of Chardin's people - a boy absorbed in watching a top spinning on his desk, the scullery maid and the cellar boy distracted and staring into space, as they mechanically perform their menial tasks, remind me of that condition of presence, of "a man in a room, waiting for nothing", that Juan Munoz speaks of. It is a condition of stillness and silence, which also infiltrates every peach pit, every grape, every olive in its cloudy jar of oil.

Chardin observed the minutiae of the everyday world. As much as he celebrated things, their textures and colour and shape, he meditated - just like the figures in his paintings, transfixed by being, rather than doing - on the solidity of things, their muteness, their shadows. Even a lone orange, set slightly apart from a number of other objects, with its stalk and a single leaf attached, has a tremendous presence and form. You can feel its enduring existence.

He never lets you forget the paintedness of things, their reduction and amplification by the act of being painted. He makes Morandi, to whom he is often compared, look plodding. There's much more to Chardin than this. The girl with the shuttlecock and racket, whose bodice is an inverted truncated cone, which rhymes with the shape of the shuttlecock itself, as though she is becoming the object in her hand by its very contemplation. Chardin, mysteriously, has painted the thing that fills her consciousness, as much as the girl and the object in itself.

I look at the boy who watches the top he has set spinning on his desk with the same mesmerised fixation as his own. I almost hear the top, skittering over the desk towards the lip, and wait for it to fall into the open drawer in the front of the desk. Or to land at my feet, on the floor of the gallery. With a jolt, I'm aware I've been standing in the same spot for 20 minutes. Not so much looking at a painting as being inside it, caught in its arrested moment. Chardin makes it possible for one to think of nothing but light turned cold as it passes through a glass of water and falls on a couple of garlic bulbs, of steam rising from a teacup, of the way light is trapped forever in the fur of the rabbit with the broken neck. Chardin is magnificent.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.body:
London stocks were in fine, albeit volatile, form once again, with the FTSE 100 closing 80.3 points higher at 6567.8.

In the last-minute jostling before the Footsie goes through its quarterly revamp on Wednesday, Vodafone Airtouch turned a stellar performance yesterday.

The newly merged telecom company was the day's busiest stock, closely followed by Royal Bank of Scotland, which yesterday completed its takeover of NatWest .

Royal Bank, which was 21p higher at 882p, was boosted by a placement of shares by its largest shareholder, Banco Santander of Spain, and by investors' rejigging their portfolios to take account of its new weighting.

And, as NatWest finally dropped out of the top 100 index, the day had arrived for Kingston Communications to take up its status as genuine blue-chip. It was sitting on the Footsie reserve list and did not have to wait for next Wednesday's meeting of the constituents committee.

Meanwhile, some heavy betting on the contenders for inclusion in the prestigious index helped the FTSE 250 index to a record close at 6,838 yesterday as shares in "new economy" companies such as Nycomed Amersham and Baltimore Technologies romped ahead.

Baltimore, trading below 500p less than 12 months ago, surged £11.50 to £135.00. Nycomed rocketed from 570p to 701p - a move of almost 25% - in frenzied dealings.

But there was also interest in some old British corporate names. GUS , for example, added 21p to 405p, and Imperial Tobacco moved ahead from 420p to 439p.

Meanwhile, among the amateur punting classes, small investors reacted furiously after a power cut prevented dealing at Charles Schwab, Britain's biggest internet-based share dealer. The website shut down at 1 pm and power supplies were not reconnected until 4.45pm, leaving thousands of investors unable to execute deals.

A Schwab spokeswoman said that the company would honour yesterday's share prices for any order that was due to be executed but was unable to be completed.

The shutdown, which Schwab insists has never happened before, comes amid growing investor frustration about call-queues and internet delays at phone and online stockbrokers, which have been swamped with new customers in recent months.

Bulletin board messages posted up in online chat rooms yesterday said that delays at Schwab were already stretching to 90-120 minutes before the power failure.

fields.headline: RIP for basic liberties
fields.standfirst: Jack Straw's bill is far too intrusive
fields.trailText: The controversial regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill fails to strike the right balance between an individual's right to privacy and the state's duty to track down criminals.
fields.body:
Michael Gapes, Labour MP for Ilford South, told the Commons yesterday how his father as a postman would have to deliver letters to a certain place where they were opened then resealed before continuing their journey to the recipient's house. He was speaking during the second reading of the controversial regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill. Everyone knows that interception takes place and that it is the duty of the authorities to hunt down drug-pushers, paedophiles and money-launderers by all legal means. The RIP bill still fails to strike the right balance between an individual's right to privacy and the state's duty to track down criminals. Even Jack Straw at his most avuncular could not explain why the right to authorise interception should rest with him (and his less avuncular successors) rather than with judges as in many other countries.

The bill contains powers that seem to be saying RIP to basic civil liberties. If you encrypt data on your home computer and forget the key (or did not have it in the first place) you are presumed guilty until proved innocent. Straw says that courts will easily distinguish between genuine memory lapses and criminals withholding information - but why should there be a presumption of guilt in the first place? Meanwhile, child pornographers will refuse to decrypt - and get a mere two years in prison instead of the long stretch they deserve.

The bill requires, for the first time, that internet service providers such as Freeserve install systems allowing the authorities to track their subscribers' communications traffic. Mr Straw argues that this is just an extension of what existing telecoms operators (and Mr Gapes' dad) have been doing for years. The difference is that internet mapping technology enables the authorities to build up networks of peoples' relationships with others. Fortunately, information gathered clandestinely is still not admissible in court - but neither is it admissible to the people being surveyed. They will never know even if they have been proved innocent. How all this squares with Britain's plans to attract e-commerce companies from all over the world is a mystery. We will soon know because Ireland is doing the opposite. It will be illegal for the authorities to force encryption users to hand over their codes. It remains to be seen whether inward investors find the grass greener on the other side of the water.

fields.headline: United have full-bodied belief
fields.trailText: David Lacey previews tonight's clash as Man United for a fillip ahead of their return match against Firoentina tomorrow week.
fields.body:
If Manchester United were a wine, club success in the second group phase of the Champions League would already have been guaranteed, what with chianti in Florence, rioja in Valencia and, tonight, a few sips of claret at the mouth of the Garonne.

As it is, United will be concerned more with matters of grass than glass when they meet Bordeaux in the Lescure Stadium here. Nevertheless Sir Alex Ferguson's players are entitled to believe they will have rather too much body for the opposition, having beaten Bordeaux more comfortably than last Wednesday's 2-0 scoreline at Old Trafford suggested.

Fiorentina, a point ahead of United at the top of Group B after beating them 2-0 in Italy in November, could only draw 0-0 here a fortnight later, so a second victory over Bordeaux would give United an important fillip going into their home game against the Florentines tomorrow week.

Ferguson believes that whether United qualify for the quarter-finals as group winners or runners-up is irrelevant. Yet the acquisition of three points rather than one will surely be at the back of his mind when he sends out his team this evening. "I always feel we can score away from home in Europe," he said on arriving here yesterday.

At Old Trafford Elie Baup's side were neat and tidy but badly lacked penetration up front. Nisa Saveljic is expected to replace the suspended Herve Alicarte in the Bordeaux defence but otherwise the only selection issue again concerns Baup's choice on the right side of midfield - Corentin Martins, who was disappointing in the first game, or Stéphane Ziani.

Paul Scholes, still suffering from a hip injury, did not travel with the United party which means that Nicky Butt will retain his position in midfield. Ferguson is expected to recall Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole, who both started on the bench against Liverpool on Saturday, with Dwight Yorke and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer standing down.

Yorke's indifferent form remains one of the season's puzzles although, as Ferguson pointed out yesterday, the Tobagan has still scored 13 goals. "I still think I can score 20," Yorke said yesterday' "but I know I'll have to change my game a little and become a bit more cute."

Certainly Bordeaux's attack will need to discover something a little more chic if they are seriously to disturb the European champions' progress. On Saturday they squeezed a 1-0 home win over Metz in the French Cup. Yet, as Liverpool showed on the same day, United's centre-back combination of Jaap Stam and Mickael Silvestre can be disrupted when they have to defend hurriedly.

United looked serene as they arrived under a cloudless sky here. That tedious soap opera The Beckhams seemed a million miles away and even a mild hiccup on the flight out gave no one serious collywobbles.

As United's plane approached its cruising altitude, it suddenly lost height while the captain ironed out a minor problem with the undercarriage. Although the passengers were told immediately afterwards what had happened Ken Ramsden, the United spokesman, said that "we would have preferred it if the pilot had told us what he was going to do beforehand".

On the ground, national as well as local police have been mobilised for tonight's match. More than 500 officers and 300 stewards have been called in to deal with any potential trouble between home supporters and 1,100 United fans.

Valencia's desire for revenge against Fiorentina in Spain tonight is heightened by their complaints that Predrag Mijatovic dived for his penalty that brought the Italian side 1-0 victory last week.

Bordeaux (probable) (4-4-2): Rame; Grenet, Afanou, Saveljic, Bonnissel; Ziani, Micoud, Pavon, Diabate; Laslandes, Wiltord.

Manchester United (probable) (4-4-2): Van der Gouw; G Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs; Sheringham, Cole.

webTitle: Brown pledges £50m to help small firms

fields.headline: Brown pledges £50m to help small firms
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday unveiled plans to spend over £50m to improve the online services provided by government to small businesses.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday unveiled plans to spend over £50m to improve the online services provided by government to small businesses.

During a visit to the north east, the chancellor underlined his commitment to create the best environment for electronic commerce by pledging £32m to the inland revenue and customs & excise and £20m for the department of trade and industry's new small business service (SBS).

The moves were disclosed as Mr Brown continued his pre-budget tour of the country's unemployment blackspots.

Visiting Sunderland, he stressed re-establishment of the work ethic in every community and the generation of a dynamic business culture.

Accompanied by Lord Trotman, the former chairman and chief executive of Ford, who is reviewing the government's small business measures, and David Irwin, in his first day as head of the SBS, Mr Brown said: "This government will be on your side if you're starting up, growing, hiring, investing, innovating, exporting or going public."

The north-east has the country's worst employment record and a low rate of small business start-ups but the chancellor highlighted his message by visiting a thriving internet company, Leighton Internet.

Compared to the tens of thousands who used to work in the mines and shipyards, the north-east's internet economy is small, its workforce totalling no more than a few thousand.

But it boasts the country's first regional electronic economy programme - a regeneration scheme based on information and communication technology - and some rapidly growing firms.

Foremost among them is Leighton, based at the Doxford International Business Park, home of the European headquarters of Nike and several major call centres. Less than two years ago, it employed nine people. Now it has a staff of over 75 young graduates. By the end of this year, it should have grown to more than 200.

The firm comprises three net-based businesses - DomainNames.com, which registers domain names for companies and individuals, Property-online.com, the biggest online database of residential property in the country, and Leighton, which designs websites for companies such as Vodafone, Bradford & Bingley and Taylor Woodrow. Most successful is DomainNames.com, due to float in June.

Paul Callaghan, managing director of the businesses, is coy about estimating the company's value but points out that DomainNames.com's biggest competitor, the US-based Register.com, went public last Friday and by the time the Nasdaq closed was worth $1.78bn.

"One of the problems that small businesses always have is how to get money without having their eyes taken out. I now know enough people in the venture capital industry to help them," said Mr Callaghan.

Mr Callaghan told the chancellor he should introduce a more generous tax-free share option scheme to improve the incentives for his staff - at the moment he can only offer them £3000 each - and refocus industrial policy.

Instead of subsidising foreign investors to come to Britain, he wants the government to place more emphasis on supporting home-grown companies like his own.

Chris Drew, chief executive of Northern Informatics, charged with implementing the regional electronic economy programme, stresses a socially inclusive approach to new technology. The business park is just a stone's throw from the Pennywell council estate, one of the most socially deprived in the country.
