The firm comprises three net-based businesses - DomainNames.com, which registers domain names for companies and individuals, Property-online.com, the biggest online database of residential property in the country, and Leighton, which designs websites for companies such as Vodafone, Bradford & Bingley and Taylor Woodrow. Most successful is DomainNames.com, due to float in June. Paul Callaghan, managing director of the businesses, is coy about estimating the company's value but points out that DomainNames.com's biggest competitor, the US-based Register.com, went public last Friday and by the time the Nasdaq closed was worth $1.78bn. "One of the problems that small businesses always have is how to get money without having their eyes taken out. I now know enough people in the venture capital industry to help them," said Mr Callaghan. Mr Callaghan told the chancellor he should introduce a more generous tax-free share option scheme to improve the incentives for his staff - at the moment he can only offer them £3000 each - and refocus industrial policy. Instead of subsidising foreign investors to come to Britain, he wants the government to place more emphasis on supporting home-grown companies like his own. Chris Drew, chief executive of Northern Informatics, charged with implementing the regional electronic economy programme, stresses a socially inclusive approach to new technology. The business park is just a stone's throw from the Pennywell council estate, one of the most socially deprived in the country.

fields.headline: Cyberbanks plan 2.4bn merger with First-e
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Two European internet banks announced a €2.4bn (£1.5bn) merger yesterday, claiming it would result in the world's first global bank in cyberspace.
fields.body:
Two European internet banks announced a €2.4bn (£1.5bn) merger yesterday, claiming it would result in the world's first global bank in cyberspace.

Under the terms of the deal Uno-e, owned by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria (BBVA) of Spain and Terra Networks, will buy First-e, the Dublin-based internet bank.

The combined group will be known as unofirst and use the First-e brand in northern Europe, Asia and the US, and the Uno-e brand in the Spanish bank's strongholds of southern Europe and Latin America.

The bank is not expected to break even until long after a planned flotation which could unlock riches for the young management of First-e who own 16% of the combined group, worth £240m at yesterday's price.

It could also mean gains for customers, who are expected to be given a chance to buy any shares in the flotation.

BBVA and Terra Networks are paying €291m to current First-e shareholders and contributing €362m in cash to raise capital for the combined group which will have €500m to fund expansion plans.

Manuel Galatas, a BBVA executive who will be chairman of the combined group, said the new internet bank would be floated on two stock exchanges in about a year's time. Its target is for 3m customers by 2003 with a possible break-even shortly afterwards.

First-e, which was launched in the UK in November by Banque d'Escompte of France and Ebna, a Dublin-based holding company, has 50,000 account holders and another 60,000 customers who have registered an interest in the high-rate interest-bearing account.

Xavier Azalbert, 35, who runs First-e, said that the merger would allow the e-bank to offer better deals to customers and put the bank at the forefront of the move from the internet to mobile phones.

"As this trend continues, dot.com financial services will make demutualisation carpet-bagging seem like small change," said Mr Azalbert, who is part of the First-e management team which owns 16% of the combined entity.

He said the bank was on track to meet its pan-European target of 220,000 customers.

First of many

 first-e started marketing in the UK in Novermber 1999

 It has 50,000 customers, with average deposits of €17,000 (£10,500) each

 It has begun trials in Germany

 Uno-e to launch in Spain this month

 Soon opening in Portugal

 Combined group will spend £325m to expand into the US, Latin America and Asia

webTitle: Greenspan hints at rate rise as technology market races towards 5,000 milestone

fields.headline: Greenspan hints at rate rise as technology market races towards 5,000 milestone
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Alan Greenspan, the US central banker, said yesterday that investors were still "groping for appropriate valuations" for internet companies as the benchmark index for technology companies in the US threatened a record.
fields.body:
Alan Greenspan, the US central banker, said yesterday that investors were still "groping for appropriate valuations" for internet companies as the benchmark index for technology companies in the US threatened a record.

The Nasdaq Composite rose to within 20 points of the 5,000 milestone as Mr Greenspan delivered a speech on technology and the new economy at the Boston college in Massachusetts.

The index was trading up almost 1% at 4,961 just after he finished his speech, which also hinted at the continued need for higher interest rates to slow down the economy. He likened buying shares in internet companies to predicting the future.

He also repeated last month's message, given in his twice yearly Humphrey Hawkins report to Congress, that interest rate rises might be necessary because productivity-driven stock gains had boosted demand in the economy to such a level that they could no longer be met by supply.

"Until market forces, assisted by a vigilant Federal Reserve, effect the necessary alignment of the growth of aggregate demand with the growth of potential aggregate supply, the full benefits of innova tive productivity acceleration are at risk of being undermined by financial and economic instability," he said.

He warned that the rising current account deficit and shrinking labour-supply factors cited for keeping inflation under control would not last forever. He referred to "analysts' fears" that increasing stock market wealth - as consumers benefit from rising share prices - "may soon begin to slow".

Presented with a cake to celebrate his 74th birthday, Mr Greenspan made more bullish comments about capital spending. "The fact that the capital spending boom is still going on indi cates that businesses will continue to find a wide array of potentially high rate-of-return and productivity enhancing investments."

In a separate speech to the assembled economists, bankers and academics, Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, also warned investors to be wary of burning their fingers by investing in internet companies yesterday.

The Nasdaq index has continued to roar ahead in spite of a series of interest rate rises by the Federal Reserve board, the US central bank.

The index first crossed the 4,000 mark in December.

fields.headline: Electro magnetism
fields.standfirst:
Alphaville/Scanner
BFI London Imax
***
fields.trailText:
Alphaville/Scanner
BFI London Imax
***
fields.body:
It's been a long time since I saw Jean-Luc Godard's 1965 film Alphaville, and tonight's version is not quite the film I remember - at least, not in terms of proportion. It's shown not in its usual ratio, but in anamorphic widescreen, with the image stretched way out of its normal shape. Eddie Constantine's futuristic gumshoe Lemmy Caution was always unnerving, with that basilisk face simmering under his fedora, but now he's transformed into a barrel-bodied homunculus stretching and squeezing as he shuffles along equally elastic corridors.

This version of Alphaville is accompanied live by electronic sound artist Scanner, who finds ample food in the film for his own preoccupations - surveillance, electronic intelligence, urban space. Yet it's one thing to rescore an old silent film, however radically, and quite another to apply new sound to a film that already has its own score. You're on especially dangerous territory when the film is by Godard, a sound design pioneer in his own right. Scanner's enterprise is as much an act of appropriation as a dialogue with the original, and the stretched image suggests that he knows the implications of what he's doing - treating the film as material to be resculpted.

He doesn't work around the soundtrack so much as grapple with it, his electronic washes plastered right over the dialogue and over Paul Misraki's original score, sometimes to the point of obliteration. He seems to sample and process both, so that the original sound comes to us at one remove, as if picked up by radio from a great spatial and temporal distance.

Stretched out along the centre of the huge Imax screen, this Alphaville is hallucinatory rather than coolly lucid, with the dense, spongy sound design emphasising the sense of oppressive space. But it undermines the film's feat of conceptual trompe-l'oeil: Alphaville seems to show us an alien sci-fi world, whereas in fact Godard is simply shooting a future- obsessed 1965 Paris. Emphasising futurism, rather than the sense of present-as-future, Scanner's electronica makes the film seem archaic, another of those fanciful Tomorrow's World projections that date sci-fi so quickly. The seductive soundtrack makes Alphaville yield a spatial environment where Scanner is perfectly at home, but Jean-Luc Godard appears to have left the building.

fields.headline: Birtwistle's challenge
fields.standfirst:
BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/ Martyn Brabbins
Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama, Glasgow
****
fields.trailText:
BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra/ Martyn Brabbins
Royal Scottish Academy of Music and Drama, Glasgow
****
fields.body:
Harrison Birtwistle's Antiphonies is one of the most challenging of recent works for piano and orchestra - for musicians and listeners. Never content to accept musical forms at face value, Birtwistle's approach to the interplay between soloist and orchestra results in a complete rethinking of the one-versus-all relationship of conventional concertos.

Playing the piece for the first time, Nicolas Hodges coped dazzlingly with the subtleties of the piano part, which is a virtually continuous barrage of percussive gestures and rhythmic complexity. With Martyn Brabbins conducting the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, the performance was a visceral, elemental game of contrasts between Hodges's convincing precision and the orchestra's stratified textures of strident brass writing and string harmonics. In the intimate confines of the Scottish Academy's Matt Thomson Hall, Hodges's intensity and Brabbins's conviction produced a physically as well as mentally draining experience.

But even with this emphatic advocacy, there remained something obstinately secretive about the structural machinations of Antiphonies. The consistent alternation and superimposition of different kinds of music pointed to an inner drama that Birtwistle conceals from view - as if piano and orchestra were participants in an ancient, monumentalised ritual.

More immediate, if no less technically daunting, was Birtwistle's The Cry of Anubis for tuba and orchestra, in a superbly committed account from Brabbins and soloist Chris McShane. Anubis is a character from Birtwistle's opera The Second Mrs Kong, and is associated with the tuba throughout that piece. In The Cry of Anubis, the format of solo and accompaniment once again goes under Birtwistle's microscope. The tuba needs the orchestra in order to complete and develop its short fragments of melody, but the soloist gradually becomes abrasively dismissive of the ensemble. A final battle between the orchestra's timpanist and McShane's tuba resulted in an eerie, uneasy truce.

Birtwistle's Bach Measures, his arrangements of eight of Bach's Chorale Preludes, are like miniature plays for ensemble. Birtwistle uses the musicians like actors, assigning them different roles in each piece. In terms of musical language, these Bach arrangements seem to be a million miles away from Antiphonies, but in Brabbins and the BBCSSO's fastidious performances, they shared the same sense of inherent, instrumental drama.

fields.headline: University challenge
fields.standfirst: 'I've got a job most graduates would kill for but feel a failure without a degree'
fields.trailText: The problem
fields.body:
The problem

I am 19 and working for a dot.com start-up. Theoretically I am on a year out before university having just failed to achieve my necessary grades.

I have two As and a D and have applied for university places for the coming year, and so far have two reasonable unconditional offers but nowhere prestigious.

Throughout school and since, I always seem to have been given more opportunities than I deserved. I (honestly) am pretty lazy and suspect I have gained these simply through being articulate.

I ran a digital photograph library for a publisher while I finished my A-levels. During a spell of temping I was offered this job. Theoretically I have a staff of three, responsibility for liaison with management and technical people and am responsible for the database of products that support a complex web site.

Often the job seems to take over my life, but I am in a position to deal with this for now and enjoy it. This is a job many graduates would kill for; I am about to get share options and a pay rise to £17,000 from my current £14,500. I have only had this job since January.

I would not describe myself as particularly driven. I am keen to avoid management and want to gain more technical skills so that I come out of this with more than just management skills on my CV.

I do not want a pressurised job long-term, yet am finding myself enjoying this one and wanting more responsibility. I actually worry that future employers will not believe that I have had this much responsibility.

Going to university is beginning to seem like an expensive luxury, in such a fast-moving market I would be back where I started, equal with other graduates after three years away. I have calculated that going to college would cost me approximately £80,000 in debts and lost earnings.

But I cannot shake off this lingering feeling of inferiority. I feel as if I am constantly failing at the job, as if I am not trusted, and as if my word is not taken on issues I know a considerable amount about.

I am constantly resentful at the pay differences between myself and other members of staff. Although I have been fairly pushy and this has not been a problem, I am unable to gauge my true position as, in such a busy company, there is little opportunity for feedback from management and few boundaries.

I worry about being the person without a degree and about this limiting me long-term. I already feel that friends who have gone to university look down on me as not bright enough. If I was offered an Oxbridge or UCL place it might be worth sacrificing this opportunity.

People tell me college is worth it for the social and intellectual sides, but it seems like a pretty expensive holiday to me.

The solution

My view may be somewhat controversial, but I am inclined to agree that university, for you, may not be necessary - or even a good idea. The idea of 'higher education for all' has, in my view, resulted in a devaluing of the degree so that it is almost becoming unworthy of the paper it is written on.

Yes, many employers want graduates, but they want so much more than that. They want communication skills, work experience, business acumen, evidence of responsibilityall the things that most graduates lack, but which you have in abundance.

Many, many people make it without going to university. And indeed, many who do get a degree, don't make it. They emerge three years later, considerably poorer, but with few of the key transferable skills that today's employer is looking for. Yes, they may have a great social life, get drunk a lot, join societies, meet peoplebut who says you can't do all these without an NUS (National Union of Students) card?

I think that you have pretty much made up your mind about university and are looking for reassurance that you are not throwing a great opportunity away. But, university will still be there, so why not take another year 'out' and see how you feel next year? There's nothing to stop you going to university in three or five years time if you feel the need or inclination.

Indeed, in my experience, mature students work harder, are more dedicated and thus get better grades anyway. They also have much more to offer the employer than their younger and less workwise contemporaries.

As for your snobby mates - ignore them. You'll have the last laugh when the money rolls in and they are scrounging a few quid from you for a pint.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work
(Purple House, £9.99) and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't (Element, £9.99)

fields.headline: For ample people
fields.standfirst:
Miriam Makeba/ Busi Mhlongo/ Sibongile Khumalo
Barbican Centre, London
****
fields.trailText:
Miriam Makeba/ Busi Mhlongo/ Sibongile Khumalo
Barbican Centre, London
****
fields.body:
The second night of the Africa: Roots & Shoots festival brings three South African divas spanning wildly differing styles and three generations. Sibongile Khumalo kicks off the evening, a powerhouse in regal red. One of the stars of the Women of Africa tour two years ago, Khumalo combines township jazz with operatics and tribal roots music. She opens with Abdullah Ibrahim's Tsakwe/Royal Blue, hitting each note with slow dignity. Her set is abstract and incantatory, moving from rich harmonies to forceful scat. A young protegée with a voice like dark wood, Claudia Bosman, takes the stage for two songs, before Khumalo concludes with a saucy rendition of the Township Medley, pulling a skinny clubber up on stage for a grinding jive. "This song is for people like me who are ample," she quips, "who've got presence."

Natal native Busi Mhlongo follows with the groove-orientated maskanda style that's featured on her recent Urban Zulu album. Dancing onstage in a riot of colour, Mhlongo is like a diminutive female shaman celebrating the rites of spring, conducting her band and backing singers with a mercurial energy. Having spent much of her career in exile, she has absorbed a variety of styles from reggae to rock, and she weaves these influences into the sinuous Zulu roots rhythm, punctuating it with her soaring voice. By the end the crowd is up on its feet. Overtaken by the moment, a young girl dives onstage from the audience and executes some athletic Zulu leg kicks. The crowd roars. Mhlongo is clearly delighted.

By contrast, 68-year-old Miriam Makeba's set is that of the elder stateswoman. She is greeted by a standing ovation but this, one suspects, is more for her status as "Mama Africa" than her current musical approach. Accompanied by a respectful, polished seven-piece band kitted out in smart shirts and trousers, she has a preference for showtune-style ballads with simple arrangements, like the sincere but slightly mawkish Africa is Where My Heart Lies. Mid-set Makeba proves she still has bite, performing with cold, clear intensity Hugh Masekela's So Into Blues, a lament about the 1976 Soweto uprising. At moments like these, her deep voice somehow expresses all the struggle, sorrow and resilience of her country. "They call us the dinosaur," she says majestically, "but at least the dinosaur has history."

Africa: Roots & Shoots continues until March 15. Details: 0171-638 8891.

Dancing onstage in a riot of colour, Mhlongo is like a diminutive female shaman celebrating the rites of spring, conducting her band and backing singers with a mercurial energy. Having spent much of her career in exile, she has absorbed a variety of styles from reggae to rock, and she weaves these influences into the sinuous Zulu roots rhythm, punctuating it with her soaring voice. By the end the crowd is up on its feet. Overtaken by the moment, a young girl dives onstage from the audience and executes some athletic Zulu leg kicks. The crowd roars. Mhlongo is clearly delighted. By contrast, 68-year-old Miriam Makeba's set is that of the elder stateswoman. She is greeted by a standing ovation but this, one suspects, is more for her status as "Mama Africa" than her current musical approach. Accompanied by a respectful, polished seven-piece band kitted out in smart shirts and trousers, she has a preference for showtune-style ballads with simple arrangements, like the sincere but slightly mawkish Africa is Where My Heart Lies. Mid-set Makeba proves she still has bite, performing with cold, clear intensity Hugh Masekela's So Into Blues, a lament about the 1976 Soweto uprising. At moments like these, her deep voice somehow expresses all the struggle, sorrow and resilience of her country. "They call us the dinosaur," she says majestically, "but at least the dinosaur has history." Africa: Roots & Shoots continues until March 15. Details: 0171-638 8891.

fields.headline: Cruickshank backs Link
fields.standfirst: Put blame on individual banks, says watchdog
fields.trailText: Don Cruickshank exerted fresh pressure on banks and building societies over the cost of cash machine withdrawals yesterday, while providing surprise support to the management of the Link network in face of fierce government criticism.
fields.body:
Don Cruickshank exerted fresh pressure on banks and building societies over the cost of cash machine withdrawals yesterday, while providing surprise support to the management of the Link network in face of fierce government criticism.

The comments by Mr Cruickshank, head of a treasury investigation into banking competition, come amid fears that customers could have to pay £2.50 to take their money from cash machines.

His findings have proved controversial after he said that bank clients should have to pay no more than 30p.

Link has tried to play down the possiblity of a £2.50 charge, which would arise from a £1 surcharge by banks such as Barclays when customers of rival banks use its machines. They might also be charged a £1.50 disloyalty fee by their own bank.

Link is urging banks and building societies to ensure that customers do not face two charges by dropping disloyalty fees when their customers face a surcharge.

Mr Cruickshank yesterday welcomed last week's moves by Link to make the business more transparent and open to competition.

He said that it was right to allow non-banks to set up cash machines and that any charges should be displayed on cash machine screens. He acknowledged that Link, under fire from the department of trade and industry for possible anti-competitive behaviour, could not be blamed for the level of charges for cash withdrawals.

"(Prices) are the business of the individual banks concerned, not the Link board, not the Link executives. Setting prices collectively through the scheme would run into problems with the competition authorities," Mr Cruickshank said.

"The valid concerns that have been expressed about these prices should not be directed at Link but at the individual banks who levy these charges."

webTitle: IMF says hold fire on euro

fields.headline: IMF says hold fire on euro
fields.standfirst:
New report backs Blair's 'wait and see' insistence over monetary union
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The International Monetary Fund last night stepped into the growing political row over Britain's membership of the euro when it gave firm backing to the government's softly-softly approach to European monetary union.
fields.body:
The International Monetary Fund last night stepped into the growing political row over Britain's membership of the euro when it gave firm backing to the government's softly-softly approach to European monetary union.

Endorsing the "wait and see" approach adopted by Labour since 1997, the IMF said that it would take time to see whether concerns over economic convergence and wage flexibility had been met.

Supporters of early British entry into the euro have been urging the government to take a stronger line in favour of Britain's membership, but the IMF report adds weight to Labour's strategy of deferring a decision until after the next election.

With recent opinion polls showing that public hostility to the single currency hardening, ministers are likely to seize on the report as justifying their cautious line, which is currently dominated by the perception that a referendum cannot be won until the public has been convinced of the benefits of Britain's membership of the European Union.

Tony Blair's speech in Ghent last month was designed to highlight the benefits of the European Union after opinion polls showed that two-thirds of the public are opposed to the euro and around 30% against British membership of the EU.

But a Mori poll released last week, following Mr Blair's speech, showed that the number of people opposed to British entry into monetary union was at its highest level since the general election, with no evidence that the recent government-backed "out of Europe, out of work" campaign had affected the public mood.

The IMF made its recommendation on the euro as it upgraded its growth forecast for the UK economy this year from 2.4% to 3%.

"Directors agreed that entry into EMU remains a key medium-term decision for Britain. They considered that, while many considerations would influence the decision of whether to join, an over-riding case for or against entry could not be made at the present time," the IMF said.

"However, many of the factors affecting this decision, such as differences between the UK's and the euro area's relative cyclical positions, and concerns over wage flexibility in the UK, were likely to change over time. The fund must continue to focus on this critical policy issue in its ongoing surveillance activities."

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has insisted that before Britain joins, the treasury's five economic tests will have to be met. These include economic convergence, the impact on employment and inward investment.

Public opposition to the euro has enhanced the importance of the tests since they were first announced in October 1997.

Earlier assumptions that the government would move swiftly to a referendum in the event of a second general election victory have since been challenged, with Mr Brown at the treasury taking a far more cautious line than Robin Cook at the foreign office.

fields.headline: Whale of a gig
fields.standfirst: Moby, The Forum, Kentish Town
fields.trailText: Moby is something of an oddity, so perhaps it was to be expected that this last gig of his short UK tour would be full of curiosities, touches of musical genius and occasional frustrations too.
fields.body:
Moby is something of an oddity, so perhaps it was to be expected that this last gig of his short UK tour would be full of curiosities, touches of musical genius and occasional frustrations too.

Not that the performance wasn't great. It was. He was. Moby bounded on stage like Tigger and kept on bouncing, banging his bongos with the vigour of a man being sustained by illegal narcotic substances. Which he most definitely wasn't because Moby is dead against things like drugs, and doesn't much care for alcohol or meat either.

In eight years and five albums, he has mixed a bewildering number of genres (house, trance, ambient, hard-rock, goth-metal, soul) and been feted for bringing something fresh to every one. Play, his current CD, is a gem that hasn't been dulled by constant airplay or the fact that it provides the theme tune to Leonardo di Caprio's latest and unloved film,The Beach.

Moby's cross-section of styles seemed reflected in the make-up of his audience: clubgoers past and clubgoers present, men in trenchcoats and winkle-pickers, women in denim, a youth wearing a panama hat. So which Moby came out to play? They all did. He gave us a little bit of everything.

The Forum came alive when the band played Porcelain and the gig bubbled on just fine for the next 80 minutes without, in truth, ever threatening to boil over. The thrash through the James Bond theme was inspired; the homage to Bruce Springsteen (Moby sang the first verse to I'm on Fire) less so. He teased us with guitar riffs from Lenny Kravitz and jokes about his DJ, a rotund figure called Sinbad.

Moby is a brilliant musician and showman but some ingredient was missing and the gig never quite reached the heights. Perhaps the run through Moby's portfolio was to blame. It left me craving a bit less of everything, and a little more of something. Or perhaps the timing of the gig was the key. Moby was on surprisingly early - 8.30.

When he dismissed the band to play a second encore on his own, the Forum waited for something special. Moby took centre stage, standing behind a keyboard. The biggest, thumpiest, tranciest beat swelled around him, speeding up as he pounded the air with his fists. The backlights flickered in time, making him glow like a messianic figure as the track reached a ear-numbing crescendo. Silence. Then it began again. Faster, harder, this time with Moby, bald and bare-chested, standing on the keyboard, raising his arms slowly heavenwards, celebrating a triumphant climax.

At 4am in a dance tent at some summer festival with the sun lifting over the horizon, this would probably have been a magical meaning-of-life moment. But it was 10.10 on a cold evening in Kentish Town. The punters could have been back in the pub well before last orders and home in time to see the second half of Match of the Day.
